('92', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. COMPENSATION FOR MURDER 1
('92', 0, 2, 3, 73) I have been asked whether the brother or other relatives of the late Rajabali should demand compensation from the Government for his murder.
('92', 0, 2, 4, 214) The deceased himself would not have considered such a death a loss.
('92', 0, 2, 5, 282) He would have held that such a murder, if allowed to go unavenged, would ultimately put an end to further murders and was therefore beneficial.
('92', 0, 2, 6, 426) To demand even the smallest compensation for the death of such a man is bound to wash away to some extent the good that it might do.
('92', 0, 2, 7, 559) How can the spirit of the deceased tolerate this?
('92', 0, 2, 8, 609) I find much substance in this argument.
('92', 0, 2, 9, 649) Murder cannot be avenged by accepting compensation for it.
('92', 0, 2, 10, 708) The proper way to avenge murder is not to answer murder with murder.
('92', 0, 2, 11, 777) Those who hold this view will not demand money for murder or commit murder in retaliation.
('92', 0, 2, 12, 868) Avenging murder with murder will only lead to an increase in murders.
('92', 0, 2, 13, 938) We can see it clearly today.
('92', 0, 2, 14, 967) It may satisfy the individual but I am certain that is can never bring peace to society or advance it.
('92', 0, 2, 15, 1070) The question can certainly arise what an individual can do in a society where murder for murder is the rule.
('92', 0, 2, 16, 1179) The answer would lie not in precept but in setting an example.
('92', 0, 2, 17, 1242) And only those have a right to set an example who have the right to avenge, namely, the relatives of Rajabali.
('92', 0, 2, 18, 1353) In the end the decision has to be theirs.
('92', 0, 2, 19, 1395) I have only pointed out the way of ahimsa as I have understood it.
('92', 0, 2, 20, 1462) SEVAGRAM, August 9, 1946 [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 18 8 1946
('92', 0, 3, 21, 1528) 2. WHAT A CHILD CAN GIVE 2
('92', 0, 4, 22, 1555) In Madras there is a little girl of five years called Aruna.
('92', 0, 4, 23, 1616) 3 Last January when I was in Madras she watched me spin and was seized with the desire to do so herself.
('92', 0, 4, 24, 1721) The atmosphere in which she is being reared has a spinning bias, but her cultured parents have been averse to forcing anything on her.
('92', 0, 4, 25, 1856) They were content with what they were
('92', 0, 5, 26, 1894) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 18 8 1946. 2 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 18 8 1946, under the title “what a Child Can Teach Us”.
('92', 0, 5, 27, 2071) 3 Vide “Letter to Vinodini”, 9 8 1946
('92', 1, 0, 1, 2109) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 1, 1, 2, 2149) able to make her do by suggestion and example.
('92', 1, 1, 3, 2196) When Aruna evinced enthusiasm for spinning they were very pleased to give her encouragement.
('92', 1, 1, 4, 2289) The result was that in a single day Aruna had prepared a sliver and brought it to me.
('92', 1, 1, 5, 2375) Then when she saw me spin that sliver her joy knew no bounds.
('92', 1, 1, 6, 2437) I explained to her the defects of the sliver and her parents helped her to remove them.
('92', 1, 1, 7, 2525) Since then she has been making slivers and spinning quite well.
('92', 1, 1, 8, 2589) Thus this five year old girl learnt two things at the same time : to clean and card cotton and make slivers and also to give to others the produce of her labour.
('92', 1, 1, 9, 2751) When children take money from their parents to give it to others all the merit goes to the parents.
('92', 1, 1, 10, 2851) A child truly gives when it gives what it has earned with its own labour, be it slivers or some other thing.
('92', 1, 1, 11, 2960) SEVAGRAM, August 9, 1946 [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 18 8 1946

('92', 1, 6, 18, 3383) 4. LETTER TO VINODINI
('92', 1, 7, 19, 3405) SEVAGRAM, August 9, 1947
('92', 1, 8, 20, 3430) VINODINI, I preserved your article Arunani Puni till today.
('92', 1, 8, 21, 3490) My first reading of it was cursory but interesting at it is, I do not consider it fit for publication.
('92', 1, 8, 22, 3593) I see a mother’s love in every single line, yet I would not call it literature.
('92', 1, 8, 23, 3673) I cannot claim to know much about literature.
('92', 2, 0, 1, 3719) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 3
('92', 2, 1, 2, 3763) Besides, your article is, however unconsciously, laden with praise for me; no one is likely to gain from the publication of such an article.
('92', 2, 1, 3, 3904) I therefore refrained from publishing it but preserved it because I had a mind to draw a lesson from it— how much a child can accomplish if it is led along the right way.
('92', 2, 1, 4, 4075) You will find it in Harijan.
('92', 2, 1, 5, 4104) 1 You might not have a copy and I can understand that as a mother you would value it, hence I am returning the article.
('92', 2, 2, 6, 4224) Blessings from BAPU VINODINIBEHN MADRAS
('92', 2, 3, 7, 4264) From a copy of the Gujarati : Pyarelal Papers.

('92', 2, 4, 9, 4331) 5. SPEECH AT SEKSARIA COLLEGE OF COMMERCE 2
('92', 2, 5, 10, 4375) WARDHA, August 9, 1946
('92', 2, 6, 11, 4398) Giving a severe castigation to the unruly crowd that had indulged in window smashing and would have smashed in the roof too if they could, in the afternoon, Gandhiji remarked that it augured ill for the independence to come.
('92', 2, 6, 12, 4623) 3 The Working Committee which was holding its meeting in their city was considering how to win Independence for the people of India in the shortest time.
('92', 2, 6, 13, 4777) It was not labouring for a change of masters.
('92', 2, 6, 14, 4823) If the masses wanted to enjoy independence, they had first to learn the secret of observing voluntary discipline.
('92', 2, 6, 15, 4937) Otherwise discipline would have to be imposed upon them by the powers that be.
('92', 2, 6, 16, 5016) That would not be independence but its negation.
('92', 2, 6, 17, 5065) Every people got the Government they deserved.
('92', 2, 6, 18, 5112) If they indulged in hooliganism, so would the Government and its officials in the name of law and order.
('92', 2, 6, 19, 5217) The result would not be freedom or independence but a balancing of anarchies, each trying to keep the other in check.
('92', 2, 6, 20, 5335) Voluntary discipline was the first requisite of corporate freedom.
('92', 2, 6, 21, 5402) If the people were well behaved the Government officials would
('92', 2, 7, 22, 5465) 1 Vide “What a Child Can Give”, 18 8 1946 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('92', 2, 7, 23, 5552) The occasion was the inauguration of the change from English to Marathi as the medium of instruction.
('92', 2, 7, 24, 5654) Those attending included Ravi Shanker Shukla, Premier of C.P., and the Vice Chancellor of the Nagpur University.
('92', 2, 7, 25, 5767) 3 According to the source nearly ten thousand people had come to Wardha from outside and the crowd was so unmanageable and undisciplined that the time and venue of the function had to be shifted and it was held in the open instead of in the College hall.
('92', 3, 0, 1, 6022) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 3, 1, 2, 6062) become their true servants.
('92', 3, 1, 3, 6090) Otherwise they would ride on their necks, not without a semblance of justification.
('92', 3, 1, 4, 6174) During the Boer War he had seen thousands of soldiers perform a noiseless march through a dense, tropical jungle in the middle of the night, in pitch darkness for not even match stick was to be struck to light a cigarette, lest it should betray their movements to the enemy.
('92', 3, 1, 5, 6449) The whole troop formation moved like one man in perfect silence and harmony.
('92', 3, 1, 6, 6526) The need for discipline for a nation on its march towards independence was infinitely greater.
('92', 3, 1, 7, 6621) Without it, Ramarajya which meant the kingdom of God on earth would remain an empty dream.
('92', 3, 2, 8, 6712) The principal and the Management of the Seksaria College had taken a big step in deciding to make the mother tongue the medium of instruction in their college.
('92', 3, 2, 9, 6872) But the reform would be still born if they were lazy or if the public did not co operate.
('92', 3, 3, 10, 6962) A fear had been expressed, observed Gandhiji, that the propagation of Rashtrabhasha or the national tongue would prove inimical to the provincial languages.
('92', 3, 3, 11, 7119) That fear was rooted in ignorance.
('92', 3, 3, 12, 7154) The present step of the Seksaria college was a living refutation of that suspicion.
('92', 3, 3, 13, 7238) Provincial tongues provided the sure foundation on which the edifice of the national tongue should rest.
('92', 3, 3, 14, 7343) The two were intended to complement, not supplant each other.
('92', 3, 4, 15, 7405) He deprecated the suggestion that it would need a lot of research and preparation to enable them to impart technical education through the medium of the mother tongue.
('92', 3, 4, 16, 7573) Those who argued like that were unaware of the rich treasure of expressions and idioms that were buried in the dialects of our villages.
('92', 3, 4, 17, 7710) In Gandhiji’s opinion there was no need to go to Sanskrit or Persian in search for many expressions.
('92', 3, 4, 18, 7811) He had been in Champaran and he had found that the village folk there could fully express themselves with ease and without the help of a single foreign expression or idiom.
('92', 3, 4, 19, 7984) As an illustration of their resourcefulness, he mentioned the word have gadi which they had coined to denote a motor car.
('92', 3, 4, 20, 8106) He challenged university scholars to coin a more poetic expression than that for a motor car.
('92', 3, 5, 21, 8200) One of the speakers had remarked that the reform would mean a saving of at least there years to the alumni of the College.
('92', 3, 5, 22, 8323) But Gandhiji was of opinion that the saving in time and labour would be even greater.
('92', 3, 5, 23, 8409) Moreover, what they learnt through the mother tongue, they would easily be able to communicate to their mothers and sisters at home and thereby bring the latter into line with themselves.
('92', 3, 5, 24, 8597) Woman had been described as man’s better half.
('92', 3, 5, 25, 8644) Today there was a hiatus between the thought world of men and women respectively in India, thanks to the intrusion of the foreign medium.
('92', 3, 5, 26, 8782) Our womenfolk were backward and ignorant with the result that India was today like a patient with paralysis of the better side.
('92', 3, 5, 27, 8910) India could not realize her full
('92', 4, 0, 1, 8943) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 5
('92', 4, 1, 2, 8987) stature unless that handicap was removed.

('92', 4, 2, 4, 9048) 6. HOW TO THINK OF GOD
('92', 4, 3, 5, 9071) A correspondent writes:
('92', 4, 4, 6, 9095) You say that the rule should be that during prayer, everyone should sit with closed eyes and think of nothing but God.
('92', 4, 4, 7, 9214) The question arises as to how and in what form we have to think of God ?
('92', 4, 4, 8, 9287) True meditation consists in closing the eyes and ears of the mind to all else except the object of one’s devotion.
('92', 4, 4, 9, 9402) Hence the closing of eyes during prayers is an aid to such concentration.
('92', 4, 4, 10, 9476) Man’s conception of God is naturally limited, Each one has, therefore, to think of Him as best appeals to him, provided that the conception is pure and uplifting.
('92', 4, 4, 11, 9639) SEVAGRAM, August 10, 1946 Harijan, 18 8 1946

('92', 5, 7, 13, 11051) [Before August 11, 1946] 2
('92', 5, 8, 14, 11078) FRIEND : You have called mine a negative attitude.
('92', 5, 8, 15, 11129) But I am quite clear in my
('92', 5, 9, 16, 11156) you mind.
('92', 5, 9, 17, 11166) I do not mind the Congress High Command carrying on negotiations with the Cabinet Mission.
('92', 5, 9, 18, 11257) But suppose the negotiations fail.
('92', 5, 9, 19, 11292) What then?
('92', 5, 9, 20, 11303) The British Government is prepared with its plan of action in that case.
('92', 5, 9, 21, 11376) But we are not.
('92', 5, 9, 22, 11392) It is my belief that we shall have to go through another struggle before freedom can be won.
('92', 5, 9, 23, 11485) I find that you have a revolutionary mentality.
('92', 5, 9, 24, 11533) I do not like himsa any more than you do.
('92', 5, 9, 25, 11575) It is bad.
('92', 5, 9, 26, 11586) My goal is the same as yours.
('92', 5, 9, 27, 11616) Show a sure non violent way of achieving our goal of Independence within a definite period and I shall most willingly follow you.
('92', 5, 9, 28, 11746) In a way I do believe in ahimsa.
('92', 5, 9, 29, 11779) A repetition of the 1933 37 pattern of struggle won’t do.
('92', 5, 9, 30, 11837) The leaders are put behind the bars at the very commencement of the struggle and then all contact between them and the masses ceases.
('92', 5, 9, 31, 11971) It is not fair that we should sit in jails in comparative comfort and safety and expect the people to face the fire.
('92', 5, 9, 32, 12088) The leaders should bear the brunt.
('92', 5, 9, 33, 12123) Let there be, say, a hundred people with your name on the top followed by those of other front rank Congress leaders to start a chain fast unto death, after giving due notice to the Government, and I am sure before the list is exhausted India will be free.

('92', 6, 1, 2, 12491) The interviewer added that he himself would in that event, be prepared to abandon his own programme and join the fast.

('92', 6, 4, 24, 14425) They have failed to fulfil their pledge up till now.

('92', 6, 5, 27, 14726) But some said that it was against your ideology.

('92', 6, 6, 30, 14870) In fact I do not want even the distinction between the political and non political prisoners.

('92', 7, 2, 10, 15516) 10. A DISCUSSION 1
('92', 7, 3, 11, 15535) [Before August 11, 1946] 2
('92', 7, 4, 12, 15562) QUESTION : What should be done about the strikes ?
('92', 7, 5, 13, 15613) ANSWER : Does it mean that the Congress has lost its hold on the people ?
('92', 7, 6, 14, 15687) Q. No, but the Congress has not spoken with one voice and that has created confusion in the public mind.
('92', 7, 7, 15, 15792) A. If the strike is unjustified on merits, it should be unequivocally denounced.
('92', 7, 8, 16, 15873) Q. By whom?
('92', 7, 9, 17, 15885) A. By the Congress, of course.
('92', 7, 10, 18, 15916) Q. What do you mean by the Congress?
('92', 7, 10, 19, 15953) The Working Committee might have.
('92', 7, 10, 20, 15987) It has not.
('92', 7, 11, 21, 15999) A. By Congress, I mean the 400 millions of India speaking through the Working Committee.
('92', 7, 12, 22, 16088) A militant suffragette who happened to be present here joined in : “But the Working Committee no longer speaks with one voice, thanks to your choice which you have imposed upon the country.
('92', 7, 12, 23, 16278) You have stifled democracy.”
('92', 7, 13, 24, 16307) Gandhiji explained that the present Working Committee was not his choice but that of the Congress President who had been democratically elected.
('92', 7, 13, 25, 16452) His part consisted mainly in persuading the Congress President to exercise his choice unfettered by consideration of personalities or the old tradition.
('92', 7, 13, 26, 16605) The present Working Committee could not stay there for a day if it did hot reflect the mind of democracy.
('92', 7, 13, 27, 16711) The only condition was that democracy should be wide awake and functioning.
('92', 7, 13, 28, 16787) As an illustration, he mentioned the case of Mr. Churchill, who, in spite of his unique victories and achievements, had been set aside by the British people the moment he
('92', 7, 14, 29, 16958) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” dated 11 8 1946 2 ibid 3 The questioner was the Premier of one of the Congress ruled Provinces.

('92', 8, 1, 2, 17142) ceased to reflect the nation’s mind.
('92', 8, 1, 3, 17179) The return of labour to power in such overwhelming strength is a great event in the history of political democracy.
('92', 8, 1, 4, 17295) It has a lesson which we would do well to take to heart.
('92', 8, 2, 5, 17352) Another in the company suggested that some sinister influence was at the back of the present strike fever.
('92', 8, 2, 6, 17459) The motive was not economic but political.
('92', 8, 2, 7, 17502) What was the remedy ?
('92', 8, 3, 8, 17524) A. You should reason with the strikers, warn them of the danger and resign if they or the people at large do not listen to you.
('92', 8, 4, 9, 17652) Q. But we owe a responsibility to the country.
('92', 8, 4, 10, 17699) Shall we be justified in abandoning the country to sinister influences, who in fact want the Congress to go out of office and want to create chaos?
('92', 8, 5, 11, 17847) A. That is the only way in which democracy can function.

('92', 8, 8, 24, 18637) I do not know that you can do much to alter them but I wonder why you cannot scrap them altogether.
('92', 8, 8, 25, 18737) The least that any State can do at this time is to recognize the status and influence of the States’ Peoples’ Conference, of which Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru is the President, and secure its endorsement before proceeding with any popular measure.
('92', 8, 8, 26, 18981) This ensures smooth passage for any such thing.
('92', 8, 8, 27, 19029) Rajkumari has already drawn your attention to Shrimati Padmaja Naidu’s pamphlet on police atrocities in some of the Hyderabad villages.
('92', 8, 8, 28, 19165) I would like you to enlighten me on these two

('92', 9, 2, 5, 19356) 12. LETTER TO SARALADEVI A. SARABHAI
('92', 9, 3, 6, 19393) SEVAGRAM, August 11, 1946
('92', 9, 4, 7, 19419) DEAR SISTER, Shyamlal has sent me the letter regarding Kamalabehn.
('92', 9, 4, 8, 19486) This seems a rather difficult case but our course is clear.
('92', 9, 4, 9, 19546) Let her deliver the child and if when it is three years old, she still has her heart in the work of service we can make full use of her.
('92', 9, 4, 10, 19683) In the meanwhile she will have a lot of spare time which she should utilize to increase her knowledge of the art of service, serve women wherever she happens to be and adapt her own life to village ways and make it becoming of a village woman.
('92', 9, 4, 11, 19927) And in order to do this she should maintain close contact with the activities of the Association.
('92', 9, 5, 12, 20025) Blessings from BAPU SMT.

('92', 10, 3, 5, 20807) 15. NOTES
('92', 10, 4, 6, 20817) SOUTH AFRICA The heroic struggle of the Indian settlers in South Africa continues with unabated zeal.
('92', 10, 4, 7, 20919) It promises to be prolonged.
('92', 10, 4, 8, 20948) The longer the resisters are made to suffer, the greater will be their glory and reward.
('92', 10, 4, 9, 21037) It is true of all long suffering.
('92', 10, 4, 10, 21071) What the Government of the Union of South Africa has done so deliberately of the going to be changed suddenly, even for the suffering of the brave men and women.
('92', 10, 4, 11, 21233) This is said not to damp the zeal of the fighters but to steel them for greater and longer suffering.
('92', 10, 4, 12, 21335) Their spokesman, when they were in India, were told in plain language that they must not expect the struggle to close quickly.
('92', 10, 4, 13, 21462) Time runs always in favour of the sufferer, for the simple reason that tyranny becomes more and more exposed as it is continued.
('92', 10, 4, 14, 21591) In reality it is never long.
('92', 10, 4, 15, 21620) Sufferers need never lose hope whether their struggle appears to have a longer lease of life or shorter, when the result is a certainty.
('92', 10, 5, 16, 21757) GOA The Goan authorities are going on merrily with their ‘humanizing’ activities by gagging the people of Goa.
('92', 10, 5, 17, 21868) The latest instance is that of their ‘court martial’ sentencing Shri Braganza Cunha to eight years and deporting him to a far off Portuguese settlement in Africa for the crime of daring to assert his elementary right of civil liberty.
('92', 10, 5, 18, 22103) 1 Well has the Working Committee passed a resolution in condemnation of the policy of the Goan authorities which stands in striking contrast to the action of the French Governor
('92', 10, 6, 19, 22281) 1Vide “Letter to The Governor General of Portuguese India”, 2 8 1946

('92', 11, 1, 2, 22391) who has encouraged the people to throw in their lot with the people in British India.

('92', 16, 8, 17, 29524) Today all the [members] of the Working Committee have left as also the Congress President, hence I am dictating this letter early in the morning.

('92', 21, 5, 14, 37066) SEVAGRAM, August 15, 1946 Friends and admirers of Mahadev Desai have been following the practice of observing his death anniversary by occupying themselves with something dear to him.
('92', 21, 5, 15, 37250) His was a rich, gifted hand.
('92', 21, 5, 16, 37279) He had many loves.

('92', 21, 5, 18, 37351) He span regularly and beautifully like the artist that he was.

('92', 21, 5, 20, 37495) It refreshed him.
('92', 21, 5, 21, 37513) Among his many accomplishments, not the least was his peerless handwriting.
('92', 21, 5, 22, 37589) There he was master.

('92', 23, 1, 2, 39321) 35. PREACHING TO EMPTINESS
('92', 23, 2, 3, 39348) SEVAGRAM, August 16, 1946 Downes was a Seventh Day Adventist.
('92', 23, 2, 4, 39410) He was a quack like me.
('92', 23, 2, 5, 39434) He was my guest years ago in Durban.
('92', 23, 2, 6, 39471) One day he said he must the preach the simple life to those who cared to listen to him.
('92', 23, 2, 7, 39559) He succeeded in borrowing a chapel hall for one hour in Mercury Lane and asked me to preside.
('92', 23, 2, 8, 39653) I warned him that with me as chairman in the very early days of my life in South Africa, probably in 1894, he must not expect an audience.
('92', 23, 2, 9, 39792) He would not heed the warning.
('92', 23, 2, 10, 39823) Precisely at the advertised time Downes began his address to an audience of one.
('92', 23, 2, 11, 39904) I asked him in vain to wait a few minutes for other comers.
('92', 23, 2, 12, 39964) He would not be party to stealing God’s time and unconcerned, he went on with his speech.
('92', 23, 2, 13, 40054) So far as I remember, a few stragglers, under ten, came in during the speech.
('92', 23, 2, 14, 40132) I happened to relate this experience to Horace Alexander whilst I was in Delhi.
('92', 23, 2, 15, 40212) He gave me in return the stranger story of Stephen Grellet, a Quaker, preaching to emptiness.
('92', 23, 2, 16, 40306) I asked him to give me the authentic version for the readers of Harijan, it being a rich experience of living faith in God.
('92', 23, 2, 17, 40430) I reproduce below the story as sent by Horace Alexander.

('92', 24, 2, 6, 41818) 37. MASS MURDER
('92', 24, 3, 7, 41834) A friend writes :
('92', 24, 4, 8, 41852) The food famine situation in Mysore and Rayalaseema is daily growing more serious.
('92', 24, 4, 9, 41935) Unless imports pour in sufficient quantities, the local co operative stores will fail to supply rations—starvation rations as they are, since only 8. oz.
('92', 24, 4, 10, 42089) of rice is being given to peasants who need 24 oz.
('92', 24, 4, 11, 42140) to keep them fit—to the peasant masses and I am afraid that we may have to be prepared to face deaths due to starvation in November and December.
('92', 24, 4, 12, 42286) If even half of what he says is true, it is a sad reflection on our capacity to cope with food famine in a vast country like India where there is land lying waste or ill used and water running rapidly into the sea for want of human ingenuity to dam and store it.
('92', 24, 4, 13, 42549) The writer says that unless imports “pour in sufficient quantities”, meaning undoubtedly from outside India, “mass deaths due to starvation in November and December” are a certainty.
('92', 24, 4, 14, 42732) I suggest to everyone concerned that if this happens, the Government of the country will be guilty of mass murder.
('92', 24, 4, 15, 42847) To look to outside sources for food supply is to invite starvation.
('92', 24, 4, 16, 42915) Has it ever been made clear that India has no capacity for growing sufficient food between now and November?
('92', 24, 4, 17, 43024) Need a vast country like India with its teeming millions starve, even if the whole world were to declare a blockade against it?
('92', 24, 5, 18, 43152) SEVAGRAM, August 16, 1946 Harijan, 25 8 1946
('92', 24, 6, 19, 43197) 1Vide also” Letter to N.G. Ranga”, 15 8 1946.

('92', 28, 4, 7, 48024) 45. DISCUSSION WITH A FRIEND 2
('92', 28, 5, 8, 48055) [Before August 17, 1946] 3
('92', 28, 6, 9, 48082) GANDHIJI : To appreciate fully the present policy of the A. I. S. A. you have to take in its etiology.
('92', 28, 6, 10, 48185) In the initial stages emphasis was on bringing relief to the poor.
('92', 28, 6, 11, 48252) Incidentally it provided a living link between the classes and the masses and assumed a political significance.
('92', 28, 6, 12, 48364) We cannot make further headway on those lines.
('92', 28, 6, 13, 48411) We cannot, for instance, further increase the wages.
('92', 28, 6, 14, 48464) Khadi won’t bear it.
('92', 28, 6, 15, 48485) So far it was spun and woven by the masses.
('92', 28, 6, 16, 48529) Now it must still be by the masses, but for their own use.
('92', 28, 6, 17, 48588) The new policy of the A. I. S. A. has not failed.
('92', 28, 6, 18, 48638) The latest figures show that it is steadily though slowly making headway.
('92', 28, 6, 19, 48712) There are difficulties.
('92', 28, 6, 20, 48736) Weaving constitutes the bottleneck.
('92', 28, 6, 21, 48772) We have not established a sufficient hold on the weavers.
('92', 28, 6, 22, 48830) The fault, again, is mine.
('92', 28, 6, 23, 48857) If I had from the very beginning insisted on all learning weaving along with spinning things would have been different today.
('92', 28, 6, 24, 48983) The working capital of the A. I. S. A. now stands at twenty five lakhs.
('92', 28, 6, 25, 49055) It has taken twenty five years to reach that figure.
('92', 28, 6, 26, 49108) During that period it distributed over seven crores of rupees as wages among four and a half lakhs of the poor spinners and weavers, principally spread over twenty thousand villages of India.
('92', 28, 6, 27, 49300) I do not know of another instance of such a huge turn over with so little capital in such a wide area.
('92', 28, 7, 28, 49403) FRIEND : That is good but by no means unique.
('92', 28, 7, 29, 49449) The Chinese Indusco did better.
('92', 28, 8, 30, 49481) G. That is not a fair comparison.
('92', 28, 8, 31, 49515) I studied in detention Nym
('92', 28, 9, 32, 49542) 1 This was sent to Dr. K. G. Saiyidain on the occasion of the University’s Silver Jubilee.
('92', 28, 9, 33, 49633) 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Khadi On Trial”, 17 8 1946 3 ibid
('92', 29, 0, 1, 49696) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 29, 1, 2, 49737) Wales’ book which was recommended to me.
('92', 29, 1, 3, 49778) Indusco’s activities were carried on under abnormal circumstances with the backing of the Chinese National Government.
('92', 29, 1, 4, 49897) Besides, all its production was war time production.
('92', 29, 1, 5, 49950) You need not have gone as far as China for your illustration.
('92', 29, 1, 6, 50012) The work of the Calicut Mission in South India would have provided a more apt instance.
('92', 29, 1, 7, 50100) In each case the field was restricted.
('92', 29, 1, 8, 50139) In the case of khadi it is trying to serve the whole of India.
('92', 29, 2, 9, 50202) F. We cannot today attract more artisans by offering better wages.
('92', 29, 2, 10, 50269) The general level of wages in the country is already so high.
('92', 29, 3, 11, 50331) G. We do not want to.
('92', 29, 4, 12, 50353) F. You mean to say you want them to produce for self.
('92', 29, 5, 13, 50407) G. Yes.
('92', 29, 6, 14, 50415) F. How can that be made practicable?
('92', 29, 7, 15, 50452) G. I explained that to Mr. Casey 1 last year.
('92', 29, 7, 16, 50498) I told him that by adopting my scheme, not only could we solve the cloth problem for Bengal, but for the whole of India.
('92', 29, 7, 17, 50619) The essence of that scheme was that, instead of supplying textiles to the people, they should be taught how to make cloth for themselves and provided the necessary means—instruments, raw materials, etc.,—for the same.
('92', 29, 7, 18, 50837) A reasonable time limit should be fixed after which no textiles would be rationed in the area covered by the scheme.
('92', 29, 7, 19, 50954) In German East Africa, I am told, cloth shortage during World War I was actually met by the Negroes being induced to manufacture their own cloth.
('92', 29, 7, 20, 51100) Whether that is so or not, if India made full use of her spinning and weaving tradition which is universal and the matchless hereditary skill of her artisans, she could not only solve her own difficulty but even help the world to meet the present crisis by releasing her mill production, for countries less favourable placed in the matter of cloth manufacture.
('92', 29, 8, 21, 51461) F. The fact, however, remains that in spite of there being such an acute cloth scarcity, khadi has failed to step into the breach.
('92', 29, 8, 22, 51592) It has missed the bus.
('92', 29, 9, 23, 51615) G. Thanks to Government interference.
('92', 29, 9, 24, 51653) They arrested khadi workers, burnt stocks of khadi and put khadi production under every conceivable handicap.
('92', 29, 10, 25, 51763) 1 R. G. Casey, Governor of Bengal in 1945, whom Gandhiji met in Calcutta on December 1, 2 and 3, 1945. Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 5 12 1945 and “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 7 12 1945.
('92', 30, 0, 1, 51952) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 31
('92', 30, 1, 2, 51997) F. The vacuum is growing.
('92', 30, 1, 3, 52023) Production charges have already touched the ceiling and yet the wages that we can offer are not adequate to attract even the unemployed.
('92', 30, 2, 4, 52160) G. Where are these unemployed?
('92', 30, 3, 5, 52191) F. Well, there are one lakh of I. N. A. men.
('92', 30, 4, 6, 52236) G. I made an offer to them.
('92', 30, 4, 7, 52264) It has yet evoked no response.
('92', 30, 4, 8, 52295) You can take the horse to the trough but you cannot make it drink.
('92', 30, 5, 9, 52362) F. Cannot Government formulate a scheme?
('92', 30, 6, 10, 52403) G. It has been done in Madras.
('92', 30, 6, 11, 52434) It is under examination.
('92', 30, 6, 12, 52459) Nothing can be imposed from above.
('92', 30, 6, 13, 52494) Everything has to be worked from below.
('92', 30, 6, 14, 52534) And those who work them should have faith and conviction and spirit of service.
('92', 30, 6, 15, 52614) A Government ukase won’t do the trick.
('92', 30, 6, 16, 52653) Government can assist.
('92', 30, 6, 17, 52676) As I told Mr. Casey, I am prepared to work out my scheme if it is left to me and the Government accord necessary facilities.
('92', 30, 6, 18, 52801) That offer still stands.
('92', 30, 7, 19, 52826) F. The danger is that, if we stop the supply of textiles to any area, as envisaged in your scheme, it may accentuate the present discontent and even cause an upheaval.
('92', 30, 7, 20, 52994) There are elements ready to pounce upon and exploit any excuse to foment discontent.
('92', 30, 7, 21, 53079) Restriction on cloth supply might even be enumerated as an ‘atrocity’ as prohibition was by a certain section in Bombay.
('92', 30, 7, 22, 53200) How can we contemplate or invite a disturbance like that?
('92', 30, 7, 23, 53258) This is not a constructive approach to the question.
('92', 30, 7, 24, 53311) It smacks of compulsion.
('92', 30, 8, 25, 53336) G. Where is the question of compulsion?
('92', 30, 8, 26, 53376) As it is, there is not enough cloth to go round.
('92', 30, 8, 27, 53425) The stocks of cloth available for distribution being short of the demand, rationing becomes a necessity.
('92', 30, 8, 28, 53530) The question is only of wise distribution.
('92', 30, 8, 29, 53573) No stocks may be expected from outside for some time.
('92', 30, 8, 30, 53627) America and England are making strenuous efforts to increase their cloth production.
('92', 30, 8, 31, 53712) But it is all needed there.
('92', 30, 8, 32, 53740) If we nationalize our textile industry and work it on a double shift basis, it would probably solve the problem of cloth shortage, but not of mass poverty.
('92', 30, 8, 33, 53896) I won’t then be able to press the case for khadi, not because there would be no case but because I won’t be able to carry conviction.
('92', 30, 9, 34, 54030) F. That is not my point.
('92', 30, 9, 35, 54055) An element of compulsion there is in all governmental measures.
('92', 30, 9, 36, 54119) If a fundamentally unsound and unstable economic situation is sought to be propped up by governmental compulsion, there is danger that it will crash one day and spread ruin all around.
('92', 30, 9, 37, 54304) I am wondering if the
('92', 31, 0, 1, 54326) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 31, 1, 2, 54367) organization of khadi production on the present lines is not an instance of that type, whether pure theory does not need to be tempered with a measure of practical realism to suit the changed conditions.
('92', 31, 1, 3, 54571) For instance, the woollen manufactures in Kashmir are not self use.
('92', 31, 1, 4, 54639) They cater for the market for fancy goods outside Kashmir.
('92', 31, 1, 5, 54698) They are extremely popular.
('92', 31, 1, 6, 54726) Now, if we introduce machine carding, they can hold their own against all competition.
('92', 31, 1, 7, 54813) But that would be against the fundamental khadi principles.
('92', 31, 1, 8, 54873) I have been thinking whether a compromise cannot be effected.
('92', 31, 1, 9, 54935) To run cottage industries with man power exclusively, has not much prospect of survival in this age of machinery.
('92', 31, 1, 10, 55049) We may try to canalize economic trends, we may not run against them in a head on collision.
('92', 31, 1, 11, 55141) If we could run cottage industries with the help of cheap electricity, for instance, they would be able to hold their own without losing their essential character.
('92', 31, 1, 12, 55305) After all, decentralized production is what we want.
('92', 31, 1, 13, 55358) We might have projects for the development of cheap hydraulic power as an aid to irrigation schemes.
('92', 31, 1, 14, 55459) They can be in operation in from six to ten years.
('92', 31, 1, 15, 55510) It will then be possible to take electricity to every village.
('92', 31, 1, 16, 55573) Shall we under those circumstances be able to work khadi on the present lines?
('92', 31, 1, 17, 55652) Normally speaking, supply should balance demand.
('92', 31, 1, 18, 55701) But instead of establishing khadi on a permanent basis, we are crippling it by artificial restrictions with the result that a lot of corruption and dishonesty has crept in.
('92', 31, 2, 19, 55874) G. It is open to all those who cannot or do not want to spin to go in for mill cloth, whether Indian or foreign.
('92', 31, 2, 20, 55987) I am walking with my eyes open.

('92', 31, 2, 22, 56117) Each time heroic measures were adopted and the crisis was overcome.
('92', 31, 2, 23, 56185) I do not expect a different result this time.
('92', 31, 2, 24, 56231) Only, we must have faith and patience and the courage to apply the right remedy which is what I am doing at present.
('92', 31, 2, 25, 56348) If in the process khadi dies, I must be prepared to take even that risk.
('92', 31, 3, 26, 56421) F. That is begging the question.
('92', 31, 3, 27, 56454) It won’t go down with people.
('92', 31, 3, 28, 56484) We have got to adjust our policy to the popular need.
('92', 31, 4, 29, 56538) G. I cannot do that.

('92', 32, 1, 2, 57173) F. You said weaving was the bottleneck.
('92', 32, 1, 3, 57213) A weaver mill yarn, can today earn as much as Rs. 3 a day.
('92', 32, 1, 4, 57272) The spinner and the weaver of the hand spun won’t work for lower wages.

('92', 32, 3, 13, 58007) Unless we make sure that our khadi policy rests on a sound practicable basis and fits into the over all picture, khadi is bound to fail.

('92', 32, 9, 26, 59131) F. All I know is that where there is widespread and genuine demand for a commodity and the supply falls short, it should be possible to devise ways and means to adjust the economic balance and satisfy the demand in question.
('92', 32, 9, 27, 59356) G. I can only warn you of the danger.
('92', 32, 9, 28, 59394) There was a time when we used machine carded slivers for spinning.

('92', 33, 1, 2, 59649) The late Sir Gangaram said to me : “Only give up the spinning wheel, concentrate on the handloom and I am with you.” He did not realize what we know today, that the use of mill yarn is the principal stranglehold on the handloom industry.

('92', 42, 8, 18, 73855) Otherwise progress would be at a snail’s pace and ambitious planning in a few villages would only stand out as a monument of costly futility.

('92', 43, 2, 4, 74720) 63. WHAT CAN VIOLENCE DO?
('92', 43, 3, 5, 74746) If newspaper reports are to be believe, responsible ministers in Sindh and other equally responsible Leaguers almost all over, are preaching violence in naked language.
('92', 43, 3, 6, 74915) Nakedness is itself a virtue as distinguished from hypocrisy.
('92', 43, 3, 7, 74977) But when it is a hymn of obscenity, it is a vice to be shunned, whether it resides in a Leaguer or any other person.
('92', 43, 3, 8, 75094) Any Muslim who is not in the League is a traitor, says one.
('92', 43, 3, 9, 75154) The Hindu is a kafir deserving the fate of such, says another.
('92', 43, 3, 10, 75217) Calcutta had given an ocular demonstration of what direct action is and how it is to be done.
('92', 43, 4, 11, 75311) Who is the gainer?
('92', 43, 4, 12, 75330) Certainly not the Muslim masses nor the sober followers of Islam which itself means sobriety and peace.
('92', 43, 4, 13, 75434) The very salute salaam alaikum means ‘peace be unto you’.
('92', 43, 4, 14, 75492) Violence may have its place in life but not that which we have witnessed in Calcutta, assuming of course that newspaper accounts are to be trusted.
('92', 43, 4, 15, 75640) Pakistan of whatever hue does not lie through senseless violence.
('92', 43, 4, 16, 75706) When I write of senseless violence, I naturally assume the possibility of sensible violence, whatever the latter may be.
('92', 43, 4, 17, 75827) The Calcutta demonstration was not an illustration of sensible violence.
('92', 43, 4, 18, 75900) What senseless violence does is to prolong the lease of the life of British or foreign rule.
('92', 43, 4, 19, 75993) I believe that the authors of the State Paper issued by the Cabinet Mission desire peaceful transfer of power to representative Indian hands.
('92', 43, 4, 20, 76135) But if we need the use of the British gun and bayonet, the British will not go or, if they do, some other foreign power will take their place.
('92', 43, 4, 21, 76278) We will make a serious mistake, if, everytime the British bayonet is used, we trot out the agent provocateur.
('92', 43, 4, 22, 76388) No doubt he has been at work.
('92', 43, 4, 23, 76418) Let us not ride that horse to death.
('92', 43, 4, 24, 76455) Calcutta has earned a bad repute of late.
('92', 43, 4, 25, 76497) It has seen too many wild demonstrations during the past few months.
('92', 43, 4, 26, 76566) If the evil reputation
('92', 43, 5, 27, 76589) 1 On August 16, which the Muslim League had declared “Direct Action Day”, savage riots broke out in Calcutta.
('92', 43, 5, 28, 76699) During four days of rioting, according to official estimates, some five thousand were killed and fifteen thousand wounded.
('92', 44, 0, 1, 76822) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 45
('92', 44, 1, 2, 76867) is sustained for some time longer, it will cease to be the City of Palaces, it will become the city of the dead.
('92', 44, 1, 3, 76980) Would that the violence of Calcutta were sterilized and did not become a signal for its spread all over.
('92', 44, 1, 4, 77085) It depends upon the leaders of the Muslim League of course, but the rest will not be free from responsibility.
('92', 44, 1, 5, 77196) They can retaliate or refrain.
('92', 44, 1, 6, 77227) Refraining is easy and simple, if there is the will.
('92', 44, 1, 7, 77280) Retaliation is complicated.
('92', 44, 1, 8, 77308) Will it be tooth against or many against one?
('92', 44, 1, 9, 77354) SEVAGRAM, August 19, 1946 Harijan, 25 8 1946

('92', 47, 1, 2, 80787) 70. LETTER TO KASHINATH TRIVEDI
('92', 47, 2, 3, 80819) SEVAGRAM, August 20, 1946
('92', 47, 3, 4, 80845) KASHINATH, I had thought of writing to Father.
('92', 47, 3, 5, 80892) But then for the first two days I forgot all about it.
('92', 47, 3, 6, 80947) Later when I suddenly remembered it no one could tell me his name.
('92', 47, 3, 7, 81014) I think I had asked you to leave me his name and address and you had said I should ask someone or the other.
('92', 47, 3, 8, 81123) No one however could give me the name.
('92', 47, 3, 9, 81162) It is possible that you left it with Krishnachandra, but he stays in Paunar.
('92', 47, 3, 10, 81239) I could not get it from the Mahila Ashram either.
('92', 47, 3, 11, 81289) Now that I have to reply to your letter I shall say here what I want to write to Father.
('92', 47, 3, 12, 81378) Tell him it is only natural for a father to be grieved by the passing away of a young son.
('92', 47, 3, 13, 81469) But if one takes a dispassionate and broad view, why should one grieve?
('92', 47, 3, 14, 81541) Everyone who is born must die, the only difference being whether death comes soon or late.
('92', 47, 3, 15, 81632) Why grieve over it then?
('92', 47, 3, 16, 81657) And one who looks upon all children as his own—and Father must adopt such an attitude—over whom can such a person grieve?
('92', 47, 3, 17, 81779) Thus I would suggest that if the cause of this death has been found we should try and remove the possibility of its recurrence in respect of others.
('92', 47, 3, 18, 81928) The main cause of typhoid is believed to be contaminated water.
('92', 47, 3, 19, 81992) Wherever this cause has been removed casualties from typhoid have been reduced almost to nil.
('92', 47, 3, 20, 82086) Now the reply to your letter.
('92', 47, 3, 21, 82116) Wherever there is a clash between groups of workers it should be understood that neither party seeks Government help.
('92', 47, 3, 22, 82234) If this is assured the conflict tends to stop.
('92', 47, 3, 23, 82281) And if they do not accept Government help one of the parties should wisely and courageously stay calm.
('92', 47, 3, 24, 82384) The conflict will then dissolve.
('92', 47, 3, 25, 82417) Everyone does not readily realize this.
('92', 47, 3, 26, 82457) Hence, one should acquire enough strength for self defence.
('92', 47, 3, 27, 82517) Detecting and removing the cause of conflict is the universally accepted remedy.
('92', 47, 3, 28, 82598) But where one party is determined to secure power by resorting to conflict, then there is nothing one can do.
('92', 47, 3, 29, 82708) It is very clear and also painful.
('92', 47, 3, 30, 82743) And the remedy lies either in the violent or the non violent way described above.
('92', 47, 4, 31, 82825) SHRI KASHINATH TRIVEDI
('92', 47, 5, 32, 82848) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('92', 47, 5, 33, 82894) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('92', 51, 0, 1, 86661) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 51, 1, 2, 86702) 77. ENGLISH INTO HINDUSTANI
('92', 51, 2, 3, 86730) What English knowing Indian has not felt the shame and sorrow at his failure to discover an equivalent for an English word in either his mother tongue or the national language?
('92', 51, 2, 4, 86907) A Gujarati lad has an English Gujarati dictionary in such a case to help him; similarly a Urdu or Hindi knowing lad has his dictionary to fall back upon.
('92', 51, 2, 5, 87061) But for Hindustani, which is neither Persianized Urdu nor Sanskritized Hindi and which is the tongue of the common folk of the North, whether Hindu or Mussalman, a writer has no dictionary to fall back upon.
('92', 51, 2, 6, 87269) An attempt will be made through a column at least of the Harijan each week to furnish for English a Hindustani word or two, spelt in both Nagari and Urdu script.
('92', 51, 2, 7, 87431) An endeavour will be made to give the names of those who will contribute their labour to this fascinating task.

('92', 52, 1, 2, 88573) 78. WE ARE ALL INDIANS
('92', 52, 2, 3, 88596) A Roman Catholic student from Goa had the sad experience of being told by some of his fellow students in Bombay that he was a Portuguese and therefore a foreigner.
('92', 52, 2, 4, 88760) When he told them that the Roman Catholics of Goa had castes just like the Hindus, he was not believed.
('92', 52, 2, 5, 88864) These transitory lapses will take place whilst we are shedding our narrownesses and claiming all to be free Indians, slaves neither of the British, nor of the Portuguese nor any other foreign rule.
('92', 52, 2, 6, 89062) If the same students were wisely handled, they would be proud to know their friend as an Indian and not as a Goan and be known themselves as Indians, not Bombayites.
('92', 52, 2, 7, 89228) Everyone’s religion is his own concern but his nationality is a corporate thing, carrying with it important and far reaching consequences.
('92', 52, 2, 8, 89367) That even among converts there are castes is a reflection upon Hinduism and should set every Hindu thinking and make him become, with me, a Bhangi.

('92', 55, 6, 12, 92254) 86. ADDRESS TO TRAINEES OF BASIC TEACHERS’ CAMP 1
('92', 55, 7, 13, 92304) SEVAGRAM, August 23, 1946 One of the complaints that has been made by one of you is that too much emphasis is laid here on manual work.
('92', 55, 7, 14, 92440) I am a firm believer in the educative value of manual work..
('92', 55, 7, 15, 92501) Our present educational system is meant for strengthening and perpetuating the imperialist power in India.
('92', 55, 7, 16, 92608) Those of you who have been brought up under it have naturally developed a taste for it and so find labour irksome.
('92', 55, 7, 17, 92723) No one in Government schools or college bothers to teach the students how to clean the roads or latrines.
('92', 55, 7, 18, 92829) Here cleanliness and sanitation form the very Alpha and Omega of your training.
('92', 55, 7, 19, 92909) Scavenging is a fine art you should take pains to learn.
('92', 55, 7, 20, 92966) Persistent questioning and healthy inquisitiveness are the first requisite for acquiring learning of any kind.
('92', 55, 7, 21, 93077) Inquisitiveness should be tempered by humility and
('92', 55, 8, 22, 93128) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('92', 55, 8, 23, 93173) There were 79 trainees sent by various Congress ruled provinces and by the Kasturba Trust.
('92', 55, 8, 24, 93264) The meeting was held in the Talimi Sangh Hall.
('92', 56, 0, 1, 93311) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 57
('92', 56, 1, 2, 93355) respectful regard for the teacher.
('92', 56, 1, 3, 93390) It must not degenerate into impudence.
('92', 56, 1, 4, 93429) The latter is the enemy of receptivity of mind.
('92', 56, 1, 5, 93477) There can be no knowledge without humility and the will to learn.
('92', 56, 1, 6, 93543) Useful manual labour, intelligently performed, is the means par excellence for developing the intellect.
('92', 56, 1, 7, 93648) One may develop a sharp intellect otherwise too.
('92', 56, 1, 8, 93697) But then it will not be a balanced growth but an unbalanced distorted abortion.
('92', 56, 1, 9, 93777) It might easily make of one a rogue and a rascal.
('92', 56, 1, 10, 93827) A balanced intellect presupposes a harmonious growth of boy, mind and soul.
('92', 56, 1, 11, 93903) That is why we give to manual labour the central place in our curriculum of training here.
('92', 56, 1, 12, 93994) An intellect that is developed through the medium of socially useful labour will be an instrument for service and will not easily be led astray or fall into devious paths.
('92', 56, 1, 13, 94166) The latter can well be a scourge.
('92', 56, 1, 14, 94200) If you grasp that essential point, the money spent by your respective government in sending you here for training will have been well spent.
('92', 56, 1, 15, 94341) Harijan, 8 9 1946

('92', 58, 7, 15, 96720) August 24, 1946 I had long talks with Kanchan.

('92', 58, 7, 18, 96819) She certainly desires conjugal pleasure and to bear children.
('92', 58, 7, 19, 96881) This wish on her part cannot be despised.

('92', 58, 7, 21, 96946) No one can find fault with you if you beget progeny.
('92', 58, 7, 22, 96999) It is only right for you to satisfy her and find satisfaction yourself.
('92', 58, 7, 23, 97071) It is another matter if, seeing your ascetic disposition and out of love and compassion for you, she herself releases you.
('92', 58, 7, 24, 97194) But at present this is beyond you both.
('92', 58, 7, 25, 97234) You have not the necessary firmness of mind.

('92', 58, 7, 32, 97658) Kanchan has suffered much.

('92', 59, 0, 1, 98020) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 59, 1, 2, 98061) 91. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 59, 2, 3, 98092) SEVAGRAM, August 24, 1946 When the Ashram was first started in Kochrab we set before us certain ideals.
('92', 59, 2, 4, 98196) The same ideals are before us today.
('92', 59, 2, 5, 98233) What is our duty in terms of these ideals in the face of the conflagration that is raging in the country today?
('92', 59, 2, 6, 98345) Let us be humble and confess that we have not got the strength today to meet all the expectations that the people entertain of us.
('92', 59, 2, 7, 98476) But we are sincerely striving for it.
('92', 59, 2, 8, 98514) If we had fully realized the principles for which we stand, we should have rushed into the blaze and offered the purest sacrifice which might have conceivably quenched the flames.
('92', 59, 3, 9, 98694) He then proceeded to give his definition of ‘pure sacrifice’.
('92', 59, 3, 10, 98756) It was not the thoughtless annihilation of the moth in the flame.
('92', 59, 3, 11, 98822) Sacrifice to be effective must be backed by the uttermost external and internal purity.
('92', 59, 3, 12, 98910) There is nothing that such sacrifice cannot achieve.
('92', 59, 3, 13, 98963) Without the requisite purity, sacrifice is no better than a desperate self annihilation devoid of any merit.
('92', 59, 3, 14, 99072) Sacrifice must, further, be willing and it should be made in faith and hope, without a trace of hatred or ill will in the heart.
('92', 59, 3, 15, 99201) Although we have fallen short of the ideal, we have never been found wanting in honest endeavour.
('92', 59, 3, 16, 99299) The art of jail going we have learnt with the rest.
('92', 59, 3, 17, 99351) But jail going is only the beginning, not the end of satyagraha.
('92', 59, 3, 18, 99416) The acme of satyagraha for us would be to lay down our lives for the defence of India’s just cause.
('92', 59, 3, 19, 99516) Let us then pray to God to give us the requisite purity and fearlessness in the true sense of the term, to make our sacrifice worthy of the altar.
('92', 59, 3, 20, 99663) Then alone shall we be worthy of the name of the Ashram.
('92', 59, 3, 21, 99720) Harijan, 8 9 1946
('92', 59, 4, 22, 99738) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s ‘Weekly Letter’, 3 9 1946
('92', 60, 0, 1, 99792) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 61
('92', 60, 1, 2, 99836) 92. HINDUSTANI v.URDU AND HINDI
('92', 60, 2, 3, 99868) A Bombay Government circular of 16 8 1939 reads :
('92', 60, 3, 4, 99918) It has been observed that the word “Hindustani” is being used indifferently for Hindi or Hindustani.
('92', 60, 3, 5, 100019) Please note that Hindustani is different and distinct from both HINDI and URDU, and when a reference to that language is to be made, it should be made as “Hindustani” only.
('92', 60, 3, 6, 100192) On 9th October 1940 a press note was issued :
('92', 60, 4, 7, 100238) In September 1938 the Government of Bombay announced their decision to introduce the study of Hindustani in the schools of the Province.
('92', 60, 4, 8, 100375) Steps were accordingly taken to implement that decision and the language is being taught in the primary schools, secondary schools and in the training institutions.
('92', 60, 4, 9, 100540) In actual practice the teaching of the language in the schools has raised certain difficulties which have to be considered.
('92', 60, 4, 10, 100664) The chief of them are lack of literature in the language, as it has yet to develop, and the absence of suitable text books for use in schools.
('92', 60, 4, 11, 100807) The Hindustani text books now in use have been found to be defective, both in regard to the language used in them which is said to contain too many words of Hindi origin and in regard to the subject matter of the lessons included in them, some of which are stated to be unsuitable for Muslim pupils.
('92', 60, 4, 12, 101107) Besides, both Urdu and Hindustani have so much of a common vocabulary that it has been suggested that it is unnecessary to insist on the teaching of Hindustani in Urdu schools.
('92', 60, 4, 13, 101284) The Government having carefully considered the whole question have now directed teaching of Hindustani in other institutions.
('92', 60, 4, 14, 101410) Urdu educational institutions in the Province, i.
('92', 60, 4, 15, 101460) e., the primary and secondary schools and training institutions where the medium of instruction is Urdu, should be exempted from the inclusion of such teaching in the curriculum.
('92', 60, 4, 16, 101639) Another circular issued in 1941 exempts Hindi schools from the teaching of Hindustani, thus leaving Hindu schools where the medium is other than Hindi or Urdu for teaching Hindustani.
('92', 60, 4, 17, 101823) What is the present Government of the Province, which is based on popular will, to do?
('92', 60, 4, 18, 101910) The answer is contained in the admission that the present Provincial Government is based on popular will.
('92', 60, 4, 19, 102016) If the Hindi schools wish to have Hindustani, the national language, taught in the primary and secondary schools, it should be taught.
('92', 60, 4, 20, 102151) Naturally the question has to be decided by the parents of the children learning in these schools.
('92', 60, 4, 21, 102250) If they do not want it and an attempt is made to impose it by force, the
('92', 61, 0, 1, 102323) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 61, 1, 2, 102364) claim for being a popular Government cannot be sustained.
('92', 61, 1, 3, 102422) I should certainly advise the parents to want their children to be taught it.
('92', 61, 1, 4, 102500) It should never be forgotten that Hindustani is essentially a cross between Hindi and Urdu and written in both the scripts.
('92', 61, 1, 5, 102624) If the parents want either only Hindi or Urdu and only one script, they cannot impose it on an unbelieving or unwilling Government.
('92', 61, 1, 6, 102756) Either party has freedom of action.
('92', 61, 1, 7, 102792) The question whether Hindustani is or can be a national form of speech is irrelevant at this stage.
('92', 61, 1, 8, 102892) The argument has, moreover, been examined often enough in previous issues of the Harijan.
('92', 61, 1, 9, 102982) SEVAGRAM, August 25, 1946 Harijan, 8 9 1946
('92', 61, 2, 10, 103026) 93. ADVICE TO AN ASHRAM INMATE 1
('92', 61, 3, 11, 103059) SEVAGRAM, August 25, 1946 Why should you want to touch my feet?
('92', 61, 3, 12, 103123) Millions cannot do that and what millions cannot afford, we should voluntarily renounce.
('92', 61, 3, 13, 103212) I go so far as to say that if ahimsa cannot be practised by the millions, I have no use for it for myself.
('92', 61, 3, 14, 103319) But if they did not want to, although they could, I would hold on to it, even if I were all alone.
('92', 61, 3, 15, 103418) People say that ahimsa is only for the saint and the seer.
('92', 61, 3, 16, 103477) I think otherwise.
('92', 61, 3, 17, 103496) If what they say is right, it ceases to have any value in my eyes.
('92', 61, 3, 18, 103563) Similarly, if it were open to me alone to desire and strive to live for 125 years, I would not entertain that desire.
('92', 61, 3, 19, 103681) But everybody can and should desire to live for 125 years, for the service of God and His creation.
('92', 61, 3, 20, 103781) Self interest too demands that.
('92', 61, 3, 21, 103813) For what would life be worth in a world in which I am the sole survivor of all those I have worked with and known?
('92', 61, 4, 22, 103928) Harijan, 1 9 1946
('92', 61, 5, 23, 103946) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('92', 61, 5, 24, 103991) The inmate had wanted to touch Gandhiji’s feet as Gandhiji was leaving Sevagram.
('92', 61, 5, 25, 104072) According to the source this incident took place on the 25th morning.
('92', 62, 0, 1, 104142) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 63
('92', 62, 1, 2, 104186) 94. ALTERNATIVE TO INDUSTRIALISM
('92', 62, 2, 3, 104219) A correspondent writes :
('92', 62, 3, 4, 104244) Do you then believe that industrialization of India—to the extent of India producing her own ships, locomotives, aeroplanes, etc., —is necessary?
('92', 62, 3, 5, 104390) If not, will you kindly suggest the alternative means by which India shall discharge her responsibilities as a free and independent nation?
('92', 62, 4, 6, 104530) If you believe in the establishment of such industries, who should, in your opinion, exercise control over the management and the profits that will accrue?
('92', 62, 4, 7, 104686) I do not believe that industrialization is necessary in any case for any country.
('92', 62, 4, 8, 104768) It is much less so for India.
('92', 62, 4, 9, 104798) Indeed, I believe that Independent India can only discharge her duty towards a groaning world by adopting a simple but ennobled life by developing her thousands of cottage [industries] and living at peace with the world.
('92', 62, 4, 10, 105019) High thinking is inconsistent with complicated material life based on high speed imposed on us by Mammon worship.
('92', 62, 4, 11, 105133) All the graces of life are possible only when we learn the art of living nobly.
('92', 62, 4, 12, 105213) There may be sensation in living dangerously.
('92', 62, 4, 13, 105259) We must draw the distinction between living in the face of danger and living dangerously.
('92', 62, 4, 14, 105349) A man who dares to live alone in a forest infested by wild beasts and wilder men without a gun and with God as his only Help, lives in the face of danger.
('92', 62, 4, 15, 105504) A man who lives perpetually in mid air and dives to the earth below to the admiration of a gaping world lives dangerously.
('92', 62, 4, 16, 105627) One is a purposeful, the other a purposeless, life.
('92', 62, 4, 17, 105679) Whether such plain living is possible for an isolated nation, however large geographically and numerically in the face of a world armed to the teeth and in the midst of pomp and circumstance, is a question open to the doubt of a sceptic.
('92', 62, 4, 18, 105917) The answer is straight and simple.
('92', 62, 4, 19, 105952) If plain life is worth living, then the attempt is worth making even though only an individual or a group makes the effort.
('92', 62, 4, 20, 106076) At the same time I believe that some key industries are necessary.
('92', 62, 4, 21, 106143) I do not believe in armchair or armed socialism.
('92', 62, 4, 22, 106192) I believe in action according to my belief, without waiting for wholesale conversion.
('92', 62, 4, 23, 106278) Hence, without having to enumerate key industries, I would have State ownership where a large number of people have to work together.
('92', 62, 4, 24, 106412) The ownership of the products of their labour,
('92', 63, 0, 1, 106459) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 63, 1, 2, 106500) whether skilled or unskilled, will vest in them through the State.
('92', 63, 1, 3, 106567) But as I can conceive such a State only based on non violence, I would not dispossess monied men by force but would invite their co operation in the process of conversion to State ownership.
('92', 63, 1, 4, 106758) There are no pariahs of society, whether they are millionaires or paupers.
('92', 63, 1, 5, 106833) The two are sores of the same disease.
('92', 63, 1, 6, 106872) And all are men “for a’ that”.
('92', 63, 1, 7, 106903) And I avow this belief in the face of the inhumanities we have witnessed and may still have to witness in India as elsewhere.
('92', 63, 1, 8, 107029) Let us live in the face of danger.
('92', 63, 1, 9, 107064) ON THE TRAIN TO DELHI, August 25, 1946 Harijan, 1 9 1946

('92', 66, 2, 6, 111177) 101. IF I WERE THE MINISTER
('92', 66, 3, 7, 111205) The talks with the Ministers concerned at Poona on 29th to 31st July on village crafts and basic education have given rise to a lot of correspondence and private discussion.
('92', 66, 3, 8, 111379) For the guidance of the Provincial Governments and others interested in the question of khadi which has naturally occasioned the bulk of the correspondence and discussion, I set forth below my thoughts on the subject.
('92', 66, 3, 9, 111597) I refer the reader to my note in the Harijan of 28th April last.
('92', 66, 3, 10, 111662) My views, then expressed, remain unaltered.
('92', 66, 3, 11, 111706) One thing has created a misunderstanding.
('92', 66, 3, 12, 111748) Some friends have read compulsion in that note.
('92', 66, 3, 13, 111796) I am sorry for the obscurity.
('92', 66, 3, 14, 111826) In it I had answered the question as to what representative governments could do if they wished.
('92', 66, 3, 15, 111923) I had, I hope pardonably, assumed that such governments’ notices too could not be interpreted as compulsion.
('92', 66, 3, 16, 112032) For every act of a bona fide representative government would assume consent of the voters represented.
('92', 66, 3, 17, 112135) The voters would mean the whole populace, whether registered as voters or not.
('92', 66, 3, 18, 112214) With that background, I wrote that the Government should notify to the villagers that mill cloth would not be supplied to the villagers after a certain fixed date, so as to enable them to wear khadi prepared by themselves.
('92', 66, 3, 19, 112437) Whatever the meaning of my article of 28th April last, I want to state that any scheme adopted about khadi without the willing co operation of those concerned must mean death to khadi as a means for attaining swaraj.
('92', 66, 3, 20, 112654) Then the taunt that khadi was a return to the darkness and slavery of the Middle Ages would be true.
('92', 66, 3, 21, 112755) But I have held the contrary view.
('92', 66, 3, 22, 112790) Whilst khadi under compulsion was a badge of slavery, khadi intelligently and voluntarily prepared, primarily for one’s own use, was easily the badge of our freedom.
('92', 66, 3, 23, 112956) Freedom is nothing if it is not all round self help.
('92', 66, 3, 24, 113009) I for one would have nothing
('92', 67, 0, 1, 113038) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 67, 1, 2, 113079) to do with khadi, if it were not a free man’s privilege as well as duty.
('92', 67, 1, 3, 113152) A friendly critic asks whether khadi thus prepared couldalso and at the same time be for sale.
('92', 67, 1, 4, 113247) Yes, if sale is its secondary use; not, if manufacture for sale is its only or even primary use.
('92', 67, 1, 5, 113344) That we began with sale of khadi shows temporary necessity as well as our limited vision.
('92', 67, 1, 6, 113434) Experience is a great teacher.
('92', 67, 1, 7, 113465) It has taught us many things.
('92', 67, 1, 8, 113495) Not the least is its primary use.
('92', 67, 1, 9, 113529) But it is by no means the last.
('92', 67, 1, 10, 113561) But I must leave this fascinating field of speculation and proceed definitely to answer the question put in the heading.
('92', 67, 1, 11, 113682) My first business, as the minister in charge of revival of the villages as the centre of all governmental activity, would be to find out from among the Permanent Service honest and incorruptible men capable for the work.
('92', 67, 1, 12, 113903) I would put the best among them in touch with the A. I. S. A. and the A. I. V. I. A., creations of the Congress, and bring in a scheme for giving the village crafts the greatest encouragement.
('92', 67, 1, 13, 114096) I would stipulate there should be no compulsion on the villagers, that they must not slave for others and that they should be taught to help themselves and rely upon their own labour and skill for the production of articles of food, cloth and other necessaries.
('92', 67, 1, 14, 114358) The scheme would thus have to be comprehensive.
('92', 67, 1, 15, 114406) I would instruct my first man, therefore, to see the Hindustani Talimi Sangh and see what it has to say.
('92', 67, 1, 16, 114511) Let us assume that the scheme, thus produced, contains a clause saying that the villagers themselves declare that they would not want mill cloth, say, after one year from a fixed date, that they require cotton, wool and necessary implements and instruction, not as a gift but to be paid for on the easiest terms.
('92', 67, 1, 17, 114824) The scheme provides too that it will not apply at once to the whole of any province but only to a part to begin with.
('92', 67, 1, 18, 114942) The scheme further tells one that the A. I. S. A. will guide and assist the working of the scheme.
('92', 67, 1, 19, 115041) Being convinced of its soundness, I would give it legal form in consultation with the law department and issue a notification, fully describing the genesis of the scheme.
('92', 67, 1, 20, 115212) The villagers as well as the mill owners and others would have been party to it.
('92', 67, 1, 21, 115293) The notification will show clearly that it is the people’s measure, though bearing the Government stamp.
('92', 67, 1, 22, 115398) The Government money will be used for the benefit of the poorest villagers, making the largest return possible to
('92', 68, 0, 1, 115512) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 69
('92', 68, 1, 2, 115556) the people concerned.
('92', 68, 1, 3, 115578) It will, therefore, be probably the most profitable investment in which expert assistance will be voluntary and overhead charges the least item.
('92', 68, 1, 4, 115723) The notification will give in detail the whole cost to the country and the return to the people.
('92', 68, 1, 5, 115820) The only question for me as minister is whether the A. I. S. A. has the conviction and capacity to shoulder the burden of creating and guiding a khadi scheme to success.
('92', 68, 1, 6, 115990) If it has, I would put my little barque to sea with all confidence.
('92', 68, 1, 7, 116058) ON THE TRAIN TO DELHI, August 26, 1946 Harijan, 1 9 1946
('92', 68, 2, 8, 116115) 102. THE PLACE OF MEDICINE IN NAYEE TALIM 1
('92', 68, 3, 9, 116159) Shrimati Asha Devi does her own work and is considerate of my time.
('92', 68, 3, 10, 116227) However, one day she asked me to give her five minutes.
('92', 68, 3, 11, 116283) Her contention was that Nayee Talim should provide for some elementary instruction in medicine and she wondered whether, to make this possible, she herself should undergo training in medicine for four or five years.
('92', 68, 3, 12, 116499) I realized at once that with the best efforts on her part she had not been able to free herself wholly from the hold of the old system of education.
('92', 68, 3, 13, 116648) Asha Devi, after all, has taken an M.A. degree from a University which was created by the British.
('92', 68, 3, 14, 116747) I myself possess no degree, and I ceased long ago to attach any value to the little knowledge I acquired at High School.
('92', 68, 3, 15, 116868) I have besides taken in deeply the system of nature cure.
('92', 68, 3, 16, 116926) So I said to her: “You say the first lesson our children have to learn is how to keep fit and how to keep themselves and their surroundings clean.
('92', 68, 3, 17, 117073) I say this covers all the medical knowledge we need.
('92', 68, 3, 18, 117126) Nayee Talim is intended for the millions in villages.
('92', 68, 3, 19, 117180) It is for their good.
('92', 68, 3, 20, 117202) They live close to nature and yet do not know the laws of natural living.
('92', 68, 3, 21, 117276) Those who know those laws do not follow them.
('92', 68, 3, 22, 117322) It is from observing their way of living that we conceived the need for Nayee Talim.
('92', 68, 3, 23, 117407) The knowledge that Nayee Talim imparts is scarcely to be had from books.
('92', 68, 3, 24, 117480) It is from the book of nature that this knowledge is to be had.
('92', 68, 3, 25, 117544) We must similarly seek what medical knowledge we need from the same book of nature.
('92', 68, 3, 26, 117628) This means that if we know the laws of hygiene and follow them and take
('92', 68, 4, 27, 117700) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 1 9 1946.
('92', 69, 0, 1, 117765) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 69, 1, 2, 117806) the right nutrition we can become our own doctors.
('92', 69, 1, 3, 117857) The man who eats in order to live, who lives in friendship with the five basic substances, namely, earth, water, ether, sun and air, who is a servant of God who has created these, can never fall ill.
('92', 69, 1, 4, 118057) And if he does, he will surrender himself to God’s care and calmly meet his end.
('92', 69, 1, 5, 118138) He will be content to use such medicinal herbs and remedies as the grounds and fields of his village yield.
('92', 69, 1, 6, 118246) Tens of millions of people live and die thus.
('92', 69, 1, 7, 118292) They have not so much as heard of a doctor, let alone seeing one.
('92', 69, 1, 8, 118358) We must make ourselves just like these villagers and teach village boys and adults who come to us also to live in that way.
('92', 69, 1, 9, 118482) Doctors say that 99 per cent of all diseases are caused by insanitation, by eating things not fit to eat and by lack of proper nutrition.
('92', 69, 1, 10, 118620) If we can teach 99 per cent of the people the art of living, we can forget the remaining one per cent.
('92', 69, 1, 11, 118723) They will find some doctors like Sushila Nayar.
('92', 69, 1, 12, 118771) We need not bother too much about them.
('92', 69, 1, 13, 118811) Today pure water, pure earth and pure air are not available.
('92', 69, 1, 14, 118872) We live sheltered from the sun.
('92', 69, 1, 15, 118904) If we pay attention to these and take proper nourishment we shall have done the work of ages.
('92', 69, 1, 16, 118998) Acquiring knowledge of this requires neither degrees nor money in crores of rupees.
('92', 69, 1, 17, 119082) All that is needed is faith in God, the spirit of service, an acquaintance with the five basic substances and knowledge of proper diet.
('92', 69, 1, 18, 119218) We can acquire all this with our own effort and in very little time without going to schools and colleges.
('92', 69, 1, 19, 119325) ON THE TRAIN TO DELHI, August 26, 1946 [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 1 9 1946

('92', 72, 1, 2, 121302) 107. LETTER TO LORD WAVELL
('92', 72, 2, 3, 121329) VALMIKI MANDIR, READING ROAD, NEW DELHI, August 28, 1946
('92', 72, 3, 4, 121386) DEAR FRIEND,
('92', 72, 4, 5, 121399) I write this as a friend and after deep thought.
('92', 72, 5, 6, 121448) Several times last evening you repeated that you were a “plain man and a soldier” and that you did not know the law.

('92', 72, 6, 12, 122010) You should be assisted, if necessary, by a legal mind enjoying your full confidence.

('92', 72, 6, 14, 122239) 3 If such be really the case then you should not have made the announcement 4 you did on 12th August.

('92', 72, 6, 16, 122446) If British arms are kept here for internal peace and order, your Interim Government would be reduced to a farce.
('92', 72, 6, 17, 122559) The Congress cannot afford to impose its will on warring elements in

('92', 73, 1, 2, 123573) India through the use of British arms.
('92', 73, 1, 3, 123612) Nor can the Congress be expected to bend itself and adopt what it considers a wrong course because of the brutal exhibition recently witnessed in Bengal.
('92', 73, 1, 4, 123766) Such submission would itself lead to an encouragement and repetition of such tragedies.

('92', 73, 1, 6, 124011) And all this will be chiefly due to the continued presence in India of a foreign power strong in and proud of its arms.
('92', 73, 1, 7, 124131) I say this neither as a Hindu nor as a Muslim.
('92', 73, 1, 8, 124178) I write only as an Indian.
('92', 73, 1, 9, 124205) In so far as I am aware, the Congress claims to know both the Hindu and Muslim mind more than you or any Britisher can do.
('92', 73, 1, 10, 124328) Unless, therefore, you can wholly trust the Congress Government which you have announced, you should reconsider your decision, as I have already suggested.
('92', 73, 1, 11, 124484) You will please convey the whole of this letter to the British Cabinet.

('92', 78, 2, 5, 130400) 117. SALES TAX 1
('92', 78, 3, 6, 130417) I have received many letters in regard to the Sales Tax Act of the Bombay Presidency.
('92', 78, 3, 7, 130503) Many arguments advanced against it are, in my opinion, thoughtless.
('92', 78, 3, 8, 130571) Nevertheless, I placed some of the complaints before the Finance Minister.
('92', 78, 3, 9, 130646) Shri Vaikunthbhai Mehta is a cautious and conscientious Minister.
('92', 78, 3, 10, 130712) He has sent me a full reply.
('92', 78, 3, 11, 130741) It appears that this Act was framed before the popular Government came in.
('92', 78, 3, 12, 130816) The present Ministry have made some essential changes in it.
('92', 78, 3, 13, 130877) The letters received by me were full of criticism giving the impression that the present Government was wilful, indifferent to public opinion and the tax was already in vogue.
('92', 78, 3, 14, 131053) As a matter of fact, not only has the collection of the Sales Tax not begun, but it has been postponed till October 1st and may be delayed still further if need be.
('92', 78, 3, 15, 131218) Moreover, many articles of necessary use have been exempted, thereby showing that the Government has paid due attention to public objections and inconvenience.
('92', 78, 3, 16, 131378) I am aware that there are people who hold that there should be no Sales Tax at all.
('92', 78, 3, 17, 131462) A great deal has been said in favour of this view.
('92', 78, 3, 18, 131513) But no government could exist if it were to listen to abstract objections.
('92', 78, 3, 19, 131588) In other words, it is wisdom, in such cases, not to raise basic issues.
('92', 78, 3, 20, 131660) The Sales Tax is in vogue in many provinces.
('92', 78, 3, 21, 131705) The main criterion in judging any tax should be that it does not hit the poor.
('92', 78, 3, 22, 131784) It should also be seen that the money raised thereby is used for the public good.
('92', 78, 3, 23, 131866) A popular ministry is responsible to the legislature, and cannot do anything without their consent.
('92', 78, 3, 24, 131966) Every elected member in a popular legislature is responsible to his voters.
('92', 78, 3, 25, 132042) Therefore the voter who represents the public should ponder well before embarking on any criticism of the government of his creation.
('92', 78, 3, 26, 132176) Moreover, one bad habit of the people should be borne in mind.
('92', 78, 3, 27, 132239) They do not like
('92', 78, 4, 28, 132256) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 8 9 1946.
('92', 79, 0, 1, 132325) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 79, 1, 2, 132366) any tax whatsoever.
('92', 79, 1, 3, 132386) Where there is good government, the tax payer gets full return for his money as, for example, the water tax in cities.
('92', 79, 1, 4, 132505) No tax payer could get water on his own for the same payment.
('92', 79, 1, 5, 132567) But even so, and in spite of the fact that the tax is levied by the popular will, tax payers always resent even paying such taxes.
('92', 79, 1, 6, 132698) It is, of course, true that one cannot prove the benefit of all taxes as easily as the one I have cited as an example.
('92', 79, 1, 7, 132817) But as society grows in size and complexity and the field of service also grows, it is difficult to explain to the individual tax payer how he gets his return for any particular tax.
('92', 79, 1, 8, 133000) This much, however, is clear that taxes as a whole should stand for the general benefit of society.
('92', 79, 1, 9, 133100) If this were not so, the argument that taxes were levied by popular will would not hold.
('92', 79, 1, 10, 133189) To the extent that we are still under foreign rule, the Government is not wholly responsible to the people.
('92', 79, 1, 11, 133297) But in the Provinces today the Government are popular to a large extent and we must judge the Sales Tax accordingly.
