('92', 79, 2, 13, 133459) 118. GOA
('92', 79, 3, 14, 133468) With reference to Mr. Gandhi’s short commentary on Goa in the Harijan of the 18th instant, 1 where he gives the so called “contrast” between French and Portuguese authorities, we have to state the following for your knowledge and publicity purposes :
('92', 79, 4, 15, 133719) There is nothing more out of place as a comparison between French India and Portuguese India.
('92', 79, 4, 16, 133813) The objects, administrative methods and the goal are absolutely dissimilar in their essence.
('92', 79, 4, 17, 133906) The recent integration (1816) of the French possessions in India in the French Colonial Empire and its setbacks, have nothing in common with Portuguese India which for more than 400 years, has been benefited by the Portuguese administration, completely identifying its destinies with the Motherland.
('92', 79, 5, 18, 134206) If the inhabitants of French India wish to identify their destinies with Free India (what has yet to be ascertained), the same does not happen in Portuguese India where the totality of the inhabitants wish to continue under the beneficial action of Portuguese administration which has been the cause of its material and moral progress to the point of Goa being the pride of the Portuguese colonizing effort and part and parcel of the
('92', 79, 6, 19, 134640) 1Vide “Goa”, 18 8 1946.
('92', 80, 0, 1, 134664) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 81
('92', 80, 1, 2, 134708) Motherland.
('92', 80, 2, 3, 134720) These being the facts based on historical data, we trust you will publish the relevant corrections in your paper : This letter to the Editor of the Harijan from the Head of the Government Information Bureau, Nova Goa, makes sorry reading.
('92', 80, 2, 4, 134959) It is an example of the truth of the proverb, “Comparisons are odious.” Surely there is not much to choose between French and Portuguese imperialism.
('92', 80, 2, 5, 135109) The hands of imperialism are always dyed red.
('92', 80, 2, 6, 135155) The sooner imperialistic powers shed their imperialism like Ashoka the Good, the better it will be for the groaning world.
('92', 80, 2, 7, 135278) One may be pardoned for giving credit to France where credit is deserved, as it is in the case of French India, assuming, of course, the truth of the newspaper version of the statement of the Governor of French India.
('92', 80, 2, 8, 135496) Moreover, it is ridiculous for the Head of the Government Information Bureau to write of Portugal as the motherland of the Indians of Goa.
('92', 80, 2, 9, 135635) Their mother country is as much India as mine.
('92', 80, 2, 10, 135682) Goa is outside British India but it is within geographical India as a whole.
('92', 80, 2, 11, 135759) And there is very little, if anything, in common between the Portuguese and the Indians of Goa.
('92', 80, 2, 12, 135855) I have read also the contradiction of my statement about Shri Purushottam Kakodkar.
('92', 80, 2, 13, 135939) I must adhere to it in spite of the contradiction of the Portuguese authorities in Goa.
('92', 80, 2, 14, 136027) Here is what his wife says in her letter dated 24 8 1946 :
('92', 80, 3, 15, 136086) Shri Purushottam Kakodkar, Secretary of the Goa National Congress, was arrested while talking to a friend on 9 8 1946 by the Portuguese authorities.
('92', 80, 3, 16, 136235) On the 10th he was removed to Panjim (Nova Goa).
('92', 80, 3, 17, 136284) On the 11th and 12th, he was kept on half rations.
('92', 80, 3, 18, 136335) When he learnt that the authorities were deliberately underfeeding him, he went on hunger strike on the 13th and was still fasting on 20th.
('92', 80, 4, 19, 136475) The Portuguese Government is undeterred in its policy and up till now (24 8 1946) no attention has been paid to the written request sent in by Shri Kakodkar for adequate food supply to himself and other prisoners.
('92', 80, 4, 20, 136689) I ask the Portuguese authorities whether they would allow a representative from the Harijan to meet Prisoner Kakodkar and ascertain facts for himself?
('92', 80, 4, 21, 136840) NEW DELHI, August 29, 1946 Harijan, 8 9 1946

('92', 87, 2, 3, 144119) August 30, 1946
('92', 87, 3, 4, 144135) BHAI VICHITRA, Thinking over the talks I had with Dada 1 and with you and the letter that is in front of me, I have come to the conclusion that your work in the U. P. should be wholly independent of the Charkha Sangh work and should be complementary to it.
('92', 87, 3, 5, 144392) You have many workers.
('92', 87, 3, 6, 144415) They are capable.
('92', 87, 3, 7, 144433) Though we all work for the same cause, there still remains a difference of outlook between the Charkha Sangh and the Gandhi Ashram.
('92', 87, 3, 8, 144565) I feel that if Gandhi Ashram grows independently, the khadi activity will probably develop faster.
('92', 87, 3, 9, 144664) I am taking the step in this hope.
('92', 87, 3, 10, 144699) You would still be under the debt of the Charkha Sangh.
('92', 87, 3, 11, 144755) I think it is indeed difficult, if not impossible, for you to pay off the whole sum right now.
('92', 87, 3, 12, 144850) Therefore, I would advise you to return the sum in ten annual instalments.
('92', 87, 3, 13, 144925) In case of failure to send the yarn or the instalment as promised or in case of khadi work being given up, the whole amount must be returned forthwith.
('92', 87, 3, 14, 145077) The first instalment—cash as well as yarn—will be payable one year after the date of this letter.
('92', 87, 3, 15, 145175) If your work does not succeed in any part of U. P., the Charkha Sangh will have the right to work there independently.
('92', 87, 3, 16, 145294) The step is being taken in the hope that it will promote decentralization and help the Gandhi Ashram to develop independently.
('92', 87, 3, 17, 145421) If you want any modification, please let me know.

('92', 90, 1, 2, 148051) 135. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 90, 2, 3, 148081) NEW DELHI, August 31, 1946
('92', 90, 3, 4, 148108) Congress leaders were going into the Interim Government to make the path of freedom somewhat easy for the people, declared Mahatma Gandhi, addressing the prayer meeting on Saturday evening.
('92', 90, 4, 5, 148298) On September 2, Mahatma Gandhi said, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Sardar Patel, Babu Rajendra Prasad and others were going to wear crowns.
('92', 90, 4, 6, 148433) But they were not going to be crowns of gold.
('92', 90, 4, 7, 148479) They were to be crowns made of thorns which would try them sorely.
('92', 90, 4, 8, 148546) They were going there—they whose whole life had been one of sacrifice—not to enjoy themselves or lead lives of ease but to serve the masses the more.
('92', 90, 5, 9, 148696) Gandhiji said he did not want the people to imagine that India was going to be free on September 2. Freedom he said, was not bought easily, nor was it a cheap commodity.
('92', 90, 5, 10, 148866) It demanded its full price always.
('92', 90, 5, 11, 148901) The leaders were going there to make the path of freedom somewhat easy for them.
('92', 90, 5, 12, 148982) It was up to the people to help the leaders by being ready for sacrifices and willing to wear a crown of thorns themselves.
('92', 90, 6, 13, 149106) The A. I. C. C., Mahatma Gandhi said, was going to be held shortly in Delhi.
('92', 90, 6, 14, 149183) Residents of Delhi would then be on trial.
('92', 90, 6, 15, 149226) He hoped they would be sober, disciplined and peaceful and make such arrangements as to ensure the safety of the smallest child.
('92', 90, 6, 16, 149355) They could only maintain their honour, as did Draupadi of old, by relying on God who alone could sustain them.
('92', 90, 6, 17, 149466) He would not speak to them on the recent holocaust in Calcutta.
('92', 90, 6, 18, 149530) Silence, he said, was his best friend.
('92', 90, 7, 19, 149569) He drew the attention of the congregation to a ‘bhajan’ sung during the prayer and said that it was a hymn which had been sung in his ears even before he went to jail in India for the first time in 1922. At that time he was sentenced to six years and for the first part of his prison life was kept by himself with two prisoner wardens to look after him.
('92', 90, 7, 20, 149923) Since prayer had become part of his very being even while he was in South Africa, he used to sing the daily ‘bhajan’ however indifferently himself.
('92', 90, 8, 21, 150071) Out of the many who went to prison, Mahatma Gandhi said, there were those who looked out for every opportunity to escape, every opportunity to deceive and cheat.
('92', 90, 8, 22, 150233) But he had long since decided that the ideal of a true satyagrahi was to make the prison a palace, and this could only be done by faith and prayer.
('92', 90, 8, 23, 150381) The ‘bhajan’ (sung at the prayer meeting on Saturday) used to sustain him.
('92', 90, 8, 24, 150456) It taught them that they could only be true to their resolution if they relied on God.
('92', 90, 8, 25, 150543) He alone could keep them on the straight path.
('92', 90, 8, 26, 150590) What could be the ideal of each one of those present except to make India free and keep themselves pure?
('92', 90, 8, 27, 150695) The Hindustan Times, 1 9 1946

('92', 92, 6, 15, 152336) 139. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('92', 92, 7, 16, 152366) NEW DELHI, September 1, 1946
('92', 92, 8, 17, 152395) MANILAL, A cutting from the Indian Opinion sent by Sushila has reached me here in Delhi.
('92', 92, 8, 18, 152484) If what it says is true it is a very serious matter.
('92', 92, 8, 19, 152537) If the whole of the Negro population enters into a bloody conflict with the whole of the Indian population, there is not the least doubt that both will perish.
('92', 92, 8, 20, 152697) One must have the capacity to fight to win in a bloody conflict.
('92', 92, 8, 21, 152762) Neither party has this.
('92', 92, 8, 22, 152786) Any help from the whites will be quite out of the question.
('92', 92, 8, 23, 152846) You will lose even such help as you are now getting.
('92', 92, 8, 24, 152899) I cannot therefore believe that except for a few crazy individuals there are any Indian groups who would wish to oppose the ghettoes through violence.
('92', 92, 8, 25, 153050) There is only one sure way and everyone knows it.
('92', 92, 8, 26, 153100) Your path, therefore, is clear.
('92', 92, 8, 27, 153132) Even if you are alone you must clearly and courteously state your views and if they put you in prison you must go to prison.
('92', 93, 0, 1, 153257) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 93, 1, 2, 153298) becoming more and more convinced each day that Sushila should not go there for the present.
('92', 93, 1, 3, 153390) If she takes care of the children as a good mother should, she will be doing her duty.
('92', 93, 2, 4, 153477) Blessings from BAPU
('92', 93, 3, 5, 153497) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G. N. 4990
('92', 93, 4, 6, 153542) 140. ANTIDOTE
('92', 93, 5, 7, 153556) After giving a graphic description of the recent unfortunate and disgraceful happenings in Calcutta, a writer asks :
('92', 93, 6, 8, 153673) What is our duty in such circumstances?
('92', 93, 6, 9, 153713) The Congress gives no clear instructions to the rank and file in such crises.
('92', 93, 6, 10, 153791) Sermons on non violence from afar are of little use.
('92', 93, 6, 11, 153844) To have offered non violent resistance would have meant allowing all property to be destroyed and every Hindu to be killed.
('92', 93, 6, 12, 153968) The Congress Working Committee has given the clearest possible lead in the last sentence of its resolution published in the newspapers.
('92', 93, 6, 13, 154104) 1 Fratricide will not abate by “intimidation and violence but by mutual understanding, friendly discussion and, if necessary, by agreed arbitration.” One does not need to believe in non violence as a creed to perceive the truth of this practical proposition.
('92', 93, 6, 14, 154363) If through deliberate courage the Hindus had died to a man, that would have been deliverance of Hinduism and India and purification of Islam in this land.
('92', 93, 6, 15, 154518) As it was, a third party had to intervene in order to still mutual savagery.
('92', 93, 6, 16, 154595) Neither the Muslims nor the Hindus concerned have gained by the intervention.
('92', 93, 6, 17, 154673) Supposing that the Calcutta virus extends to the whole of India and British gunpowder keeps the two from stabbing one another, the British power or its substitute will be in possession of India for a long time to come.
('92', 93, 6, 18, 154892) The length will be measured by the period required by the parties coming to sanity.
('92', 93, 6, 19, 154976) It will come either by an exhausting mutual fight, independent of the foreign element or by one party eschewing violence in spite of the heaviest odds.
('92', 93, 6, 20, 155128) Successful mutual strife is obviously impossible in the present state of general igno rance of the use of modern weapons and their inaccessibility.
('92', 93, 6, 21, 155276) Non violence does not require any outside or outward training.
('92', 93, 7, 22, 155339) 1 The Working Committee met in Delhi from August 27 to August 30.
('92', 94, 0, 1, 155405) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 95
('92', 94, 1, 2, 155449) simply requires the will not to kill even in retaliation and the courage to face death without revenge.
('92', 94, 1, 3, 155553) This is no sermon on ahimsa but cold reason and the statement of a universal law.
('92', 94, 1, 4, 155635) Given the unquenchable faith in the law, no provocation should prove too great for the exercise of forbearance.
('92', 94, 1, 5, 155747) This I have described as non violence of the brave.
('92', 94, 1, 6, 155799) Unfortunately for us, we are strangers to the non violence of the brave on a mass scale.
('92', 94, 1, 7, 155888) Some even doubt the possibility of the exercise of non violence by groups, much less by masses of people.
('92', 94, 1, 8, 155994) They restrict its exercise to exceptional individuals.
('92', 94, 1, 9, 156049) Only, mankind can have no use for it if it is always reserved only for individuals.
('92', 94, 1, 10, 156133) Be that as it may, this much is clear that if the people are probably not ready for the exercise of non violence of the brave, they must be ready for the use of force in self defence.
('92', 94, 1, 11, 156317) There should be no camouflage.
('92', 94, 1, 12, 156348) Self defence must be pure and simple.
('92', 94, 1, 13, 156386) Then too it must never be cowardly or crude.
('92', 94, 1, 14, 156431) It must, therefore, never be secret.
('92', 94, 1, 15, 156468) Such is stabbing in the back and evading detection.
('92', 94, 1, 16, 156520) I am conscious of the fact that we are a people unarmed and untrained in the use of arms.
('92', 94, 1, 17, 156610) Opinions will differ as to whether it is good that we are in that position.
('92', 94, 1, 18, 156686) There can be no denying the fact that no one needs training in the use of arms in self defence.
('92', 94, 1, 19, 156782) What is wanted for the purpose is strong arms and stronger will.
('92', 94, 1, 20, 156847) Doing injury to another is obviously violence but harbouring injury to another and yet unwillingness from cowardice to defend oneself or one’s neighbour is also violence and probably worse than the first.
('92', 94, 1, 21, 157052) What then are the leaders to do?

('92', 95, 4, 24, 159346) 142. VILLAGE INDUSTRIES EXHIBITION:
('92', 95, 5, 25, 159382) WHAT IT SHOULD BE LIKE 1
('92', 95, 6, 26, 159407) The Congress session is in the offing.
('92', 95, 6, 27, 159446) The question arises what it should be like, considered from the villagers’ point of view, for only the villagers’ point of view can be relevant in India.
('92', 95, 6, 28, 159600) If we want the villages to survive and become strong and prosperous the exhibition should be free from all pomp and ostentation characteristic of the cities.
('92', 95, 6, 29, 159758) There should be no place for city games and entertain ments.
('92', 95, 6, 30, 159819) The exhibition should not under any circumstances be reduced
('92', 95, 7, 31, 159880) 1 The Hindi original of this was published in Gramodyog Patrika.
('92', 96, 0, 1, 159945) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 97
('92', 96, 1, 2, 159989) to a show or a source of revenue.
('92', 96, 1, 3, 160023) It should not become an attraction for traders.
('92', 96, 1, 4, 160071) No goods should be sold, not even khadi or other products of village industry.
('92', 96, 1, 5, 160150) The exhibition should become a place of education.
('92', 96, 1, 6, 160201) It should be interesting and should be such that, having seen it, a villager should be inspired to learn some craft or other.
('92', 96, 1, 7, 160327) There should be people to explain to the visitors the shortcomings of the villages in general and how to remove them.
('92', 96, 1, 8, 160445) They should be shown what progress has been made since the work for the uplift of villages was first taken up.
('92', 96, 1, 9, 160556) There should also be someone to instruct the villagers in the ways in which village life can be made artistic.
('92', 96, 1, 10, 160667) Let us now see how the exhibition can be made to conform to these requirements.
('92', 96, 1, 11, 160747) (1) There should be two models of villages: one showing an average village as it is today and the other showing the village as it will look after the reform.
('92', 96, 1, 12, 160905) The reformed village will be clean, with dwellings, village paths, general surroundings, fields and the condition of the livestock greatly improved.
('92', 96, 1, 13, 161054) There should be maps and charts and books to show how different industries are carried on and developed.
('92', 96, 1, 14, 161159) (2) Guidance should be provided on how the various village indus tries are run and where the necessary tools for them are to be had or man ufactured.
('92', 96, 1, 15, 161309) There should also be demonstrations of the working of the va rious industries.
('92', 96, 1, 16, 161388) Along with this we should show the following things : (a) Ideal village diet (b) The difference between cottage industry and machine industry (c) An object lesson in animal husbandry (d) A model latrine (e) An art section (f) Organic manure v.
('92', 96, 1, 17, 161632) chemical fertilizers (g) The utilization of hides and bones of dead cattle (h) Folk music and folk dances (i) Village sports, gymnastics and wrestling (j) Nayee Talim (k) Village herbs (l) Village maternity home If further things can be added keeping in view the guide 
('92', 97, 0, 1, 161902) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('92', 97, 1, 5, 162141) Without them the exhibition should be considered as of no value.

('92', 97, 2, 7, 162239) 143. WHY GO ABROAD?
('92', 97, 3, 8, 162259) An Indian doctor went to America in order to learn neurosurgery, so that he might return and serve his people here.
('92', 97, 3, 9, 162375) He has with difficulty secured a seat in the Columbia University and is working as a house surgeon.
('92', 97, 3, 10, 162475) He writes to ask me to influence students not to go abroad for the following reasons :
('92', 97, 4, 11, 162562) (a) The amount our poor country spends on sending and training ten students abroad could be better utilized by securing the services of a first rate professor who could train 40 students as well as equip a laboratory.
('92', 97, 5, 12, 162780) (b) Students who come here acquire basic knowledge in research but do not know how to equip a laboratory on their return home.
('92', 97, 6, 13, 162907) (c) They have no chance of continued work.
('92', 97, 7, 14, 162950) (d) If we have experts brought out, our laboratories will also get perfected.
('92', 97, 7, 15, 163028) I have never been an advocate of our students going abroad.
('92', 97, 7, 16, 163088) My experience tells me that such, on return, find themselves to be square pegs in round holes.
('92', 97, 7, 17, 163183) That experience is the richest and contributes most to growth which springs from the soil.
('92', 97, 7, 18, 163274) But today the craze for going abroad has gripped students.
('92', 97, 7, 19, 163333) May the extract quoted serve as a warning!
('92', 97, 7, 20, 163376) NEW DELHI, September 2, 1946 Harijan, 8 9 1946

('92', 98, 1, 2, 163467) 144. NOTES
('92', 98, 2, 3, 163478) THE DEVADASI SYSTEM
('92', 98, 3, 4, 163498) A correspondent writes :
('92', 98, 4, 5, 163523) It is a well known fact that you are trying your best to uplift the Harijan community and even spending your most precious time in the Harijan Colony.
('92', 98, 4, 6, 163674) But may I assure you that there are thousands of Devadasi girls of the Harijan community residing in Poona and Bombay and are leading a life of public prostitution.
('92', 98, 4, 7, 163839) Why should this be so?
('92', 98, 4, 8, 163862) Is it because these girls belong to low caste community and are induced to lose their moral character that they are neglected by the public and put to the shameful life of prostitution?
('92', 98, 5, 9, 164048) May I be justified in stating that this is a most important and urgent problem.
('92', 98, 5, 10, 164128) Is it not possible to stop this illegal practice in the Bombay province as in Madura and Madras by the Madras Government under the ruling of Section 366A, 366B, 372 and 373 of the Indian Penal Code, page No.
('92', 98, 5, 11, 164336) I have, on more than one occasion, written about the shame attached to the Devadasi system, whether in temples or in other places.
('92', 98, 5, 12, 164467) “Prostitutes” is commonly supposed to apply to women of lewd character.
('92', 98, 5, 13, 164539) But the men who indulge in vice are just as much, if not more, prostitutes as the women who, in many instances, have to sell their bodies for the sake of earning a livelihood.
('92', 98, 5, 14, 164715) The evil practice should be declared illegal.
('92', 98, 5, 15, 164761) But the law can only help up to a point.
('92', 98, 5, 16, 164802) The evil exists clandestinely in every country in spite of the law.
('92', 98, 5, 17, 164870) Vigorous public opinion can help the law as it also hinders.
('92', 98, 6, 18, 164931) UNTOUCHABILITY AND THE FLUSH SYSTEM
('92', 98, 7, 19, 164967) Q. Do you consider that the adoption of the flush system is one way of eradicating untouchability?
('92', 98, 7, 20, 165066) If so, you would not presumably oppose its introduction on the basis of your dislike of machinery.
('92', 98, 8, 21, 165165) A. Where there is ample supply of water and modern sanita tion can be introduced without any hardship on the poor, I have no objection to it.
('92', 98, 8, 22, 165307) In fact, it should be welcomed as a means of improving the health of the city concerned.
('92', 98, 8, 23, 165396) At the moment, it can only be introduced in towns.
('92', 98, 8, 24, 165447) My opposition to machinery is much misunderstood.
('92', 98, 8, 25, 165497) I am not opposed to machinery as such.
('92', 98, 8, 26, 165536) I am opposed to machinery which displaces labour and leaves it idle.
('92', 98, 8, 27, 165605) Whether the
('92', 99, 0, 1, 165617) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 99, 1, 2, 165659) flush system will remove the curse of untouchability is open to grave doubt.
('92', 99, 1, 3, 165736) This latter has to go from our hearts.
('92', 99, 1, 4, 165775) It will not disappear through such means as has been suggested.
('92', 99, 1, 5, 165839) Not until we all become bhangis and realize the dignity of the labour of scavenging and latrine cleaning, will untouchability really be exorcized.
('92', 99, 1, 6, 165986) NEW DELHI, September 2, 1946 Harijan, 15 9 1946
('92', 99, 2, 7, 166034) 145. ADVICE TO THE MADRAS GOVERNMENT
('92', 99, 3, 8, 166071) NEW DELHI, September 2, 1946 All credit to the Madras Government for being the first in the field, among the Provincial Ministries, to put forward a definite Scheme 1 for the reconstruction of our sadly neglected villages including, as the most vital and fundamental part of it, a large scale scheme for the development of khadi.
('92', 99, 3, 9, 166401) I appreciate the completely sincere faith in khadi which has prompted the Madras Government to offer their resources, on a scale without precedent, for the rapid development of khadi, but I am afraid they have not realized that the conditions necessary for securing the success of such a large scale venture probably do not exist now, and that they have yet to be created by extensive propaganda by all genuine lovers of khadi, including the Provincial Ministers and members of the Provincial Legislatures.
('92', 99, 3, 10, 166908) I am quite clear in my own mind that it would be extremely unwise to force the pace in regard to a matter like khadi, until the proper atmosphere has been created and has borne fruit in the form of a strong public demand from the villagers themselves, thus guaranteeing immediate success and giving lasting benefit from large scale expenditure of the money and energy such as is involved in the Madras Government’s scheme.
('92', 99, 3, 11, 167331) The Madras Government seems to have underestimated the difficulties of securing enduring success in a field, steady progress in which has not been found too easy even by experts, namely, the All India Spinners’ Association.
('92', 99, 3, 12, 167555) I am naturally most anxious that Shri Prakasam should not embark upon any Khadi Scheme, the success of which is not assured.
('92', 99, 3, 13, 167680) If we try to move too fast,
('92', 99, 4, 14, 167708) 1 The Khadi Scheme of the Madras Government which envisaged making villages as far as possible self sufficient in cloth; vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting, 25 9 1946.
('92', 100, 0, 1, 167872) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 101
('92', 100, 1, 2, 167917) I have no doubt that we shall fail, and fail badly, and such failure will not only reflect discredit on the Government which has embarked upon such a venture without sufficient consideration, but will also do great harm to khadi work in general.
('92', 100, 1, 3, 168163) It is, therefore, necessary, especially as expenditure of funds allotted from Provincial Revenues is involved, that we should be very careful before undertaking the work on a large scale.
('92', 100, 1, 4, 168351) 2. I would accordingly advise the Madras Government to be guided in this matter by the only expert body in India which can claim intimate and long experience of khadi work, namely, the All India Spinners’ Association.
('92', 100, 1, 5, 168569) Subject to my approval, the Association will select a group or compact groups of villages in which khadi has made some progress already, and which will, therefore, be a hopeful field for intensive work of the kind contemplated by the Madras Government.
('92', 100, 1, 6, 168822) The khadi work in these areas should be done in accordance with a plan prepared by the Association, which the Madras Government should announce after finalising it in consultation with the Association.
('92', 100, 1, 7, 169024) The plan will provide for allotment of the necessary funds by the Government, and also for the appointment, by them, of the necessary wholetime staff in consultation with the Association.
('92', 100, 1, 8, 169212) The staff so appointed will execute the Scheme under the instructions and guidance of the Association.
('92', 100, 1, 9, 169315) If, as we all hope, this modest scheme succeeds, I shall gladly support proposals for its extension, with modifications if any suggested by our experience of its actual working, to other and larger areas.
('92', 100, 1, 10, 169520) 3. I am requesting Shri Jajuji to prepare immediately, a scheme on the lines indicated above, in consultation with the Provincial Textile Commissioner, Madras, who will be meeting him at Sevagram for the purpose, on his way back to Madras.
('92', 100, 1, 11, 169760) I shall ask Shri Jajuji to forward the scheme to Shri Prakasam after I have approved it.
('92', 100, 1, 12, 169849) 4. I not only agree, but I am most anxious, that in these areas selected for the khadi work, all other items of rural reconstruction, as envisaged in Shri Prakasam’s note dated 22 5 46 should also be tried simultaneously in consultation with the A.I.V.I.A. and the A.I.T.S. 5. In any event, and in order to create the proper khadi spirit, all schools and colleges under the Government should be instructed to devote at least half an hour per day to spinning together with the anterior processes, the charkhas or taklis, as the case may be, to be
('92', 101, 0, 1, 170395) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 101, 1, 2, 170437) supplied by the Government, and khadi training schools be immediately established by them in consultation with and under the guidance of the A.I.S.A. 6. It should be remembered that the scheme I have in view does not contemplate any workshop for the manufacture of spinning wheels, these being already in existence in the villages to be selected.
('92', 101, 1, 3, 170784) The scheme also contemplates the manufacture of wheels and the like by the local village carpenters and blacksmiths.

('92', 104, 6, 13, 174546) 152. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 104, 7, 14, 174576) NEW DELHI, September 2, 1946
('92', 104, 8, 15, 174605) At last the way to purna swaraj has been opened.
('92', 104, 8, 16, 174654) The whole of India has waited for this day for years and years and made innume rable sacrifices.
('92', 104, 8, 17, 174751) Whatever our quarrels with the British Government in the past, we must thank it today, for it has voluntarily arrived at a settlement with our leaders.
('92', 104, 8, 18, 174903) A correspondent asks me, now that the Government is in the hands of Indians, when the Viceroy’s House will be turned into a hospital for the poor.
('92', 104, 8, 19, 175050) My answer is that this will be done when people have all the power in their hands.
('92', 104, 8, 20, 175133) So far we have not secured full independence.
('92', 104, 8, 21, 175179) There was no exaggeration in what I had said on the subject at the Round Table Conference.
('92', 104, 8, 22, 175270) Undoubtedly Harijans are amongst the poorest of the Poor.
('92', 104, 8, 23, 175328) The Viceroy is still there in the Viceroy’s House.
('92', 104, 8, 24, 175379) And so long as he occupies his office as Viceroy, it will be discourteous to tell him to vacate it.
('92', 104, 8, 25, 175479) We shall have full freedom only when our uncrowned king Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and his colleagues in the Interim Government devote themselves to the service of the poor as people expect them to do.
('92', 104, 8, 26, 175678) This is a memorable day in the history of India.
('92', 104, 8, 27, 175727) There is no
('92', 105, 0, 1, 175739) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 105, 1, 2, 175781) occasion, however, for illuminations and jubilation.
('92', 105, 1, 3, 175834) We must remember that today our ministers are putting on the crown of thorns.
('92', 105, 1, 4, 175912) The Muslim League, which is the second most important organization after the Congress and represents the Muslims of India, has not joined the Interim Government.
('92', 105, 1, 5, 176074) Muslims are related to us by blood, for they are the children of the same land.
('92', 105, 1, 6, 176154) They are angry with the Hindus.
('92', 105, 1, 7, 176186) The Muslim League contends that the Hindus have betrayed them.
('92', 105, 1, 8, 176249) The followers of the League are observing this day as a day of mourning.
('92', 105, 1, 9, 176322) But the Hindus should not answer anger with anger and blow with blow.
('92', 105, 1, 10, 176392) Time was when the Ali Brothers were with the Hindus.
('92', 105, 1, 11, 176445) So, even though the Hindus cannot join the Muslim Leagues in observing the day as a day of mourning they should avoid illuminations, feasting and other forms of rejoicing.

('92', 105, 1, 17, 176983) Then I really do not understand why it wants to non co operate with the latter.
('92', 105, 1, 18, 177063) This is not in keeping with the teaching of Islam.

('92', 105, 1, 25, 177649) The question has been asked what the Congress Ministers should do as a first step.
('92', 105, 1, 26, 177732) Here, my mind goes back to the days of the Dandi March.
('92', 105, 1, 27, 177788) Our women played a great part at that time.
('92', 105, 1, 28, 177832) The heroism and sacrifice they displayed then was unprecedented.
('92', 105, 1, 29, 177897) The Dandi March symbolized the resolve of the Congress to secure freedom for the poor.
('92', 105, 1, 30, 177984) The cry was raised that salt tax be abolished.
('92', 105, 1, 31, 178031) Therefore the very first step of the Interim Government should be to abolish that tax, so that the poorest villager can have the feeling that the dawn of freedom has arrived.
('92', 105, 1, 32, 178206) The poor include Hindus as well as Muslims of India.
('92', 105, 1, 33, 178259) I have said a good deal about communal unity.

('92', 106, 1, 4, 178484) If I had my way I would not let them seek military or police help.
('92', 106, 1, 5, 178551) Well, if Hindus and Muslims must fight each other it is better that they bravely do their fighting themselves.
('92', 106, 1, 6, 178662) So long as we depend on the British for protecting us, true freedom will not be ours.

('92', 107, 3, 8, 180821) 154. SOUTH AFRICA
('92', 107, 4, 9, 180839) Sir Shafaat Ahmed Khan who, but for the recent murderous assault on him, would have joined the Interim Government 1 yesterday wrote on August 6th to me an interesting letter from which I quote as follows :
('92', 107, 5, 10, 181045) My study of the Indian community while I was in South Africa convinced me that but for your heroic work in the Union, the Indian race in that country would not have survived as a self respecting community.
('92', 107, 5, 11, 181251) You built up, cell by cell, the power of resistance in a highly gifted race and your work in that country is the inspiration of the Indian race in South Africa at the present time.
('92', 107, 6, 12, 181432) My sole aim in South Africa was to lay the foundation of Indian unity in Natal.
('92', 107, 6, 13, 181512) I do not think I succeeded completely in my aim but I am inclined to think that the heroic struggle which our race is carrying on at the present time would have been impossible but for the dissolution of the Natal Indian Association and A. I. Kajee’s Natal Indian Congress and the revival of the Natal Indian Congress, which you had founded in 1894. This was accomplished on August 29th 1943 and since that time, there has been only one political organization of Indians in Natal.
('92', 107, 7, 14, 181993) The South African situation is complicated and owing to conventions of diplomacy, my lips are sealed.
('92', 107, 7, 15, 182095) My despatches from South Africa which give a complete picture of the political situation for three years and are very exhaustive, cannot be published owing to conventions of international intercourse.
('92', 107, 8, 16, 182296) I came to the conclusion that no redress of our grievances in South Africa is possible unless we are masters in our own homeland and India is free.
('92', 107, 9, 17, 182444) 1 Vide “ South Africa”, 3 9 1946
('92', 108, 0, 1, 182477) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 109
('92', 108, 1, 2, 182522) In reply to my letter 1 acknowledging receipt of the above, Sir Shafaat Ahmed Khan further writes :
('92', 108, 2, 3, 182622) You will be glad to hear that since my return from South Africa, I have been busy preparing my speeches in South Africa and have added a section in my book, shortly to be published, on the history of the Indian community in South Africa.
('92', 108, 2, 4, 182860) In this I have made bold to give a brief account of your work there and followed with the greatest interest your march to Volksrust, etc.
('92', 108, 3, 5, 182998) For more than three years—1942 45, I wrote lengthy despatches to the Government of India on the South African problem and in April 1943 I warned them against General Smuts’ policy and told them to take the strongest measures against the Union Government in connection with the Pegging Act.
('92', 108, 3, 6, 183288) Strong measures have been taken now, but I am afraid it is too late.
('92', 108, 3, 7, 183357) If the Congress forms a National Government soon and the new member in charge of the Department decides to publish these despatches, particularly from April 1943 onwards, they will clear up numerous points for the next session of U. N. O. I am bound to say that the convention is that such despatches are not published unless and until there is rupture of relations between two countries.
('92', 108, 3, 8, 183746) I offer no opinion as to whether they should be published at all.
('92', 108, 3, 9, 183812) This is a matter which the new Government should decide.

('92', 116, 7, 15, 195352) [September 3, 1946] 2
('92', 116, 8, 16, 195374) RAJASAHEB, I have your two letters.
('92', 116, 8, 17, 195410) Why do you sign in English?
('92', 116, 8, 18, 195438) I have written a lot about the Zamindars; I cannot remember in which particular issues.
('92', 116, 8, 19, 195526) A good many collections of my articles have been published.
('92', 116, 8, 20, 195586) With a little effort one of your secretaries will be able to look these up and tell you.
('92', 116, 8, 21, 195675) My opinion, in brief, is that no zamindar or rich man should perish.
('92', 116, 8, 22, 195744) The greatest need is to bring about a change of heart in them.
('92', 116, 8, 23, 195807) If every zamindar, every Rajah and every millionaire lives as servant of the people there will be no problem.
('92', 116, 8, 24, 195917) In the final analysis land belongs to the man who has worked on it.
('92', 116, 8, 25, 195985) The present system which divides people into capitalists or landlords on the one hand and the have nots or serfs on the other, should not be tolerated.
('92', 116, 8, 26, 196137) All this I have explained in my articles a number of times.

('92', 117, 1, 2, 196412) As to religion, I feel our country, and indeed the world, should have room for all religions.
('92', 117, 1, 3, 196506) I consider no one high and no one low.
('92', 117, 1, 4, 196545) The duties enjoined on a Brahmin or Kshatriya are for all.
('92', 117, 1, 5, 196604) Only, some have these in greater measure than others.
('92', 117, 1, 6, 196658) But these are duties, never rights.
('92', 117, 1, 7, 196694) One who claims a right to Brahminhood is not a Brahmin.
('92', 117, 1, 8, 196750) Similarly, the claimant to the prerogatives of a Kshatriya ceases to be one.
('92', 117, 1, 9, 196827) I have shown the easiest way to save Hinduism and that is that we should all become Bhangis voluntarily.
('92', 117, 1, 10, 196932) For a Bhangi can have knowledge, valour and business acumen, while the spirit of service will always be there.
('92', 117, 1, 11, 197043) In my own view all these are for service.

('92', 117, 3, 14, 197147) 169. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 117, 4, 15, 197177) NEW DELHI, September 3, 1946 The Viceroy’s House is kept very neat and clean.
('92', 117, 4, 16, 197255) 1 Not a scrap of waste paper, not a piece of rag can be spotted anywhere.
('92', 117, 4, 17, 197329) The houses occupied by former members of the Viceroy’s Executive Council were equally clean and well appointed.
('92', 117, 4, 18, 197441) There is no gainsaying that we have not learnt the art of external sanitation to the degree that the English have.
('92', 117, 4, 19, 197556) What is so distressing is that the living quarters of the menials and sweepers employed in the Viceroy’s House are extremely dirty.
('92', 117, 4, 20, 197688) This is a state of affairs the ministers of our new Government will not tolerate.
('92', 117, 4, 21, 197770) Although they will occupy the same well kept bungalows, they will see to it that the lodgings of their servants are kept as clean as their own.
('92', 117, 4, 22, 197914) They will also have to pay attention to the cleanliness of the wives and children of the staff.
('92', 117, 4, 23, 198010) Jawaharlal and Sardar have no objection to cleaning their own lavatories.
('92', 117, 4, 24, 198084) How can they have any in having the living quarters of their attendants cleaned?
('92', 117, 4, 25, 198165) A one time Harijan servant of Jawaharlal is now a member of the U. P. Assembly.
('92', 117, 4, 26, 198245) I shall be satisfied only when the lodgings of the ministers’ staff are as neat and tidy as their own.
('92', 117, 4, 27, 198348) [From Hindi] Hindustan, 4 9 1946
('92', 117, 5, 28, 198381) 1 Gandhiji was commenting on the fear expressed by some Englishmen that with the departure of the British the gardens of the house occupied by the members of the Viceroy’s Executive Council would suffer neglect, the furniture would be ruined by oil and grease, lavatories would be left uncleaned, and so on.

('92', 118, 1, 2, 198734) 170. NOTES 1
('92', 118, 2, 3, 198747) THE LOWLY COW A knowledgeable sister writes :
('92', 118, 3, 4, 198793) Q. 1. With the exception of those cows or buffaloes that are in calf, cannot all others, whether in milk or not, be used to plough the land?
('92', 118, 3, 5, 198934) This would be of immense help to the farmer but the general public is averse to the idea.
('92', 118, 3, 6, 199024) What is your opinion?
('92', 118, 4, 7, 199046) Q. 2. There is a great dearth of pasture land in our country.
('92', 118, 4, 8, 199108) It is difficult for the farmer to provide fodder even for useful cattle.
('92', 118, 4, 9, 199181) Are you then in favour of the slaughter of all such animals as cannot be made use of or do you think this slaughter should be forbidden by law?
('92', 118, 5, 10, 199325) A. 1. The first question was put to me as long ago as 1915. I felt then as now, that if the cows referred to were used for purposes of ploughing the land, it would not hurt them.
('92', 118, 5, 11, 199504) On the contrary it would make them strong and increase their yield of milk.
('92', 118, 5, 12, 199580) But this benefit could only come about provided the cow was treated as a friend and not cruelly as cattle in our land so often are.
('92', 118, 5, 13, 199712) This friendly treatment should of course be insisted on for animals from whom we take service.
('92', 118, 5, 14, 199807) Every living being has to work within or its limitations.
('92', 118, 5, 15, 199865) Such work uplifts, never lowers either man or beast.
('92', 118, 6, 16, 199918) A. 2. The second question also has long since been answered by me.
('92', 118, 6, 17, 199985) Cow slaughter can never be stopped by law.
('92', 118, 6, 18, 200028) Knowledge, education, and the spirit of kindness towards her alone can put an end to it.
('92', 118, 6, 19, 200117) It will not be possible to save those animals that are a burden on the land or perhaps even man if he is a burden.
('92', 118, 7, 20, 200232) KHADDAR Readers of the Harijan may well say that in the present atmosphere of mad frenzy any talk of khadi is meaningless, because many khadi loving persons live in cities and so far, the trouble is, by the grace of God, confined to cities.
('92', 118, 7, 21, 200473) As a matter of fact, all city dwellers are by no means party to the senseless strife, and those who truly love khadi must always be actuated by thoughts of peace.
('92', 118, 7, 22, 200636) We have either to make khadi universal among the masses or give up all dreams of non violent swaraj.
('92', 118, 7, 23, 200737) Therefore, all who love and believe in peace, however fiercely the storm of communal strife may rage
('92', 118, 8, 24, 200838) 1 The Hindi original was published in Harijan Sevak 15 9 1946.
('92', 119, 0, 1, 200901) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 119, 1, 2, 200943) around them, will forget neither the spinning wheel nor khadi.
('92', 119, 1, 3, 201006) They may omit their meals but not the charkha.
('92', 119, 1, 4, 201053) The request given below on behalf of the Charkha Sangh is thus quite proper.
('92', 119, 1, 5, 201130) Such requests have been made by other khadi loving organizations too.
('92', 119, 1, 6, 201200) Those who look upon khadi in the above light will act on the resolution passed by the A. I. S. A. as referred to below :
('92', 119, 2, 7, 201321) 1. The Trustees of the Charkha Sangh hereby appeal to all Khadi Bhandars and all khadi lovers to try their utmost to secure 78,000 ordinary co operators for the coming seventy eighth Khadi Jayanti, of which number, at least half shall be self sufficient.
('92', 119, 3, 8, 201576) 2. By an ordinary co operator is meant one who is a habitual khadi wearer and will donate at least 6 hanks of self spun yarn annually to the Charkha Sangh.
('92', 119, 4, 9, 201732) 3. By ‘self sufficient’ is meant one who, unless prevented by illness or other sufficient and unavoidable cause, regularly produces whether spun by himself or through his family members or friends, at least 71 2 hanks yarn, per
('92', 119, 5, 10, 201960) month or 5 hanks, if he has done his own ginning, carding and slivering.
('92', 119, 6, 11, 202033) 4. The Charkha Sangh has also passed a resolution to the effect that in all khadi producing centres, at least one square yard per person, according to the population, must be used by the people in the area.
('92', 119, 6, 12, 202240) This much at least must be accomplished.

('92', 121, 7, 25, 204882) NEW DELHI, September 4, 1946
('92', 121, 8, 26, 204911) Gandhiji said that they had a right to hope that their country would soon become a country where there was no sorrow and sighing.
('92', 121, 8, 27, 205041) That country, however, of the poet’s imagination, Gandhiji reminded them, was in their hearts and they all knew the conditions necessary for bringing about that peace and happiness.
('92', 121, 8, 28, 205223) If everyone made room in his heart for God, there could be no sorrow and no sighing.
('92', 121, 8, 29, 205308) But today, alas!
('92', 121, 8, 30, 205325) the people were filled with fear and anger.
('92', 121, 8, 31, 205369) Brother quarrelled with brother and returned anger for anger and blow for blow.
('92', 121, 8, 32, 205449) What could their Ministers do?
('92', 121, 8, 33, 205480) Were they expected to send military and police to protect them?
('92', 121, 8, 34, 205544) The whole atmosphere was
('92', 122, 0, 1, 205569) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 123
('92', 122, 1, 2, 205614) rotten.
('92', 122, 1, 3, 205622) Offices and staff had been multiplied a hundredfold.
('92', 122, 1, 4, 205675) No wonder bribery and corruption were rampant.
('92', 122, 2, 5, 205722) On Tuesday, Gandhiji said, he had spoken to them of the duty of proper attention to hygiene and sanitation.
('92', 122, 2, 6, 205830) It was an essential factor for health and the duty of every citizen.
('92', 122, 2, 7, 205899) But inward cleanliness was even more necessary and much more difficult.
('92', 122, 2, 8, 205971) Nevertheless, if they did not purify themselves they would make Government impossible for their Ministers and displace the very men whom they had put in power.
('92', 122, 3, 9, 206131) Gandhiji again referred to the evil of untouchability.
('92', 122, 3, 10, 206186) It pained him to hear and read of the persecution of Harijans in villages.
('92', 122, 3, 11, 206261) If there was an epidemic they were beaten.
('92', 122, 3, 12, 206304) They could not draw water from wells.
('92', 122, 3, 13, 206342) They lived in hovels.
('92', 122, 3, 14, 206364) This state of affairs, Gandhiji said, may not exist in the country of our dreams.
('92', 122, 3, 15, 206446) All human beings are one in the sight of God and they must look upon Harijans as no less members of the great human family than they themselves were.
('92', 122, 4, 16, 206596) Gandhiji then said a word to the Bhangis whose first servant he said he was.
('92', 122, 4, 17, 206673) It pained him to hear of the bribery and corruption among them.
('92', 122, 4, 18, 206737) He did not want their so called leaders to oppress them.
('92', 122, 4, 19, 206794) He did not want Bhangis to look upon themselves as beggars at anyone’s door.
('92', 122, 4, 20, 206871) They must demand justice and fight for it but with clean hands.
('92', 122, 4, 21, 206935) And now with their own Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and others as Ministers they need have no fear that justice would not be meted out to them.

('92', 125, 4, 10, 210556) 180. HARIJANS AND WELLS 1
('92', 125, 5, 11, 210582) Shri Hardev Sahay writes :
('92', 125, 6, 12, 210609) Last evening (4 9 ’46) in your address to the prayer gathering, you drew the attention of the public to the disability attached to Harijans in the matter of drawing water public wells.
('92', 125, 6, 13, 210794) After 25 years of incessant effort on their behalf, we have not yet succeeded in removing this disability.
('92', 125, 6, 14, 210901) No one knows of their sufferings more than you.
('92', 125, 7, 15, 210949) It is my humble opinion that now that Congress Government are in power, they should forthwith proclaim their policy towards the Harijans and remove all such of their disabilities as they can by law.
('92', 125, 7, 16, 211148) In this connection I should like to draw your attention to conditions in the Punjab.
('92', 125, 7, 17, 211233) Leave aside the question of drawing water from wells, Harijans are not even permitted to obtain land for sinking a well for themselves.
('92', 125, 7, 18, 211369) I would beg of you to appeal to the Punjab Government to provide wells for Harijans at State expense, wherever there are no facilities of drawing water or at least provide them with land for sinking wells for themselves.
('92', 125, 7, 19, 211590) There are ever so many villages in the Punjab where, even if the Harijans are willing to spend their own money, they are not given the requisite land.
('92', 125, 8, 20, 211741) There are a few places where the Government has started making wells for the Harijans; but they are wholly insufficient.
('92', 125, 8, 21, 211862) It is surely the duty of the State to see that a proper supply of drinking water is available to all its citizens.
('92', 125, 8, 22, 211977) The writer is perfectly right in what he says.
('92', 125, 8, 23, 212024) It is the duty of the Government to provide wells for the Harijans.
('92', 125, 8, 24, 212092) It is not enough only to give the land; the Government should be responsible for sinking the wells.

('92', 126, 1, 2, 212356) 181. QUESTION BOX
('92', 126, 2, 3, 212374) NATURE CURE A PANACEA
('92', 126, 3, 4, 212396) Q. It has been said that nature cure can be applied to every disease.
('92', 126, 3, 5, 212466) If so, can it cure short or long sightedness, cataract and other eye diseases?
('92', 126, 3, 6, 212545) Can one avoid spectacles?
('92', 126, 3, 7, 212571) Can hernia, tonsils etc., which need the surgeon’s knife be cured by nature cure?
('92', 126, 4, 8, 212653) A. I know that the claim attributed to nature cure has been made by its exponents.
('92', 126, 4, 9, 212736) I do not count myself among them.
('92', 126, 4, 10, 212770) This much, however, can be safely claimed.
('92', 126, 4, 11, 212813) Disease springs from a wilful or ignorant breach of the laws of nature.
('92', 126, 4, 12, 212885) It follows, therefore, that timely return to those laws should mean restoration.
('92', 126, 4, 13, 212966) A person who has tried nature beyond endurance, must either suffer the punish ment inflicted by nature or, in order to avoid it, seek the assistance of the physician or the surgeon as the case may be.
('92', 126, 4, 14, 213167) Every submission to merited punishment strengthens the mind of man, every avoidance saps it.
('92', 126, 5, 15, 213260) FORCED MARRIAGE A sister writes :
('92', 126, 6, 16, 213294) What is an unwilling girl to do when her parents insist either upon her marriage or leaving the parental home?
('92', 126, 6, 17, 213405) Where is she to go if she has not been educated enough to earn her own living?
('92', 126, 6, 18, 213484) Whose protection is she to seek?
('92', 126, 7, 19, 213517) A. The question makes sad reading.
('92', 126, 7, 20, 213552) It is wholly wrong of parents to force marriage on their daughters.
('92', 126, 7, 21, 213620) It is also wrong to keep their daughters unfit for earning their living.
('92', 126, 7, 22, 213693) No parent has a right to turn a daughter out on the streets for refusal to marry.
('92', 126, 7, 23, 213775) Let us hope that such cruel specimens are rare.
('92', 126, 7, 24, 213823) To the girl concerned, my advice would be not to look on any labour with her hands, down to scavenging, as beneath her dignity.
('92', 126, 7, 25, 213951) Women may not look for protection to men.
('92', 126, 7, 26, 213993) They must rely on their own strength and purity of character and on God as did Draupadi of old.
('92', 126, 7, 27, 214089) NEW DELHI, September 6, 1946 Harijan, 15 9 1946

('92', 127, 5, 17, 215267) They feel it is a violation of ahimsa, whether accepted as a creed or as a policy.

('92', 127, 6, 20, 215613) By and large the ahimsa of the Congress has been the ahimsa of the weak.
('92', 127, 6, 21, 215686) This was the only thing possible under the prevailing conditions in India.
('92', 127, 6, 22, 215761) I admit that there can be no objection to people who accept ahimsa only as a policy accepting positions of power.

('92', 130, 4, 5, 220012) 186. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 130, 5, 6, 220044) NEW DELHI, September 6, 1946
('92', 130, 6, 7, 220073) Mahatma Gandhi criticized the public for sending hundreds of telegrams daily to the Viceroy and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('92', 130, 6, 8, 220194) He considered them a foolish waste of public money and at the same time waste of the Viceroy’s and Pandit Nehru’s precious time.
('92', 130, 6, 9, 220323) Time was when the Viceroy was all powerful and could do everything.
('92', 130, 6, 10, 220391) But now he had of his own free will relegated his powers to the Cabinet of which, like the King of England, he was constitutional head.
('92', 130, 6, 11, 220527) The King of England could not do anything without the consent of his Ministers.
('92', 130, 6, 12, 220607) The people of England even beheaded one monarch because he went against their will.
('92', 130, 6, 13, 220691) Gandhiji hoped that the people’s Ministers here would never do anything of the kind because they had in their possession the matchless weapon of satyagraha, should occasion ever arise for its use.
('92', 130, 6, 14, 220888) In any case, the people who sent these wires should realize that apart from burdening the recipients and the telegraph offices they were also wasting the people’s money.
('92', 130, 6, 15, 221058) The well to do imagined that it was their money, but it really belonged to the starving masses whom they exploited.
('92', 130, 7, 16, 221174) Gandhiji then turned with a heavy heart to the continued strife in Bombay.
('92', 130, 7, 17, 221249) He did not know who killed whom.
('92', 130, 7, 18, 221282) But it was tragic that some people even rejoiced that Hindus were enough to kill in return those who tried to kill them.
('92', 130, 7, 19, 221403) Such revenge was folly.
('92', 130, 7, 20, 221427) He would far rather that Hindus died without retaliation, for that was the only way to quench the fire of hatred.
('92', 130, 7, 21, 221541) He did not want the people to ask the Government anywhere for military and police protection.
('92', 130, 7, 22, 221635) They must generate their own strength and not rely on anyone else.
('92', 130, 7, 23, 221702) Even if they demanded this help the Ministers should refuse it.
('92', 130, 7, 24, 221766) The Ministers and leaders should be willing to go into the fray themselves and lay down their lives for the sake of Hindu and Muslim honour.
('92', 130, 7, 25, 221907) As for military, they should be harnessed to all kinds of constructive work at which they were adepts.
('92', 130, 7, 26, 222010) Let them grow more food for the starving millions and all kinds of other work that

('92', 131, 5, 18, 223671) 187. PROHIBITION
('92', 131, 6, 19, 223688) The following extracts from Rev.
('92', 131, 6, 20, 223721) E. Gordon’s writing provoke thoughts on total prohibition :
('92', 131, 7, 21, 223781) With famine facing the country, we cannot very well quarrel with sincere efforts for combating the menace, but why prohibition of food stuffs such as pastries, ice cream, etc., which have real good value, and why talk of prohibition or severe reduction of supply of sugar to aerated water and other mineral water manufactures and yet keep absolutely silent about the prohibition or severe reduction of cereals and sugar to the distilleries and breweries?
('92', 131, 7, 22, 224236) Is the drinking of alcoholic liquors any less of a luxury than the eating of pies, pastries and cakes?
('92', 131, 7, 23, 224339) Can even the most astute and ardent lovers of alcoholic beverages argue that these drinks are so essential to life that no reduction can be made in the amount of cereals and sugar required to make whisky, beer, etc.?
('92', 131, 8, 24, 224556) Granted that there is a certain amount of food value in beer, is it equal in value to the barley that could be used in making bread or cakes?

('92', 133, 2, 5, 227653) 188. HARIJAN WORK IN KISTNA DISTRICT
('92', 133, 3, 6, 227690) Shri G. Ramachandra Rao writes a letter giving an account of his Harijan work.
('92', 133, 3, 7, 227769) The following is a precis of it :
('92', 133, 4, 8, 227803) We have taken up the problem of the use of public wells by Harijans.
('92', 133, 4, 9, 227872) Section 126A of the Madras Local Boards Act of 1920 provides for the use, by persons of whatever caste or creed, of wells, tanks, reservoirs, water ways, etc., maintained by a Panchayat.
('92', 133, 4, 10, 228059) It even imposes a fine of Rs. 100 on anyone who obstructs its operation.
('92', 133, 4, 11, 228132) But the law is honoured in the breach where the Harijans are concerned.
('92', 133, 4, 12, 228204) It is pathetic to see the latter often waiting in long queues for hours at a time in front of a public well for some generous non Harijan to fill their pots with water.
('92', 133, 4, 13, 228373) We chose Kankipadu village where a public well is maintained by the local Panchayat and explained to the leaders, not only the implications of the law but also their moral obliga tions.
('92', 133, 4, 14, 228559) The response, after about three weeks of propaganda, being heartening, we called a public meeting where, owing to overwhelming support for the proposition, it was announced that in future Harijans would be allowed to use the well in question without molestation.
('92', 133, 5, 15, 228822) The next morning, however, the Harijans themselves were found to be too timid to take advantage of the decision.
('92', 133, 5, 16, 228935) It was a sad commentary on their mentality and we had to work hard to bring them to the well.
('92', 133, 5, 17, 229029) As soon as they began drawing water, a reaction set in among the caste Hindus, the vast majority of whom, even at personal inconvenience, refrained from coming to the well.
('92', 133, 5, 18, 229202) A few, however, remained staunch to their resolve and gradually the opposition was worn down.
('92', 133, 5, 19, 229296) I had also to appeal to the Deputy Inspector of Local Board to explain to the people the implications of section 126A.
('92', 133, 6, 20, 229415) This experience has encouraged us to take up similar work in other villages too, where Harijans have no facilities for obtaining water.
('92', 133, 6, 21, 229551) I am of opinion that for the removal of such disabilities, moral persuasion and legal provision should go hand in hand.
('92', 133, 6, 22, 229671) Absence of one renders the other inefficient.
('92', 133, 6, 23, 229717) The existing Government acts dealing with social disabilities are vague and weak.
('92', 133, 6, 24, 229799) This defect must be remedied and the Government of Madras, who have set aside one crore of rupees for Harijan work, might well utilize a certain sum for publicity of the provisions of the relevant laws already on the
('92', 134, 0, 1, 230016) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 135
('92', 134, 1, 2, 230061) statute book.
('92', 134, 1, 3, 230075) Execution of the law is as important as its passing.
('92', 134, 1, 4, 230128) Professor Rao deserves hearty congratulations for his assiduous work on behalf of the oppressed Harijans.
('92', 134, 1, 5, 230234) His effort ought to be supported by the public.
('92', 134, 2, 6, 230282) NEW DELHI, September 7, 1946 Harijan, 15 9 1946
('92', 134, 3, 7, 230330) 189. ABOUT HINDUSTANI 1
('92', 134, 4, 8, 230354) A gentleman from Bihar writes :
('92', 134, 5, 9, 230386) The great and commendable work that is going on under your leadership for Hindustani Prachar is of immense help for the country’s progress and freedom.
('92', 134, 5, 10, 230538) A nation that has no language of its own has hardly any right to exist.
('92', 134, 5, 11, 230610) And that is our misfortune today.
('92', 134, 5, 12, 230644) Yet our leaders are not fully aware of the problem.
('92', 134, 5, 13, 230696) In spite of your efforts, Congress workers are not whole hearted in this regard.
('92', 134, 5, 14, 230777) You will also be aware that at Congress Committee meetings as also in our legislatures, most people, including even whose mother tongue is either Hindi or Urdu, prefer to speak in English.
('92', 134, 5, 15, 230966) Is it not possible to make it obligatory for Congressmen to speak, whether at meetings or in legislatures, in Hindustani, as it is obligatory for them to wear khadi?
('92', 134, 5, 16, 231132) Some concession can be allowed in regard to those who cannot at all speak Hindustani, but a time limit should be set for them also to learn Hindustani.
('92', 134, 5, 17, 231284) My experience is that responsible Congressmen who know Hindustani prefer to speak in English.

('92', 137, 7, 17, 235711) NEW DELHI, September 7, 1946 The speeches being made by the Qaid e Azam and his followers cause me much pain.
('92', 137, 7, 18, 235821) They say that they will take what they want by force.
('92', 137, 7, 19, 235875) It is true that the reins of the Government are now in the hands of the Congress, but this only adds to their responsibilities and duties.

('92', 137, 7, 24, 236233) In true suffering there is no room for revenge.
('92', 137, 7, 25, 236281) Then alone can success be assured.

('92', 138, 0, 1, 236517) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 139
('92', 138, 1, 2, 236562) I am a villager.

('92', 138, 1, 4, 236608) The Congress has accepted power for the sake of these downtrodden villages.
('92', 138, 1, 5, 236684) I had taken up the cause of Hindu Muslim unity long before I joined the Congress.
('92', 138, 1, 6, 236766) I had a number of Muslim friends when I was at school.
('92', 138, 1, 7, 236821) I went to South Africa to plead the case of some Muslim friends of my brother.
('92', 138, 1, 8, 236900) I had gone there to gain my livelihood, but soon after my arrival there I gave the first place to service.
('92', 138, 1, 9, 237007) As a coolie barrister I served my friends of the labouring class.
('92', 138, 1, 10, 237073) I had gone as an employee of a Muslim firm and I served the Hindus through them.
('92', 138, 1, 11, 237154) My memory of those days is a happy one.
('92', 138, 1, 12, 237194) It is a matter of deep regret that even in South Africa communal differences have arisen.
('92', 138, 1, 13, 237284) Nevertheless they are unitedly fighting for the rights of Indians.
('92', 138, 1, 14, 237351) I still remember those hefty Muslims, and especially Seth Cachalia, who participated in the satyagraha and who said they would rather die than live as slaves.
('92', 138, 1, 15, 237510) When the Qaid e Azam and his followers describe Hindus as their enemies I am surprised and pained.
('92', 138, 1, 16, 237609) I am not a Muslim but I venture to say that Islam does not preach enmity towards anyone.
('92', 138, 1, 17, 237698) I think I am as much a Christian, a Sikh and a Jain as I am a Hindu.
('92', 138, 1, 18, 237767) Religion does not teach one to kill brother however different his belief.
('92', 138, 1, 19, 237841) No one can treat another as his enemy until the latter has become his own enemy.
('92', 138, 1, 20, 237922) Muslim League leaders were not right when they said that they would compel the Congress, the Hindus and the British to accede to their demand.

('92', 138, 1, 27, 238488) I am day and night tormented by the question what I can do to hasten the coming of that day.

('92', 140, 4, 14, 241344) 197. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 140, 5, 15, 241374) NEW DELHI, [September 8, 1946]
('92', 140, 6, 16, 241405) Though she could never swim in plenty, India could grow enough food for her requirement, chances of wastage being eliminated, said Mahatma Gandhi in his after prayer speech on Sunday evening.
('92', 140, 6, 17, 241597) Talking of cloth shortage, he said that if only the country took to the khadi scheme, no Indian need be in want.
('92', 140, 7, 18, 241710) Gandhiji said that their President Jawaharlalji had also referred to these two primary needs in his broadcast on Saturday evening.
('92', 140, 7, 19, 241841) He had appealed to those countries abroad who could spare food also to send it to India.
('92', 140, 7, 20, 241930) Gandhiji had no objection to anyone who could spare anything and felt like sending out foodstuffs.
('92', 140, 7, 21, 242029) But he was quite certain that India could not live if she was going to depend on outside aid for her food.
('92', 140, 7, 22, 242136) He had maintained from the beginning that India could grow enough food for her requirement.
('92', 140, 8, 23, 242228) An English sister who was like a relation of his, was with him just now on her way to China.
('92', 140, 8, 24, 242321) She was a woman who had chosen to make her home among the poor in London and when he went there for the (second) R. T. C. she had invited him to stay with her which he gladly did and looked upon Kingsley Hall as a palace.
('92', 140, 8, 25, 242543) She had told him how strictly rationed they were for everything in England, how rationing included everyone from the King and Prime Minister downwards and how proud everyone was to share the burden.
('92', 140, 8, 26, 242742) These people were disciplined and war had taught
('92', 141, 0, 1, 242791) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 141, 1, 2, 242833) them to suffer willingly.
('92', 141, 1, 3, 242859) If one goes further into the war devastated countries of Europe, the suffering was much worse and would be still greater with the approaching winter.
('92', 141, 2, 4, 243009) Today the whole world was starving, and why should India look for relief from outside.
('92', 141, 2, 5, 243096) Gandhiji maintained that if everyone put his shoulder to the wheel all would be well with them.
('92', 141, 2, 6, 243192) No one must eat a morsel more than he required and everyone who had any little piece of land should at once grow vegetables or cereals on it.
('92', 141, 2, 7, 243334) In the U. P. he had been told that 75,000 bighas of uncultivated land was waiting to be ploughed.
('92', 141, 2, 8, 243432) All this meant that they could produce much more food if they directed their energies to it.
('92', 141, 3, 9, 243525) Gandhiji said it hurt him to hear it said that Travancore had food only for 15 days more.
('92', 141, 3, 10, 243615) This was a land of plenty and yet the poor lived in perpetual want because of exploitation by a foreign power and the city folk.
('92', 141, 3, 11, 243744) Gandhiji explained that when he said that enough food could be grown he did not mean that they could afford to waste anything.
('92', 141, 3, 12, 243871) They would never be swimming in an ocean of milk.
('92', 141, 3, 13, 243921) That was possible only for God.
('92', 141, 3, 14, 243953) But for the absolute lack of any milk or ghee or even oil for the poor the city folk must hang their heads in shame.
('92', 141, 4, 15, 244070) Gandhiji next turned to India’s nakedness.
('92', 141, 4, 16, 244113) The answer to this was, in his opinion, quite simple.
('92', 141, 4, 17, 244167) People talked glibly of starting more textile mills.
('92', 141, 4, 18, 244220) But they needed none of these.
('92', 141, 4, 19, 244251) The mills existed today in their villages in the shape of hands, spindles, wheels and looms.
('92', 141, 4, 20, 244344) The art was an old one and was alive.
('92', 141, 4, 21, 244382) He knew, as President of the Spinners’ Association what wonders could be worked if only everyone would take to the wheel.
('92', 141, 4, 22, 244504) It was a crying shame that we who had plenty of cotton to export should have to depend upon mills.
('92', 141, 4, 23, 244603) He appealed to each one to spin and send the yarn to him.
('92', 141, 4, 24, 244661) He would have it woven and given to the poor or sold to the giver of enough yarn.
('92', 141, 4, 25, 244743) It was up to the public to be true to themselves and help to the utmost to solve the problem.
('92', 141, 4, 26, 244837) The solution lay in their own hands, not in those of the few members of the Cabinet.

('92', 141, 5, 28, 244952) 198. WHAT TO DO?
('92', 141, 6, 29, 244969) A friend sends the following questions :
('92', 141, 7, 30, 245010) Q. 1. You have all along held and expressed the view that persons should observe strict non violence even when attacked by hooligans or others.
('92', 141, 7, 31, 245154) Does this hold good when women are attacked or outraged?
('92', 141, 7, 32, 245211) If people are unable to follow your lead regarding non violence would you advise them to die as cowards or resist aggression with violence?
('92', 141, 8, 33, 245351) Q. 2. Should you not unequivocally condemn the dual role that the Muslim
('92', 142, 0, 1, 245424) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 143
('92', 142, 1, 2, 245469) League is playing today?
('92', 142, 1, 3, 245494) While, on the one hand, its leaders are openly preaching violence and jehad against Hindus, the same men continue, on the other hand, to hold office as Ministers having a controlling hand on all the threads of administration, including police and justice.
('92', 142, 2, 4, 245750) Q. 3. Is there no constituted authority in India which can put a stop to this grave anomaly which is unprecedented in history?
('92', 142, 3, 5, 245877) Q. 4. Do you realize that if the present happenings are allowed to continue, civil war will become inevitable?
('92', 142, 3, 6, 245988) How would you advise your countrymen to face such a catastrophe, if it comes?
('92', 142, 4, 7, 246066) A. 1. In a society of my imagination, outrage posited by the questioner cannot take place.
('92', 142, 4, 8, 246157) But in the society in the midst of which we are living, such outrages do take place.
('92', 142, 4, 9, 246242) My answer is unequivocal.
('92', 142, 4, 10, 246268) A non violent man or woman will and should die without retaliation, anger or malice, in self defence or in defending the honour of his womenfolk.
('92', 142, 4, 11, 246414) This is the highest form of bravery.
('92', 142, 4, 12, 246451) If an individual or a group of people are unable or unwilling to follow this great law of life, which is miscalled my lead, retaliation or resistance unto death is the second best, though a long way off from the first.
('92', 142, 4, 13, 246670) Cowardice is impotence worse than violence.
('92', 142, 4, 14, 246714) The coward desires revenge but being afraid to die, he looks to others may be the Government of the day, to do the work of defence for him.
('92', 142, 4, 15, 246854) A coward is less than man.
('92', 142, 4, 16, 246881) He does not deserve to be a member of a society of men and women.
('92', 142, 4, 17, 246947) Lastly, let me add that if women had followed or would now follow my advice, every woman would protect herself without caring or waiting for aid from her brother or sister.
('92', 142, 5, 18, 247120) A. 2. Of course, the dual role adverted to is unequivocally bad.
('92', 142, 5, 19, 247185) It is a sad chapter in our national life.
('92', 142, 5, 20, 247227) My condemnation is of universal application.
('92', 142, 5, 21, 247272) Fortunately it is so bad that it cannot last long.
('92', 142, 6, 22, 247323) A. 3. The only constituted authority is the British.
('92', 142, 6, 23, 247376) We are all puppets in their hands.
('92', 142, 6, 24, 247411) But it would be wrong and foolish to blame that authority.
('92', 142, 6, 25, 247470) It acts according to its nature.
('92', 142, 6, 26, 247503) That authority does not compel us to be puppets.
('92', 142, 6, 27, 247552) We voluntarily run into their camp.
('92', 142, 6, 28, 247588) It is, therefore, open to any and every one of us to refuse to play the British game.
('92', 142, 6, 29, 247674) Let us also admit frankly that the British authority is struggling to quit India.
('92', 142, 6, 30, 247756) It does not know how.
('92', 142, 6, 31, 247778) It honestly wants to leave India but wants before leaving to undo the wrong it has been doing for so
('92', 143, 0, 1, 247879) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 143, 1, 2, 247921) Being in the position of ‘the toad under the harrow’, I must know where it hurts.
('92', 143, 1, 3, 248003) I have been telling the authority, if it will undo the wrong quickly, to leave India to her fate.
('92', 143, 1, 4, 248101) But those who compose the British service cannot realize this obvious fact.
('92', 143, 1, 5, 248177) They flatter themselves with the belief that they know India better than we do ourselves.
('92', 143, 1, 6, 248267) Having successfully kept us under subjection for over a century, they claim the right to constitute themselves judges of our destiny.
('92', 143, 1, 7, 248401) We may not grumble, if we are to come into our own through the way of peace.
('92', 143, 1, 8, 248478) Satyagraha is never vindictive.
('92', 143, 1, 9, 248510) It believes not in destruction but in conversion.
('92', 143, 1, 10, 248560) Its failures are due to the weaknesses of the satyagrahi, not to any defect in the law itself.
('92', 143, 1, 11, 248655) The British authority having decided to quit, (whatever the reason), will show growing defects and weaknesses.
('92', 143, 1, 12, 248766) Parties will find that it is more and more a broken reed.
('92', 143, 1, 13, 248824) And, when parties quarrel as Hindus and Muslims do let one or the other or both realize that, if India is to be an independent nation, one or both must deliberately cease to look to British authority for protection.
('92', 143, 2, 14, 249040) A. 4. This brings me to the last question.
('92', 143, 2, 15, 249083) We are not yet in the midst or civil war.
('92', 143, 2, 16, 249125) But we are nearing it.
('92', 143, 2, 17, 249148) At present we are playing at it.
('92', 143, 2, 18, 249181) War is a respectable term for goondaism practised on a mass or national scale.
('92', 143, 2, 19, 249260) If the British are wise, they will keep clear of it.
('92', 143, 2, 20, 249313) Appearances are to the contrary.
('92', 143, 2, 21, 249346) Even the English members in the Provincial Assemblies refuse to see that they were given seats by the Act of 1935, not because it was right but in order that they might protect British interest and keep Hindus and Muslims apart.
('92', 143, 2, 22, 249575) But they do not see this.
('92', 143, 2, 23, 249601) It is a small matter.
('92', 143, 2, 24, 249623) Nevertheless it is a straw showing the way the wind is blowing.
('92', 143, 2, 25, 249687) Lovers and makers of swaraj must not be dismayed by these omens.
('92', 143, 2, 26, 249752) My advice is satyagraha first and satyagraha last.
('92', 143, 2, 27, 249803) There is no other or better road to freedom.
('92', 143, 2, 28, 249848) Whoever wants to drink the ozone of freedom must steel himself against seeking military or police aid.
('92', 143, 2, 29, 249951) He or they must ever rely upon their own strong arms or, what is infinitely better, their strong mind and will which are independent of arms, their own or other.

('92', 149, 2, 3, 255532) NEW DELHI, September 9, 1946
('92', 149, 3, 4, 255561) BHAI VITHALDAS, I have your letter.
('92', 149, 3, 5, 255597) I cannot regard the Hindustani translation as accurate but I see no misinterpretation in it.
('92', 149, 3, 6, 255690) Since there is a question mark I cannot see the possibility of any frightful interpretation of it.
('92', 149, 3, 7, 255789) But I might understand what you want to say if you throw more light.
('92', 149, 3, 8, 255858) I cannot revise what I have written regarding Kakodkar’s case.
('92', 149, 3, 9, 255921) Please remember that I have not said it in regard to fasting in general.
('92', 149, 3, 10, 255994) I had only Kakodkar’s fast in mind.
('92', 149, 3, 11, 256030) The only untoward outcome of the fast would have been that he might have died and I would not have regarded it as a terrible consequence.
('92', 149, 3, 12, 256168) I would have regarded it as wrong if the fast had been given up owing to fear hunger, or a false notion of morality.
('92', 149, 3, 13, 256285) Uncertified khadi means khadi that does not come up to the standard, but is it not khadi all the same?
('92', 149, 3, 14, 256388) I for one would regard it as wrong to use mill cloth in place of such khadi.
('92', 149, 3, 15, 256465) The fact is it is wrong to expect at present khadi for book binding and so on.
('92', 149, 4, 16, 256544) VITHALDAS KOTHARI GUJARATI VIDYAPITH

('92', 153, 6, 16, 261452) The Finance Member has not yet taken charge of his office.

('92', 153, 6, 18, 261525) The Cabinet must do everything after full deliberation.
('92', 153, 6, 19, 261581) It is I who should be impatient, for it was I who initiated the fight for the abolition of this tax.
('92', 153, 6, 20, 261682) Ialso know how the loss of revenue can be made up for.
('92', 153, 6, 21, 261737) Nevertheless I think we should not be impatient.
('92', 153, 6, 22, 261786) We should not hustle the Cabinet.
('92', 153, 6, 23, 261820) The Cabinet is of the people and works under their mandate.
('92', 153, 6, 24, 261880) We must have faith that the salt tax will go and he who has faith can afford to be patient.
('92', 153, 6, 25, 261972) There are many other things that the Cabinet has to do for the people as quickly as possible.
('92', 153, 6, 26, 262066) If we continue to give it our support it will surely do all that should be done for the good of the masses.
('92', 153, 6, 27, 262174) Yesterday I told you that if we would learn to make our cloth ourselves there would be no need for anyone to go naked.
('92', 153, 6, 28, 262293) Many people do not know how to spin.

('92', 154, 10, 20, 263329) 220. LETTER TO HORACE G. ALEXANDER
('92', 154, 11, 21, 263364) NEW DELHI, September 10, 1946
('92', 154, 12, 22, 263394) MY DEAR HORACE, Muriel read your letter and gave it to me last evening.
('92', 154, 12, 23, 263466) I am glad you have frankly given me your reaction to the situation in Calcutta.
('92', 154, 13, 24, 263546) I wholly endorse your first reaction.
('92', 154, 13, 25, 263584) It is in every way undesirable for the Congress to rely upon British troops or even police for upholding authority and keeping law and order.
('92', 154, 13, 26, 263726) It is tantamount to suicide.
('92', 154, 13, 27, 263755) I wholly dissent from the second.
('92', 154, 13, 28, 263789) One can waive a right.
