('92', 157, 1, 2, 267180) 223. LEPROSY AND CONTAMINATION
('92', 157, 2, 3, 267211) Dr. R. G. Cochrane, Principal of the Missionary Medical College for Women in Vellore, writes : 1
('92', 157, 3, 4, 267308) My good friend Mr. Jagadisan has brought to my attention a paragraph in the Hindu of Madras of August the 26th.
('92', 157, 3, 5, 267420) It reads: ‘Bihar is going to have a separate jail for the leper prisoners, it is learnt, to save other prisoners from contamination.
('92', 157, 3, 6, 267553) Arrangements are being made in the first instance, it is understood, to segregate about 100 such prisoners at Govindpur in the District of Manbhum.
('92', 157, 3, 7, 267701) I was so pained by the news that I could not resist the urge to write to you, for you have been a consistent champion of those who suffer from leprosy and indeed, of all persons in society who are undeservedly stigmatized.
('92', 157, 3, 8, 267924) I feel that I should write to you and say that it will be a great pity if the Bihar Government were to build a separate jail for prisoners with leprosy.
('92', 157, 3, 9, 268077) It is a gratuitous measure whose only effect will be the strengthening of the public’s prejudice against leprosy.
('92', 157, 3, 10, 268191) On examination, it is likely to be found that 80 per cent at least of the prisoners with leprosy are non infective, and therefore there is absolutely no reason why these should be separated from the other prisoners.
('92', 157, 3, 11, 268407) With regard to the prisoners who suffer from infective leprosy, the main precautions are that the prisoner should not come into contact with healthy persons during night and should avoid direct close contact during the day.
('92', 157, 3, 12, 268631) As leprosy is a mildly contagious disease, even its infective types, a prisoner with infective leprosy could be more easily dealt with than prisoners with other infective diseases.
('92', 157, 3, 13, 268812) And yet, if the report is true, the Bihar Government is going to act on the fear of ‘contamination’.
('92', 157, 3, 14, 268913) The very use of this word indicates a mediaeval attitude to leprosy.
('92', 157, 3, 15, 268982) It is a great pity that statements are being continually published to suggest that leprosy patients are contaminated in some way or other.
('92', 157, 4, 16, 269121) We in Madras, enthusiastically supported by Mr. Jagadisan, are doing all we can to protest against the discrimination of the patient suffering from leprosy on the grounds of social stigma.
('92', 157, 4, 17, 269310) It is no more of a disgrace to get leprosy than to get measles, and not until the general public realize that it is not a rapidly spreading plague, as it is commonly believed to be, shall we make any advance in the control of leprosy.
('92', 157, 4, 18, 269545) I am very grateful to hear from Mr. Jagadisan that you have now put leprosy work as an integral part of the nation’s Constructive Programme.
('92', 157, 4, 19, 269686) Your remark that the leprosy patient is as
('92', 157, 5, 20, 269729) 1Vide “Letter to Dr. R.G. Cochrane”.
('92', 157, 5, 21, 269766) 11 9 1946.
('92', 158, 0, 1, 269777) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 159
('92', 158, 1, 2, 269822) much a part of society as the tallest of us moves me deeply.
('92', 158, 1, 3, 269883) May I hope that India’s leave will follow your footsteps and do the right thing by the leprosy patient?
('92', 158, 1, 4, 269987) It is to be hoped that the information about Bihar is not true and that, if it is, this letter of his will dissipate the fear of leprosy.
('92', 158, 1, 5, 270125) “Superstitions die hard.” In this land of faith and superstitions, both flourish abundantly.
('92', 158, 1, 6, 270218) Hence, they often intermingle and the conta mination of superstitions—a multitude—seems to have overlaid faith, so much so that it is hard to distinguish between the two.
('92', 158, 1, 7, 270389) But my faith, which burns too bright for the army of superstitions to touch it, tells me that leprosy is no contamination.
('92', 158, 1, 8, 270512) We must learn the laws governing infectious and contagious diseases and obey them.
('92', 158, 1, 9, 270595) Dr. Cochrane is, I believe, a medical philanthropist.
('92', 158, 1, 10, 270649) He knows a great deal about leprosy and lepers.
('92', 158, 1, 11, 270697) I what that the National Governments will not be wrong in accepting his judgment that, of all the diseases of the kind, leprosy is the least among them.
('92', 158, 1, 12, 270850) In its virulent form, it deprives a patient of his limbs and defies ordinary medical treatment.
('92', 158, 1, 13, 270946) What nature does is yet unknown.
('92', 158, 1, 14, 270979) But the ordinary man does not need to bother about this difficult matter.
('92', 158, 1, 15, 271053) Enough if he realizes that a leper is as much his brother as any other, and he is on no account to be shunned.
('92', 158, 1, 16, 271164) NEW DELHI, September 11, 1946 Harijan, 22 9 1946
('92', 158, 2, 17, 271213) 224. TIRED OF SATYAGRAHA?
('92', 158, 3, 18, 271239) News comes from Durban that a group of Indians has sprung up in South Africa who have lost faith in satyagraha.
('92', 158, 3, 19, 271351) They cherish the dream that they can overthrow the rule of the White man there only by joining forces with the Negroes the coloured people, other Asiatics and European sympathizers and adopting violent means.
('92', 158, 3, 20, 271560) The rumour, if there is any truth in it, is disturbing and a definite fly in the ointment.
('92', 158, 3, 21, 271651) All, whether they believe in non violence or not, should realize that Indians in South Africa gained world wide esteem simply because, in spite of being a handful, they showed infinite capa city for suffering and did not, through losing their patience, resort to sabotage and violence.
('92', 158, 3, 22, 271937) They learnt the wholesome lesson that true well being
('92', 158, 4, 23, 271991) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 22 9 1946.
('92', 159, 0, 1, 272066) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 159, 1, 2, 272108) springs from suffering and that victory lies in unity.
('92', 159, 1, 3, 272163) From my own experience, my firm advice to Indians in South Africa is that they should, on no account, be lured away into throwing aside the matchless weapon of satyagraha.
('92', 159, 1, 4, 272335) This does not, however, imply that they are not to accept the help of the coloured people, Negroes and any other sympathizers or that they will not help them in their need, should occasion arise.
('92', 159, 1, 5, 272531) The only condition is that satyagraha should be their one and only weapon.
('92', 159, 1, 6, 272606) If they go astray from the path of non violence, they will conform to the description of the poor woman who as an Indian proverb goes, went in search of a son and succeeded in losing her husband!

('92', 166, 1, 2, 279609) 237. UNCERTIFIED KHADI v.
('92', 166, 1, 3, 279635) MILL CLOTH 1
('92', 166, 2, 4, 279648) A Gujarati friend 2 asks :
('92', 166, 3, 5, 279675) Ever so many national organizations insist that not only should their staff be dressed in khadi, but that even books should be khadi bound.
('92', 166, 3, 6, 279815) Since certified khadi can only be had from the recognized bhandars on payment of a certain quota of yarn, they naturally resort to uncertified khadi.
('92', 166, 3, 7, 279965) Is this right?
('92', 166, 3, 8, 279980) Is not mill cloth preferable to uncertified khadi?
('92', 166, 3, 9, 280031) Is not insistence on khadi that results in buying it from uncertified shops really a false pretence?
('92', 166, 3, 10, 280132) When, among other things, there is a dearth of khadi, it is improper to insist on its use for purposes of bookbinding, etc.
('92', 166, 3, 11, 280256) When there was an abundance of khadi, it was I who recommended its use for all such purposes.
('92', 166, 3, 12, 280350) The entire Congress Camp in Ahmedabad in 1921 was bedecked in khadi.
('92', 166, 3, 13, 280419) Today it would be madness to attempt such a thing.
('92', 166, 3, 14, 280470) Time and circumstances alter methods.
('92', 166, 3, 15, 280508) But I do not understand the writer’s plea for mill cloth as opposed to uncertified khadi.
('92', 166, 3, 16, 280598) What is uncertified khadi?
('92', 166, 3, 17, 280625) Is it not hand spun and hand woven cloth though uncertified?
('92', 166, 3, 18, 280686) That there may be fraud about it is another matter.
('92', 166, 3, 19, 280738) The Charkha Sangh cannot guarantee cent per cent purity in even certified khadi.
('92', 166, 3, 20, 280819) That nothing in this world is proof against deceit has been true throughout the ages.
('92', 166, 3, 21, 280905) Drawbacks in uncertified khadi are well known.
('92', 166, 3, 22, 280952) In it there is no fixity of wages to the spinners and the weavers.
('92', 166, 3, 23, 281019) Those who sell it make what profits they like.
('92', 166, 3, 24, 281066) Often do persons set up shops, merely to spite the Charkha Sangh Bhandars.
('92', 166, 3, 25, 281141) Nevertheless, where there is no fraud, all cloth which is hand spun and hand woven must be called khadi.
('92', 166, 3, 26, 281246) What a person spins and has woven into cloth for himself, is not certified in the legal sense and yet it is khadi in the highest and purest sense of the term.
('92', 166, 3, 27, 281405) It would be a crime on that person’s part to use mill cloth instead of the cloth made from the labour of his own hands.
('92', 166, 3, 28, 281525) The upshot is that exclusion of mill cloth must be maintained.
('92', 166, 3, 29, 281588) Uncertified khadi should be avoided as far as possible, but where certified khadi is not available and the choice lies between mill cloth and uncertified home spun preference should be given to the latter,
('92', 166, 4, 30, 281794) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 22 9 1946. 2 Presumably Vithaldas Kothari; vide “Letter to Vithaldas Kothari”, 9 9 1946.
('92', 167, 0, 1, 281942) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 167, 1, 2, 281984) assuming of course that it is pure khadi.
('92', 167, 1, 3, 282026) You may condemn, if you like, as uncertified, cloth made out of the labour of one’s own hands; but the fact remains that it is a purer production than certified khadi.
('92', 167, 1, 4, 282194) And, if all span enough to have cloth woven for their requirements, what need would there then be for the Charkha Sangh?
('92', 167, 1, 5, 282315) Heaven and earth would then ring with cries of victory to the Charkha Sangh.
('92', 167, 1, 6, 282392) NEW DELHI, September 12, 1946 Harijan, 22 9 1946
('92', 167, 2, 7, 282441) 238. LETTER TO JIVANJI D. DESAI
('92', 167, 3, 8, 282473) NEW DELHI, September 12, 1946
('92', 167, 4, 9, 282503) BHAI JIVANJI, I glanced through Harijanbandhu and Harijan Sevak today.
('92', 167, 4, 10, 282574) I was a little unhappy to see that, while Harijanbandhu has sixteen columns, Harijan Sevak has only eight.
('92', 167, 4, 11, 282681) I don’t understand the reason behind this.
('92', 167, 4, 12, 282724) Maybe you were not able to cope with the Hindustani articles.
('92', 167, 4, 13, 282786) If I go a little deeper into this, I can find out whether or not this guess is correct.
('92', 167, 4, 14, 282874) But I don’t propose to do so.
('92', 167, 4, 15, 282904) I will say only this: that as I have already informed you, you should print only as much Hindustani matter as I send from here and whatever translations you require for Harijanbandhu should be made from Hindustani, never from English.
('92', 167, 4, 16, 283139) Though you have capable translators there to translate from English into Gujarati, I do receive complaints from time to time.
('92', 167, 4, 17, 283265) Hence the best course would be that I should send from here Hindustani and Gujarati translations from English.Or I shall send Hindustani from here and Gujarati you can do there.
('92', 167, 4, 18, 283443) It should be child’s play to translate from Hindustani into Gujarati.
('92', 167, 4, 19, 283513) If, however, there are any complications even in this, let me know.
('92', 167, 4, 20, 283581) We should receive no complaints about translation.
('92', 167, 4, 21, 283632) If we follow this policy there will be no difference in size between Harijan Sevak and Harijanbandhu.
('92', 167, 4, 22, 283734) Our ideal should be to have the same size for all the three.
('92', 167, 4, 23, 283795) It will take us some time to reach this ideal, for many things have to be put across to foreign readers and that can be done only through English.
('92', 167, 4, 24, 283942) I have already written to you about the dictionary and, therefore,
('92', 168, 0, 1, 284009) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 169
('92', 168, 1, 2, 284054) I don’t repeat it here.
('92', 168, 1, 3, 284078) It will be all right if you give four pages every fortnight.
('92', 168, 1, 4, 284139) One column contains nearly forty words, which means 320 words for eight columns.
('92', 168, 1, 5, 284220) I shall be satisfied with that.
('92', 168, 1, 6, 284252) I shall not keep you waiting for it till the last.
('92', 168, 1, 7, 284303) I hope to supply it in good time.
('92', 168, 1, 8, 284337) When I had dictated the above I looked again at Pyarelal’s suggestion and found that the Urdu and Hindi editions of Harijan Sevak are not identical word for word.
('92', 168, 1, 9, 284500) I must of course admit my negligence, namely, that I don’t go through all the issues.
('92', 168, 1, 10, 284586) Certainly I don’t compare them.
('92', 168, 1, 11, 284618) I did so today out of curiosity and discovered this.
('92', 168, 1, 12, 284671) Pyarelal tried to put up some defence for this difference but he has not so far been able to justify it.
('92', 168, 1, 13, 284776) Let us see if he can.
('92', 168, 1, 14, 284798) He told me, however, that the Persian script occupies more space.
('92', 168, 1, 15, 284864) This I knew and, therefore, I started looking into the issues and inspected the issues of September 1. On doing so, I found that the Hindi edition had eight pages whereas Urdu had sixteen and also that Urdu had nineteen articles and Hindi had thirteen.
('92', 168, 1, 16, 285117) I will be glad if you explain to me the reason for this difference.
('92', 168, 1, 17, 285185) If I go further into it, I may discover something more.
('92', 168, 1, 18, 285241) I shall see what I myself can do.
('92', 168, 1, 19, 285275) But I do expect it of you that you will not attempt anything beyond your capacity.
('92', 168, 1, 20, 285358) You will then be able to do full justice to what you do.
('92', 168, 1, 21, 285415) You did very well in sending me the two complaints regarding the dictionary.
('92', 168, 1, 22, 285492) If there are any other complaints, send them too.
('92', 168, 1, 23, 285542) If there are any mistakes, it won’t be difficult to rectify them.
('92', 168, 1, 24, 285608) I will procure a copy of the dictionary which you have mentioned.
('92', 168, 1, 25, 285674) I have told Brijkrishna about it.
('92', 168, 1, 26, 285708) Not revised.

('92', 173, 0, 1, 290669) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 173, 1, 2, 290711) 247. DISCONTINUE IT
('92', 173, 2, 3, 290731) Actionary that Harijan has been publishing already exists and asks why there should be another.
('92', 173, 2, 4, 290827) If the question has substance I should think that Harijan’s labour is wasted.
('92', 173, 2, 5, 290905) If such a work exists it will cause me surprise and pain that none of my co workers told me about it or themselves knew of its existence.
('92', 173, 2, 6, 291043) I am making enquiries and have asked for a copy of the dictionary that has been mentioned.
('92', 173, 2, 7, 291134) If I find I have made a mistake I shall set it right and save the labour.
('92', 173, 2, 8, 291208) Another friend, writing in English, has said the same thing and added that my Hindustani is in fact Urdu and it is making me more and more unpopular in the Hindi world.
('92', 173, 2, 9, 291377) The same is true of the Urdu world, only for the opposite reason.
('92', 173, 2, 10, 291443) The charge here is that in the name of Hindustani I am introducing into Urdu words from Hindi, that is Sanskrit.
('92', 173, 2, 11, 291556) I welcome both charges.
('92', 173, 2, 12, 291580) My Hindustani is neither Urdu nor Hindi.
('92', 173, 2, 13, 291621) It is the mingling of the two.
('92', 173, 2, 14, 291652) The Saraswati that is to flow from the confluence of these two is still invisible.
('92', 173, 2, 15, 291735) Scholars tell me that at one time it had become visible and then it disappeared.
('92', 173, 2, 16, 291816) Be that as it may.
('92', 173, 2, 17, 291835) The idea behind Hindustani Prachar is that the two languages, which have the same grammar but derive their vocabulary from two different sources should not remain separate but should mingle and flow as one stream.
('92', 173, 2, 18, 292049) Whether the effort will succeed or not will depend upon the zeal of those working for it.
('92', 173, 2, 19, 292139) If they put some vigour in their efforts they will not go in vain.
('92', 173, 2, 20, 292206) In the end of course success is in the hands of God.
('92', 173, 2, 21, 292259) And where He is the Doer and the Destroyer, what cause is there for grief and sorrow?
('92', 173, 2, 22, 292345) And is the purpose of the effort to gain popularity?
('92', 173, 2, 23, 292398) A public servant is not flattered by praise nor frightened by censure.
('92', 173, 2, 24, 292469) He who swells with applause and droops with criticism cannot render service.
('92', 173, 2, 25, 292546) The reward of the worker lies in the work he does.
('92', 173, 2, 26, 292597) I would therefore request my critics that, rather than criticize me, they should help in this noble cause and enlarge and enrich the language written and spoken by the masses of such a vast country as India.
('92', 173, 2, 27, 292805) Then both the sister languages Hindi and Urdu will shine and India will advance.
('92', 173, 2, 28, 292886) It will not offend God if I call Him Khuda or Ishwar and my knowledge of that Supreme Power will increase.
('92', 173, 2, 29, 292993) What quarrel can one have with
('92', 174, 0, 1, 293024) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 175
('92', 174, 1, 2, 293069) a person who respects both the languages and wants to unite the two?

('92', 174, 2, 4, 293209) 248. GUJARAT—PROUD OR INSANE?
('92', 174, 3, 5, 293239) Who would not like Gujarat to be described as proud?
('92', 174, 3, 6, 293292) One might in jest also describe Gujarat as insane.

('92', 174, 3, 8, 293442) Shri Parikshitlal is a servant of Harijans but how can he cope with the mad Gujarat?

('92', 174, 3, 10, 293597) On the cremation ground at any rate all should be one.
('92', 174, 3, 11, 293652) Once the dead body is reduced to ashes any impurity in it is also burnt up.
('92', 174, 3, 12, 293728) Nevertheless Harijans have not the right to burn their dead on the cremation ground.
('92', 174, 3, 13, 293813) It required much effort to persuade the mahajan of Navasari to let an old Harijan be cremated on the common cremation ground.
('92', 174, 3, 14, 293939) How culd it be called a favour?

('92', 174, 3, 16, 294012) “In a treeless country the castor oil plant is honoured.” Similarly when a Harijan body was allowed to be cremated on the cremationground, the event was eulogized.
('92', 174, 3, 17, 294176) It was justified.
('92', 174, 3, 18, 294194) The result was good.
('92', 174, 3, 19, 294215) Then there is another case, which is wholly tragic.Shri Parikshitlal has furnished me the name and other particulars of the village which I shall not give here.
('92', 174, 3, 20, 294376) 2 The reprehensible part of it is that when cattle die of an epidemic the Harijans are held responsible.
('92', 174, 3, 21, 294481) The so called savarna Hindus do not even bother to see the obvious cause of the mortality among the livestock.
('92', 174, 3, 22, 294592) When there are rains grass comes up.
('92', 174, 3, 23, 294629) It is infested with insects.
('92', 174, 3, 24, 294658) The starved cattle go mad at the sight of the grass and devour it, insects and all.
('92', 174, 3, 25, 294742) Then they sicken and die.
('92', 174, 3, 26, 294768) The cause is thus obvious and Harijans’cattle suffer no less.
('92', 174, 3, 27, 294830) And yet the Harijans are held responsible and they are subjected to abuses and beatings by the caste Hindus.
('92', 174, 3, 28, 294939) Such is the woeful tale the letter before me contains.
('92', 174, 3, 29, 294994) I wish my words could reach the villagers concerned.
('92', 174, 3, 30, 295047) Now that the reformers hold the reins of the Government, the
('92', 174, 4, 31, 295108) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 22 9 1946, under the title “Proud or Insane”.

('92', 175, 1, 2, 295301) villages can be rid of much of the ignorance if the officials will make the effort.
('92', 175, 1, 3, 295385) If the mahajans shed their superstition, if the Harijans wake up and the Government and Harijan Sevaks do their duty their is a chance that Gujarat can be freed of this evil.

('92', 176, 4, 5, 296535) I send this letter to you in English.
('92', 176, 4, 6, 296573) So far as I am aware you are a bankrupt concern if what Ramprasad has told me is true.

('92', 176, 4, 17, 297369) You cannot have it mechanically.
('92', 176, 4, 18, 297402) It is not like a quinine pill or sun bath.
('92', 176, 4, 19, 297445) It stands on its own and by itself.
('92', 176, 4, 20, 297481) I can understand and appreciate your objection to Ahuramazda because of the bad associations.
('92', 176, 4, 21, 297575) Hence it is that we describe God as long suffering and patient beyond human endurance.
('92', 176, 4, 22, 297662) Just now you must swear by your injections and pills although you are a trustee for nature cure.

('92', 177, 1, 2, 297955) 252. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('92', 177, 2, 3, 297986) NEW DELHI, September 13, 1946
('92', 177, 3, 4, 298016) NARANDAS, I got your letter.
('92', 177, 3, 5, 298045) I will write and send something for the Rentiabaras.
('92', 177, 3, 6, 298098) 1 It will be published in the Harijanbandhu of the 22nd 2. I will, therefore, send you a copy of what I write.
('92', 177, 3, 7, 298209) You must meet the demand for the equipment.
('92', 177, 3, 8, 298253) There are two ways of securing the wood.
('92', 177, 3, 9, 298294) You should collect or buy up old and disused furniture from people.
('92', 177, 3, 10, 298362) The other way is to use the minimum quantity of wood in making the equipment.
('92', 177, 3, 11, 298440) The box charkha is a development of the Gandiva, and the latter can be set up on anywhere if you have but the two wheels.
('92', 177, 3, 12, 298562) For instance, it can be set up a desk or on a parapet and one can easily spin on it standing.
('92', 177, 3, 13, 298656) At any rate one can spin sitting.
('92', 177, 3, 14, 298690) I had tried all these methods in Yeravda jail and found them suitable.
('92', 177, 3, 15, 298761) In some jails there are cement platforms, covered with wooden boards, to sleep on.
('92', 177, 3, 16, 298844) I used to place the Gandiva on the board.
('92', 177, 3, 17, 298886) Then I had tried and made a charkha from deodar strips obtained from packing cases.
('92', 177, 3, 18, 298970) I think I had even brought it to Sabarmati.
('92', 177, 3, 19, 299014) Ultimately we have to work in the villages for the poor and should, as far as possible, acquire even in cities only such things as can be introduced in villages.
('92', 177, 3, 20, 299176) Think over the matter from this point of view.
('92', 177, 3, 21, 299223) I have written to Kishorelal about a man.
('92', 177, 3, 22, 299265) I have received about five names.
('92', 177, 3, 23, 299299) We cannot trouble Mavalankar.

('92', 179, 6, 13, 301445) 256. COLLECTIVE PRAYER
('92', 179, 7, 14, 301468) Q. You believe in mass prayer.
('92', 179, 7, 15, 301499) It congregational worship as practised today a true prayer?
('92', 179, 7, 16, 301559) In my opinion, it is a degrading thing and therefore dangerous.
('92', 179, 7, 17, 301623) Jesus said: “When thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are, but enter into thine inner chamber and having shut thy door pray to the Father which is in secret.” Most people in a crowd are inattentive and unable to concentrate.
('92', 179, 7, 18, 301862) Prayer then becomes hypocrisy.
('92', 179, 7, 19, 301893) The yogi is aware of this.
('92', 179, 7, 20, 301920) Should not the masses, therefore, be taught self examination which is the true prayer?
('92', 179, 8, 21, 302007) A. I hold that congregational worship held by me is true prayer for a collection of men.
('92', 179, 8, 22, 302096) The convener is a believer and no hypocrite.
('92', 179, 8, 23, 302141) If he were one, the prayer would be tainted at the source.
('92', 179, 8, 24, 302200) The men and women who attend do not go to any orthodox prayer house from which they might have to gain an earthly end.
('92', 179, 8, 25, 302319) The bulk of them have no contact with the convener.
('92', 179, 8, 26, 302371) Hence it is presumed, they do not come for show.
('92', 179, 8, 27, 302420) They join in because they believe that they somehow or other, acquire merit by having common prayer.
('92', 179, 8, 28, 302521) That most or some persons are inattentive or unable to concentrate is very true.
('92', 179, 8, 29, 302602) That merely shows that they are beginners.
('92', 179, 8, 30, 302645) Neither inattention nor inability to concentrate are any proof of hypocrisy or falsity.
('92', 179, 8, 31, 302733) It would be, if
('92', 180, 0, 1, 302749) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 181
('92', 180, 1, 2, 302794) they pretended to be attentive when they were not.
('92', 180, 1, 3, 302845) On the contrary, many have often asked me what they should do, when they are unable to concentrate.
('92', 180, 1, 4, 302945) The saying of Jesus quoted in the question is wholly inapplicable.
('92', 180, 1, 5, 303012) Jesus was referring to individual prayer and to hypocrisy underlying it.
('92', 180, 1, 6, 303085) There is nothing in the verse quoted against collective prayer.
('92', 180, 1, 7, 303149) I have remarked often enough that without individual prayer collective prayer is not of much use.
('92', 180, 1, 8, 303247) I hold that individual prayer is a prelude to collective, as the latter, when it is effective, must lead to the individual.
('92', 180, 1, 9, 303371) In other words, when a man has got to the stage of heart prayer, he prays always, whether in the secret or in the multitude.
('92', 180, 1, 10, 303496) I do not know what the questioner’s yogi does or does not.
('92', 180, 1, 11, 303555) I know that the masses when they are in tune with the Infinite, naturally resort to self examination.
('92', 180, 1, 12, 303657) All real prayer must have that end.
('92', 180, 1, 13, 303693) NEW DELHI, September 14, 1946 Harijan, 22 9 1946
('92', 180, 2, 14, 303742) 257. NOTES
('92', 180, 3, 15, 303753) BLANK MINUTE BOOKS A student writes :
('92', 180, 4, 16, 303791) It has become a fashion for all to pose as political workers.
('92', 180, 4, 17, 303853) And politics consist in speeches and participation in election campaigns.
('92', 180, 4, 18, 303927) You would be pained to know that the minute books of Congress Committees are entirely blank, except for proceedings of annual sittings.
('92', 180, 4, 19, 304063) It is all power politics.
('92', 180, 4, 20, 304089) Students also get drawn into its vertex.
('92', 180, 4, 21, 304130) What is your ideal of a political worker?
('92', 180, 4, 22, 304172) I have all along stressed the need for constructive work and to that end, I drew up a list of items for the guidance of all workers.
('92', 180, 4, 23, 304305) I hold that if the constructive programme were worked with vigour and understanding, the result would be far more than mere political swaraj.
('92', 180, 4, 24, 304447) Speeches and election campaigns would be almost unnecessary if our workers established the Congress in the hearts of the people through service.
('92', 180, 4, 25, 304592) Then there will be more service than power and the weekly or fortnightly meetings of Congress committees will be filled with a recital of the activities and achievements of committees in the wide field of work.
('92', 181, 0, 1, 304803) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 181, 1, 2, 304845) IS IT NOT COWARDICE ?
('92', 181, 2, 3, 304867) Q. Non violence in your opinion is not cowardice, but it is a form of resistance to injustice.
('92', 181, 2, 4, 304962) You have admitted that it is wrong to arrest and imprison innocent persons which civil resisters are.
('92', 181, 2, 5, 305064) And you have cheerfully courted arrest and imprisonment.
('92', 181, 2, 6, 305121) Is this not inconsistent and cowardly?
('92', 181, 3, 7, 305160) A. Evidently you do not know the working of non violence.
('92', 181, 3, 8, 305218) An unjust law is itself a species of violence.
('92', 181, 3, 9, 305265) Arrest for its breach is more so.
('92', 181, 3, 10, 305299) Now the law of non violence says that violence should be resisted not by counter violence but by non violence.
('92', 181, 3, 11, 305410) Any breach of a law carries with it a penalty.
('92', 181, 3, 12, 305457) It does not become unjust merely because I say so.
('92', 181, 3, 13, 305508) Nevertheless, in my opinion, it is unjust.
('92', 181, 3, 14, 305551) The State has the right to enforce it, whilst it is on the statute book.
('92', 181, 3, 15, 305624) I must resist it non violently.
('92', 181, 3, 16, 305656) This I do by breaking the law and by peacefully submitting to arrest and imprisonment.
('92', 181, 3, 17, 305743) I call such behaviour an act of bravery to the extent required.
('92', 181, 3, 18, 305807) That imprisonment for a man like me today carries no suffering with it is irrelevant, if it may be assumed that ordinary prison treatment would make no difference in my mental condition.
('92', 181, 3, 19, 305994) Thus non resistance in the case under discussion is an essential condition of non violence, not a symptom of cowardice.
('92', 181, 3, 20, 306114) Resistance in the shape of refusing to be arrested etc., on the other hand, will in this case be certainly blustering, thoughtless violence and might be classified as cowardly brag.
('92', 181, 3, 21, 306296) NEW DELHI, September 14, 1946 Harijan, 22 9 1946
('92', 181, 4, 22, 306345) 258. CHARKHA JAYANTI 1
('92', 181, 5, 23, 306368) What is known as Charkha Jayanti is not Gandhi Jayanti.
('92', 181, 5, 24, 306424) It is true it has become linked with my birthday, but the reason for this is clear.
('92', 181, 5, 25, 306508) Formerly the charkha bore no relation to freedom.
('92', 181, 5, 26, 306558) If anything it stood for the slavery that lay behind it.
('92', 181, 5, 27, 306615) For a crust of bread our women had to go through the drudgery of spinning.
('92', 181, 5, 28, 306690) They span and a few cowries or pies were thrown to them each day.
('92', 181, 5, 29, 306756) I remember watching, in my childhood, the Thakore Saheb of Rajkot throw to the
('92', 181, 6, 30, 306835) 1 A translation of this also appeared in Harijan, 22 9 1946.
('92', 182, 0, 1, 306896) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 183
('92', 182, 1, 2, 306941) poor on the Shili Satam 1 day.
('92', 182, 1, 3, 306972) I considered this throwing of money a game and it was fun to watch the game.
('92', 182, 1, 4, 307049) I can imagine how, much in the same way, cowries must have been thrown to women spinners for their yarn and how greedily they must have pounced on them.
('92', 182, 1, 5, 307202) It was in 1908, in South Africa, that the idea came to me that if the poor of India were to be delivered from serfdom, we would have to learn to look upon the charkha, and the yarn produced on the charkha, not as a symbol of slavery but as a symbol of freedom and plenty.
('92', 182, 1, 6, 307474) The person who to my knowledge understood this most fully was Narandas Gandhi.
('92', 182, 1, 7, 307553) From this he understood the significance of the Charkha Jayanti.
('92', 182, 1, 8, 307618) Before the date Bhadarva Vad 12 became associated with the charkha neither he nor anyone else, to my knowledge, had celebrated that day as my birthday.
('92', 182, 1, 9, 307770) I was well known among the people in South Africa but I do not recollect anyone there celebrating my birthday.
('92', 182, 1, 10, 307881) It was only here that the charkha was associated with it and Charkha Jayanti began to be observed on the day.
('92', 182, 1, 11, 307991) It was then thought that my birthday according to the Western Calendar should also be observed and so two days, namely Bhadarva Vad 12 and October 2, came to be observed as Charkha Jayanti.
('92', 182, 1, 12, 308181) Narandas took, as he still does, a leading part in all this.
('92', 182, 1, 13, 308242) As I write this I can remember the observances in Rajkot on Bhadarva Vad 12 and October 2. But Charkha Jayanti will be truly observed when the charkha, which is the symbol of freedom and ahimsa, hums in every home.
('92', 182, 1, 14, 308457) What can the observance signify if a few poor women, or even a million poor women, spin to earn a pittance?
('92', 182, 1, 15, 308565) What great work will have been accomplished?
('92', 182, 1, 16, 308610) This is possible even under a tyrannical regime and is indeed the normal thing in the capitalist system.
('92', 182, 1, 17, 308715) The doles given to the poor help in sustaining the affluence of the millionaires, even if such doles be in the form of wages.
('92', 182, 1, 18, 308841) The observance will have meaning only when both the rich and the poor understand that all created alike by God, that all must work to attain glory and that the freedom of all will be protected not by guns but by the ball of yarn, not by violence but by non violence.
('92', 182, 1, 19, 309108) If we consider the atmosphere of the world today, what I have
('92', 182, 2, 20, 309170) 1 The seventh day of the moon in the month of Shravan, observed as the day of Shitala, the goddess of smallpox
('92', 183, 0, 1, 309281) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 183, 1, 2, 309323) said above will sound ludicrous.
('92', 183, 1, 3, 309356) But if we think deeply, this alone is right; this alone is true for all time.
('92', 183, 1, 4, 309434) For the present it is only devotees of the charkha like Narandas who show this faith.
('92', 183, 1, 5, 309520) Let us all observe Charkha Jayanti and October 2 in a similar spirit.
('92', 183, 1, 6, 309590) NEW DELHI, September 14, 1946 [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 22 9 1946
('92', 183, 2, 7, 309661) 259. AN APPEAL TO CORRESPONDENTS 1
('92', 183, 3, 8, 309696) Some good people waste money on sending wires, asking me to secure seats on the Interim Government, others regarding strikes in various places, yet others on matters of fasting.
('92', 183, 3, 9, 309874) To all these I would say that they not only take unnecessary trouble and waste money but pile work on an over worked group of co workers and helpers, without securing needed help from me.
('92', 183, 3, 10, 310062) I have no wish to influence the National Cabinet in the choice of co ministers and I hold that it would be wrong on my part or anybody else’s to do so.
('92', 183, 3, 11, 310214) The members of the Cabinet should be left undisturbed in their choice if they are to render national service in an efficient and honest manner.
('92', 183, 3, 12, 310358) In matters of strikes and fasts, my views are well known.

('92', 183, 4, 19, 310811) 260. VILLAGE UNIVERSITY
('92', 183, 5, 20, 310835) Dr. Kini has been a secretary in the education department in Mysore.
('92', 183, 5, 21, 310904) He has sent a very long article for Harijan.
('92', 183, 5, 22, 310949) His contention is that India is poor and has remained so because the Government has kept the poor of the villages away from right education.
('92', 183, 5, 23, 311090) He believes that the existing colleges and universities in our cities cannot serve our
('92', 183, 6, 24, 311177) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.
('92', 184, 0, 1, 311220) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 185
('92', 184, 1, 2, 311265) villages because the education imparted in these is designed to advance western influence and it is difficult to introduce education that will be of use to the villages.
('92', 184, 1, 3, 311435) Dr. Kini is of the opinion that there should be village universities for the villagers where adults also can study.
('92', 184, 1, 4, 311551) Dr. Kini writes to say that the village universities should provide instruction in agriculture, horticulture, village sericulture, animal husbandry, poultry farming, bee keeping, fishery, khadi industry, rural sanitation and hygiene, rural electrical engineering, rural roads and transport, rural home economics, rural pottery, rural economics, rural sociology, rural reconstruction, rural trade, rural bullion and banking, etc.
('92', 184, 1, 5, 311980) If all these subjects were taught in the villages as sciences, the writer feels that the face of rural India would be changed.
('92', 184, 1, 6, 312107) The villages then would not have to look to the cities for help but on the contrary the cities would have to look to the villages for help.
('92', 184, 1, 7, 312247) I have just given a gist of Dr. Kini’s article.
('92', 184, 1, 8, 312295) If the Central and the Provincial cabinets accept his suggestions a great thing can be achieved.
('92', 184, 1, 9, 312392) To give his proposals a concrete shape, Dr. Kini should consult Dr. Zakir Husain and the Aryanayakums.
('92', 184, 1, 10, 312495) I personally believe that even urban universities can be changed.

('92', 188, 8, 15, 316482) 269. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 188, 9, 16, 316514) NEW DELHI, September 15, 1946
('92', 188, 10, 17, 316544) Gandhiji said that the sight of 144 of them attending the spinning classes 2
('92', 188, 11, 18, 316621) daily in the fullness of faith, made him hug the hope that one day the whole of India would be clad in khadi.
('92', 188, 11, 19, 316731) When he started the spinning revival in 1918, India was buying 60 crores worth of foreign cloth excluding Indian mill cloth.
('92', 188, 11, 20, 316856) This was the largest single import.
('92', 188, 11, 21, 316892) Next came sugar with 18 crores and then hardware with 7 crores.
('92', 188, 11, 22, 316956) Today, with the inflated prices the price of all mill cloth, indigenous and foreign, was probably 300 crores.
('92', 188, 11, 23, 317066) Gandhiji asked his audience to ponder and realize what wealth this would mean to India, if 300 crores worth of cloth was produced by their own hands in the villages.
('92', 188, 11, 24, 317232) There was a veritable mint of gold for them and if khadi became universal, the villages would rise to unknown heights.
('92', 188, 11, 25, 317351) Today our masses were poverty stricken, without the lustre of hope or intelligence in their eyes.
('92', 188, 11, 26, 317449) The pure hands of the spinners could create this miracle for them and everyone could help.
('92', 188, 11, 27, 317540) They should have understanding hearts and seeing eyes to detect the beauty in khaddar even if it is coarse and not be allured by mill finery which could never clothe their nakedness in the true sense of the term.
('92', 188, 11, 28, 317753) The only way to clothe their nakedness and drive away hunger was for them to grow their own food and make their own cloth.
('92', 188, 12, 29, 317876) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly letter”.
('92', 188, 12, 30, 317921) A report of the speech was also published in The Hindustan Times, 16 9 1946. 2 Under the eleven day spinning course organized by Kanu Gandhi
('92', 189, 0, 1, 318062) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 189, 1, 2, 318104) If this happy consummation could be achieved, the eyes of the whole world would be turned towards India.
('92', 189, 1, 3, 318209) Today everything seemed to be going wrong in this land.
('92', 189, 1, 4, 318265) He referred to the story that had appeared in the Press of the mad gunmen in Bombay who caused death of several innocent people.
('92', 189, 1, 5, 318394) This shameful news must have been flashed over the radio to the world and they must hang their heads in sorrow.
('92', 189, 1, 6, 318506) But, said Gandhiji, if they would only listen to him, all would be well with India.
('92', 189, 1, 7, 318590) If all purified themselves and all thought of themselves as Indians, then they would have succeeded in learning the true lesson of the charkha.
('92', 189, 1, 8, 318734) Harijan, 22 9 1946
('92', 189, 2, 9, 318753) 270. TALK WITH A CHRISTIAN MISSIONARY 1
('92', 189, 3, 10, 318793) NEW DELHI, [Before September 16, 1946] If I were a dictator, religion and State would be separate.
('92', 189, 3, 11, 318892) I swear by my religion.
('92', 189, 3, 12, 318916) I will die for it.
('92', 189, 3, 13, 318935) But it is my personal affair.
('92', 189, 3, 14, 318965) The State has nothing to do with it.
('92', 189, 3, 15, 319002) 2 The State would look after your secular welfare, health, communications, foreign relations, currency and so on, but not your or my religion.
('92', 189, 3, 16, 319145) That is everybody’s personal concern!
('92', 189, 3, 17, 319183) You must watch my life, how I live, eat, sit, talk, behave in general.
('92', 189, 3, 18, 319254) The sum total of all those in me is my religion.
('92', 189, 4, 19, 319303) Asked which movement, e.
('92', 189, 4, 20, 319328) g., women’s, political, scientific or religious, would have had the most far reaching influence in the world of tomorrow and would be considered 50 years hence as having had the greatest impact on world affairs as a whole and for the greatest good of mankind, he said it was wrong to bracket religious movement with the rest.
('92', 189, 4, 21, 319654) He said : It is the religious movement that will dominate the future.
('92', 189, 4, 22, 319724) It would do so today but it does not, for religion has been reduced to a Saturday or a Sunday affair; it has to be lived every moment of one’s life.
('92', 189, 4, 23, 319873) Such religion, when it comes, will dominate the world.
('92', 189, 5, 24, 319928) Q. Do you feel there is any special significance in the increasing number and magnitude of labour strikes, especially in India of late?
('92', 189, 5, 25, 320064) What do you think will be the outcome of this labour trouble in India?
('92', 189, 6, 26, 320135) A. Strikes have today become a universal plague.
('92', 189, 6, 27, 320184) there are
('92', 189, 7, 28, 320194) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 16 9 1946 2 The missionary had asked whether in free India religion would be separate from the State.
('92', 190, 0, 1, 320341) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 191
('92', 190, 1, 2, 320386) strikes everywhere, America and England not excepted.
('92', 190, 1, 3, 320440) But in India they have a special significance.
('92', 190, 1, 4, 320487) We are living under an unnatural condition.
('92', 190, 1, 5, 320531) As soon as the lid is removed and there is a crevice letting in the fresh air of freedom, there will be an increasing number of strikes.
('92', 190, 1, 6, 320668) The fundamental reason for this spreading strike fever is that life here as elsewhere is today uprooted from its basis, the basis of religion, and what an English writer has called ‘cash nexus’ has taken its place.
('92', 190, 1, 7, 320883) And that is a precarious bond.
('92', 190, 1, 8, 320914) But even when the religious basis is there, there will be strikes, because it is scarcely conceivable that religion will have become for all the basis of life.
('92', 190, 1, 9, 321074) So there will be attempts at exploitation on the one hand and strikes on the other.
('92', 190, 1, 10, 321158) But these strikes will then be of a purely non violent character.
('92', 190, 1, 11, 321224) Such strikes never do harm to anyone.
('92', 190, 1, 12, 321262) It was such a strike perhaps that brought General Smuts to his knees.“If you had hurt an Englishman,” said Jan Smuts, “I would have shot you, even deported your people.
('92', 190, 1, 13, 321431) As it is, I have put you in prison and tried to subdue you and your people in every way.
('92', 190, 1, 14, 321520) But how long can I go on like this when you do not retaliate?” And so he had to come to terms with a mere coolie on behalf of coolies as all Indians were then called in South Africa.
('92', 190, 1, 15, 321703) Harijan, 22 9 1946
('92', 190, 2, 16, 321722) 271. POOR OR SMALL COUNTRIES
('92', 190, 3, 17, 321751) Shri Chandrashankar, basing himself on well known English writers, has very ably described for Harijan the plight of the small countries during war time.
('92', 190, 3, 18, 321905) 1 I give here the gist of it.
('92', 190, 3, 19, 321935) The Gujarati readers are not going to benefit much by its translation.
('92', 190, 3, 20, 322006) What will they gain by knowing the names of English writers?
('92', 190, 3, 21, 322067) It will be enough if we know what views eminent writers of contemporary Europe hold on war.
('92', 190, 3, 22, 322159) They say that a time has come when only big and wealthy countries can fight a war.
('92', 190, 3, 23, 322242) They have the money and the armed forces.
('92', 190, 3, 24, 322284) The big nations either swallow up the small nations or wipe them out.
('92', 190, 3, 25, 322354) Besides, the small nations are not able to manufacture armaments.
('92', 190, 3, 26, 322420) They buy them from big nations and have to procure even spare parts from them.
('92', 190, 3, 27, 322499) In the result small nations end up by becoming
('92', 190, 4, 28, 322546) 1 Chandrashankar Shukla’s article “What Can Poor Nations Do?” appeared in Harijan, 13 10 46.
('92', 191, 0, 1, 322639) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 191, 1, 2, 322681) subservient to big nations.
('92', 191, 1, 3, 322709) Very often, whether they wish it or not, small nations are forced to buy arms from big nations.
('92', 191, 1, 4, 322805) For example, when a big nation owes money to a small nation, it repays neither in cash nor in goods but in arms.
('92', 191, 1, 5, 322918) Accepting such arms has only one implication for a small nation, namely, that it has become a vassal of the big nation.
('92', 191, 1, 6, 323038) The writers conclude that the time has come when small nations cannot have independent existence.
('92', 191, 1, 7, 323136) They may well believe that triumph will not be of truth but of those who have the arms, the money and the bombs.
('92', 191, 1, 8, 323249) But if we have faith, we will proclaim that in the end truth will prevail, never untruth.
('92', 191, 1, 9, 323339) Experience also teaches this.
('92', 191, 1, 10, 323369) NEW DELHI, September 16, 1946 [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 13 10 1946

('92', 192, 1, 2, 324224) 273. RAMA THE SON OF DASHARATHA 1
('92', 192, 2, 3, 324258) An Arya Samajist writes :
('92', 192, 3, 4, 324284) How can the Rama whom you believe to be undying, be the Rama who is the son of Dasharatha and the husband of Sita?
('92', 192, 3, 5, 324399) Tormented by the doubt, I do join your prayers but take no part in singing the Ramdhun.
('92', 192, 3, 6, 324487) This irks me for you say that everyone should join in singing and you are right.
('92', 192, 3, 7, 324568) Could you not so modify the Ramdhun that all can join in it.
('92', 192, 3, 8, 324629) I have already explained what I mean by everyone.
('92', 192, 3, 9, 324679) It means everyone who can join heartily and sing in unison.
('92', 192, 3, 10, 324739) The others should remain silent.
('92', 192, 3, 11, 324772) But this is of small importance.
('92', 192, 3, 12, 324805) The more important question is how Dasharatha’s son can be imagined as undying.
('92', 192, 3, 13, 324885) Tulsidas himself has raised the question and answered it.
('92', 192, 3, 14, 324943) Such questions cannot be answered by the intellect or to the satisfaction of the intellect.
('92', 192, 3, 15, 325035) This is a matter of the heart and the heart alone knows the ways of the heart.
('92', 192, 3, 16, 325114) I first worshipped Rama as Sita’s Lord but, as realization and experience grew, my Rama became undying and all pervasive.
('92', 192, 3, 17, 325236) This means that He continued to be Sita’s Lord but the content of that description was enlarged.
('92', 192, 3, 18, 325333) This is how the world goes on.
('92', 192, 3, 19, 325364) The Rama of the man who conceives him merely as Dasharatha’s son cannot be all pervasive.
('92', 192, 3, 20, 325454) But to the man for whom Rama is all pervasive, Dasharatha also becomes all pervasive.
('92', 192, 3, 21, 325540) It may be said that this is all arbitrary, “to each man according to his faith”.
('92', 192, 3, 22, 325621) But I see no other way.
('92', 192, 3, 23, 325645) If all religions are essentially one, we have to harmonize them.
('92', 192, 3, 24, 325710) Today they are kept separate and that is why we kill each other.
('92', 192, 3, 25, 325775) When we are tired of religion, we become atheists and then our ego alone is left and nothing else, not even God.
('92', 192, 3, 26, 325888) But when we acquire true understanding, the ego perishes and God alone remains.
('92', 192, 3, 27, 325968) Rama then is and is not the son of Dasharatha, the Lord of Sita, the brother of Bharata and Lakshamana.
('92', 192, 3, 28, 326072) All honour then to those who not believing in Rama, the son of Dasharatha, still join the prayers.
('92', 192, 3, 29, 326171) This is not rationalism.
('92', 192, 3, 30, 326196) I have merely outlined what I do and what I believe.
('92', 192, 3, 31, 326249) NEW DELHI, September 16, 1946 [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 22 9 1946
('92', 192, 4, 32, 326317) 1 A translation of this also appeared in Harijan, 22 9 1946.

('92', 193, 1, 2, 326420) 274. TRACTORS v.
('92', 193, 1, 3, 326437) BULLOCKS 1
('92', 193, 2, 4, 326448) Under this heading Mirabehn has written an article for Harijan.
('92', 193, 2, 5, 326512) Since it merits consideration I give a gist of it below : Some people say that there should be no mechanical ploughs or tractors.
('92', 193, 2, 6, 326642) They require large fields.
('92', 193, 2, 7, 326669) In the long run the soil is ruined as it does not get cow dung manure and also the cattle are rendered useless.
('92', 193, 2, 8, 326781) Mirabehn admits that there is substance in the argument.
('92', 193, 2, 9, 326838) But in reply she says that in U. P. alone there are 79 lakh acres of fallow land.
('92', 193, 2, 10, 326920) Almost all the provinces have such fallow land.
('92', 193, 2, 11, 326968) It is difficult to plough such land with the help of bullocks and even if it was done it would take years to bring it under cultivation.
('92', 193, 2, 12, 327105) So she says that to start with such land should be broken with tractors.
('92', 193, 2, 13, 327178) This can be done immediately.
('92', 193, 2, 14, 327208) For the rest bullocks should be used.
('92', 193, 2, 15, 327246) We would thus be making a legitimate and limited use of tractors and this would cause no harm.
('92', 193, 2, 16, 327341) She agrees that using tractors permanently would be harmful.
('92', 193, 2, 17, 327402) Also she says the tractors are imported from abroad and trained personnel are needed to operate them.
('92', 193, 2, 18, 327504) Besides tractors require other implements.
('92', 193, 2, 19, 327547) At the moment our country is not ready for that and it should never be.
('92', 193, 2, 20, 327619) NEW DELHI, September 16, 1946 [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 29 9 1946
('92', 193, 3, 21, 327687) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.

('92', 199, 1, 2, 333277) 285. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI
('92', 199, 2, 3, 333308) NEW DELHI, September 17, 1946
('92', 199, 3, 4, 333338) JAMNADAS, I am glad you have written a long full letter after many days.
('92', 199, 3, 5, 333411) I agree with your view as regards students.
('92', 199, 3, 6, 333455) But who is to bell the cat?
('92', 199, 3, 7, 333483) Lilavati Munshi has discussed at length the question whether they should give one year or more for public work.
('92', 199, 3, 8, 333595) But who will persuade the students!
('92', 199, 3, 9, 333631) You yourself are weak.
('92', 199, 3, 10, 333654) Besides, you think too much and hence nothing tangible is achieved by you.
('92', 199, 3, 11, 333729) Others do not think, nor do they influence students.
('92', 199, 3, 12, 333782) Those who can influence students believe in the kind of work you write about and all of them honestly hold the opinions they express.
('92', 199, 3, 13, 333916) Such is the prevailing confusion.
('92', 199, 3, 14, 333950) And it is not confined to this country but prevails throughout the world as one can see from the papers.
('92', 199, 3, 15, 334055) Now tell me, what we should do.
('92', 199, 3, 16, 334087) What you write about the happenings in Bombay and other places is correct.
('92', 199, 3, 17, 334162) But the idea you have expressed appears to me to be rather immature.
('92', 199, 3, 18, 334231) If there were two parties, one calm and the other agitated, I have no doubt that the former would stand to gain in the absence of the police and the military.
('92', 199, 3, 19, 334390) This you can say, that no one barring me would carry on without the police or the military.
('92', 199, 3, 20, 334482) Mine is a voice in the wilderness.
('92', 199, 3, 21, 334517) Indeed I need and I yearn for clearer vision, greater penance and greater courage.
('92', 199, 3, 22, 334600) But can it all come for the yearning?
('92', 199, 3, 23, 334638) Isn’t it a fact that “the fifth and the last factor is the Unseen” 1?
('92', 199, 3, 24, 334708) This is the truth.
('92', 199, 3, 25, 334727) Let us therefore cling to devout faith and hope for human effort and Divine grace.
('92', 199, 3, 26, 334810) The effort should be sincere.
('92', 199, 3, 27, 334840) I can elaborate further.
('92', 199, 3, 28, 334865) But where do I have the time?
('92', 199, 3, 29, 334895) Sushila will write about what she was given to read.
('92', 199, 3, 30, 334948) I don’t let her have much time either.
('92', 199, 3, 31, 334987) If I can organize things better or if they settle down themselves, I shall get some more time.
('92', 199, 3, 32, 335082) There is much work to do.
('92', 199, 3, 33, 335108) God’s will be done.
('92', 199, 3, 34, 335128) Are you keeping well?
('92', 199, 3, 35, 335150) How are Santok and Radha?
('92', 199, 4, 36, 335176) Blessings from BAPU
('92', 199, 5, 37, 335196) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('92', 199, 5, 38, 335242) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('92', 199, 6, 39, 335261) 1 Bhagavad Gita xviii, 14; the other four being the field, the doer, the various means and several different operations

('92', 203, 7, 11, 338441) 293. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 203, 8, 12, 338471) NEW DELHI, September 18, 1946 A U. S. Army general came to visit me a little before the prayer this evening.
('92', 203, 8, 13, 338580) I was spinning at the time.
('92', 203, 8, 14, 338608) As you all know the charkha to me is an inseparable companion.
('92', 203, 8, 15, 338671) Whether I went to jail or journeyed to England, the charkha went with me.
('92', 203, 8, 16, 338745) I laughingly told the American friend that since he would soon be going back to the U. S. A. he should tell his compatriots that Gandhi intended to defeat them with his puny spindles.
('92', 203, 8, 17, 338929) The general laughed heartily at this but he understood the economic necessity of everyone producing to satisfy his own wants.
('92', 203, 8, 18, 339055) This is what I meant by defeating the U. S. A. Today India has to import cloth because, for our own fault, we do not have enough cloth in India.
('92', 203, 8, 19, 339200) It will be a real victory for us when we can, without depending on mills, produce enough cloth to meet our requirements.
('92', 203, 8, 20, 339321) This cannot be done through use of force.
('92', 203, 8, 21, 339363) People should be able to look after their primary needs.
('92', 203, 8, 22, 339420) If it is folly to look to others for the foodgrains we need, it is equally folly to depend on others for our requirements of cloth.
('92', 203, 8, 23, 339552) In doing this we go against the principles of natural living and that because we are too lazy.
('92', 203, 8, 24, 339647) Laziness is a sin that makes us stray from
('92', 203, 9, 25, 339690) 1 Name assumed by Baldev Chaube, a village worker who had founded a Harijan Gurukul in Dehrighat, Distt.
('92', 203, 9, 26, 339795) Azamgarh, U. P. 2 Vide “Letter to Dharmanand Kosambi”,15 9 1946.
('92', 204, 0, 1, 339860) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 205
('92', 204, 1, 2, 339905) our purpose.
('92', 204, 1, 3, 339918) He alone is a wise man who makes full use of every minute of every day of his time.
('92', 204, 1, 4, 340002) If we can but be self reliant in food and clothing we shall be at peace with the whole world.
('92', 204, 1, 5, 340096) It is thus in the charkha that genuine freedom is to be found.
('92', 204, 1, 6, 340159) The charkha is necessary for villages as well as towns.
('92', 204, 1, 7, 340215) I have not the slightest doubt that if the inhabitants of Delhi take up spinning they can produce enough cloth for their needs.
('92', 204, 1, 8, 340343) [From Hindi] Hindustan, 19 9 1946
('92', 204, 2, 9, 340377) 294. QUESTION BOX 1
('92', 204, 3, 10, 340397) WHAT USE AHIMSA?
('92', 204, 4, 11, 340414) Q. In whichever direction in the world one looks today one sees only violence, onslaughts on people’s rights and power politics.
('92', 204, 4, 12, 340543) This is true even of America and England where it is said the voice of the people is the sole arbiter.
('92', 204, 4, 13, 340646) Have you considered what your ahimsa can do in such a situation?
('92', 204, 5, 14, 340711) A. It is true there is power politics everywhere.
('92', 204, 5, 15, 340761) But you are mistaken in thinking that in America and England the voice of the people is the sole arbiter.
('92', 204, 5, 16, 340867) The voice of the people should be the voice of God.
('92', 204, 5, 17, 340919) That is why we say that the Pancha are Parameshwar.
('92', 204, 5, 18, 340971) But where people themselves feed on other people, how can one say that the voice of the people is the voice of God?
('92', 204, 5, 19, 341087) We see how America and England live on the coloured races, exploit other peoples.
('92', 204, 5, 20, 341169) It needs no proving.
('92', 204, 5, 21, 341190) Exploiters are seen to co operate with exploiters but that does not make their voice the voice of the people.
('92', 204, 5, 22, 341300) Where the voice of the people is the voice of God the people do not want to live on others.
('92', 204, 5, 23, 341392) They have truth on one scale of the balance and ahimsa on the other, both always having equal weight.
('92', 204, 5, 24, 341494) This covers my whole reply.
('92', 204, 5, 25, 341522) For me ahimsa is not disabled; it is not weak; it is supreme.
('92', 204, 5, 26, 341584) Where there is ahimsa there is Truth and, Truth is God.
('92', 204, 5, 27, 341640) How that God manifests Himself I do not know.
('92', 204, 5, 28, 341686) All I know is that He is all pervading and where He is all is well.
('92', 204, 5, 29, 341754) There is therefore one law for all.
('92', 204, 5, 30, 341790) Wherever in the world truth and ahimsa reign there is perfect peace and perfect happiness.
('92', 204, 5, 31, 341881) If they are not to be found anywhere we must understand that they are hidden from view.
('92', 204, 5, 32, 341969) But they cannot totally disappear.
('92', 204, 5, 33, 342004) Those who possess the barque of this faith will
('92', 204, 6, 34, 342052) 1 The sub titles are from Harijan, 29 9 1946, in which a translation of this appeared.
('92', 205, 0, 1, 342139) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 205, 1, 2, 342181) safely go across in it and carry others across.
('92', 205, 2, 3, 342229) SHOULD FOREIGNERS BE WELCOME ?
('92', 205, 3, 4, 342260) Q. You say that foreigners who decide to live in free India as Indians will have no cause for fear.
('92', 205, 3, 5, 342360) You will admit that such has not been the case in any other country.
('92', 205, 3, 6, 342429) Where emphasis is on self others are not disliked but even so some suspicion of them always remains.
('92', 205, 3, 7, 342530) Can free India escape this?
('92', 205, 4, 8, 342558) A. I am firmly of the view that free India will escape this.
('92', 205, 4, 9, 342619) I can cite striking evidence for it.
('92', 205, 4, 10, 342656) But it is not necessary.
('92', 205, 4, 11, 342681) Only this much must be remembered: foreigners have to live here as Indians.
('92', 205, 4, 12, 342757) If a foreigner staying here wants to protect his rights as a foreigner it can become difficult.
('92', 205, 4, 13, 342853) It will mean that he wants to stay in free India as a superior person.
('92', 205, 4, 14, 342924) This must lead to friction.
('92', 205, 4, 15, 342952) The present quarrel with the British Government cannot go on when India is free.
('92', 205, 4, 16, 343033) If it does, India cannot be said to be free.
('92', 205, 4, 17, 343078) NEW DELHI, September 19, 1946 [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 29 9 1946

('92', 206, 6, 11, 343895) 297. CONGRESS MINISTERS, NOT SAHIB LOG 1
('92', 206, 7, 12, 343936) A Congress worker asks :
('92', 206, 8, 13, 343961) Should the Congress Ministers live in great State like their English predecessors?
('92', 206, 8, 14, 344044) Will it be right for them to use Government cars for private work?
('92', 206, 8, 15, 344111) From my point of view there can be only one reply to both the questions.
('92', 206, 8, 16, 344184) If the Congress wants to continue as a people’s organization, the Ministers cannot live as sahib log nor use for private work facilities provided by Government for official duties.

('92', 207, 1, 2, 344569) 298. LETTER TO MIRZA ISMAIL
('92', 207, 2, 3, 344597) BHANGI COLONY, NEW DELHI, September 20, 1946
('92', 207, 3, 4, 344642) DEAR SIR M. ISMAIL, Much as I should like to I may not write to you in Urdu.
('92', 207, 3, 5, 344719) I have now talked to Swami Ramanand Tirth and Shri Kashinath Vaidya.
('92', 207, 3, 6, 344788) As I have already told you the contemplated reforms are no reforms.
('92', 207, 3, 7, 344856) 1 The more I think of them the more I feel that they are not worthy of you.
('92', 207, 3, 8, 344932) You may not seek to impose them on the inhabitants of Hyderabad.
('92', 207, 3, 9, 344997) If you are sure that the States Peoples’ Conference does not represent them, then of course I am out of court.
('92', 207, 3, 10, 345108) Maulana Sahib wants to help you.
('92', 207, 3, 11, 345141) Sarojini Devi likewise.
('92', 207, 3, 12, 345165) I count myself among them.
('92', 207, 3, 13, 345192) But you know my limitations.
('92', 207, 3, 14, 345221) I am a born satyagrahi and hope to die as such and that is my limitation as it is my strength.
('92', 207, 3, 15, 345316) Strength has got to be proved.
('92', 207, 3, 16, 345347) The limitation stares all my friends in the face.
('92', 207, 3, 17, 345397) If you cannot scrap the reforms and if you will not impose them you should postpone them and see whether they admit of amendments.
('92', 207, 3, 18, 345528) Of course, their real guide is the States Peoples’ Conference.
('92', 207, 3, 19, 345591) But they have not yet learnt to forget me as I would like them to do.
('92', 207, 3, 20, 345661) And since you and I know and like each other I must write this for what it is worth.
('92', 207, 3, 21, 345746) The Hindu, 31 12 1946

('92', 212, 4, 8, 351149) 307. FOOD SHORTAGE
('92', 212, 5, 9, 351168) There is nothing so depressing as when fear pervades the atmosphere.
('92', 212, 5, 10, 351237) I remember an occasion when the waters of the Sabarmati were rising fairly high and a message said to be from Sardar Patel was received after midnight to the effect that inside of an hour the Ashram would be covered with the rising waters and that we were likely to be drowned in them if we did not vacate.
('92', 212, 5, 11, 351544) It was a most anxious time for all of us—men, women and children.
('92', 212, 5, 12, 351610) A sigh of relief went up to heaven when it was discovered that after causing some loss to property, the angry waters had begun to subside and that no loss of life need be feared.
('92', 212, 5, 13, 351789) Precisely in the same manner the danger of shortage reported from authoritative quarters bids fair to demoralize us into a panic which would be more fatal than real starvation.Such was my plight when a paragraph in the papers was read to me that of all the places in the world its intrepid Diwan had seriously contended that Travancore had a storage of foodgrainsonly for a fortnight.
('92', 212, 5, 14, 352174) Knowing Travancore so well I imagined all sorts of calamities not merely for Travancore but for all India.
('92', 212, 5, 15, 352281) Travancore with its luxuriant growth of edible tubers, coconut and fish had no need to starve for a single day, even though it might have no other supply from the other parts of India.
('92', 212, 5, 16, 352466) My faith in Travancore kept me whole.
('92', 212, 5, 17, 352504) And to my joy I discovered that the shortage was not of food but of wheat and rice only.
('92', 212, 5, 18, 352593) Travancore can grow rice, not wheat.So far as the cereals are concerned the inhabitants of Travancore are rice eaters.
('92', 212, 5, 19, 352712) They take to wheat with difficulty and under stress.
('92', 212, 5, 20, 352765) Would that the present distress could make us shed our provincialism and induce all India habits so as to make us feel fully at home, no matter which part of India we happened to find ourselves in.
('92', 213, 0, 1, 352963) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 213, 1, 2, 353005) For the moment, however, my object would be fully served if all responsible men in India would definitely tell the people in their respective provinces, districts and States, not to look beyond India for supply of food but to grow what they can themselves and learn to eke out a living from their own produce.
('92', 213, 1, 3, 353315) And, if the numerous authentic letters I receive are an indication of things as they are or should be, we need fear no starvation for want of life giving vegetables plus a little milk for vegetarians and fish, flesh or fowl for non vegetarians.
('92', 213, 1, 4, 353560) Let India realize that as yet we have no appreciable quantity of food from outside our shores.
('92', 213, 1, 5, 353655) Many are willing to help but they are themselves for the most part sufferers or have more calls on them than they are able to cope with.
('92', 213, 1, 6, 353792) The transport difficulty is very real for all of them and our own will commence when the food stuff reaches our shores.
('92', 213, 1, 7, 353912) Internal transport and distribution constitute a problem by themselves.
('92', 213, 1, 8, 353984) It is, therefore, practical wisdom to brace ourselves for the struggle and declare with one voice our resolve that we shall grow our eatables for ourselves and perish bravely in the attempt if we must.
('92', 213, 1, 9, 354186) This is the only way and no other.
('92', 213, 1, 10, 354221) NEW DELHI, September 21, 1946 Harijan, 29 9 1946
('92', 213, 2, 11, 354270) 308. DO NOT ELIMINATE TRUTH AND NON VIOLENCE 1
('92', 213, 3, 12, 354317) A correspondent who sends his name and describes himself as devoted to service writes :
('92', 213, 4, 13, 354405) I read Harijanbandhu regularly.
('92', 213, 4, 14, 354437) Recently in your reply to Shri Shankarrao Deo you said: “I have been saying for some time that the words ‘truth and non violence’ should be removed from the Congress constitution.”
('92', 213, 5, 15, 354618) If this happens in the existing circumstances, people will lose their faith in the Congress because they will feel that so long as it was not in power it was thought best to adhere to truth and non violence but now that power has come it contemplates removing these words from the constitution.
('92', 213, 5, 16, 354913) They might even infer that the removal is being resorted to in order to counter the Muslim League’s threat of direct action.
('92', 213, 6, 17, 355038) If these words are eliminated from the constitution Congress will fall from the high pedestal which these means alone have secured for it.
('92', 213, 6, 18, 355177) It will lose in
('92', 213, 7, 19, 355193) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 29 9 1946. The Harijan translation reproduced here has been revised to bring it into conformity with the original.
('92', 214, 0, 1, 355367) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 215
('92', 214, 1, 2, 355413) prestige.
('92', 214, 1, 3, 355423) You have always said that you yourself cannot go forward one step without truth and non violence and is it not their adherence to these that makes the public think of Congressmen as trustworthy, merciful, full of the spirit of service and bravery ?
('92', 214, 1, 4, 355672) The tree must perish if its roots are destroyed.
('92', 214, 1, 5, 355721) You must see to it that the roots go deeper and deeper and are not eradicated.
('92', 214, 2, 6, 355800) Therefore I feel that you should compel every Congressman to follow these principles and if he refuses, he must leave the Congress.
('92', 214, 2, 7, 355932) How can I, a champion of ahimsa, compel anyone to perform even a good act ?
('92', 214, 2, 8, 356008) A well known Englishman has said that he would rather be free and make mistakes than be unfree and avoid them.
('92', 214, 2, 9, 356119) I agree with him.
('92', 214, 2, 10, 356137) The reason is obvious.
('92', 214, 2, 11, 356160) The mind of a man who is good under compulsion cannot be good; in fact it gets worse.
('92', 214, 2, 12, 356246) And when compulsion is removed all the defects well up to the surface with even greater force.
('92', 214, 2, 13, 356341) Besides, no individual should have the power to force others.
('92', 214, 2, 14, 356403) Even the Congress cannot force its members to follow truth and non violence.
('92', 214, 2, 15, 356480) These have to be accepted willingly from the heart.
('92', 214, 2, 16, 356532) I have been recommending the elimination of these words from the constitution for over a year, long before the Muslim League con templated direct action.
('92', 214, 2, 17, 356686) Thus my recommendation has no connec tion with the League’s resolution.
('92', 214, 2, 18, 356758) But I have no help for those who invariably attribute sinister motives to my words.
('92', 214, 2, 19, 356842) I have strong grounds for my recommendation.
('92', 214, 2, 20, 356887) The Congress may not hide untruth and violence under the guise of truth and non violence.
('92', 214, 2, 21, 356977) Is not this an all sufficing reason ?
('92', 214, 2, 22, 357015) If Congressmen would not be hypocrites, nothing could be better than that Congress should adhere to these two pillars.
('92', 214, 2, 23, 357134) It could never be my wish that the Congress, the moment it comes to power, should discard the very ladder by which it has climbed so high.
('92', 214, 2, 24, 357273) I believe that if Congressmen, while in power, renounce truth and non violence, the lustre surrounding the Congress will grow dim.
('92', 214, 2, 25, 357404) We must all guard against one mistake.
('92', 214, 2, 26, 357443) There is no rule against following what is not in the constitution.
('92', 214, 2, 27, 357511) Indeed my hope is that when these words are removed, all, or a large majority of Congressmen, will heartily follow truth and non violence even to the point of death.
('92', 214, 2, 28, 357677) The writer has forgotten to mention one thing which I should like to clarify.
('92', 214, 2, 29, 357755) The words in the Constitution are ‘peaceful and legiti mate’.
('92', 214, 2, 30, 357817) I have no right to interpret them as truthful and non violent, if
('92', 215, 0, 1, 357883) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 215, 1, 2, 357925) they don’t bear that meaning.
('92', 215, 1, 3, 357955) Congress has adopted them as a policy, not as a creed.
('92', 215, 1, 4, 358010) The question of my right to retain or eliminate them does not arise.
('92', 215, 1, 5, 358079) But whilst it lasts, policy is tantamount to creed and hence becomes obligatory.Of course, my recommendation has no meaning if ‘peaceful’ can be interpreted as violent and ‘legitimate’ as untruthful.
('92', 215, 1, 6, 358279) NEW DELHI, September 21, 1946 Harijan, 29 9 1946

('92', 216, 4, 9, 359861) 311. NOT SENTIMENT BUT REASON
('92', 216, 5, 10, 359891) Brij Narain has devoted two columns of the Lahore Tribune in support of the salt tax.
('92', 216, 5, 11, 359977) I dare not combat his arguments though they make little appeal to my lay mind.
('92', 216, 5, 12, 360056) He has come to the gratuitous conclusion that I ask for repeal on grounds of sentiment rather than reason.
('92', 216, 5, 13, 360163) He reminds me of armchair politics and philo sophy.
('92', 216, 5, 14, 360215) Salt tax hits not only men, women and children, but also fish and cattle.
('92', 216, 5, 15, 360289) Reason demands its immediate repeal.
('92', 216, 5, 16, 360326) It is not the amount of the tax that kills, it is the monopoly and all it means that kills the poor villager and his cattle.
('92', 216, 5, 17, 360451) Imagine what would happen if the poor were prohibited from breathing air or drinking water without per mission of the Government.
('92', 216, 5, 18, 360581) The condition as to salt is not radically different.
('92', 216, 5, 19, 360634) The scientist has not taken the trouble to study what this prohibition to prepare salt even for one’s own consumption has cost India.
('92', 216, 6, 20, 360768) Brij Narain will not allow the Congress to be national istic enough even to warrant its abolishing a monopoly which presses heavily upon all the poor people without distinction, unless the Pro fessor ignorantly imagines that the Muslims have no poor to think of.
('92', 216, 6, 21, 361031) NEW DELHI, September 22, 1946

('92', 219, 1, 2, 364173) 318. LETTER TO SHARDA G. CHOKHAWALA
('92', 219, 2, 3, 364209) NEW DELHI, September 22, 1946
('92', 219, 3, 4, 364239) BABUDI, Isn’t it good I received your letter ?
('92', 219, 3, 5, 364286) Would it not be better if you, as also Anand were at Sevagram while you were in indifferent health ?
('92', 219, 3, 6, 364387) Maybe you will recover there; Anand also will recover and Gordhandas’s worry will be lessened.
