('92', 224, 1, 2, 371847) 326. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 224, 2, 3, 371879) NEW DELHI, September 23, 1946 The music of the charkha murmurs sweetly that we are all one, born to be equal sharers in the goods of the earth with no one higher or wealthier than the other.
('92', 224, 2, 4, 372070) Yet the world is today full of inequalities of wealth and invidious distinctions of high and low.
('92', 224, 2, 5, 372168) This is folly.
('92', 224, 2, 6, 372183) In our arrogance we forget that we are all one day going to be levelled with the dust by death that knows no distinctions.
('92', 224, 2, 7, 372306) The second lesson is that we are to earn our bread by the sweat of our brow—what a Russian savant has called “bread labour”, and the third is that if we are one of and with the people, we should refuse to give food to those who are not in need or to take more than we need for health.
('92', 224, 2, 8, 372591) If we all did that there would be no scarcity of food in this land and we would refuse to look across the seas for food stuffs.
('92', 224, 3, 9, 372719) Yet his nearest comrades were about to make the mistake of serving refreshments, after the Jhanda vandan by Dr. Rajendra Prasad, to volunteers and Harijans who were not in need of such.
('92', 224, 3, 10, 372905) 2 Was it not criminal to fritter away food stuff that would serve to keep alive twenty men, to provide titbits to Harijans and volunteers who were certainly not suffering pangs of hunger?
('92', 224, 3, 11, 373093) They were deceiving themselves if they thought that thereby they served the Harijans.
('92', 224, 3, 12, 373179) The real hunger of the Harijans which needed to be satisfied was not for morsels of food but for decent living as self respecting equal citizens, for a square deal as human beings, for freedom from fear, inculcation of clean and sanitary habits, thrift, industry, education.
('92', 224, 3, 13, 373454) That required perseverance, self sacrifice and patient intelligent labour on our part.
('92', 224, 3, 14, 373541) If they gave him money to feed Harijans he would refuse to accept it.
('92', 224, 3, 15, 373611) For he did not want to make beggars and idlers of them.
('92', 224, 3, 16, 373667) He pointedly referred to the fact that Dr. Rajendra Prasad was their Food Member who wanted to save for the famishing every morsel of food.
('92', 224, 3, 17, 373807) In the circumstances he very much questioned whether the oversight of his comrades was not due to his being lax with himself.
('92', 224, 3, 18, 373933) Was he not allowing himself to partake rather too freely of the fruits that were placed before him?
('92', 224, 3, 19, 374033) The lesson of yesterday, he remarked, was a grave warning for all, if we are to learn truly the lesson of the charkha.
('92', 224, 3, 20, 374152) Harijan, 29 9 1946
('92', 224, 4, 21, 374171) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('92', 224, 4, 22, 374216) The Hindustan Times, 25 9 1946, also reports the speech.
('92', 224, 4, 23, 374273) 2 This was to be in celebration of Gandhiji’s birthday according to the Vikram calendar.
('92', 225, 0, 1, 374362) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 225, 1, 2, 374404) 327. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('92', 225, 2, 3, 374432) NEW DELHI, [On or after September 23, 1946]
('92', 225, 3, 4, 374476) Q. Wrangling and corrupt practices have today become a common feature of our elections.
('92', 225, 3, 5, 374564) What should be the attitude of Congressmen with regard to the elec tions?
('92', 225, 4, 6, 374638) A. What you say only shows that we seek leadership in stead of being servants of the nation.
('92', 225, 4, 7, 374731) There can be no room for wran gles when service is the ideal.
('92', 225, 4, 8, 374793) Congressmen should realize that only a few can become leaders, the goal for all Congressmen to set before themselves can only be to qualify as true servants of the nation.
('92', 225, 4, 9, 374965) An institution that suffers from a plethora of leaders is surely in a bad way.
('92', 225, 4, 10, 375044) For instance, if every Khudai Khidmatgar aspired to become the chief, it would make the life of Badshah Khan hell besides disrupting the Khudai Khidmatgar organization itself.
('92', 225, 4, 11, 375220) If Congressmen lived up to the creed which they professed, viz., the attainment of swaraj through truthful and non violent means, paraphrased in the Congress constitution by the words “peaceful and legitimate”, there should be no wrangling and no corruption.
('92', 225, 4, 12, 375479) The existence of election wrangles and irregular practices is thus only a proof that the Congress policy of “attainment of swaraj through ‘peaceful and legitimate’ means” is honoured more in the breach than in the observance.
('92', 225, 4, 13, 375705) I have, therefore, suggested that it should be dropped in the amended constitution that is to come into being.
('92', 225, 4, 14, 375816) Pending the setting up of the new constitution I have suggested a plan of work which does away with further elections for the time being and which requires all Congressmen to be active servants.
('92', 225, 4, 15, 376011) If it is adopted it should cut across all our difficulties and troubles.
('92', 225, 5, 16, 376084) Q. Very few minorities’ representatives have been returned at the elections.
('92', 225, 5, 17, 376161) What remedy do you suggest ?
('92', 225, 6, 18, 376190) A. Minorities being a minority, their representation in the Congress organization will naturally be proportionately less.
('92', 225, 6, 19, 376312) If they feel dissatisfied, they can keep out of the Congress without ceasing to be Congressmen as I have done.
('92', 225, 6, 20, 376423) It is my claim that I am not less a Congressman but more by reason of my ceasing to be even a four 
('92', 225, 7, 21, 376523) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s report under the title “Some Posers”.
('92', 225, 7, 22, 376589) The questions were asked by the Presidents and Secretaries of various Provincial Congress Committees who had assembled in Delhi for the A. I. C. C. session held on September 23 and 24.
('92', 226, 0, 1, 376774) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 227
('92', 226, 1, 2, 376820) anna member of the Congress.
('92', 226, 1, 3, 376849) At Faizpur Congress the question was raised by Mrs. Anasuyabai Kale at a gathering at which I was present.
('92', 226, 1, 4, 376956) On interrogation it was found that the number of those who were four anna members was very small.
('92', 226, 1, 5, 377054) But in reply to the question as to how many in the gathering were not four anna members, a forest of hands went up.
('92', 226, 1, 6, 377170) These are real Congressmen seeking no reward but seeking ever to serve it.
('92', 226, 1, 7, 377245) Bereft of them it would dwindle into a parlour show.
('92', 226, 1, 8, 377298) The only worthy aim of a Congressman can be to belong wholly to the Congress, never to capture and dominate the Congress.
('92', 226, 1, 9, 377420) If everybody took up the correct attitude there would be no minorities and majorities.
('92', 226, 1, 10, 377507) To try to ‘capture’ the Congress would be to kill the Congress.
('92', 226, 1, 11, 377571) And a Congressman who is worthy of his salt would die rather than be guilty of the murder.
('92', 226, 2, 12, 377662) Q. The policy of the Interim Government is to keep down the prices of foodgrains.
('92', 226, 2, 13, 377744) Would it not adversely affect the production of foodgrains?
('92', 226, 3, 14, 377804) A. I want to reduce the prices of foodgrains still further.
('92', 226, 3, 15, 377864) I claim to be a peasant myself and I know that only a fraction of the price paid by the consumer actually reaches the grower of food.
('92', 226, 3, 16, 377998) It should be the business of the Interim Government to see that the tiller of the soil gets full value of his produce and that every pie paid by the consumer reaches the peasant’s pocket or else it should get out.
('92', 226, 3, 17, 378212) The Interim Government can never be guilty of wishing to provide cheap grains to the consumer at the expense of the grower of food.
('92', 226, 3, 18, 378344) The trouble with the cultivator is not low prices but the middleman.
('92', 226, 3, 19, 378413) Even in khadi production I set the target of 8 as.
('92', 226, 3, 20, 378464) a day for the spinners.
('92', 226, 3, 21, 378488) We actually reached the rate of 4 as.
('92', 226, 3, 22, 378526) in spite of the objection that dear khadi would spell the ruin of khadi production that illustrates my attitude towards the producer.
('92', 226, 3, 23, 378660) I would eliminate the middleman altogether.
('92', 226, 3, 24, 378704) It is he who today sponges upon the agriculturist.
('92', 226, 3, 25, 378755) Otherwise, there is no reason why the peasant should starve.
('92', 226, 3, 26, 378816) At the same time a peasant who profiteers or exploits the black market belies his calling.
('92', 226, 3, 27, 378907) He is no less an exploiter than the zamindar.
('92', 226, 4, 28, 378953) Q. The growth of parties in the Congress is having a very adverse effect on the Congress organization.
('92', 226, 4, 29, 379056) What is the remedy?
('92', 226, 5, 30, 379076) A. There can be only one party in the Congress, i.e., that of Congressmen and no other.
('92', 226, 5, 31, 379164) That is not to say that there is no room in the Congress for individuals or groups holding different opinions.
('92', 226, 5, 32, 379275) I do not believe in dead uniformity.“All men are born equal and
('92', 227, 0, 1, 379339) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 227, 1, 2, 379381) free” is not Nature’s law in the literal sense.
('92', 227, 1, 3, 379429) All men are not born equal in intellect, for instance, but the doctrine of equality will be vindicated if those who have superior intellect will use it not for self advancement at the expense of others, but for the service of those who are less forward in that respect than they.
('92', 227, 1, 4, 379709) Today there are all sorts in the Congress.
('92', 227, 1, 5, 379752) That is why I have suggested the removal of the words “peaceful and legitimate” from the Congress objective.
('92', 227, 1, 6, 379861) That need not mean abandonment of truth and non violence by Congressmen.
('92', 227, 1, 7, 379934) The object is only to purge out hypocrisy.
('92', 227, 1, 8, 379977) It jars.
('92', 227, 1, 9, 379986) Let those who believe in the doctrine of the sword openly avow it.
('92', 227, 1, 10, 380053) To take the name of non violence when there is sword in your heart is not only hypocritical and dishonest but cowardly.
('92', 227, 1, 11, 380173) Our non violence vis a vis the British Government has been the non violence of the weak.
('92', 227, 1, 12, 380262) Otherwise, why should there be all these wrangles among ourselves?
('92', 227, 1, 13, 380329) We try to justify the disorganization and chaos in our midst by pointing to the example of “squatters” in England, forgetting that blind imitation would not help us.There is nothing more demoralizing than fake non violence of the weak and impotent.
('92', 227, 1, 14, 380578) If we had the requisite non violence in us, our public life would be characterized by utmost toleration.
('92', 227, 1, 15, 380683) There will then be room for as many parties as there are opinions.
('92', 227, 1, 16, 380750) Differences of opinion would be an indication of healthy independence of mind which is the law of life, not party intrigues and party strife.
('92', 227, 1, 17, 380892) The latter are incompatible with independence.
('92', 227, 2, 18, 380939) Q. How should the Hindu Muslim questions be tackled?
('92', 227, 3, 19, 380992) A. I must own defeat on that point.
('92', 227, 3, 20, 381028) I know that mine is today a voice in the wilderness and yet I claim that mine is the only practicable solution.
('92', 227, 3, 21, 381140) I can never subscribe to the view that because certain members of a particular community have indulged in inhuman acts, therefore the whole community may be condemned outright and put beyond the pale.
('92', 227, 3, 22, 381341) The Muslim League may call Hindus names and declare India to be Dar ul Harb, where the law of jehad operates and all Muslims who co operate with the Congress are Quislings fit only to be exterminated.
('92', 227, 3, 23, 381542) But we must not cease to aspire, in spite of this wild talk, to befriend all Mussalmans and hold them fast as prisoners of our love.
('92', 227, 3, 24, 381675) It would be a present possibility if Hindus in their lakhs offered themselves to be cut to pieces without retaliation or anger in their hearts.
('92', 227, 3, 25, 381819) Non violence is today rightly laughed out of court as Utopian.
('92', 227, 3, 26, 381882) Nevertheless, I maintain that it is the only way to keep Hinduism alive
('92', 228, 0, 1, 381954) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 229
('92', 228, 1, 2, 382000) and India undivided.
('92', 228, 1, 3, 382021) The history of the Congress non violence for the last twenty five years has taught us nothing if it has not taught us that.
('92', 228, 2, 4, 382145) Q. How can we counteract the activities of the Communists, who are openly opposing the Congress ?
('92', 228, 3, 5, 382243) A. The principle which I have laid down vis a vis the Hindu Muslim question also holds good in respect of the Communists.
('92', 228, 3, 6, 382365) By “Muslim” I mean the Muslim League.
('92', 228, 3, 7, 382403) For, not all the Muslims are Muslim Leaguers.
('92', 228, 3, 8, 382449) The Muslim Leaguers have today raised the slogan that ten crores of Indian Muslims are in danger of being submerged and swept out of existence unless they constitute themselves into a separate State.
('92', 228, 3, 9, 382649) I call that slogan scare mongering pure and simple.
('92', 228, 3, 10, 382701) It is nonsense to say that any people can permanently crush or swamp out of existence one fourth of its population, which the Mussalmans are in India.
('92', 228, 3, 11, 382852) But I would have no hesitation in conceding the demand of Pakistan if I could be convinced of its righteousness or that it is good for Islam.
('92', 228, 3, 12, 382994) But I am firmly convinced that the Pakistan demand as put forth by the Muslim League is un Islamic and I have not hesitated to call it sinful.
('92', 228, 3, 13, 383137) Islam stands for the unity and brotherhood of mankind, not for disrupting the oneness of the human family.
('92', 228, 3, 14, 383244) Therefore, those who want to divide India into possibly warring groups are enemies alike of India and Islam.
('92', 228, 3, 15, 383353) They may cut me to pieces but they cannot make me subscribe to something which I consider to be wrong.
('92', 228, 3, 16, 383456) The question of the Communists stands on a slightly different footing.
('92', 228, 3, 17, 383527) They seem to have made trouble making their profession.
('92', 228, 3, 18, 383583) I have friends among them.
('92', 228, 3, 19, 383610) Some of them are like sons to me.
('92', 228, 3, 20, 383644) But it seems they do not make any distinction between fair and foul, truth and falsehood.
('92', 228, 3, 21, 383734) They deny the charge.
('92', 228, 3, 22, 383756) But their reported acts seem to sustain it.
('92', 228, 3, 23, 383800) Moreover, they seem to take their instructions from Russia, whom they regard as their spiritual home rather than India.
('92', 228, 3, 24, 383920) I cannot countenance this dependence on an outside power.
('92', 228, 3, 25, 383978) I have even said that we should not depend even on Russian wheat in our present food crisis.
('92', 228, 3, 26, 384071) We must have the ability and courage to subsist on what our soil can give us rather than depend on foreign charity.
('92', 228, 3, 27, 384187) Oterwise, we shall not deserve to exist as an independent country.
('92', 228, 3, 28, 384254) The same applies to foreign ideologies.
('92', 228, 3, 29, 384294) I would accept them only to the extent that I
('92', 229, 0, 1, 384340) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 229, 1, 2, 384382) can assimilate them and adapt them to the Indian scene.
('92', 229, 1, 3, 384438) But I must refuse to go under them.
('92', 229, 1, 4, 384474) My formula for the Communists, therefore, is that I would prefer to die at their hands, but I will not retaliate.
('92', 229, 1, 5, 384588) Harijan, 6 10 1946
('92', 229, 2, 6, 384607) 328. TALK WITH AN AMERICAN JOURNALIST 1
('92', 229, 3, 7, 384647) NEW DELHI, [Before September 24, 1946] 2
('92', 229, 4, 8, 384688) Q. Are you full of the joy of life ?
('92', 229, 4, 9, 384725) Why do you want to live for 125 years?
('92', 229, 5, 10, 384764) A. Gandhiji told him that his desire to live up to 125 years was not for enjoy 
('92', 229, 6, 11, 384844) ment but service.
('92', 229, 6, 12, 384862) He explained that both were not the same and proceeded to explain
('92', 229, 7, 13, 384928) to the puzzled interviewer the doctrine of “enjoyment through renunciation” as set
('92', 229, 8, 14, 385011) forth in the Ishopanishad.
('92', 229, 9, 15, 385038) Q. When did your real enjoyment of life begin?
('92', 229, 10, 16, 385085) A. When I was born.
('92', 229, 11, 17, 385105) Q. No, I mean when did that pattern of life begin when service became a joy
('92', 229, 12, 18, 385181) for ever ?
('92', 229, 13, 19, 385192) A. When I understood the inner meaning of life.
('92', 229, 14, 20, 385240) Q. Is that India’s speciality?
('92', 229, 15, 21, 385271) A. The only speciality of India is her poverty as America’s is her glamour of riches.
('92', 229, 16, 22, 385357) Q. May not there be occasions when one may have to compromise ideals
('92', 229, 17, 23, 385426) with expediency?
('92', 229, 18, 24, 385443) A. No, never.
('92', 229, 18, 25, 385457) I do not believe that the end justifies the means.
('92', 229, 19, 26, 385508) Q. Is it possible that your activities may some day be removed from the
('92', 229, 20, 27, 385580) political field ?
('92', 229, 21, 28, 385598) A. Perhaps you do not know that I felt compelled to come into the political field because I found that I could not do even social work
('92', 229, 22, 29, 385733) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 2 Pyarelal explains that the talk took place about the same time as the “Talk with an English Journalist”, which was before September 24.
('92', 230, 0, 1, 385915) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 231
('92', 230, 1, 2, 385961) without touching politics.
('92', 230, 1, 3, 385988) I feel that political work must be looked upon in terms of social and moral progress.
('92', 230, 1, 4, 386074) In democracy no part of life is untouched by politics.
('92', 230, 1, 5, 386129) Under the British you cannot escape politics in the good sense.
('92', 230, 1, 6, 386193) It embraces the whole life.
('92', 230, 1, 7, 386221) All who breathe must pay a tax.
('92', 230, 1, 8, 386253) That is British rule in India.
('92', 230, 1, 9, 386284) Take the salt tax for instance.
('92', 230, 1, 10, 386316) It concern everybody.
('92', 230, 1, 11, 386338) The collector of revenue and the policeman are the only symbols by which millions in India’s villages know British rule.
('92', 230, 1, 12, 386459) One cannot sit still while the people are being ravaged.
('92', 230, 2, 13, 386516) Q. Then your job will never be finished?
('92', 230, 3, 14, 386557) A. It will be finished only with my death.
('92', 230, 3, 15, 386600) I must be watchful, whether it is the foreign government that is in power or indigenous, if I am a social reformer in the true sense of the term.
('92', 230, 3, 16, 386746) This is applicable to all.
('92', 230, 4, 17, 386773) Q. When people attain power they grow away from the people.
('92', 230, 4, 18, 386833) What about
('92', 230, 6, 19, 386844) A. Let us hope and pray that this will never happen here.
('92', 230, 6, 20, 386902) I have likened our people’s office acceptance to wearing a crown of thorns and pretty sharp thorns at that.
('92', 230, 7, 21, 387010) Q. What do you think of the students’ strikes?
('92', 230, 8, 22, 387057) A. It seems to be a universal malady, an epidemic.
('92', 230, 9, 23, 387108) Q. Do you ever feel depressed?
('92', 230, 10, 24, 387139) A. I believe in an over ruling Power as I believe I am talking to you just now.
('92', 230, 10, 25, 387219) This may be unreal, but that is real.
('92', 230, 10, 26, 387257) It dominates me and enables me to remain calm even in the midst of storm.
('92', 230, 11, 27, 387331) Q. Gandhiji’s questioner next asked his opinion about predestination.
('92', 230, 12, 28, 387401) A. It is a much abused word.
('92', 230, 12, 29, 387430) It is true that we are not quite as free as we imagine.
('92', 230, 12, 30, 387486) Our past holds us.
('92', 230, 12, 31, 387505) But like all other doctrines this may well be ridden to death.
('92', 230, 13, 32, 387568) Q. This provoked the question as to how one could overcome the unpleasant
('92', 230, 14, 33, 387642) effects of one’s predestination since predestination was a reality.
('92', 230, 15, 34, 387710) A. By taking the pleasant with the unpleasant in perfect detach ment and thereby sterilizing the unpleasantness of its sting, even as you have tackled the problem of the prickly pear by removing its thorns through judicious selection and cultivation and converting it
('92', 231, 0, 1, 387978) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 231, 1, 2, 388020) into edible fodder for cattle.
('92', 231, 2, 3, 388051) Q. How to prevent the next war?
('92', 231, 3, 4, 388083) A. By doing the right thing, irrespective of what the world will do.
('92', 231, 3, 5, 388152) Each individual must act according to his ability without waiting for others if he wants to move them to act.
('92', 231, 3, 6, 388262) There comes a time when an individual becomes irresistible and his action becomes all pervasive in its effect.
('92', 231, 3, 7, 388373) This comes when he reduces himself to zero.
('92', 231, 3, 8, 388417) If the third war comes, it will be the end of the world.
('92', 231, 3, 9, 388474) The world cannot stand a third war.
('92', 231, 3, 10, 388510) For me the second war has not stopped, it still goes on.

('92', 232, 1, 2, 389159) 330. TALK WITH AN ENGLISH JOURNALIST 1
('92', 232, 2, 3, 389198) NEW DELHI, [Before September 24, 1946] India is on the march to Independence, it is coming whether there is an agreement between the Muslim League and the Congress or not.
('92', 232, 2, 4, 389370) No one can stop it.
('92', 232, 2, 5, 389390) It is her destiny.
('92', 232, 2, 6, 389409) She has bled enough for it.
('92', 232, 2, 7, 389437) Of course, if there is heart co operation between the two, the progress will be quicker and smoother.
('92', 232, 2, 8, 389539) But it must be real heart unity—not a make believe.
('92', 232, 3, 9, 389591) Gandhiji, who claims kinship with Pressmen and therefore their friendship began by telling this friend what he considered to be the function of journalism.
('92', 232, 3, 10, 389747) There are occasions when a journalist serves his profession best by his silence.
('92', 232, 4, 11, 389828) Did not Gandhiji believe in the capacity of the average man to judge correctly provided he had enough knowledge of facts?
('92', 232, 4, 12, 389950) Not knowledge of facts.
('92', 232, 4, 13, 389974) What passes for facts is only impres sions or estimate of things and estimates vary.
('92', 232, 4, 14, 390059) Hence one gets diffe rent versions of the same event.
('92', 232, 4, 15, 390113) What is really needed to make democracy function is not knowledge of facts but right education.
('92', 232, 4, 16, 390209) And the true function of journalism is to educate the public mind, not to stock the public mind with wanted and unwanted impressions.
('92', 232, 4, 17, 390343) A journalist has, therefore, to use his discretion as to what to report and when.
('92', 232, 4, 18, 390425) As it is, journalists are not content to stick to facts alone.
('92', 232, 4, 19, 390488) Journalism has become the art of ‘intelligent anticipation of events’.
('92', 232, 4, 20, 390559) As a public man and a social reformer, it is for me to judge when to say something and when to hold my tongue.
('92', 232, 4, 21, 390670) What the world needs is not words but action.
('92', 232, 4, 22, 390716) Actions and thoughts tell far more than speech.
('92', 232, 4, 23, 390764) And this applies to all men both great and small.
('92', 232, 5, 24, 390814) Q. What do you think of Russia ?
('92', 232, 5, 25, 390847) A. Russia is an enigma to me.
('92', 232, 5, 26, 390877) It hurts me to think (if the reports are true) that a country which stood for the people has turned into an imperialist power.
('92', 232, 5, 27, 391004) But I may not pass judgment on a great people and a great man like Stalin.
('92', 232, 5, 28, 391079) I lack the data.
('92', 232, 6, 29, 391096) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 24 9 1946. The talk took place in the course of Gandhiji’s morning walk.
('92', 233, 0, 1, 391214) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 233, 1, 2, 391256) Q. Is the world progressing?
('92', 233, 1, 3, 391285) Has the making of life and struggle for existence easier in the modern world resulted in the dulling of man’s instincts and sensibilities?
('92', 233, 2, 4, 391424) A. If that is your comment, I will subscribe to it.
('92', 233, 3, 5, 391476) Q. And the atom bomb?
('92', 233, 4, 6, 391498) A. Oh, on that point you can proclaim to the whole world without hesitation that I am beyond repair.
('92', 233, 4, 7, 391599) I regard the employment of the atom bomb for the wholesale destruction of men, women and children as the most diabolical use of science.
('92', 233, 5, 8, 391736) Q. What is the antidote?
('92', 233, 5, 9, 391761) Has it antiquated non violence?
('92', 233, 6, 10, 391793) It is the only thing the atom bomb cannot destroy.
('92', 233, 6, 11, 391844) I did not move a muscle when I first heard that the atom bomb had wiped out Hiroshima.
('92', 233, 6, 12, 391931) On the contrary, I said to myself, ‘Unless now the world adopts non violence, it will spell certain suicide for mankind.’
('92', 233, 7, 13, 392053) Q. What would be your fatherly advice to a young man about to launch into the world?
('92', 233, 8, 14, 392138) A. To hold his tongue.
('92', 233, 8, 15, 392161) Was it not Shakespeare who said, ‘Lend everybody thine ear, thy voice to none?’
('92', 233, 9, 16, 392241) Q. You followed that policy fairly in your own case.
('92', 233, 10, 17, 392294) A. Yes, I used to think in my early days that I was a dunce and an idiot, that I should never be able to speak.
('92', 233, 10, 18, 392406) Now I feel thankful for that disability.
('92', 233, 11, 19, 392447) Q. You have been a fighter all your life.
('92', 233, 11, 20, 392489) What has fighting done for you?
('92', 233, 12, 21, 392521) A. It has braced me for the next struggle.
('92', 233, 12, 22, 392564) Fighting has done me good.
('92', 233, 12, 23, 392591) What it has done to others, I do not know.
('92', 233, 13, 24, 392634) Q. Considering that the difference between the Muslim League and the Con gress has narrowed down to one or two basic issues would it not be better to make a little sacrifice to secure agreement?
('92', 233, 14, 25, 392829) A. You can not sacrifice a principle to gain a doubtful advan tage.
('92', 233, 15, 26, 392897) Q. After hearing both sides of the controversy, an outsider feels at sea.
('92', 233, 15, 27, 392971) The only course, it seems, is to suspend judgment under the circumstances.
('92', 233, 16, 28, 393046) A. When two parties cannot agree and both are sincere in their convictions it is clear one of them must be wrong.
('92', 233, 16, 29, 393160) Both cannot be right.
('92', 233, 16, 30, 393182) The world must be the arbiter in that case.
('92', 233, 16, 31, 393226) It dare not withhold judgment.
('92', 233, 16, 32, 393257) It has often been found in the progress of non violence
('92', 234, 0, 1, 393313) VOL. 92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 235
('92', 234, 1, 2, 393359) that even people who want to be perfectly just come to wrong judgment.
('92', 234, 2, 3, 393430) Before taking leave the friend tendered Gandhiji congratulations in advance on his coming birthday.
('92', 234, 2, 4, 393530) I attach no importance to it.
('92', 234, 2, 5, 393560) Every day one is reborn.
('92', 234, 2, 6, 393585) I, at any rate, am.

('92', 236, 2, 8, 396831) 335. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR THE WORKING COMMITTEE 1
('92', 236, 3, 9, 396881) [On or before September 25, 1946] 2
('92', 236, 4, 10, 396917) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, the then President of the I[ndian] N[ational] C[ongress], had with the consent of the W[orking] C[ommittee] assured Pandit J[awaharlal] N[ehru] that the Congress would make his cause in Kashmir their own and that the Pundit should come back from Kashmir in order to continue the valuable work he was doing for the Congress.
('92', 236, 4, 11, 397266) The Pundit willingly returned though not without misgivings.
('92', 236, 4, 12, 397327) The W. C. regret to find that his misgivings were true.
('92', 236, 4, 13, 397383) From all accounts received by the W. C. things are not going on as they should in that State.
('92', 236, 4, 14, 397477) Repression of a subtle type is going on.
('92', 236, 4, 15, 397518) Reforms though promising looking on paper are reported to be so only in name.
('92', 236, 4, 16, 397596) The W. C. cannot conceive the possibility of substantial reforms whilst unchecked repression is going on in Kashmir.
('92', 236, 4, 17, 397713) The W. C. therefore earnestly recommend to the Kashmir State they should invite the Congress to send a deputation of reputable men of unques tioned ability and impartiality to find whether there is repression of liberty in Kashmir, whether there is tampering with the voters and whether reforms promised are substantial enough to secure content ment and prosperity of the people of the Statet.
('92', 236, 4, 18, 398107) In this recommen dation the W. C.invite the co operation of all the enlightened States of India and the people residing in the States.

('92', 236, 5, 22, 398455) He returned from there after Azad gave him the assurance that the Working Committee would take up the cause of Kashmir.

('92', 238, 7, 14, 400571) 339. LETTER TO H. GREENFIELD
('92', 238, 8, 15, 400600) VALMIKI MANDIR, READING ROAD, NEW DELHI, September 25, 1946
('92', 238, 9, 16, 400660) DEAR MR. GREENFIELD, Herewith is my proposal as promised.
('92', 238, 9, 17, 400718) In it I have endeavoured to minimize all dislocation and loss to the Government save what abolition of the tax must involve.
('92', 238, 9, 18, 400843) But while salt will no longer be a dutiable article, as a source of national instruction, refining a vital food adjunct of all dirt and increasing its output for man and beast will continue and make increasing progress from day to day.
('92', 238, 9, 19, 401079) I hug the hope that loss of revenue as a burdensome tax will be more than made up by increase in the consumption of salt.
('92', 238, 10, 20, 401201) 1 Gandhiji’s birthday according to the Vikram calendar fell on September 22.
('92', 239, 0, 1, 401278) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 239, 1, 2, 401320) If you discover any flaw in this presentation, please tell me without the slightest hesitation.
('92', 239, 2, 3, 401416) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('92', 239, 3, 4, 401446) H. GREENFIELD, ESQ., C.S.I., C.I.E.
('92', 239, 4, 5, 401482) [ENCLOSURE]
('92', 239, 5, 6, 401494) Salt monopoly shall cease as from the first day of October 1946, and the duty on salt as from the first day of January 1947, subject to the exceptions and conditions hereinafter set forth.
('92', 239, 5, 7, 401683) The humanitarian clause on salt of the agreement popularly known as Irwin Gandhi Pact shall be in full operation and all inspec tion of and interference with private manufacture of salt for evasion of duty shall forthwith cease.
('92', 239, 5, 8, 401912) Government control of salt works and factories hitherto main tained shall continue unabated till complete nationalization of salt industry is attained.
('92', 239, 5, 9, 402064) These factories and works unlike private manu facture for sale shall carry duty up to 31st December.
('92', 239, 5, 10, 402165) In order to give full effect to the foregoing notification, any change in the Salt Act or rules or notices issued thereunder and required in law shall be made as soon as practicable but without interference with full effect being given to the foregoing notification.

('92', 240, 4, 7, 403487) 341. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 240, 5, 8, 403517) NEW DELHI, September 25, 1946
('92', 240, 6, 9, 403547) Mahatma Gandhi spoke to the prayer audience on two matters, on Wednesday evening.
('92', 240, 6, 10, 403629) First, he related how Shri Prakasam, Prime Minister of Madras, had under taken to carry out three big schemes in that province, viz., the production of khadi with a view to clothe the entire province with it in time, the encouragement of village industries and the introduction of Nayee Talim in the villages.
('92', 240, 7, 11, 403939) Mr. Prakasam and his Ministry were also determined to root out the evil of untouchability, which was a special blot on the fair name of Madras, as also to bring in the much needed reform of Prohibition.
('92', 240, 7, 12, 404142) All these schemes had for many years been part and parcel of the Congress programme.
('92', 240, 7, 13, 404227) To bring them into active existence, Gandhiji said, needed not to much intelligence as faith and determination, the faith and determination that enable man to die for a cause.
('92', 240, 8, 14, 404403) Congress leaders had to be true to their word and pure of heart.
('92', 240, 8, 15, 404468) They must not be tempted by crores.
('92', 240, 8, 16, 404504) They must be willing to go smiling to the gallows, if need be, for the sake of their principles.
('92', 240, 8, 17, 404601) Textile mills had been started everywhere even before the last war.
('92', 240, 8, 18, 404669) The provinces were being asked to start new ones.
('92', 240, 8, 19, 404719) The machinery for them would be costly, but the money that was supposed to follow in their wake was the lure.
('92', 240, 8, 20, 404829) Gandhiji explained how he thought textile mills were like poison for village India and therefore to be avoided.
('92', 240, 9, 21, 404941) People might wonder, Gandhiji explained, how he lived as a guest of a mill owner—but these mill owners had, in spite of his views, taken him in as one of their family, and non violence demanded tolerance and love for all even if they differed from one.
('92', 240, 9, 22, 405194) Shri Prakasam had promised Gandhiji that he would not be tempted with new textile mills for Madras and he would even hope to eliminate the existing ones as soon as enough khadi became available.
('92', 240, 9, 23, 405389) For as Gandhiji said, mills and khadi could not go hand in hand.
('92', 240, 9, 24, 405454) Khadi clothed everyone and put crores worth of cloth into the hands of the poor.
('92', 240, 9, 25, 405535) The crores accruing from mills went into a few hands.
('92', 240, 10, 26, 405589) The second topic which Gandhiji referred to was food.
('92', 240, 10, 27, 405643) Gandhiji said that Shri Rajendra Prasad had the heart of a king.
('92', 240, 10, 28, 405708) He would share his last crust of bread with the
('92', 241, 0, 1, 405756) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 241, 1, 2, 405798) The moment he heard a cry of distress from the South he got rice from wherever he could and promised them supplies.
('92', 241, 1, 3, 405914) Gandhiji asked Shri Prakasam how his province could ever starve.
('92', 241, 1, 4, 405979) He knew well the people of South India.
('92', 241, 1, 5, 406019) His first introduction to the latter was in South Africa through a poor indentured labourer Balasundaram whose case he had sponsored.
('92', 241, 1, 6, 406153) The poor man had his teeth knocked out.
('92', 241, 1, 7, 406193) Later, when indentured Indians joined the Satyagraha movement he saw how clever and self reliant they were.
('92', 241, 1, 8, 406301) They only got a pound of bread and an ounce of sugar and during the resistance march he heard them singing and cooking a vegetable meal for themselves from soft edible leaves on the ground.
('92', 241, 1, 9, 406491) Theirs was a land which produced the banana, the coconut, the yam, tamarind, greens and chillies.
('92', 241, 1, 10, 406589) What more did they want?
('92', 241, 2, 11, 406614) They with their intelligence and resourcefulness could easily learn to do without rice if they were asked to do so.
('92', 241, 2, 12, 406730) Gandhiji said he had asked Shri Prakasam not to worry.
('92', 241, 2, 13, 406785) Shri Rajen Babu and he (Mr. Prakasam) had promised he would not.
('92', 241, 2, 14, 406850) It remained to be seen what strength he was given by God to make Madras self sufficient.
('92', 241, 2, 15, 406939) It behoved everyone today, wherever they were, to be self reliant and resourceful, brave and willing, with intelligence and determination to face the food crisis.
('92', 241, 2, 16, 407102) If all joined forces it would be well with India.
('92', 241, 2, 17, 407152) The Hindustan Times, 26 9 1946

('92', 244, 7, 24, 410559) NEW DELHI, September 26, 1946
('92', 244, 8, 25, 410589) Mahatma Gandhi asked the prayer audience on Thursday evening to ponder over the fact that all was not well with them.
('92', 244, 8, 26, 410707) News of stabbing affrays came daily whether from Calcutta, Bombay, Ahmedabad, Dacca or elsewhere.
('92', 244, 8, 27, 410805) This showed that they were not making any real progress.
('92', 244, 8, 28, 410862) The latter could only be if they made God witness to every action of theirs.
('92', 244, 8, 29, 410939) Mirabai’s hymn that they had listened to during the prayer told them that God was the only one who could rid them of their woes and heal their pain.
('92', 244, 8, 30, 411088) The devotee called God “Thou”—the most familiar of epithets—because all contact with Him was through love.
('92', 244, 8, 31, 411195) It was up to man to own his own weakness.
('92', 244, 8, 32, 411237) He was nothing without God’s grace.
('92', 244, 8, 33, 411273) If they leant on Him, then alone would one or the other party drop the sword.
('92', 245, 0, 1, 411351) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 245, 1, 2, 411393) A brave Bengali had put some questions to him, Gandhiji said, as to how they should act at such times as Calcutta had recently been through.
('92', 245, 1, 3, 411534) His advice was that the highest duty would be for Hindu or Muslim to lay down his life without retaliation.
('92', 245, 1, 4, 411642) Gandhiji said he was daily receiving letters from friends to say that some relative or other had died.
('92', 245, 1, 5, 411745) He wrote to all that they should not mourn nor should they expect him to sorrow with them.
('92', 245, 1, 6, 411836) Man is born to die.
('92', 245, 1, 7, 411856) Death is the natural corollary to physical birth.
('92', 245, 1, 8, 411906) It is the soul alone that is immortal.
('92', 245, 1, 9, 411945) So, whether God sent them a natural death or whether they were killed by the assassin’s knife, they must go smiling to their end.
('92', 245, 2, 10, 412075) Man cannot really kill anyone, said Gandhiji.
('92', 245, 2, 11, 412121) That power rests in God’s hands.
('92', 245, 2, 12, 412154) If they realized this, there would not be knives and sticks seen all over the place, as they were today.
('92', 245, 2, 13, 412259) Gandhiji, therefore, asked all to pray to God to rid this land of the present trial and give them the strength to live and die without killing.

('92', 245, 3, 15, 412434) 350. DISCUSSION WITH LORD WAVELL 1
('92', 245, 4, 16, 412469) September 26, 1946
('92', 245, 5, 17, 412488) Lord wavell left the Interim Government not a moment’s respite.
('92', 245, 5, 18, 412552) On the 26th September, he invited Gandhiji to meet him.
('92', 245, 5, 19, 412608) In the course of their meeting he again returned to his pet theme :
('92', 245, 6, 20, 412676) VICEROY: The League must be brought in somehow.
('92', 245, 7, 21, 412724) GANDHIJI: The Congress is ready provided the League is willing to come in a straight way.
('92', 245, 7, 22, 412814) Let Jinnah seek an interview with Pandit Nehru and come to an honourable understanding.
('92', 245, 7, 23, 412902) It will be a great day if and when the Congress and the League come together in the Interim Government after a mutual understanding, without any mental reservations, and not to non co operate and fight.
('92', 245, 8, 24, 413105) V. The only stumbling block is the inclusion of a nationalist Muslim in the Interim Government.
('92', 245, 8, 25, 413201) The Congress has undoubted right to nominate a nationalist Muslim.
('92', 245, 8, 26, 413268) But in view of the fact that Jinnah is obstinate on that point, where is the harm in waiving it?
('92', 245, 9, 27, 413365) G. One may waive a right, one cannot waive a duty.
('92', 245, 10, 28, 413416) V. But if the League refuses to come in, what happens to the Constituent Assembly?
('92', 245, 11, 29, 413499) G. I admit that in that event the Constituent Assembl cannot properly meet.I must, however, make it clear that in this I represent nobody but myself.
('92', 245, 12, 30, 413649) 1 For Wavell’s version of the discussion, vide Appendix “Lord Wavell’s Note on Interview with Gandhiji”, 26 9 1946.

('92', 246, 1, 2, 413810) V. Let us pursue this line of thinking a little further.

('92', 246, 7, 16, 414632) 351. THE RIGHTS OF HARIJANS 1
('92', 246, 8, 17, 414662) I have received letters from Harijan friends and some have been to see me too.
('92', 246, 8, 18, 414741) They feel that now that power is in the hands of the people, there should be more than one Harijanminister.
('92', 246, 8, 19, 414849) According to the population ratio the number should be at least three, and they should be similarly represented in every department.
('92', 246, 8, 20, 414982) They hold that it would be erroneous to argue that there are not enough able persons among them.
('92', 246, 8, 21, 415079) Besides, it is not as if only able persons were taken in every province.
('92', 246, 8, 22, 415152) Numerous instances of nepotism could be cited.
('92', 246, 8, 23, 415199) I am not ready to admit the correctness of all they say.
('92', 246, 8, 24, 415256) My ideas in this regard are different.
('92', 246, 8, 25, 415295) Man must pursue his duty, his dharma.
('92', 246, 8, 26, 415333) Rights spring only from duties well done.
('92', 246, 8, 27, 415375) Such rights alone are becoming and lasting.
('92', 246, 8, 28, 415419) There are vast numbers of non Harijans possessing ability.
('92', 246, 8, 29, 415478) If they all claimed their right society would be disrupted.
('92', 246, 8, 30, 415538) Performance of duty is open to every one.
('92', 246, 8, 31, 415580) The field of service is immense.
('92', 246, 8, 32, 415613) Only a few can become leaders and those who try to do so do fall behind.
('92', 246, 8, 33, 415686) I know, however, that people do not act as I have suggested.
('92', 246, 8, 34, 415747) There is generally a scramble for power and many have to be disappointed.
('92', 246, 8, 35, 415821) Holding the views I do, and having acted on them and made others act on them over the last fifty years, I have no interest left in
('92', 246, 9, 36, 415952) 1 A translation of this also appeared in Harijan, 6 10 1946
('92', 247, 0, 1, 416012) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 247, 1, 2, 416054) fighting for personal rights.
('92', 247, 1, 3, 416084) I shall therefore advise Harijan brethren that they should think only of their duties.
('92', 247, 1, 4, 416171) They may be sure that rights will follow fast on the heels of duties done.

('92', 247, 2, 6, 416317) 352. LETTER TO LORD WAVELL
('92', 247, 3, 7, 416344) VALMIKI MANDIR, READING ROAD, NEW DELHI, September 27, 1946
('92', 247, 4, 8, 416404) DEAR FRIEND, It occurs to me that I should reduce to writing my impressions of our talk of yesterday.
('92', 247, 5, 9, 416506) You were good enough to explain to me at length the result so far of your effort at peace making between the Congress and the Muslim League.
('92', 247, 5, 10, 416647) In the course of our conversation you told me that your leanings were towards the League.
('92', 247, 5, 11, 416737) In your opinion there was left only one point of difference between the two parties, viz., the question of representation of a non League Muslim out of the Congress quota.
('92', 247, 5, 12, 416909) You recognized fully the reasonableness of the Congress position but you held that it would be an act of high statesmanship if the Congress waived the right for the sake of peace.
('92', 247, 5, 13, 417089) I urged that if it was a question of waiving a right it would be a simple thing.
('92', 247, 5, 14, 417170) It was a question of non performance of a duty which the Congress owed to non League Muslims.
('92', 247, 5, 15, 417264) I entirely agreed with you on the proposition that it would be a great day if and when the Congress and the Muslim League came to a mutual understanding without reservations, mental or otherwise, and that it would be worse than useless if the two came together only with a view to fight each other.
('92', 247, 5, 16, 417563) Moreover, I stressed the point that Quaid e Azam Jinnah should seek an interview with Pandit Nehru and try to come to an honourable understanding.
('92', 247, 5, 17, 417710) If, however, the worst happened and the Muslim League boycott of the Constituent Assem bly persisted and the British Government decided to discontinue the Constituent Assembly, I would hold it to be perfectly honourable.
('92', 247, 6, 18, 417931) 1Vide “Discussion with Lord Waveli”, 26 9 1946 and Appendix “Lord Wavell’s Note on Interview with Gandhiji”, 26 9 1946.
('92', 248, 0, 1, 418051) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 249
('92', 248, 1, 2, 418096) even though the Cabinet Mission had led one to suppose that they would continue the Constituent Assembly, I did not expect that they would or could continue it in spite of the successful boycott by one of the major parties.
('92', 248, 1, 3, 418320) You then interpolated the remark that there were three parties, not only two.
('92', 248, 1, 4, 418398) The States were the third party.
('92', 248, 1, 5, 418431) You added that if the boycott persisted you had grave doubts as to whether the States would come in.
('92', 248, 1, 6, 418532) Though I might be alone to hold the view, I said that I could not envisage the framing of a workable constitution if one of the two parties withheld co operation and force had to be used to keep the boycotters under restraint.
('92', 248, 1, 7, 418759) You then asked me to work out the logical conclusion of the discontinuance of the Constituent Assembly and asked me what I thought of the Interim Government.
('92', 248, 1, 8, 418917) I told you that I had little doubt that no matter what happened, the National Government, having been once summoned, should continue to function unless they themselves felt unable, owing to their own incompetence or inability, to do so.
('92', 248, 1, 9, 419154) I added that the Congress had put up its very best men, not at all in the spirit of gaining power for a party but in the spirit of selfless service of the whole nation.
('92', 248, 1, 10, 419323) They were so considerate towards you and the League that they had hesitated to fill in the two Muslim seats in the hope of the League coming into the Interim Government.
('92', 248, 1, 11, 419493) You doubted if you could contemplate the continuance of the Interim Government and that in any case you were only a servant of the Crown and that you would have to take your order from His Majesty’s Government.
('92', 248, 1, 12, 419704) Whilst I appreciated your stand, I said the continuance of a bona fide National Government at the Centre was a vital necessity and that any departure from it would lay the British people open to the gravest suspicion on the part of the people of India and would be a tragedy of the first magnitude.
('92', 248, 1, 13, 420003) At the conclusion of our cordial talk, encouraged by you to say anything further if I wished to, I mentioned the Kashmir case about which the Working Committee had passed a very just resolution which, in the event of Kashmir State’s obstinacy or notions of false prestige, might lead to far reaching consequences and I asked for your friendly, as distinguished from legal, assistance to smooth out rough edges.
('92', 249, 0, 1, 420414) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 249, 1, 2, 420456) I had a talk last night with Pandit Nehru and Sardar Patel and as a result I have decided to stay on here for some days, maybe even a month.
('92', 249, 3, 3, 420597) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI H. E. THE VICEROY THE VICEROY’S HOUSE NEW DELHI

('92', 252, 1, 2, 423606) 358. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 252, 2, 3, 423636) NEW DELHI, September 27, 1946
('92', 252, 3, 4, 423666) Mahatma Gandhi at his after prayer speech on Friday evening, narrated a curious incident of a magistrate resorting to hunger strike in order to persuade people in his area to obey his orders.
('92', 252, 4, 5, 423858) This story had come to Gandhiji from an Indian State.
('92', 252, 4, 6, 423912) Briefly, some goondas had looted some shops and even beaten some persons.
('92', 252, 4, 7, 423986) The inhabitants were frightened and the shopkeepers closed their shops.
('92', 252, 4, 8, 424058) A special magistrate was sent to restore order.
('92', 252, 4, 9, 424106) He could not prevail upon the shop keepers to open their shops in spite of the assurances he gave them.
('92', 252, 4, 10, 424210) As the people were put to great inconvenience the magistrate, instead of resorting to the law and forcibly having the shops opened, undertook a fast.
('92', 252, 4, 11, 424360) The effect on the populace was almost immediate and calm was restored and the culprits caught.
('92', 252, 5, 12, 424455) Gandhiji said he had never heard of such action by a magistrate.
('92', 252, 5, 13, 424520) As a rule, officials were hard and rigid.
('92', 252, 5, 14, 424562) It was, however, possible for the Vice roy or a Prince to act as this magistrate did.
('92', 252, 5, 15, 424648) Officials differed only in rank.
('92', 252, 5, 16, 424681) Perhaps people would say that it would be madness for them to do so.
('92', 252, 5, 17, 424750) But Gandhiji did not think so.
('92', 252, 5, 18, 424781) Many people today resorted to hunger strike for all sorts of demands.
('92', 252, 5, 19, 424851) Those were not proper fasts.
('92', 252, 5, 20, 424880) This fast was undertaken to allay the sufferings of the poor people and melt the hearts of those who were putting them to trouble.
('92', 252, 5, 21, 425011) It was, therefore, a big act if the story was true.
('92', 252, 5, 22, 425063) It should be a matter of pride and joy that there was such a magistrate in India.
('92', 252, 5, 23, 425145) He hoped there were many more.
('92', 252, 6, 24, 425176) Shri Suchetabehn having sung one of Gurudev’s Bengali hymns at the prayer that day (Friday), Gandhiji referred to the desirability of having such gems translated into Hindustani.
('92', 252, 6, 25, 425355) Mahadev Desai, who was a worshipper at the shrine of Gurudev’s poetry, had done a translation of this particular ‘bhajan’ into Gujarati.
('92', 252, 6, 26, 425492) There were few among them, but there ought to be many more, who should be familiar with Indian languages so that they could easily make translations of what was worth while.
('92', 252, 6, 27, 425666) Gandhiji hoped to give them a Hindustani translation of the ‘bhajan’ the next day and to continue the practice when a non Hindustani ‘bhajan’ was sung.
('92', 252, 6, 28, 425818) He would not promise them printed translations.
('92', 252, 6, 29, 425866) A servant of the people was a jealous trustee of the money he might raise.
('92', 252, 6, 30, 425941) The Hindustan Times, 28 9 1946
('92', 253, 0, 1, 425972) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 253, 1, 2, 426014) 359. A DEED OF MERCY 1
('92', 253, 2, 3, 426037) A Pathan, an ex I. N. A. man, now employed by a firm, tried to defend a lad of 10 years.
('92', 253, 2, 4, 426126) His entreaty was in vain.
('92', 253, 2, 5, 426152) The assailants stabbed both the boy and the Pathan.
('92', 253, 2, 6, 426204) The boy died.
('92', 253, 2, 7, 426218) The Pathan lives.
('92', 253, 2, 8, 426236) The deceased boy’s father offered Rs. 4,000 as a reward for his bravery.
('92', 253, 2, 9, 426309) He refused saying he tried to do his duty and would not take the reward offered.
('92', 253, 2, 10, 426390) Would that such instances were multiplied!

('92', 253, 3, 12, 426482) 360. RIDING TWO HORSES 2
('92', 253, 4, 13, 426507) There are a fair number of Tantis in Orissa.
('92', 253, 4, 14, 426552) In law they are classed as Harijans and are known as Pan Tantis.
('92', 253, 4, 15, 426617) Many of them earn their living in Kolhan in Singbhum District.
('92', 253, 4, 16, 426680) They do not call themselves Pan Tantis but only Tantis.
('92', 253, 4, 17, 426736) As a result they are not classed with Harijans in Bihar.
('92', 253, 4, 18, 426793) Their leaders also, when entering office, do not identify themselves as Harijans.
('92', 253, 4, 19, 426875) In my view what they do is right.
('92', 253, 4, 20, 426909) Why should one desire to be classed as a Harijan?
('92', 253, 4, 21, 426959) What is to be gained by it, unless it is the votes, Governmental assistance and scholarship from the Harijan Sevak Sangh for education?
('92', 253, 4, 22, 427095) Why should one demean oneself for this?
('92', 253, 4, 23, 427135) The very idea is debasing.
('92', 253, 4, 24, 427162) Is one to debase oneself for bread?
('92', 253, 4, 25, 427198) Tantis do not have to be Pan Tantis.
('92', 253, 4, 26, 427235) Today we have popular governments.
('92', 253, 4, 27, 427270) It is their duty to see that backward classes get the same deal as Harijans in the matter of education, etc.
('92', 253, 4, 28, 427379) It was the British Government that constituted the Harijans into a separate class.
('92', 253, 4, 29, 427462) To the popular government all poor and illiterate people are one, or should be.
('92', 253, 4, 30, 427542) It cannot distinguish between high and low, between this religion and that, for all are Indian.
('92', 253, 4, 31, 427638) The Tantis should not try to become Harijans.
('92', 253, 4, 32, 427684) They should also not hanker after Government jobs.
('92', 253, 4, 33, 427735) What will happen to the crores of other Indians will happen to them and others like them.

('92', 258, 1, 2, 434115) 367. CRIMINAL WASTE 1
('92', 258, 2, 3, 434137) All the suggestions made by the writer can and should be adopted at once if a major disaster is to be averted.
('92', 258, 2, 4, 434248) Harijan, 29 9 1946
('92', 258, 3, 5, 434267) 368. THOU TOO, BIHAR !
('92', 258, 4, 6, 434290) It is a grim irony of fate that Bihar, which did so well during the golden days of satyagraha should now disgrace itself by criminal lawlessness.
('92', 258, 4, 7, 434436) If the news published is authentic, chain pulling and stopping trains without cause has become a common occurrence in Bihar, with the result that the trains rarely run to time.
('92', 258, 4, 8, 434613) Passengers consider it superfluous to buy tickets for train journeys.
('92', 258, 4, 9, 434683) Under a national government, they argue, payment should be unnecessary.
('92', 258, 4, 10, 434755) Jai Hind is regarded as a cry for loot and murder.
('92', 258, 4, 11, 434806) I do not know what truth there is in these charges which are as wild as they well can be.
('92', 258, 4, 12, 434896) I know some parts of Bihar where persons do not distinguish between things lawful and unlawful.
('92', 258, 4, 13, 434992) I have even heard the argument that I am largely responsible for the prevailing lawlessness, not only in Bihar but throughout India.
('92', 258, 4, 14, 435125) I need hardly say that it is a thoughtless charge.
('92', 258, 4, 15, 435176) The lawlessness, if it can be so descri bed, that I have advocated is like prescribing wholesome and neces sary food for the body.
('92', 258, 4, 16, 435307) Behind my ‘lawlessness’ there is discipline, construction and well being of society.
('92', 258, 4, 17, 435392) It is an effective protest against unjust and injurious law or act.
('92', 258, 4, 18, 435460) It can never take the form of selfish evasion of a duty.
('92', 258, 4, 19, 435517) It is a duty never to pull the alarm chain except in well defined and rare emergencies and never to travel without due payment for the class in which we travel.
('92', 258, 4, 20, 435678) Loot, arson and murder have never been part of my programme of so called lawlessness.
('92', 258, 4, 21, 435764) The answer to the argument that whilst my programme may be good enough for a select few, it can never be for the masses, lies in the question whether I am expected to starve the masses of good food for fear of their taking bad or poisonous food.
('92', 258, 4, 22, 436010) I have purposely entered upon what appears to be a personal
('92', 258, 5, 23, 436070) 1 The article under this title by Amrit Kaur described the inefficiency with which stocks of foodgrains were handled and suggested ways of saving food.

('92', 259, 2, 7, 436825) 369. NOTES
('92', 259, 3, 8, 436836) CO OPERATIVES IN KERALA
('92', 259, 4, 9, 436860) Kelappan came to see me two days ago and informed me that co operative movement was going strong and had become very popular in Kerala.
('92', 259, 4, 10, 436996) If the societies are sound, it was heartening news that Sjt.
('92', 259, 4, 11, 437057) Kelappan gave me.
('92', 259, 4, 12, 437075) I, however, expressed my serious doubts.
('92', 259, 4, 13, 437116) The secret of successful co operative effort is that the members must be honest and know the great merit of co operation and it must have a definite progressive goal.
('92', 259, 4, 14, 437283) Thus holding a certain sum of money in co operation for the sake of making more money by charging exorbitant rates of interest is a bad goal.
('92', 259, 4, 15, 437425) But co operative farming or dairying is undoubtedly a good goal promoting a national interest.
('92', 259, 4, 16, 437520) Such instan ces can be multiplied.
('92', 259, 4, 17, 437555) I wonder what these numerous Kerala societies are.
('92', 259, 4, 18, 437606) Have they honest inspectors who know their work?
('92', 259, 4, 19, 437655) It may be mentioned that such movements have often proved disastrous when the management has been dishonest and the goal questionable.

('92', 261, 6, 13, 439849) 372. HAND SPINNING v.
('92', 261, 6, 14, 439871) MILL SPINNING
('92', 261, 7, 15, 439885) Some time before the Provincial Ministries throughout India were formed, I had heard that quotas of spindles were offered to the Provinces on pain—if a particular province did not take its quota—of the refused quota being transferred to the other provinces.
('92', 261, 7, 16, 440143) Now that the Provincial administrations are in full swing, the question has arisen as to whether these Governments can admit new mills and, at the same time, promote hand spinning on a national scale.
('92', 261, 7, 17, 440344) My answer is emphatically in the negative, if the encouragement of hand spinning is meant to be sincere.
('92', 261, 7, 18, 440449) Behind the India wide quota is the fundamental belief that mills alone can and must supply India’s needs for cloth and that hand spun may be permitted to exist for the fastidious few.
('92', 261, 7, 19, 440633) That was not how hand spinning was conceived in Congress resolutions and that certainly is not the way that the A. I. S. A. has progressed.
('92', 261, 7, 20, 440773) If the national Governments have come to the conclusion that hand spinning has and should have no future, they should not waste a single rupee along the lines followed by the A. I. S. A. If, on the other hand, they share the belief of the A. I. S. A., they should forgo their quota even if the forgoing should involve some initial loss.
('92', 261, 7, 21, 441110) The loss will be demonstrably for the future gain of the masses.
('92', 261, 7, 22, 441175) Another question has arisen as to why the Working Committee should not, at any rate, declare a uniform policy to be followed by all the Congress Provinces.There is nothing to prevent the Committee from doing so.
('92', 261, 7, 23, 441387) But it is open to them to say that the Congress policy has been enunciated times without number.
('92', 261, 7, 24, 441484) Each Province has to
('92', 262, 0, 1, 441505) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 263
('92', 262, 1, 2, 441550) measure its own belief in the Congress scales.
('92', 262, 1, 3, 441597) The Working Committee might not go into details.
('92', 262, 1, 4, 441646) Then why may not the Central Government lay down a policy?
('92', 262, 1, 5, 441705) The answer is obvious.The Central Government represents all India and all parties.
('92', 262, 1, 6, 441788) It may not, therefore, lay down any exclusively Con gress policy, much less a policy in a matter wholly within the jurisdiction of the Provinces.
('92', 262, 1, 7, 441934) It would be an unwarranted interference with the rights of Provinces.
('92', 262, 1, 8, 442004) Looked at from all points of view, in the matter of khadi as of prohibition and other subjects allotted to the Provinces, the Provinces must evolve along their own lines.
('92', 262, 1, 9, 442175) They will miserably fail if they look to the Working Committee to guide them.
('92', 262, 1, 10, 442253) The Central Government simply has not the right, even if it had the unholy wish.
('92', 262, 1, 11, 442334) NEW DELHI, September 30, 1946 Harijan 6 10 1946
('92', 262, 2, 12, 442382) 373. SCAVENGERS’ LOT
('92', 262, 3, 13, 442403) Q. You have doubtless written on this subject before but I would like you to say a word again in regard to the duty of municipal and other authority as well as private employers in the matter of providing Bhangis with the proper means of scavenging.
('92', 262, 3, 14, 442653) Unless water tight iron pails are provided, for example, the drippings during the rainy season, through baskets or gunny bags, fall on the unfortunate workers.
('92', 262, 3, 15, 442813) All scavenging should really be able to be done without soiling the hands or any part of the body.
('92', 262, 3, 16, 442912) If this were so, the work would assume a dignity which it does not carry at the moment.
('92', 262, 3, 17, 443000) Along with the supply of proper means of scavenging, sweeping, etc., the Bhangi needs instruction.
('92', 262, 3, 18, 443099) It is a matter which local and provincial authority should take up in the cause of cleanliness.
('92', 262, 4, 19, 443195) A. I would advocate bye laws requiring authorized receptacles, brooms, etc., which would avoid physical handling of dirt and would also prescribe simple working costume.
('92', 262, 4, 20, 443365) Inspectors or overseers will be trained for the humane and sanitary work instead of being expec ted to exact work anyhow.
('92', 262, 4, 21, 443487) The result of the present system is maxi mum of insanitation and minimum of work plus bribery, corruption and bad manners.

('92', 263, 1, 2, 443701) 374. HOW?
('92', 263, 2, 3, 443711) A correspondent writes :
('92', 263, 3, 4, 443736) You are aware of the backward States of the Simla Hills.
('92', 263, 3, 5, 443793) The Raja Saheb of Rampur Bushahr is a man of orthodox views.
('92', 263, 3, 6, 443854) Recently a young man of a high caste Hindu family married a Koli girl.
('92', 263, 3, 7, 443925) The Lambardar of the village (Mandhol) brought the matter to the notice of the ruler.
('92', 263, 3, 8, 444011) The Raja Saheb has sentenced both husband and wife to six months’ imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 100 each.
('92', 263, 3, 9, 444118) Such action is intolerable and retards progress.
('92', 263, 3, 10, 444167) Some others who were contemplating inter caste marriages have been deterred.
('92', 263, 4, 11, 444244) Must we wait till autocracy is wiped out?
('92', 263, 4, 12, 444286) The rule of one man over many is intolerable.
('92', 263, 4, 13, 444332) It must end.
('92', 263, 4, 14, 444345) How is the question.
('92', 263, 4, 15, 444366) The way is for the many to begin to live.
('92', 263, 4, 16, 444408) To cut off the head of one ruler is easy enough.
('92', 263, 4, 17, 444457) Remember the legend of Ravana.
('92', 263, 4, 18, 444488) He had ten heads.
('92', 263, 4, 19, 444506) As soon as one was cut off, another popped up in its place.
('92', 263, 4, 20, 444566) The moral is that no cutting off of heads becomes necessary in the presence of a living Demos.
('92', 263, 4, 21, 444661) The one will respond and submit.
('92', 263, 4, 22, 444694) In the given instance the couple will cheerfully undergo the sentence.
('92', 263, 4, 23, 444765) Only many should follow their example, if the tie is not lustful bondage but a bond of love born out of the zeal for reform.
('92', 263, 4, 24, 444890) If the reformers do not wish to suffer imprisonment, they should migrate to a free place where they can live without let or hindrance.

('92', 270, 11, 19, 453821) 389 SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 270, 12, 20, 453852) [October 1, 1946] In the song that has just been sung, the poet says that he who loses the self finds God.
('92', 270, 12, 21, 453959) If we understand its significance, we really need nothing more.
('92', 270, 12, 22, 454023) This is what the spinning wheel teaches us.
('92', 270, 13, 23, 454067) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 7 10 1946
('92', 271, 0, 1, 454122) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 271, 1, 2, 454164) might ask how it is possible to find God through the spinning wheel.
('92', 271, 1, 3, 454233) As I have told you before, the spinning wheel enables us to identify ourselves with the millions.
('92', 271, 1, 4, 454331) The millionaires imagine that money can bring them anything in the world.
('92', 271, 1, 5, 454405) But it is not so.
('92', 271, 1, 6, 454423) At any moment death might come and snuff them out.
('92', 271, 1, 7, 454474) Some are being stabbed daily but losing one’s life that way is not the same thing as shedding the self.
('92', 271, 1, 8, 454578) One has to learn to efface the self or the ego voluntarily and as a sacrifice in order to find God.
('92', 271, 1, 9, 454678) The spinning wheel rules out exclusive ness.
('92', 271, 1, 10, 454723) It stands for all, including the poorest.
('92', 271, 1, 11, 454765) It, therefore, requires us to be humble and to cast away pride completely.
('92', 271, 1, 12, 454840) It holds the key to swaraj.
('92', 271, 1, 13, 454868) But can one spin for swaraj and yet not be filled with subtle pride?
('92', 271, 1, 14, 454937) If pride is there, spinning won’t bring one the swaraj of the spirit or the realization of God.
('92', 271, 1, 15, 455033) When the self is shed the change will be reflected in our out ward behaviour.
('92', 271, 1, 16, 455111) It will show in the least of our little acts.
('92', 271, 1, 17, 455157) The whole outlook on life will be changed.
('92', 271, 1, 18, 455200) Everything we do will be undertaken not for the self but for all.
('92', 271, 1, 19, 455266) The hymn goes on to say that to find God one need not go out anywhere.
('92', 271, 1, 20, 455337) He resides in our hearts.
('92', 271, 1, 21, 455363) But if we instal the self or the ego there we dethrone poor God.
('92', 271, 1, 22, 455428) I have here used the epithet ‘poor’ advisedly.For, although He is the King of kings, Most High Almighty, yet He is at the beck and call of anyone who has reduced himself to zero and turns to Him in uttermost humility of spirit.
('92', 271, 1, 23, 455656) Let us then become poor in spirit and find Him within ourselves.
('92', 271, 1, 24, 455721) Harijan, 13 10 1946

('92', 275, 1, 2, 459420) 398. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 275, 2, 3, 459450) NEW DELHI, October 2, 1946 It is as though God had sent us a special message in the form of this song.
('92', 275, 2, 4, 459553) 1 In truth the springs of India’s life are drying up.
('92', 275, 2, 5, 459607) It would be folly to suppose that because there is a Congress Government at the Centre all is well.
('92', 275, 2, 6, 459707) I shall not dwell on the stabbings that are going on, shocking as they are.
('92', 275, 2, 7, 459783) To illustrate to you how the springs of our life are drying up, I shall say something on what is going on in Goa.
('92', 275, 2, 8, 459897) Goa is a small island.
('92', 275, 2, 9, 459920) It is an integral part of India.
('92', 275, 2, 10, 459953) News has come that Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia has been arrested immediately on his arrival there and placed in solitary confinement.
('92', 275, 2, 11, 460081) A few days ago Shri Kakodkar was arrested for having raised his voice for civil liberty and sentenced to imprisonment for nine years.
('92', 275, 2, 12, 460215) It is being said that he may be deported.
('92', 275, 2, 13, 460257) Dr. Lohia is a learned man.
('92', 275, 2, 14, 460285) I may not agree with his views but this does not mean that I can remain untouched by his case.
('92', 275, 2, 15, 460380) You must all be as much pained as I am by the arrest of Dr. Lohia and the happenings in Goa.
('92', 275, 2, 16, 460473) I carried on some correspondence with the authorities in Goa, but it was infructuous.
('92', 275, 2, 17, 460559) To tell any Indian that he cannot enter Goa is as insulting as to tell me that I may not enter any particular part of India.
('92', 275, 2, 18, 460684) Goa is as much a part of India as Kashmir or any other State.
('92', 275, 2, 19, 460746) It is intolerable that Dr. Lohia should be treated as foreigner and denied the right of entry into Goa.
('92', 275, 2, 20, 460850) Let us see what steps Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, who has donned the crown of thorns, and Lord Wavell take to see that this high handedness on the part of the Goa authorities is stopped.
('92', 275, 2, 21, 461034) [From Hindi] Hindustan, 3 10 1946
('92', 275, 3, 22, 461068) 1 A song written by Rabindranath Tagore and sung at the congregation.
('92', 275, 3, 23, 461138) Translated, its first line read : “When the springs of life are drying up, do then come as a shower of mercy.”

('92', 276, 1, 2, 461294) 399. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('92', 276, 2, 3, 461322) NEW DELHI, October 3, 1946 In the context of the forthcoming Congress Presidential election, some friends tell me, it is being said that I am in favour of Acharya Kripalani being elected.
('92', 276, 2, 4, 461510) I have also been shown a newspaper report to this effect.
('92', 276, 2, 5, 461568) Although I do have my own personal views in the matter I have told friends who came to consult me not to cite my name in any way in connection with the election.
('92', 276, 2, 6, 461730) It is my firm view that Con gressmen should exercise their vote in this election without being influenced by any other Congressman or by those who are not mem bers of the Congress, such as myself.
('92', 276, 2, 7, 461927) Congressmen should consider what is best in the interest of the country and vote accordingly.
('92', 276, 2, 8, 462021) [From Hindi] Hindustan, 4 10 1946
('92', 276, 3, 9, 462055) 400. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 276, 4, 10, 462085) NEW DELHI, October 3, 1946
('92', 276, 5, 11, 462112) Gandhiji expressed satisfaction that the second charkha class was going on better than the first.
('92', 276, 5, 12, 462210) There were fewer absentees.
('92', 276, 5, 13, 462238) They had only three more days left, but if the will was there much work could be done in three days.
('92', 276, 6, 14, 462339) Gandhiji then referred to a letter he had received asking him how they should celebrate Dussehra.
('92', 276, 6, 15, 462437) Should they take out a procession and eat and drink and be merry?
('92', 276, 6, 16, 462503) Yesterday he had told them that the fountain of life had gone dry.
('92', 276, 6, 17, 462570) Could there be rejoicing in a country where daily stabbings were taking place and brother hated brother?
('92', 276, 6, 18, 462675) Dussehra was the celebration of Rama’s victory over Ravana, but this victory was not achieved by violence.
('92', 276, 7, 19, 462782) When Vibhishana asked Shri Ramachandra how unarmed, unshod, without any armour, he was going to defeat the heavily armed and mighty Ravana with his chariots, Rama’s reply was that it was faith and purity that would win the battle.
('92', 276, 7, 20, 463013) His bow was his self control.
('92', 276, 7, 21, 463043) His victory was the victory of good over evil.
('92', 276, 7, 22, 463090) Gandhiji, therefore, advised the people to spend Dussehra quietly at home in prayer if they had understood the real meaning of religion and Dussehra.
('92', 276, 8, 23, 463240) Gandhiji added that he was daily receiving letters of abuse saying that his
('92', 277, 0, 1, 463316) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 277, 1, 2, 463358) doctrine of non violence was emasculating Hindus, that he was no Mahatma, that he was injuring them and leading them astray.
('92', 277, 1, 3, 463483) He had never laid claim to being a Mahatma.
('92', 277, 1, 4, 463527) He was an ordinary mortal as anyone of them.
('92', 277, 1, 5, 463572) He hoped he had never injured anyone.
('92', 277, 1, 6, 463610) What he told them he told them for their own and universal good.
('92', 277, 1, 7, 463675) He had said that if they could not act non violently they should defend themselves violently rather than be cowards.
('92', 277, 2, 8, 463792) But the ability to die smiling at the hands of a brother without any retaliation, physical or mental, was the highest bravery.
('92', 277, 2, 9, 463919) In no case was it right to spoil for a fight.
('92', 277, 2, 10, 463965) That was no self defence.
('92', 277, 2, 11, 463991) It was bad for them, bad for the country and utter disloyalty to their leaders.
('92', 277, 2, 12, 464071) It was hindering them in their march towards swaraj.
('92', 277, 3, 13, 464124) Gandhiji reiterated that today no one had a right to feast and eat one morsel more than necessary.
('92', 277, 3, 14, 464223) If they behaved in a disciplined manner, India would live.
('92', 277, 3, 15, 464282) If they did not, then India would die and they would be unable to hold their heads high.
('92', 277, 3, 16, 464371) The Hindustan Times, 4 10 1946

('92', 278, 1, 2, 464676) 402. AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CONGRESS, THE MUSLIM LEAGUE AND THE NAWAB OF BHOPAL 1
('92', 278, 2, 3, 464757) October 4, 1946 The Congress does not challenge and accepts that the Muslim League now is the authoritative representative of an overwhelming majority of the Muslims of India.
('92', 278, 2, 4, 464933) As such and in accordance with democratic principles they alone have today an unquestionable right to represent the Muslims of India.
('92', 278, 2, 5, 465067) But the Congress cannot agree that any restriction or limitation should be put upon the Congress to choose such representatives as they think proper from amongst the members of the Congress as their representatives.
('92', 278, 2, 6, 465283) It is understood that all the Ministers of the Interim Govern ment will work as a team for the good of the whole of India and will never invoke the intervention of the Governor General in any case.
('92', 278, 2, 7, 465481) I accept this formula.
('92', 278, 3, 8, 465504) M. K. GANDHI HAMIDULLAH [NAWAB OF BHOPAL] SHOAIB QURESHI
('92', 278, 4, 9, 465561) Sardar Patel’s Correspondence, Vol. III, p.
('92', 278, 5, 10, 465605) 1 This was intended to enable the Muslim League to join the Interim Government, which was to consist of 14 members—6 from the Congress, 5 from the League and 3 representatives of minorities to be nominated by the Viceroy.
('92', 278, 5, 11, 465827) Jinnah put forth the condition that there should be no Muslim among the nominees of the Congress.
('92', 278, 5, 12, 465925) Gandhiji therefore accepted the formula laid down in the agreement.
('92', 278, 5, 13, 465993) As it was, it found no approval from other Congress leaders, notably Nehru, who found the formula “not happily worded”.
('92', 278, 5, 14, 466113) In a letter to Jinnah he was prepared to concede to the Muslim League “the right to represent the Muslims of India, provided that for identical reasons the League recognized the Congress as the authoritative organization representing all non Muslims and such Muslims as have thrown in their lot with the Congress.” He further suggested that no formula was necessary.
('92', 278, 5, 15, 466480) In the event the Congress list contained the name of Asaf Ali and the League nominated Jogendranath Mandal.
('92', 279, 0, 1, 466588) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('92', 280, 9, 19, 468537) NEW DELHI, October 4, 1946 In the song that has been sung Mirabai says that she has bought Govind.
('92', 280, 9, 20, 468636) There is a similar song by her in Gujarati, too.
('92', 280, 9, 21, 468685) How can one buy God?
('92', 280, 9, 22, 468706) Not with money, but with love certainly.

('92', 281, 2, 21, 470222) 408. ROWDYISM RUN RIOT

('92', 282, 3, 4, 471480) 409. QUESTION BOX 1
('92', 282, 4, 5, 471500) IS NOT WORK WORSHIP?
('92', 282, 5, 6, 471521) Q. Would it not be better for a man to give the time he spends in worship to the service of the poor?
('92', 282, 5, 7, 471623) If a man did this, would worship be still necessary for him?
('92', 282, 6, 8, 471684) A. I sense mental laziness and unbelief in the question.
('92', 282, 6, 9, 471741) The biggest of karmayogis never give up devotional singing and worship.
('92', 282, 6, 10, 471813) Of course as a general principle it can be said that selfless service itself is worship and those who engage in it do not need any other kind of worship.
('92', 282, 6, 11, 471967) But in truth bhajans, etc., are a help in the work of service and keep the awareness of God ever fresh.
('92', 282, 7, 12, 472071) HOW TO REMOVE UNTOUCHABILITY
('92', 282, 8, 13, 472100) Q. It is no doubt good to provide education to Harijans, to let them use pub lic wells and visit temples, but really Harijans should not be segregated in cherries and the like.
('92', 282, 8, 14, 472277) Then alone can untouchability be uprooted.
('92', 282, 9, 15, 472320) A. It feels good to say that Harijans not having separate quarters will be a sign of the vanishing of untouchability.
('92', 282, 9, 16, 472438) Even at present, so far as I know, there is no law compelling Harijans to live in locations especially built for them.
('92', 282, 9, 17, 472557) Only the evil custom segregates them.
('92', 282, 9, 18, 472595) The custom is going, though rather slowly.
('92', 282, 9, 19, 472638) It is the duty of all to do away with it.
('92', 282, 9, 20, 472680) It is a question of moving the hearts of people.
('92', 282, 9, 21, 472729) Such an enterprise can succeed only with tapascharya.
('92', 282, 9, 22, 472783) Tulsidas says : Through the power of tapa Brahma created the world.
('92', 282, 9, 23, 472851) Through the power of tapa Vishnu sustains the world.
('92', 282, 9, 24, 472904) Tapa, O Parvati, is the basis of all creation.
('92', 282, 9, 25, 472951) Go and do tapa, knowing this in heart.
('92', 282, 9, 26, 472990) The day someone is born who has this power everything will become easy and dharma will be saved.
