('92', 283, 0, 1, 473149) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 283, 1, 2, 473191) IS RAMANAMA THE SAME AS INCANTATIONS?
('92', 283, 2, 3, 473229) Q. My nephew was ill.
('92', 283, 2, 4, 473251) The relatives did not give him any medical treatment.
('92', 283, 2, 5, 473305) They called in medicine men and resorted to incantations.
('92', 283, 2, 6, 473363) One cannot say that these did any good.
('92', 283, 2, 7, 473403) Maybe your mother did the same in your case.
('92', 283, 2, 8, 473448) Now you talk of Ramanama.
('92', 283, 2, 9, 473474) Could Ramanama be the same as incantations?
('92', 283, 3, 10, 473518) A. I have, in one form or another, answered this question before.
('92', 283, 3, 11, 473584) But it is as well to do so again.
('92', 283, 3, 12, 473618) So far as I can recollect, my mother did give me medical treatment.
('92', 283, 3, 13, 473686) But she certainly believed in incantations too.
('92', 283, 3, 14, 473734) I do not.
('92', 283, 3, 15, 473744) I have a few learned friends who believe in them, but I cannot have this faith.
('92', 283, 3, 16, 473824) I can therefore categorically say that incantations have no connection whatever with my Ramanama.
('92', 283, 3, 17, 473922) I have said that to utter Ramanama or any other name of God from the heart is to seek succour from the supreme power.
('92', 283, 3, 18, 474040) What that Power can do no other power can.
('92', 283, 3, 19, 474083) The atom bomb is as nothing compared with it.
('92', 283, 3, 20, 474129) It is the cure for all pains.
('92', 283, 3, 21, 474159) It must, however, be admitted that it is one thing to talk about uttering Ramanama from the heart, quite another to do it.
('92', 283, 3, 22, 474282) Nevertheless, however difficult it may be, it is the highest thing in life.

('92', 284, 4, 25, 476574) It is a betrayal of India.

('92', 291, 1, 2, 485028) 421. LETTER TO KANCHAN M. SHAH
('92', 291, 2, 3, 485059) N[EW] D[ELHI], Silence Day, October 7, 1946
('92', 291, 3, 4, 485103) KANCHAN, I got both your letters.
('92', 291, 3, 5, 485137) I do not at all like your having fallen ill.
('92', 291, 3, 6, 485182) Now that your yearning has been satisfied, you should get well soon at least for the sake of the baby that will be born.
('92', 291, 3, 7, 485303) You will do so not by overeating but by eating moderately, taking sun baths, living in the open air, drinking clean water, taking fruit juice, eating steamed or boiled vegetables and avoiding sweets and spicy foods.
('92', 291, 3, 8, 485519) If you take friction baths and hip baths, you will get well soon.
('92', 291, 3, 9, 485585) Why need you feel ashamed of being pregnant?
('92', 291, 3, 10, 485630) That is what you were yearning for.
('92', 291, 3, 11, 485666) Why need one feel ashamed of what one yearns for and of what happens to everybody?

('92', 298, 4, 7, 495372) 434. DISCUSSION WITH MEMBERS OF A. I. S. A. 1
('92', 298, 5, 8, 495418) NEW DELHI, [October 8, 1946] 2
('92', 298, 6, 9, 495449) A member suggested that the A. I. S. A. might pass a resolution requesting the Government to nationalize all new textile mills and the existing ones also as soon as practicable.
('92', 298, 6, 10, 495627) Gandhiji demurring to the suggestion explained that they could not ask the Government to nationalize new textile mills when they were telling them that khadi and the erection of new mills could not go together.
('92', 298, 6, 11, 495838) Shri T. Prakasam, the Premier of Madras, had already made an announcement to the effect that no new textile mills would be erected in the Madras Presidency.
('92', 298, 6, 12, 495995) They might ask for the nationalization of the existing mills but he himself preferred putting them under strict State control to taking charge of and running them as a State concern.
('92', 298, 6, 13, 496178) As a believer in non violence he believed in trusteeship.
('92', 298, 6, 14, 496236) He wanted a peace ful conversion of mill owners, so that the mill owners and their employees would all come under social control voluntarily.
('92', 298, 6, 15, 496378) That meant that though, for in stance, X might continue to be the legal owner, he would only take such commission out of the profits for himself as was warranted by his services and sanctioned by the people.
('92', 298, 6, 16, 496586) The real owners would be the labourers in the mills.
('92', 298, 6, 17, 496639) In one of the Tata concerns the labourers were reported to have become profit sharers.
('92', 298, 6, 18, 496726) Shri J. R. D. Tata’s speech in that connection was worthy of perusal.
('92', 298, 6, 19, 496796) He (Gandhiji) considered such solution to be the best.
('92', 298, 6, 20, 496851) Several mill owners had assured him that they were ready to co operate in any such scheme, if required, and would prevent further expansion of their textile mills.
('92', 298, 6, 21, 497015) He deprecated the idea of joint control of the mill industry by the Government, the A. I. S. A. and the mill owners.
('92', 298, 6, 22, 497132) He said:
('92', 298, 7, 23, 497141) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 15 10 1946 and 18 10 1946. The annual meeting of the A. I. S. A. was held at the Harijan Colony in Kingsway on the 8th, 9th and 10th October.
('92', 298, 8, 24, 497328) 2 From Indian Annual Register
('92', 299, 0, 1, 497358) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 299, 1, 2, 497400) Our job is not to run mills but to ply the little wheel by hand.
('92', 299, 1, 3, 497465) Why should we spend time in discussing a thing which lies outside our sphere of action.
('92', 299, 1, 4, 497553) I would not shed a single tear if all the mills were to close.
('92', 299, 1, 5, 497616) If mills flourish, khadi must die.
('92', 299, 1, 6, 497651) It might still function as a supplementary occupation for the relief of the poor.
('92', 299, 1, 7, 497733) But for that you do not need a big organization like the Charkha Sangh.
('92', 299, 2, 8, 497805) He would, he concluded, be perfectly satisfied if the State exercised control over the textile mills in consultation with them and so far as possible according to their advice.
('92', 299, 3, 9, 497982) “Would it not be advisable”, asked Shri Jajuji, “to ask the Government to give those who spin for themselves a subsidy so as to reduce the charges of weaving for self spinners?” Gandhiji’s reply was that they should not ask for subsidy but ask the Government to help in supplying cotton, the necessary implements and the services of teachers and technical experts to those who would take to spinning for their own cloth requirements.
('92', 299, 3, 10, 498416) He did not want to have it said that the Charkha Sangh was cashing its influence to make the government squander money on the whims of cranks and faddists.
('92', 299, 3, 11, 498572) He wanted no favour for the Charkha Sangh which must stand or fall on its merits.
('92', 299, 3, 12, 498654) He wanted everybody to feel that nothing had been given at the instance of the Charkha Sangh which had not been paid back tenfold.
('92', 299, 4, 13, 498785) Another member suggested that the weavers should be required to weave a certain amount of hand spun yarn and unless they did that the quota of mill yarn should not be given to them.
('92', 299, 4, 14, 498967) Any kind of compulsion, replied Gandhiji, would only create a revulsion against khadi.
('92', 299, 4, 15, 499054) It would then cease to be the ‘livery of freedom’.
('92', 299, 4, 16, 499105) He said : The spirit of independence is in the air.
('92', 299, 4, 17, 499157) The weaver might well refuse to be compelled.
('92', 299, 5, 18, 499203) “There is control in everything—food, cloth, etc.
('92', 299, 5, 19, 499253) Why cannot joint control be introduced with regard to weavers?” Gandhiji replied : I do not like the idea.
('92', 299, 5, 20, 499360) We do not use compulsion with regard to spinners.
('92', 299, 5, 21, 499410) We cannot use it for weavers.
('92', 299, 5, 22, 499440) Let us go to the root of the difficulty.
('92', 299, 5, 23, 499481) Our initial mistake was that we took to spinning but neglected weaving.
('92', 299, 5, 24, 499553) If we had adopted universal weaving along with spinning, all these difficulties would not have arisen.
('92', 299, 5, 25, 499656) The remedy is to improve the yarn so that the weavers have as little difficulty in weaving as possible.
('92', 299, 5, 26, 499760) We should reason with the weavers and explain to them that dependence on mill yarn must kill their avocation in the end.
('92', 299, 5, 27, 499881) Mill owners are no philanthropists.
('92', 299, 5, 28, 499917) They would draw the noose tight round the handloom weavers’ neck the moment they came within effective range of competition with mill cloth.
('92', 300, 0, 1, 500058) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 NOVEMBER, 1946 301
('92', 300, 1, 2, 500100) If we have faith in the charkha, we must forge ahead undis mayed by these temporary bottlenecks.
('92', 300, 1, 3, 500197) The number of handlooms weaving hand spun will increase in due course.
('92', 300, 1, 4, 500268) We have got enough artisans and indigenous skill in our country to produce all the cloth that we require for ourselves.
('92', 300, 2, 5, 500388) JAJUJI: This means that the work must go on as before at a snail’s pace.
('92', 300, 2, 6, 500461) Our scheme of making 4 lakhs of people self sufficient in cloth in a short time in this way will not succeed.
('92', 300, 3, 7, 500571) GANDHIJI: If it does not, the fault will be ours.
('92', 300, 4, 8, 500621) J. That is right in the ultimate sense.
('92', 300, 4, 9, 500661) But circumstances also count.
('92', 300, 5, 10, 500691) G. It is man’s privilege to overcome adverse circumstances.
('92', 300, 5, 11, 500751) Is not conquest of nature the slogan of the age we are living in?
('92', 300, 5, 12, 500817) If circumstances alone had counted, Germany and Japan would have won the war.
('92', 300, 5, 13, 500895) Let us in this respect take a leaf out of the book of the English people who do not know what it is to admit defeat.
('92', 300, 5, 14, 501012) We have to cultivate austerity and penance on our life.
('92', 300, 5, 15, 501068) There is nothing that the power of penance cannot achieve.
('92', 300, 6, 16, 501127) “You have taught us to be straight and above board in everything,” asked another member.
('92', 300, 6, 17, 501216) “Is it not dishonest to wear uncertified khadi and be known as a khadiwala when one does not fulfil the conditions of wearing khadi?
('92', 300, 6, 18, 501349) Is it not better to be honest and use mill cloth instead?”
('92', 300, 7, 19, 501408) Gandhiji replied that he did not approve of uncertified khadi, but he was of opinion that khadi, so long as it was genuine stuff, was preferable to mill cloth.
('92', 300, 7, 20, 501568) All uncertified khadi was not dishonest.
('92', 300, 7, 21, 501609) For instance, people who spin for themselves or their family and have their yarn woven do not use certified khadi.
('92', 300, 7, 22, 501724) Yet such khadi is of the highest merit.
('92', 300, 7, 23, 501764) Certified khadi carried the guarantee that the rules of the A. I. S. A. have been observed, as for instance paying to the spinners a certain minimum wage.
('92', 300, 7, 24, 501919) Khadi, even when the spinners are not paid the standard A. I. S. A. wage, is preferable to mill cloth.
('92', 300, 7, 25, 502022) The higher wages paid to labourers in the spinning mills are more appa 
('92', 300, 8, 26, 502094) rent than real.
('92', 300, 8, 27, 502110) Mill cloth is 21 2 times cheaper than khadi today.
('92', 300, 9, 28, 502161) Experts have told me that if the mill industry did not receive special privileges and concessions in several ways, which it today enjoys, mill cloth would not sell cheaper than khadi.
('92', 300, 9, 29, 502345) For instance, we provide cheap transport facilities to the mills to enable raw materials and mass produced finished goods to be taken from one place to another.
('92', 300, 9, 30, 502506) Again, enormous sums have been spent on growing long staple cotton
('92', 301, 0, 1, 502573) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 301, 1, 2, 502615) or on starting technical institutes and on research work.
('92', 301, 1, 3, 502673) No one has bothered to do anything for any of the seven lakhs of India’s villages.
('92', 301, 1, 4, 502756) So the mills are today actually being subsidized in some shape or other.
('92', 301, 1, 5, 502829) Remove all that and then see whether mill cloth is cheaper than khadi.
('92', 301, 2, 6, 502900) He could not possibly encourage uncertified khadi, continued Gandhiji, but mill cloth should be absolutely taboo.
('92', 301, 3, 7, 503014) A day might come when the A. I. S. A. might stop issuing certificates.
('92', 301, 3, 8, 503085) Anybody would then be free to sell khadi.
('92', 301, 3, 9, 503127) That would be inevitable when khadi became universal.
('92', 301, 3, 10, 503181) The Charkha Sangh would then function as the custodian of the ethics and the general policy of khadi.
('92', 301, 3, 11, 503283) Its business activities would cease.
('92', 301, 3, 12, 503320) People must become honest by habit and insist upon meticulous honesty on the part of the producers or the dealers in khadi so that only genuine stuff is sold and bought.
('92', 301, 3, 13, 503490) I have called khadi and the charkha the symbols of non vio lence.
('92', 301, 3, 14, 503556) But it is said that there is dishonesty even in certified bhan dars.
('92', 301, 3, 15, 503625) I wish it were not so.
('92', 301, 3, 16, 503648) But there is no denying the fact that it is true of some.
('92', 301, 3, 17, 503706) I have objected to the term vegetable ghee because it is not ghee.
('92', 301, 3, 18, 503773) It should be labelled as vegetable oil.
('92', 301, 3, 19, 503813) Similarly, I cannot tolerate that cloth which is not khadi, i.
('92', 301, 3, 20, 503876) e., is not hand spun and hand woven, should pass as such.
('92', 301, 3, 21, 503934) The ultimate remedy lies in the buyer’s hands.
('92', 301, 3, 22, 503981) “Buyer beware” is a sound legal maxim for all to remember.
('92', 301, 4, 23, 504040) It was suggested that the formulation of khadi policy for each unit of area should be left entirely to local bodies which should be completely in dependent of the central organization.
('92', 301, 4, 24, 504225) Gandhiji, while he was entirely in favour of the maximum decentralization of initiative and responsibility, was opposed to the creation of local committees of untrained men and women to take the place of khadi workers.
('92', 301, 4, 25, 504444) For organization of khadi work what was needed was a body of technicians and experts, men endowed with business talent and filled with the spirit of service.
('92', 301, 4, 26, 504602) There was no room in it for personal ambition or power politics.
('92', 301, 4, 27, 504667) The latter had become the bane of the Congress.
('92', 301, 4, 28, 504715) To get rid of corruption in the Congress organization he had suggested that it should convert itself into an organization of workers.
('92', 301, 4, 29, 504849) To introduce an element of democracy into khadi work would be to kill khadi.
('92', 301, 4, 30, 504926) The Charkha Sangh was not a democratic organization in the sense the Congress was.
('92', 301, 4, 31, 505009) It was an organization created by the Congress for the building up of democracy.
('92', 301, 4, 32, 505090) Like the Directorate of the Bank of England, it was a business organization first and last.
('92', 301, 4, 33, 505182) Only it was motivated by an altruistic, not profit, motive.
('92', 301, 4, 34, 505242) A business organization of a democratic body could not be bound by the procedure of the democratic vote.
('92', 301, 4, 35, 505347) He said :
('92', 302, 0, 1, 505357) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 NOVEMBER, 1946 303
('92', 302, 1, 2, 505399) We want to disperse in the villages.
('92', 302, 1, 3, 505436) A khadi worker can have no use for any other sanction save such as persuasion and service can command.
('92', 302, 1, 4, 505539) The moment he seeks to arm himself with any other, he kills khadi.
('92', 302, 2, 5, 505606) “To make khadi universal,” finally asked a friend, “you need to inspire the co operation of everybody.”
('92', 302, 3, 6, 505710) Gandhiji replied that since khadi workers were expected to be full servants of the people, their worth if there was any could create public opinion in their favour.
('92', 302, 3, 7, 505875) The need was not for a committee of members who might be a hindrance rather than help, whereas if service drew supporters they would be a powerful help.
('92', 302, 4, 8, 506028) “What would be the authority of the A. I. S. A. after khadi became decentralized?” was another question.
('92', 302, 5, 9, 506133) The answer came quick!
('92', 302, 5, 10, 506156) The authority of the Sangh would be merely moral and, therefore, more potent than at present.
('92', 302, 5, 11, 506250) Its function would not be to provide money or material but only to smooth the way for khadi work by the creation of a moral sanction.
('92', 302, 5, 12, 506384) It would lend the khadi workers the use of its name but not seek to impose its will upon them.
('92', 302, 5, 13, 506479) Its moral authority would be available to anybody who accepted its policy.
('92', 302, 5, 14, 506554) Even its present assets would be put at the disposal of any unit that was ready and considered fit to claim autonomy, provided only that it guaranteed the right use of the assets allotted to it and bound itself to return the same after a certain period.
('92', 302, 5, 15, 506808) The Charkha Sangh would have the right of inspection but even that would be at the will of the autonomous unit.
('92', 302, 5, 16, 506920) Harijan, 20 10 1946 and 27 10 1946
('92', 302, 6, 17, 506955) 435. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING

('92', 307, 3, 6, 512531) 444. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 307, 4, 7, 512561) NEW DELHI, October 10, 1946
('92', 307, 5, 8, 512589) Addressing the prayer meeting in Bhangi Colony on Thursday evening, Mahatma Gandhi said that he had thought that all the jewellery that had been presented to him had been auctioned out.
('92', 307, 5, 9, 512775) But a ring had just then been given him which he auctioned, as usual, immediately after the prayer.
('92', 307, 5, 10, 512875) He was, led to recall how over than 20 years ago he had, during the course of one of his tours, begun collecting money by auction at Ahmednagar.
('92', 307, 5, 11, 513020) In those days, auctions used to go on by the hour and he used to collect thousands in a day.
('92', 307, 5, 12, 513113) Now he had not the physical strength to do this.
('92', 307, 6, 13, 513162) Among other things, he even used to auction garlands of flowers which were presented to him.
('92', 307, 6, 14, 513255) Here he confessed that he had never liked garlands of flowers.
('92', 307, 6, 15, 513318) He had always held it to be cruel or wrong to pick flowers from plants.
('92', 307, 6, 16, 513390) Flowers should be allowed to fall to the ground in a natural way.
('92', 307, 6, 17, 513456) They then made a beautiful carpet under the trees and looked just as lovely as when they were in blossom.
('92', 307, 6, 18, 513562) In his ashram people were expected not to pick flowers from off the trees.
('92', 307, 6, 19, 513637) Thus was introduced the custom of presenting garlands of hand spun yarn in the place of flowers.
('92', 307, 7, 20, 513734) Gandhiji, however, assured the audience that he did not want them to think that all who bid at the auctions had to pay or indeed bid at all.
('92', 307, 8, 21, 513875) The Hindustan Times, 11 10 1946
('92', 307, 9, 22, 513907) 1 The message was for the convocation of the Udyogshala.
('92', 307, 9, 23, 513964) Gandhiji was not able to be present.

('92', 311, 1, 3, 517658) The skein has a nice look, but it is difficult to unwind.
('92', 311, 1, 4, 517716) It had been my experience in the past that unwinding the yarn took a long time and it frequently broke in the process.
('92', 311, 1, 5, 517835) The result was further delay and more labour.
('92', 311, 1, 6, 517881) What the spinner should do is to take off the yarn entirely from the spindle and put it on a winder that takes a round of four feet.
('92', 311, 1, 7, 518014) They should count the rounds for each hank and tie them up.

('92', 311, 2, 16, 518545) 451. HINDU PANI AND MUSLIM PANI
('92', 311, 3, 17, 518577) A stranger travelling in Indian trains may well have a painful shock when he hears at railway stations for the first time in his life ridiculous sounds about pani, tea and the like being either Hindu or Muslim.
('92', 311, 3, 18, 518788) It would be repulsive now that the Government at the Centre is wholly national and a well known Indian in the person of Asaf Ali Saheb is in charge of Transport and Railways.
('92', 311, 3, 19, 518963) It is to be hoped that we shall soon have the last of the shame that is peculiarly Indian.
('92', 311, 3, 20, 519054) Let no one imagine that Railways being under a Muslim, Hindus may not get justice.
('92', 311, 3, 21, 519137) In the Central and Provincial Governments, there is or should be no Hindu, Muslim or any other communal distinctions.
('92', 311, 3, 22, 519255) All are Indians.
('92', 311, 3, 23, 519272) Religion is a personal matter.
('92', 311, 3, 24, 519303) Moreover, the members of the Cabinet have set up a wholesome convention that they should always meet at the end of the day’s work and take stock of what each member has done.
('92', 311, 3, 25, 519478) It is team work in which the members are jointly and severally responsible for one another’s work.
('92', 311, 3, 26, 519577) It is not open to any member to say that a particular thing is not his work because it is no part of his portfolio.
('92', 311, 3, 27, 519693) We have a right therefore to assume that this unholy practice of having separate everything for every community at railway stations will go.
('92', 311, 3, 28, 519834) Scrupulous cleanliness is a desideratum for all.
('92', 311, 3, 29, 519883) If taps are used for all liquids there need be no
('92', 312, 0, 1, 519933) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 NOVEMBER, 1946 313
('92', 312, 1, 2, 519975) compunction felt by the most orthodox about helping themselves.
('92', 312, 1, 3, 520039) A fastidious person may keep his own lota and cup and receive his milk, tea, coffee or water through a tap.
('92', 312, 1, 4, 520147) In this there is no inter ference with religion.
('92', 312, 1, 5, 520196) No one is compelled to buy anything at railway stations.
('92', 312, 1, 6, 520253) As a matter of fact many orthodox persons fast for water and food during travel.
('92', 312, 1, 7, 520334) Thanks we still breathe the same air, walk on the same mother earth.
('92', 312, 1, 8, 520403) All communal cries at least at railway stations should be unlaw ful.
('92', 312, 1, 9, 520472) As I have often said in these columns trains and steamers are the best media for the practical education of the millions of travellers in spotless cleanliness, hygiene, sanitation and camaraderie between the different communities of India.
('92', 312, 1, 10, 520712) Let us hope that the Cabinet will have the courage to act up to their convictions and may confidently expect the hearty co operation of the Railway staff and the public in making this much needed reform a thorough success.

('92', 312, 2, 12, 520983) 452. REAL INDIA
('92', 312, 3, 13, 520999) If my frequent wanderings throughout India of the villages have not deceived me, it can be confidently asserted that the 700,000 villages get and want no police protection.
('92', 312, 3, 14, 521172) The solitary Patel to a village is a terrorist lording it over the villages and is designed for helping the petty revenue collector to collect revenue due to the Ma Bap 1. I am not aware of the policeman having aided the villagers in protecting their goods or cattle against depredations of man and beast.

('92', 313, 1, 2, 522148) nor that he does not wish the most distant village to realize that he is determined under instructions from Whitehall to shed every vestige of British control in the quickest time possible.
('92', 313, 1, 3, 522338) The relevance of all this writing is for showing that we do not yet learn from the village in which India lives that every Indian, man or woman, is his or her own policeman.
('92', 313, 1, 4, 522512) This he or she can only do when neither harbours mischief against his or her neighbour, no matter what religion he professes or denies.

('92', 313, 4, 12, 523444) Q. In these last four weeks, I have seen so much bloodshed and firing that it has left a bitter taste in my mouth.

('92', 315, 3, 17, 527912) Therein lies the value of the charkha.
('92', 315, 3, 18, 527951) If anything goes wrong with the charkha the spinners should learn how to put it right.

('92', 315, 3, 20, 528086) So long as this does not happen khadi can never replace mill cloth.

('92', 317, 5, 11, 530508) 458. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 317, 6, 12, 530540) NEW DELHI, October 12, 1946
('92', 317, 7, 13, 530568) Mahatma Gandhi began his address by telling the audience that he had been in two minds whether or not to break his silence, which he had taken to for various reasons, in order to address them.
('92', 317, 7, 14, 530761) Ultimately he decided to break it.
('92', 317, 7, 15, 530796) He wanted to tell them that while he had not taken a vow of silence he had made up his mind for the time being to speak only on business to those whom he called his jailors.
('92', 317, 7, 16, 530970) One result of his imposed silence was that he had been able to get through a fair amount of writing for Harijan.
('92', 317, 8, 17, 531083) Gandhiji went on to say how he felt impelled to tell them of the error committed by him three days ago.
('92', 317, 8, 18, 531187) He was thoroughly ashamed of it.
('92', 317, 8, 19, 531220) For him, at his time of life, it was unpardonable.
('92', 317, 8, 20, 531271) No harm had been done to anyone because of it.
('92', 317, 8, 21, 531318) It was not possible for him to remember ever having done anything to hurt anyone.
('92', 317, 8, 22, 531400) His error consisted in being over hasty.
('92', 317, 8, 23, 531441) He read a little thing hurriedly, though there was no occasion for hurry, and fancied it was quite right whereas it was not quite that.
('92', 317, 8, 24, 531577) No public servant had the right to act in this way.
('92', 317, 8, 25, 531629) He seemed, for the moment, to have lost confidence in himself and the belief that he would live for 125 years.
('92', 317, 9, 26, 531740) The first verse of the Ishopanishad demanded giving oneself and all possessions to God.
('92', 317, 9, 27, 531828) If a man fully did that, he could never be hasty.
('92', 317, 9, 28, 531878) It may be that he was old now and his brain was getting weak.
('92', 317, 9, 29, 531940) He knew that his memory was not as good as it used to be.
('92', 317, 9, 30, 531998) It never was extra good.
('92', 317, 9, 31, 532023) But when a man was guilty of error it was his duty to call God as witness and vow never to commit the mistake again.
('92', 317, 10, 32, 532140) 1 A slightly different version of this speech also appeared in Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” in Harijan, 20 10 1946.
('92', 318, 0, 1, 532254) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 NOVEMBER, 1946 319
('92', 318, 1, 2, 532296) was the only true way of repentance to realize the guilt and confess it immediately before the sun went down.
('92', 318, 1, 3, 532406) Death had got to come to everyone, and who knew when it would come ?
('92', 318, 2, 4, 532475) Gandhiji said his life was an open book and he hid nothing from the world.
('92', 318, 2, 5, 532550) They who listened to him were his world for the time.
('92', 318, 2, 6, 532604) He was telling them of his mistake in order that they may learn a lesson from it and never be hasty or careless in their actions.
('92', 318, 2, 7, 532734) While his mind had been relieved of a burden by confession, Gandhiji said it would take a long time for him to regain the lost confidence as far as living 125 years was concerned.
('92', 318, 2, 8, 532914) The Hindustan Times, 13 10 1946

('92', 318, 5, 15, 533355) LOHIA AGAIN
('92', 318, 6, 16, 533367) Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia’s letter to the Chief Judge of the Goa High Court deserves more than passing attention.
('92', 318, 6, 17, 533477) I copy it below from the daily Press :
('92', 318, 7, 18, 533516) At the time of my arrest 2, I had not, so far as I know, violated any Goan law.
('92', 318, 7, 19, 533596) I may have been intent on doing so but that is irrelevant.
('92', 318, 7, 20, 533655) The police officer at Collem walked into my compartment, asked me no questions and put me straightway under arrest.
('92', 318, 7, 21, 533771) International law, as it stands today, probably empowers the Portuguese Government to arrest and deport anyone whom they consider an undesirable alien but they are surely not empowered to hold him in prison unless he has actually violated some law.
('92', 318, 7, 22, 534020) The Portuguese Government have in the past declared me as alien and taken up their stand on a provision in International Law with regard to me.
('92', 318, 7, 23, 534164) They owe me an apology and damages for illegal imprisonment or else

('92', 321, 3, 14, 538953) Why is Umia feeling unhappy ?
('92', 321, 3, 15, 538983) Bring her along with you.

('92', 322, 0, 1, 539932) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 NOVEMBER, 1946 323
('92', 322, 1, 2, 539974) 464. DEADLY EMBRACE
('92', 322, 2, 3, 539994) In Bombay a Hindu gave shelter to a Muslim friend the other day.
('92', 322, 2, 4, 540059) This infuriated a Hindu mob who demanded the head of the Muslim friend.
('92', 322, 2, 5, 540131) The Hindu would not surrender his friend.
('92', 322, 2, 6, 540173) So both went down literally in deadly embrace.
('92', 322, 2, 7, 540220) This was how it was described to me authentically.
('92', 322, 2, 8, 540271) Nor is this the first instance of chivalry in the midst of frenzy.
('92', 322, 2, 9, 540338) During the recent blood bath in Calcutta, stories of Muslims having, at the peril of their lives, sheltered their Hindu friends and vice versa were recorded.
('92', 322, 2, 10, 540496) Mankind would die if there were no exhibition any time and anywhere of the divine in man.
('92', 322, 2, 11, 540586) Shri Balasaheb Kher, the Premier of Bombay, has described in glowing terms the instance of two youths rushing to still the wrath of a Muslim mob and meeting what they knew was certain death.
('92', 322, 2, 12, 540777) They met Death as their true friend.
('92', 322, 2, 13, 540814) Let no scoffer deny the inestimable value of such sacrifice—sacred deed.
('92', 322, 2, 14, 540887) It would be mock sacrifice, if every such act ended in success so called.
('92', 322, 2, 15, 540961) The certain moral is that, if such instances are sufficiently multiplied, the senseless slaughter on either side in the name of religion will stop.
('92', 322, 2, 16, 541109) One indispensable condition is that there should be no hypocrisy, no mock heroism.
('92', 322, 2, 17, 541192) Let us appear as we are.
('92', 322, 2, 18, 541217) NEW DELHI, October 15, 1946 Harijan, 20 10 1946
('92', 322, 3, 19, 541265) 465. DECENTRALIZATION
('92', 322, 4, 20, 541287) At the meeting of the Charkha Sangh at Delhi on the 10th many important subjects were discussed.
('92', 322, 4, 21, 541384) One of them was decentralization.
('92', 322, 4, 22, 541418) Decentralization is the soul of khadi.
('92', 322, 4, 23, 541457) The ambition of the Charkha Sangh is to see that charkhas and looms find a home in the seven lakh villages of India, that crores of Indians wear only khadi and mill cloth is completely wiped out.
('92', 322, 4, 24, 541653) The time has come for a province to become self reliant, if it wants.
('92', 322, 4, 25, 541723) However, if it does not want to do so or if it cannot do so a district can become self reliant.
('92', 322, 4, 26, 541819) If it fails to do that a taluka can become self reliant.
('92', 322, 4, 27, 541876) If that is not possible a group of villages can and if even they can’t become self reliant, a single one can.
('92', 322, 4, 28, 541986) Ultimately an individual can certainly become self reliant.
('92', 323, 0, 1, 542046) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 323, 1, 2, 542088) One should not ask how this can be possible.
('92', 323, 1, 3, 542133) Those who are members of the Charkha Sangh should write to its Secretary in detail, and their problem will be solved.
('92', 323, 1, 4, 542251) Those who possess the property of the Sangh will have to make some arrangement to return the money.
('92', 323, 1, 5, 542351) Only he will be bound by the policies of the Sangh who accepts them.
('92', 323, 1, 6, 542420) No one is obliged to accept them.
('92', 323, 1, 7, 542454) Discipline is for those who want to observe it.
('92', 323, 1, 8, 542502) There is no uniform code of conduct.
('92', 323, 1, 9, 542539) There is one root but there are many branches and each branch has many leaves.
('92', 323, 1, 10, 542618) Diversity in unity is a wonderful law of the world.Therefore the Charkha Sangh has adopted as its policy the giving of as much encouragement as possible to decentralization.
('92', 323, 1, 11, 542792) On the other hand the branches of the Sangh should aspire to become independent as soon as possible.
('92', 323, 1, 12, 542893) NEW DELHI, October 15, 1946

('92', 327, 11, 20, 546952) 475. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 327, 12, 21, 546982) NEW DELHI, October 15, 1946
('92', 327, 13, 22, 547010) Addressing the prayer meeting on Tuesday evening in Bhangi Colony, New Delhi, Gandhiji said he was grieved to learn that floods in Assam had taken a heavy toll of life and property.
('92', 327, 13, 23, 547192) Thousands had been rendered homeless, property worth lakhs had been destroyed, and many persons were reported to have been washed away by the floods.
('92', 327, 13, 24, 547342) That was an act of Nature.
('92', 327, 14, 25, 547369) But what was far worse than the news from Assam was the fact that there
('92', 327, 15, 26, 547441) 1 This could have been addressed to Moulvi Abdul Haq; vide “Letter to Abduk Haq”, 19 9 1946. 2 Blank space in the source
('92', 328, 0, 1, 547562) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 329
('92', 328, 1, 2, 547606) was rioting in Noakhali in Eastern Bengal.
('92', 328, 1, 3, 547649) The papers said that the Hindus, a very small minority there, were being attacked by the Muslims.
('92', 328, 1, 4, 547747) He did not want to go into the details of the happenings.
('92', 328, 1, 5, 547805) He knew his doctrine did not count for much among the people today and yet it was his duty to give his advice whether they acted upon it or not.
('92', 328, 1, 6, 547950) Gandhiji himself had never thought that there was any difference between Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsis or others.
('92', 328, 1, 7, 548070) All were brothers, sons of the same soil.
('92', 328, 1, 8, 548112) But even brothers fought furiously with each other sometimes and this was what was happening today between Hindus and Muslims.
('92', 328, 2, 9, 548239) Ever since he had heard the news of Noakhali, indeed ever since the blood bath of Calcutta, he had been wondering where his duty lay.
('92', 328, 2, 10, 548373) God would show him the way.
('92', 328, 2, 11, 548401) But what he wanted to tell them and through them a wider public was that it was the duty of every Hindu not to harbour any thoughts of revenge on Muslims in spite of what they did in Noakhali.
('92', 328, 2, 12, 548594) That was the creed of the Congress.
('92', 328, 2, 13, 548630) It had brought them thus far.
('92', 328, 2, 14, 548660) But was non violence only an expedient against the British, as some people thought, because the British were so strong?
('92', 328, 3, 15, 548780) Such an approach to non violence was wholly wrong.
('92', 328, 3, 16, 548831) The Congress had an overwhelming majority of Hindu members but it belonged to all communities.
('92', 328, 3, 17, 548926) Maulana Saheb had served it for years and through it everybody, irrespective of caste or creed.
('92', 328, 3, 18, 549022) His name was up again but he was withdrawing it and Gandhiji had supported his withdrawal.
('92', 328, 3, 19, 549113) He was an ill man today.
('92', 328, 3, 20, 549138) The new President was Shri Kripalani whom he had first met in Champaran.
('92', 328, 3, 21, 549211) He was going not only to wear a crown of thorns but also lie on a bed of thorns.
('92', 328, 3, 22, 549292) It was a much more difficult place than even the Cabinet members were filling.
('92', 328, 4, 23, 549371) Shri Kripalani would have to teach people how to die.
('92', 328, 4, 24, 549425) That was the only way to end this fratricidal war, to learn how to die without killing.
('92', 328, 5, 25, 549513) A friend from Ahmedabad had some time ago written and said that people knew how to return blow for blow, they had learnt how to be fearless of going to jail but they had not learnt how to die without killing.
('92', 328, 5, 26, 549722) It was up to him and others who believed in non violence to teach people this supreme way by personal act.
('92', 328, 6, 27, 549829) Gandhiji said that the Muslim League was, according to Press reports, coming into the Interim Government.
('92', 328, 6, 28, 549935) He hoped they were coming in to work as brothers.
('92', 328, 6, 29, 549985) If they did, all would be well.
('92', 328, 6, 30, 550017) And just as he had exhorted Hindus not to slay Muslims nor harbour ill will towards them, so he appealed to the Muslim League, even if they wanted to fight for Pakistan, to fight cleanly and in a friendly manner.
('92', 328, 7, 31, 550230) Quaid e Azam had said how everyone would receive justice in Pakistan.
('92', 328, 7, 32, 550300) It was as good as Pakistan where they were in the majority and he implored them to treat Hindus as blood brothers and not as enemies.
('92', 328, 7, 33, 550434) He hoped both Hindus and Muslims would vow not to hurt each other henceforth.
('92', 328, 7, 34, 550512) Unless they did this he would like to
('92', 329, 0, 1, 550550) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 329, 1, 2, 550592) proclaim from the housetops that they had not got and would never get the independence they craved for.
('92', 329, 1, 3, 550696) No man or people could be free who followed the law of the jungle.
('92', 329, 1, 4, 550763) The Hindustan Times, 16 10 1946

('92', 332, 4, 6, 554155) 483. LETTER TO PREMA KANTAK
('92', 332, 5, 7, 554183) NEW DELHI, October 16, 1946
('92', 332, 6, 8, 554211) PREMA, Two letters of yours are lying in front of me.
('92', 332, 6, 9, 554265) I started writing a reply as soon as I received the second one, but laid it aside when the people for whose sake I am here came in.
('92', 332, 6, 10, 554397) I am, therefore, writing the reply today.

('92', 335, 5, 19, 559963) 488. HAND SPUN v.
('92', 335, 5, 20, 559981) MILL CLOTH
('92', 335, 6, 21, 559992) The Premier of Madras has fallen foul of the big capitalist interests such as the Chamber of Commerce and even some Congressmen.
('92', 335, 6, 22, 560121) I have had cuttings sent to me from the Madras Press.
('92', 335, 6, 23, 560175) I am sorry to say that the criticism seems to me to be interested and ignorant.
('92', 335, 6, 24, 560255) My name has been dragged in the controversy.
('92', 335, 6, 25, 560300) That I sponsored the Premier’s scheme should not affect a dispassionate discussion of the very simple problem.
('92', 335, 6, 26, 560411) The simple question is merely this:can khadi become universal in Madras if encouragement is given by the Madras Government to new mills being erected or old ones being so expanded as to enable them to double production?
('92', 335, 6, 27, 560631) Are the villagers expected to be so simple as not to understand that it would be merely playing with khadi if mill cloth, heavily aided, is to be dumped down in their midst, probably at
('92', 336, 0, 1, 560817) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 337
('92', 336, 1, 2, 560861) a rate cheaper even than cotton required to weave a particular length of calico?
('92', 336, 1, 3, 560942) This happened when Japan sent her calico to India.
('92', 336, 1, 4, 560993) The Madras scheme is undoubtedly meant to utilize a part of the idle hours of the villagers for spinning sufficient yarn to clothe themselves.
('92', 336, 1, 5, 561136) Is it chimerical to induce and expect the people to utilize their idle hours to do useful, national, honest labour?
('92', 336, 1, 6, 561252) It will be time to declaim against the Madras Government when there is a feasible scheme to find useful and more remunerative employment for all who need work.
('92', 336, 1, 7, 561412) It is hardly an honourable pastime to dismiss from consideration honest servants of the nation by dubbing them idealists, dreamers, fanatics and faddists.
('92', 336, 1, 8, 561567) Let not capitalists and other entrenched personages range themselves against the poor villagers and prevent them from bettering their hard lot by dignified labour.
('92', 336, 1, 9, 561731) The great flaw about new mills in the Madras scheme was detected by me.
('92', 336, 1, 10, 561803) It was when the Textile Commissioner was convinced of the absurdity of the two things running side by side and the feasibility of the scheme as envisaged by the A.I.S.A. that he ventured to recommend it to the Madras Government.
('92', 336, 1, 11, 562032) His reputation will be at stake if it is impracticable or unworkable, not the critics’.
('92', 336, 1, 12, 562120) This is work for democracy by a democratic Government.
('92', 336, 1, 13, 562175) Hence the scheme must be popular at least where it is to be tried.
('92', 336, 1, 14, 562242) It must not be one man’s scheme but the whole Government’s.
('92', 336, 1, 15, 562302) It must have the backing of the Legislature.
('92', 336, 1, 16, 562347) In no case may it smack of compulsion.
('92', 336, 1, 17, 562386) It must be intrinsically practicable and of benefit to the masses.
('92', 336, 1, 18, 562453) These conditions of success are all reduced to writing.
('92', 336, 1, 19, 562509) The Government has accepted them in toto after, I understand, full discussion with experts and among themselves.
('92', 336, 1, 20, 562622) Let it be remembered that the existing Madras mills will not be touched at present.
('92', 336, 1, 21, 562706) That the whole mill industry will be affected if the scheme spreads like wildfire, as I expect some day such a thing must, goes without saying.
('92', 336, 1, 22, 562850) Let not the largest capitalist rue the day when and if it comes.
('92', 336, 1, 23, 562915) The only question then worth considering is whether the
('92', 337, 0, 1, 562971) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 337, 1, 2, 563013) Madras Government are honest and competent.
('92', 337, 1, 3, 563057) If they are not, everything will go wrong.

('92', 343, 6, 10, 568838) 501. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 343, 7, 11, 568868) NEW DELHI, October 17, 1946
('92', 343, 8, 12, 568896) Gandhiji referred again to the tragic happenings in Noakhali and Tippera districts in East Bengal.
('92', 343, 9, 13, 568995) What hurt him very much more than the killings was the fact that women were being carried away, abducted and converted to Islam.
('92', 343, 9, 14, 569124) Of course women generally did not carry swords.
('92', 343, 9, 15, 569172) The Rani of Jhansi had one.
('92', 343, 9, 16, 569200) All could not be Ranis.
('92', 343, 9, 17, 569224) But he would remind them of the incomparable power of Sita whom all the physical might of Ravana could not defile.
('92', 343, 9, 18, 569339) Women must learn how to die before a hair of their head could be injured.
('92', 343, 9, 19, 569413) He would like to say to the Hindus wherever they were in the minority and vice versa to the Muslims not to die helplessly but face death bravely and without a murmur.
('92', 343, 9, 20, 569580) Then only could the terrible killings now going on in Noakhali and Tippera come to a stop.
('92', 343, 10, 21, 569671) Sarat Babu, brother of Subhas Babu, who knew no barriers of caste or creed, will be visiting Bengal in a day or two.
('92', 343, 10, 22, 569788) He was ill but that was not going to deter him.

('92', 349, 0, 1, 580374) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 350
('92', 349, 1, 2, 580419) Dr. Wellington Koo, at one of his meetings in London, once narrated a sweet story about a Chinese family.
('92', 349, 1, 3, 580525) The eldest member of the family was considered, as with us, the head of the family.
('92', 349, 1, 4, 580609) As such he had the right to use an ancient family stick by way of punishment whenever necessary.
('92', 349, 1, 5, 580706) Once a hundred years old man used the stick on the back of his seventy five years old son.
('92', 349, 1, 6, 580797) Tears ran down the withered cheeks of the son.
('92', 349, 1, 7, 580844) The father asked the cause of the tears which he had never before seen him shed on a similar occasion.
('92', 349, 1, 8, 580947) The son replied, “Father your stick has lost its original force.
('92', 349, 1, 9, 581012) Your feebleness hurts me.
('92', 349, 1, 10, 581038) Hence the tears.
('92', 349, 1, 11, 581055) Kakasaheb was in Delhi with me when the letter was received.
('92', 349, 1, 12, 581116) I gave it to him to read and he said such things had happened in our country in the past and must be happening even now.
('92', 349, 1, 13, 581237) He narrated the following incident : One day a High Court judge of Madras is said to have gone out with a friend at the end of the day’s work instead of going home as usual.
('92', 349, 1, 14, 581411) When, therefore, he reached home late in the evening he met his mother standing in the doorway waiting for him.
('92', 349, 1, 15, 581523) “Why have you come late?” asked the old lady with a slap on his face.
('92', 349, 1, 16, 581593) Tears rolled down the son’s cheeks.
('92', 349, 1, 17, 581629) The friend remarked that it was but natural that a grown up learned man like him should feel insulted on being slapped like that.
('92', 349, 1, 18, 581759) It was strange on the mother’s part to have slapped him.
('92', 349, 1, 19, 581816) “No, there was no insult in that slap,” promptly replied the judge.
('92', 349, 1, 20, 581884) “It is my proud privilege to receive a slap from my revered mother now and then.
('92', 349, 1, 21, 581965) My eyes became wet only because I missed this time the strength that used to be in her slap.
('92', 349, 1, 22, 582058) Evidently she has grown old and weak.
('92', 349, 1, 23, 582096) Should not that hurt a dutiful son?” NEW DELHI, October 18, 1946 [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 27 10 1946

('92', 354, 4, 10, 586586) NEW DELHI, October 18, 1946
('92', 354, 5, 11, 586614) Gandhiji advised the women in East Bengal to commit suicide by poison or some other means to avoid dishonour.
('92', 354, 5, 12, 586724) Yesterday he told the women to suffocate themselves or to bite their tongues to end their lives.

('92', 356, 1, 2, 590284) 518. I AM DEFEATED
('92', 356, 2, 3, 590303) Letters continue to rain down on me regarding uncertified khadi.
('92', 356, 2, 4, 590368) They are from persons of repute and experience.
('92', 356, 2, 5, 590416) I do not find any flaw in my argument.
('92', 356, 2, 6, 590455) My defeat would lie in the fact that though there are large stocks of uncertified khadi it is very difficult to find in it genuine khadi.
('92', 356, 2, 7, 590593) If this is true then I have to withdraw my words and I do so.
('92', 356, 2, 8, 590655) It is necessary to understand in what lies the defeat.
('92', 356, 2, 9, 590710) I do not have any doubt and indeed no one has any doubt that genuine khadi, even if it is uncertified, is superior to mill cloth.
('92', 356, 2, 10, 590840) But my friends laugh at me because genuine khadi is always certified and what is available in the market is an imitation only.
('92', 356, 2, 11, 590967) It is adulterated; there is fraud in it and the desire to cheat.
('92', 356, 2, 12, 591032) I must accept that such khadi is as good as mill cloth.
('92', 356, 2, 13, 591088) I have come to know from reliable sources that because of mywritings some dishonest traders were able to increase their loot.
('92', 356, 2, 14, 591214) I therefore hope that from now onwards a khadi buyer will go only to a certified khadi bhandar and buy whatever is available there.
('92', 356, 2, 15, 591346) He should not even by mistake go to a store where uncertified khadi is sold.
('92', 356, 2, 16, 591423) Those who can prove to me that they are unable to spin I will consider as friends and give them the certificate that I have received yarn from them, because I always have yarn accumulated with me.

('92', 366, 4, 7, 601926) 538. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 366, 5, 8, 601956) NEW DELHI, October 20, 1946
('92', 366, 6, 9, 601984) Mahatma Gandhi devoted his after prayer discourse on Sunday to answering the question put to him during the previous 24 hours as to what should be done with persons who were forcibly converted or abducted.
('92', 366, 7, 10, 602190) He said he had no hesitation in maintaining that forcible conversion was no conversion at all nor abduction a bar to the return to her home of the abducted girl.
('92', 366, 7, 11, 602352) He held that no purification or penance was necessary in such cases.
('92', 366, 7, 12, 602421) Hindu society was wrong when it imposed penance on such persons.
('92', 366, 7, 13, 602486) They had not erred.
('92', 366, 8, 14, 602506) Gandhiji said that he had lived for years among Muslims and Christians.
('92', 366, 8, 15, 602578) They had all assured him that there could be no use of force in religion.
('92', 366, 8, 16, 602652) Those who resorted to force did not deserve to be called men of religion.
('92', 366, 8, 17, 602726) In a sense he and his audience who believed that God was one and no other and who believed that Mohammed was one of His messengers were Muslims.
('92', 366, 8, 18, 602871) But if anyone forced them or him to recite the Kalma, they would flatly refuse to obey and take the consequences.
('92', 366, 9, 19, 602985) It was his fervent hope that all good Muslims would stand up against the practices reported from the affected areas in East bengal.
('92', 366, 10, 20, 603117) The Hindustan Times, 21 10 1946
('92', 367, 0, 1, 603149) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 368
('92', 367, 1, 2, 603194) 539. A THOUGHT FOR THE DAY 1
('92', 367, 2, 3, 603223) PANCHGANI, July 16, 1946 He who loses patience, loses Truth as well as Non violence.
('92', 367, 2, 4, 603308) July 17, 1946 There is no happiness like Truth, no misery like untruth.
('92', 367, 2, 5, 603380) July 18, 1946 The wonder is that even though a man knows where true happiness lies, he wastes his life in pursuing untruth!
('92', 367, 2, 6, 603504) July 19, 1946 Whatever we do should be done not to please or displease anyone, but only to please God.
('92', 367, 2, 7, 603607) July 20, 1946 Even if you have told someone something a hundred times and he has not listened, you must tell him again and again.
('92', 367, 2, 8, 603737) That is patience.
('92', 367, 2, 9, 603755) July 21, 1946 Accepting undesired service, which is not joyfully rendered, is a painful burden.
('92', 367, 2, 10, 603851) July 22, 1946 Great caution is necessary when a man represses his nature.
('92', 367, 2, 11, 603925) July 23, 1946 If the nature is evil, it needs not repression but casting out.
('92', 367, 2, 12, 604003) July 24, 1946 He who wishes to save time will never do a single unnecessary thing.
('92', 367, 2, 13, 604086) July 25, 1946 He who obeys God’s Law will never care for any other law which is opposed to the Divine Law.
('92', 367, 3, 14, 604193) 1 Gandhiji started writing “A Thought for the Day” for Anand T. Hingorani at the latter’s request, on November 20, 1944, and continued the practice for about two years.
('92', 367, 3, 15, 604362) The thoughts for the period covered by this volume are reproduced as a single item under the last date, 10 10 1946. These were originally in Hindi.
('92', 367, 3, 16, 604510) The translation by Anand T. Hingorani is reproduced here with slight alterations.

('92', 381, 1, 2, 621368) 554. INTERVIEW TO PRESTON GROVER 1
('92', 381, 2, 3, 621403) NEW DELHI, October 21, 1946
('92', 381, 3, 4, 621431) Mahatma Gandhi declared in an interview today that the Muslim League Ministry in Bengal should be able to control the outbreak of disorders in East Bengal in which a good few thousands have been driven from their homes and an undetermined number killed or kidnapped.
('92', 381, 3, 5, 621698) He said : Control will depend on the Ministry.
('92', 381, 3, 6, 621745) If the Muslim League wanted to control it, I should think that it could.
('92', 381, 3, 7, 621818) The Muslim League has the overwhelming percentage of Muslim voters on their side.
('92', 381, 4, 8, 621900) Mahatma Gandhi described the Bengal outbreak as “heart breaking”.
('92', 381, 4, 9, 621966) His comments on the outbreak of robbing, burning and looting in East Bengal were made in his small room in the Untouchable Colony where he has lived most of the time since the arrival of the British Cabinet Mission in March.
('92', 381, 4, 10, 622191) He sat on a thin mat with a small sloping desk before him and I sat on the floor while he talked of many things including America, the new Government in India, South Africa and his own health.
('92', 381, 5, 11, 622384) He announced again his intention of visiting the troubled areas in Bengal after his meeting on October 23 with Pandit Nehru and the Working Committee where they will discuss problems created by the entry of the Muslim Group into the Central Ministry.
('92', 381, 5, 12, 622635) He said : The fact that I go there will satisfy the soul and may be of some use.
('92', 381, 6, 13, 622716) PRESTON GROVER: Will the Muslims listen to you?
('92', 381, 7, 14, 622764) GANDHIJI: I don’t know.
('92', 381, 7, 15, 622788) I don’t go with any expectation, but I have the right to expect it.
('92', 381, 7, 16, 622856) A man who goes to do his duty only expects to be given strength by God to do his duty.
('92', 381, 8, 17, 622943) To a question as to when this type of disturbances would end in India, he replied : You may be certain that they will end.
('92', 381, 8, 18, 623066) If the British influence were withdrawn, they would end much quicker.
('92', 381, 8, 19, 623136) While the British influence is here, both parties, I am sorry to confess, look to the British power for assistance.
('92', 381, 9, 20, 623252) 1 Of the Associated Press of America
('92', 382, 0, 1, 623289) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 383
('92', 382, 1, 2, 623334) Turning to the affairs of the Interim Government, Mahatma Gandhi regretted the statement 1 of Raja Ghazanfar Ali Khan, the Muslim League selection for the Central Government.
('92', 382, 1, 3, 623509) To Raja Ghazanfar Ali Khan’s statement that the League was going into the Interim Government to fight for Pakistan, Mr. Gandhi said : That is an extraordinary and inconsistent attitude.
('92', 382, 1, 4, 623695) The Interim Government is for the interim period only and may not last long.
('92', 382, 1, 5, 623772) While it is there to deal with the problems that face the country— starvation, nakedness, disease, bad communications, corruption, illiteracy.
('92', 382, 1, 6, 623915) Any one of these problems would be enough to tax the best minds of India.
('92', 382, 1, 7, 623989) On these there is no question of Hindu or Muslim.
('92', 382, 1, 8, 624039) Both are naked.
('92', 382, 1, 9, 624055) Both are starving.
('92', 382, 1, 10, 624074) Both wish to drive out the demon of illiteracy and un Indian education.
('92', 382, 1, 11, 624146) There is not much time to elapse between this Government and that to be set up by the Constituent Assembly.
('92', 382, 1, 12, 624254) The time will be shortened if both apply their will to the completion of the work of the Constituent Assembly.
('92', 382, 1, 13, 624365) The Constituent Assembly is based on the State Paper.
('92', 382, 1, 14, 624419) That Paper has put in cold storage the idea of Pakistan.
('92', 382, 1, 15, 624476) It has recommended the device of “grouping”which the Congress interprets in one way, the League in another and the Cabinet Mission in a third way.
('92', 382, 1, 16, 624623) No law giver can give an authoritative interpretation of his own law.
('92', 382, 1, 17, 624693) If then there is a dispute as to its interpretation, a duly constituted court of law must decide it.
('92', 382, 2, 18, 624794) [P. G.] But if the Muslim League do not accept the court interpretation?
('92', 382, 3, 19, 624867) [G.] They cannot impose theirs on others.
('92', 382, 3, 20, 624909) If they do, they put themselves in the wrong box.
('92', 382, 3, 21, 624959) The alternative is to come to blows.
('92', 382, 3, 22, 624996) We are all savages and come to blows often when we don’t agree.
('92', 382, 3, 23, 625060) Yet we are all gentlemen.
('92', 382, 3, 24, 625086) This is so whether in America or Europe.
('92', 382, 4, 25, 625127) Asked for his reaction to the decision of the Madras Ministry which has decided against any expansion of the cotton mills industry in the Province in order to promote the Gandhian plan for home spinning and weaving, the Mahatma said : I think it is the finest thing going.
('92', 382, 4, 26, 625400) If you want to follow this logically, then you must follow it through.
('92', 382, 5, 27, 625471) Asked whether it would then be logical to “follow through” to the extent that mills presently in the Province would be stopped, he replied that if in time, through
('92', 382, 6, 28, 625635) 1 Ghazanfar Ali Khan made the statement while addressing a students’ meeting at Lahore on October 19.
('92', 383, 0, 1, 625737) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 383, 1, 2, 625779) the progressive programme, the mills came to have no customers, then they would quit—“unless they chose to sell outside India”.
('92', 383, 2, 3, 625907) He assailed the Natal Sugar Mills industry as responsible for bringing indentured Indians there to work and thus creating the segregation problem.
('92', 383, 3, 4, 626054) To a question as to what would become of Englishmen in the service of the Government of India, Gandhi said : I think that India has use for every one of them who is loyal to India and to Indian traditions and conditions and who will be above temptation and corruption.
('92', 383, 3, 5, 626323) I don’t want to say that they should be disloyal to England.
('92', 383, 3, 6, 626384) That is not the point.
('92', 383, 3, 7, 626407) They should not be disloyal to India.
('92', 383, 3, 8, 626445) These things not conflict but it has happened in history.
('92', 383, 3, 9, 626503) Most have come here to serve the country of their birth by exploiting India.
('92', 383, 3, 10, 626580) That is hypocrisy.
('92', 383, 3, 11, 626599) It is dishonesty.
('92', 383, 3, 12, 626617) There is no room for dishonesty in any service or outside it.
('92', 383, 4, 13, 626679) Asked if he had any message for America, he said : Dislodge the money God called Mammon from the throne and find a corner for poor God.
('92', 383, 4, 14, 626815) I think America has a very big future but in spite of what is said to the contrary, it has a dismal future if it swears by Mammon.
('92', 383, 4, 15, 626946) Mammon has never been known to be a friend of any of us to the last.
('92', 383, 4, 16, 627015) He is always a false friend.
('92', 383, 5, 17, 627044) Mahatma Gandhi, who has passed 77 years of age, said : I am shaken in that belief, although not because it is illegitimate.
('92', 383, 5, 18, 627168) But there are well defined limits to the fulfilment of that wish.
('92', 383, 5, 19, 627234) If you do not fulfil those limits, then you may not attain the wish.
('92', 383, 5, 20, 627303) For the time being, I feel dislodged.
('92', 383, 5, 21, 627341) I have not attained the necessary equanimity.
('92', 383, 5, 22, 627387) I don’t want to live 125 years or even one year on nostrums, medicines and that kind of thing.
('92', 383, 5, 23, 627482) I want to live a life of service in my present way.
('92', 383, 5, 24, 627534) That is possible provided you have equableness under every circumstance.
('92', 383, 5, 25, 627607) Nothing should irritate you.
('92', 383, 5, 26, 627636) I am not able to say today that nothing irritates me or has irritated me.
('92', 383, 6, 27, 627710) He said he had thought calmly of living until 125 “until a few days ago”, when he had a “rude shock”.
('92', 383, 6, 28, 627812) It was on the occasion of his birthday by the Hindu calendar, which came this year ten days ahead of October 2, the day of his birthday by the ordinary calendar.
('92', 383, 6, 29, 627974) Rajendra Prasad, the Food Member in the Cabinet, had come to preside at a flag raising in connection with the birthday, and on that occasion, he was told, “monkey nuts, raisins, etc., were to be served to the Harijan children and volunteers in the camp”.
('92', 384, 0, 1, 628229) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 385
('92', 384, 1, 2, 628274) He said he considered it an insult to the Food Minister to give food needlessly in his presence to children and others “who were not in need”.
('92', 384, 1, 3, 628417) His anger flared up, he said, because “every morsel of food has to be husbanded.
('92', 384, 1, 4, 628498) If we do it, there will be no shortage.
('92', 384, 1, 5, 628538) India is the last country in the world that should be short of food if our rulers know their business—and ther is no black marketing.” The Mahatma said : I flared up madly.
('92', 384, 1, 6, 628711) I lost my balance.
('92', 384, 1, 7, 628730) You can use any adverb or adjective you may like to describe it.
('92', 384, 1, 8, 628795) It was then I discovered my failure.
('92', 384, 1, 9, 628832) This loss of self control has cost some years of my life— which it will be possible to regain if I regain my equanimity—or gain it.
('92', 384, 1, 10, 628964) That is the humbler way to say it.
('92', 384, 1, 11, 628999) Harijan, 3 11 1946

('92', 384, 5, 25, 629829) It should be clear to them that these were not days of festivity or merry making.

('92', 387, 6, 9, 633572) 562. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('92', 387, 7, 10, 633602) NEW DELHI, October 22, 1946
('92', 387, 8, 11, 633630) Gandhiji said that a correspondent had drawn his attention to the fact that he
('92', 387, 9, 12, 633709) had said nothing against illuminations at Diwali in his message on Monday.
('92', 387, 10, 13, 633784) an accidental omission.
('92', 387, 10, 14, 633808) He had been opposed to illuminations even in the olden days
('92', 387, 11, 15, 633868) when there was no food shortage.
('92', 387, 11, 16, 633901) To burn oil or ghee today when there was not
('92', 387, 12, 17, 633946) enough to eat was unthinkable.
('92', 387, 12, 18, 633977) Real India did not reside in cities like Delhi.
('92', 387, 13, 19, 634025) resided in the seven lakhs of villages.
('92', 387, 13, 20, 634065) For the hungry and naked villagers there could
('92', 387, 14, 21, 634112) be no Diwali illuminations or any other kind of festivity.
('92', 387, 14, 22, 634171) It was their duty to abstain
('92', 387, 15, 23, 634200) and save all the ghee, oil and money they could.
('92', 387, 16, 24, 634249) Commenting on the Marathi bhajan sung by Shri Balasaheb Kher, the Premier
('92', 387, 17, 25, 634323) of Bombay, Gandhiji said that like Shri Thakkar Bapa, Kher Saheb had been a servant
('92', 387, 18, 26, 634407) of the Harijans and Adivasis ever since he had known him.
('92', 387, 18, 27, 634465) Now he had put on the
('92', 387, 19, 28, 634487) crown of thorns and become the Premier of Bombay.
('92', 387, 19, 29, 634537) For Gandhiji his service to
('92', 387, 20, 30, 634565) Harijans and Adivasis was more important than anything else.
('92', 387, 20, 31, 634626) In the bhajan

('92', 388, 4, 11, 636066) 564. HOW VILLAGES CAN MANUFACTURE THEIR CLOTH
('92', 388, 5, 12, 636112) After reciting the scheme which I copied in the Harijan of August 14, 1946, from his letter to me, Shri Manu Subedar 3 has given his argument in support of the scheme in the Rast Rahbar.
('92', 388, 5, 13, 636299) I copy below two relevant paragraphs from the interesting article : 4
('92', 388, 6, 14, 636369) Not only will the cloth produced under the above scheme becheaper than the black market, but it would be cheaper than the mill cloth for the reason that many items, which go into the price of the mill cloth to the consumer, would be eliminated.
('92', 388, 6, 15, 636614) Amongst these are profits of the mills and of the
('92', 388, 7, 16, 636664) 1 Hisam ud Din and Abul Kalam Azad, in separate statements, not reproduced here, had condemned the arson, murder and forcible conversions in East Bengal as un Islamic and called upon the Muslim majority there to protect the Hindu minority.
('92', 388, 8, 17, 636904) 3 Member, Central Legislative Assembly 4 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('92', 389, 0, 1, 636980) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 389, 1, 2, 637022) middleman distributor of cloth, the cost of transport of cloth and cotton both ways, the cost of supervision and management, and interest charges and depreciation.
('92', 389, 1, 3, 637186) Since the labour up to the stage of the yarn would be contributed and the labour charged for weaving would be in kind, even in normal peace time cloth produced under these conditions would be cheaper than factory cloth.
('92', 389, 2, 4, 637406) I would invite the leaders to note that in the above scheme not only is there co operation under the guidance of the village Panch and complete self government, free from any interference of anybody outside, but there is the seed of the kind of economic revolution which we seek in this country.
('92', 389, 2, 5, 637702) The amount of State assistance involved in the proposal is so miserably small per head and is actually lower than the cost incurred by the State for many other purposes for the benefit of other groups and grades of the Indian population.
('92', 389, 2, 6, 637940) The further advantage in this scheme is that it would be automatic in so far as in some villages it would take root quickly and they may want another bale inside a month.
('92', 389, 2, 7, 638111) In other villages it might take them three or four months.
('92', 389, 2, 8, 638170) Some of the villages will probably supply all their requirements by this method in the next few months and may have something to spare, and indeed I would not consider it wrong if cloth produced under these circumstances after it was found to be in excess of the requirement of the village which has produced it, was made available in the larger cities for sale to the general public.
('92', 389, 2, 9, 638555) I would, however, sound a warning that the scheme would break down if individual exploitation is permitted.
('92', 389, 2, 10, 638663) The surplus should not be dealt with except through the village collectively and should not be brought to the city except through the Government agency, which lands the bale at the door of the village.
('92', 389, 2, 11, 638865) Nor should it be sold in the cities except at the Government retail shops.
('92', 389, 2, 12, 638940) In a letter in Gujarati, Shri Subedar says : If my scheme is not adopted, we may have the sorrowful spectacle of womenfolk going without cover and therefore remaining indoors.
('92', 389, 2, 13, 639116) The hard heartedness which mill owners and middlemen have exhibited require some such immediate remedy as I have suggested.
('92', 389, 2, 14, 639240) You have rightly said that the removal of the salt tax will drive home to the millions of villagers the truth that our Sarkar has now the reins of Government in its hands.
('92', 389, 2, 15, 639412) Will they not also realize this truth, if the villages have cotton
('92', 390, 0, 1, 639479) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 391
('92', 390, 1, 2, 639524) cotton delivered at their homes on the easiest terms possible so that with a little corporate labour they can clothe themselves without difficulty?

('92', 400, 2, 6, 657818) 578. PLUCKY STAND
('92', 400, 3, 7, 657836) Papers received from Natal contain among other things a remarkable correspondence between the Mayoral Secretary of Durban and the Natal Indian Congress Secretary.
('92', 400, 3, 8, 657999) A committee has been formed for making arrangements for the royal visit to Durban proposed to take place in the month of March next year.
('92', 400, 3, 9, 658137) The main committee has established a sub committee to deal with the question of joining the coloured and non European sections of the population of Durban.
('92', 400, 3, 10, 658293) For the purpose, the Committee invited the Natal Indian Congress to appoint two representatives to serve on the sub committee so as to give their advice and assistance to enable the Indian community to see Their Majesties and the Royal Princesses.
('92', 400, 3, 11, 658541) To this invitation the Joint Hon.
('92', 400, 3, 12, 658575) Secretary of the Natal Indian Congress (Meer Saheb) sent the following plucky reply on the 11th September last :
('92', 400, 4, 13, 658688) I am directed by my Executive to state that while the Indian community has the greatest respect for Their Majesties and the Royal Princesses, it must be noted that the Indians of South Africa are at the present moment passing through the most critical period in their history.
('92', 400, 4, 14, 658965) A series of colour discriminatory Acts depriving us of our elementary human rights during the last half century has culminated in the passing of the Asiatic Land Tenure and Indian Representation Act, 1946, passed in the teeth of the strongest opposition ever voiced by our community.
('92', 400, 4, 15, 659249) The action of the Union Government in thus oppressing a voteless section of its population has plunged the whole Indian community in a state of grave unrest.
('92', 400, 4, 16, 659407) Recent trends in colour legislation leave no room for doubt as to what is in store for people of colour in this country.
('92', 400, 4, 17, 659528) The colour of a man’s skin has become the sole criterion of judging human qualities.
('92', 400, 5, 18, 659613) As a result of all this the Indian community of South Africa resolved on the 13th June, 1946 to launch a campaign of passive resistance against colour discrimination in the laws of this country.
('92', 400, 5, 19, 659808) This peaceful protest still goes on
('92', 401, 0, 1, 659844) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 401, 1, 2, 659886) and 627 of our people, including national leaders like Dr. Yusuf Dadoo and Dr. G. M. Naicker, have been sent to jail where they are treated like common criminals.
('92', 401, 1, 3, 660049) Some of them have served their sentences and have been released after being subjected to inhuman treatment, but hundreds still remain behind prison bars and many more continue to be sent to prison daily.
('92', 401, 2, 4, 660253) While the Indian community finds itself in such an unhappy situation in a part of His Majesty’s Empire, it is most unreasonable to expect Indians to participate in any rejoicing or celebrations in honour of Royalty.
('92', 401, 2, 5, 660469) In the circumstances we cannot but suggest that you advise Their Majesties to postpone their visit until such time as there is peace and goodwill in South Africa between the rulers and the ruled, the White and the non White, the represented and the unrepresented, the privileged and under privileged, so that all who constitute the South African nation can equally share, not only its burdens, but also its rewards.
('92', 401, 2, 6, 660885) The Natal Indian Congress Executive is to be congratu lated on the reply.
('92', 401, 2, 7, 660959) The Royal visit can evoke no feeling of joy among those who are fighting for their self respect in South Africa in the making of which they have no mean share.
('92', 401, 2, 8, 661119) Let us hope that the Royal visit will be postponed to a more propitious time when the colour bar has become a thing of the past.
('92', 401, 2, 9, 661248) Such self denial on the part of Their Majesties will be quite in keeping with the direction which the King and Queen recently issued to substitute in the National Anthem the following new verses :
('92', 401, 3, 10, 661445) Nor on this land alone,
('92', 401, 4, 11, 661469) But be God’s mercies known,
('92', 401, 5, 12, 661497) From shore to shore.
('92', 401, 6, 13, 661518) Lord make the nations see,
('92', 401, 7, 14, 661545) That men should brothers be,
('92', 401, 8, 15, 661574) And form one family,
('92', 401, 9, 16, 661595) The wide world o’er.
('92', 401, 9, 17, 661616) for the antiquated and indefensible verses :
('92', 401, 10, 18, 661661) Oh, Lord our God arise,
('92', 401, 11, 19, 661685) Scatter his enemies,
('92', 401, 12, 20, 661706) and make them fall.
('92', 401, 13, 21, 661726) Confound their politics,
('92', 401, 14, 22, 661751) Frustrate their knavish tricks.
('92', 401, 15, 23, 661783) On Thee our hopes we fix,

('92', 402, 1, 2, 661918) 579. A WISE STEP Shri G. D. Tapase, Minister for Backward Classes (Bombay) has sent me a copy of the Bombay Harijan (Removal of Social Disabilities) Act just passed by the Bombay Legislature.
('92', 402, 1, 3, 662110) I give below the most relevant clauses :
('92', 402, 2, 4, 662151) 3. Notwithstanding anything contained in any instrument or any law, custom or usage to the contrary, no Harijan shall merely on the ground that he is a Harijan—
('92', 402, 3, 5, 662312) (a) be ineligible for office under any authority constituted under any law; or
('92', 402, 4, 6, 662391) (b) be prevented from—
('92', 402, 5, 7, 662414) (i) having access to or using any river, stream, spring, well, tank, cistern, water tap or any bathing place, burial or cremation ground, any sanitary convenience, any road, or pathway which the members of all other castes and classes of Hindus have right to use or have access to;
('92', 402, 6, 8, 662696) (ii) having access to or using any public conveyance licensed by the Provincial Government or any local authority to ply for hire;
('92', 402, 7, 9, 662827) (iii) having access to or using any building, well, cistern or place used for charitable or public purposes maintained wholly or partially out of the revenues of the Province or the funds of a local authority;
('92', 402, 8, 10, 663037) (iv) having access to a place of public amusement or place of public entertainment;
('92', 402, 9, 11, 663121) (v) having access to a shop which the members of all other castes and classes of Hindus have a right to have access to;
('92', 402, 10, 12, 663241) (vi) having access to or using any place set apart or maintained for the use of Hindus generally but not for the use of any particular section or class thereof;
('92', 402, 11, 13, 663402) (vii) enjoying any benefit under a charitable trust created for the benefit of Hindus generally but not for the benefit of any particular section or class thereof.

('92', 403, 22, 23, 665399) year and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to Rs. 1,000. The author of the measure has kindly supplied me with the text of his speech delivered on his introducing the measure.

('92', 403, 23, 25, 665636) This untouchability amounts to irrationality.
('92', 403, 23, 26, 665682) As soon as a Harijan is born, untouchability applies to him.
('92', 403, 23, 27, 665743) As a Harijan he is born, as a Harijan he lives all through his life and as a Harijan he dies.
('92', 403, 23, 28, 665837) However clean he may be, however wise he may be, however superior he may be, to the so called orthodox Hindus, he is not a superior being.
('92', 403, 23, 29, 665976) The worse of it is that even after his death his dust and ashes are not allowed to mingle with the dust and ashes of the others.
('92', 403, 23, 30, 666105) The agonies of the untouchable are further aggravated by the fact that he is treated as an untouchable not only by the caste Hindus but even by Christians, Muslims and others.
('92', 403, 23, 31, 666281) To my mind the Bill gives a sanad, a charter, to the Harijans for the exercise of certain social, civic, fundamental rights.
('92', 403, 23, 32, 666406) It is worthy of note that the Bill was passed without opposition worth the name from the Hindu side.
('92', 403, 23, 33, 666507) That is a good augury for the

('92', 404, 1, 2, 666582) successful working of the Act.
('92', 404, 1, 3, 666613) And yet it would not do to be over sanguine about it.
('92', 404, 1, 4, 666667) Unfortunately for us, we know that we pass resolutions by acclamation and allow them to become dead letter.
('92', 404, 1, 5, 666775) The greatest vigilance will have to be exercised by the Government and the reformers in the strict enforcement of the law.
('92', 404, 1, 6, 666898) It is no use blinking the fact that the reign of irrationality referred to by the author of the relief bill is still very much to the fore in India.
('92', 404, 1, 7, 667047) It is not merely in regard to untouchability but many other things.

('92', 407, 1, 2, 670793) 586. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 407, 2, 3, 670825) NEW DELHI, October 25, 1946 India is passing through a difficult time.
('92', 407, 2, 4, 670896) As a matter of fact the whole world is passing through a crisis and India is no exception.
('92', 407, 2, 5, 670987) What help do we need to meet this crisis?
('92', 407, 3, 6, 671029) According to the teaching of the Gita the first requisite for spiritual conduct was fearlessness.
('92', 407, 3, 7, 671127) On New Year’s Day people made some good resolve.
('92', 407, 3, 8, 671176) He wanted them to make a firm resolve to shed all fear.
('92', 407, 3, 9, 671232) Without fearlessness all other virtues were turned into dust.
('92', 407, 3, 10, 671294) Attainment of truth or non violence was impossible without fearlessness.
('92', 407, 4, 11, 671367) Fearlessness did not mean arrogance or aggressiveness.

('92', 407, 4, 13, 671457) Fearlessness presupposed calmness and peace of mind.
