('92', 407, 6, 19, 671793) 587. SIND BANS “SATYARTH PRAKASH” One had thought that the ban on Satyarth Prakash had lapsed, never to be renewed.
('92', 407, 6, 20, 671909) 2 But the hope was a dupe.
('92', 407, 6, 21, 671936) Here is the renewed ban :
('92', 407, 7, 22, 671962) Whereas it appears to the Government of Sind that Chapter XIV of the book in Sindhi entitled Satyarth Prakash contains matter which promotes feelings of enmity or hatred between different classes of His Majesty’s subjects—
('92', 407, 8, 23, 672185) Now, therefore, in exercise of the powers conferred by Section 99 A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Government of Sind hereby declares to be forfeited to His Majesty every copy wherever found of the book in Sindhi entitled Satyarth Prakash written by Swami Dayanand Saraswati and published by Professor Tarachand D. Gajra, M.A., on behalf of the Pratinidhi Sabha, Sind, Karachi, and all other documents containing copies, reprints or translations of, or extracts from,
('92', 407, 9, 24, 672667) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”
('92', 407, 10, 25, 672711) 2 The ban had lapsed on September 30, 1946.
('92', 408, 0, 1, 672755) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 409
('92', 408, 1, 2, 672800) Chapter XIV of the said book on the grounds that in the said chapter the author (a) ridicules some of the religious beliefs of the Muslims; (b) misrepresents and reviles the teachings of the Koran; (c) attacks and belittles the authority of the Prophet Mohammed; and (d) generally contains matter calculated to hurt and which hurts, the religious susceptibilities of Muslims.
('92', 408, 1, 3, 673176) It is wider in application than before.
('92', 408, 1, 4, 673216) The lapsed ban made it criminal to print or publish the book containing Chapter XIV.
('92', 408, 1, 5, 673301) The renewed ban makes the possession of such a copy a crime.
('92', 408, 1, 6, 673362) I cannot help feeling that the ban is senseless and is calculated to wound the susceptibilities of the Arya Samajists all the world over.
('92', 408, 1, 7, 673500) Satyarth Prakash enjoys the same status for 40 lakhs of Arya Samajists as the Koran for the Muslims and the Bible for the Christians.
('92', 408, 1, 8, 673634) It is possible to understand a ban on contemporaneous controversial literature, though at this time of the day popular Governments are reluctant even then to use their power.
('92', 408, 1, 9, 673809) But is seems to be mischievous to ban a scriptural book.
('92', 408, 1, 10, 673866) I would, therefore, urge the Sind Government to withdraw the ban in question.
('92', 408, 1, 11, 673944) The Sindhi translation of Satyarth Prakash is not a new publication.
('92', 408, 1, 12, 674013) Is it to be contended that a book that has passed through so many editions and has been translated in most of the languages of the world has been now found to contain matter “which promotes feelings of enmity or hatred between different classes of His Majesty’s subjects”?
('92', 408, 1, 13, 674286) The virtue of toleration is never strained, especially in matters of religion.
('92', 408, 1, 14, 674365) Differences of religious opinion will persist to the end of time; toleration is the only thing that will enable persons belonging to different religions to live as good neighbours and friends.
('92', 408, 1, 15, 674558) Religion never suffers by reason of the criticism—fair or foul—of critics; it always suffers from the laxity or indifference of its followers.

('92', 412, 6, 20, 680515) 594. WHO CAN BE A TRUSTEE?
('92', 412, 7, 21, 680542) The purpose for which the A. I. S. A. has been created is so vast and great that the qualifications to be a trustee of the A. I. S. A. require careful consideration.
('92', 412, 7, 22, 680708) In my opinion they should be as below : 1. No one should be a trustee merely in name or for the sake of name.
('92', 412, 7, 23, 680818) A trustee should have the faith that in a country like India
('92', 412, 8, 24, 680879) 1 Jawaharlal Nehru, Vallabhbhai Patel, Rajendra Prasad, Asaf Ali, Baldev Singh, Jagjivan Ram, John Matthai, C. Rajagopalachari, C. H. Bhabha, Liaquat Ali Khan, I. I. Chundrigar, Abdul Rab Nishtar, Ghazanfar Ali Khan and Jogendra Nath Mandal
('92', 412, 9, 25, 681120) 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 3 11 1946. The translation reproduced here has been revised so as to bring it into conformity with the original.
('92', 413, 0, 1, 681292) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 413, 1, 2, 681334) where crores remain unemployed for four to six months in the year, everybody can easily be clad in self spun cloth and need not touch any other if all those who are physically fit spin for a reasonable time every day, say on an average for an hour every day.
('92', 413, 1, 3, 681593) 2. A trustee who has this unshakable faith will spin regularly to set a good example to others and for the satisfaction of contributing his or her mite to the service of the country.
('92', 413, 1, 4, 681776) 3. He or she will try his or her best to attune his or her life with the life in the villages of India.
('92', 413, 1, 5, 681880) 4. India is made of villages, but our intelligentsia has neglected them.
('92', 413, 1, 6, 681953) A trustee of the A. I. S. A. would try his or her utmost to remedy the handicaps from which our village life suffers.
('92', 413, 1, 7, 682071) In doing so he or she should remember that village life must not become a copy or appendage of city life.
('92', 413, 1, 8, 682177) The cities have to adopt the pattern of village life and subsist for the villages.
('92', 413, 1, 9, 682260) 5. If a trustee’s husband is connected with the mill industry, she should engage a weaver out of her personal money to weave yarn spun by herself or her friends and relatives and use the cloth thus produced.
('92', 413, 1, 10, 682468) A trustee should read all the literature about hand spinning and hand weaving and understand the economic and moral significance of the cloth making industry.
('92', 413, 1, 11, 682627) He or she should know that it is possible to make it universal and explain it to others.
('92', 413, 1, 12, 682716) 6. A trustee should study and understand the history of the A. I. S. A. from the beginning to date and from it should learn how the various processes connected with cotton, i.
('92', 413, 1, 13, 682892) e., carding, spinning and weaving, have been revolutionized.
('92', 413, 1, 14, 682953) I have given my views as suggestions.
('92', 413, 1, 15, 682991) They cannot be obligatory.
('92', 413, 1, 16, 683018) I shall welcome all helpful suggestions by way of amendment or addition.
('92', 413, 1, 17, 683091) NEW DELHI, October 27, 1946 Harijan, 3 11 1946

('92', 417, 9, 16, 687113) NEW DELHI October 27, 1946
('92', 417, 10, 17, 687140) Speaking before the evening prayer Gandhiji said that he was leaving for Calcutta the following morning.
('92', 417, 10, 18, 687245) He did not know when God would bring him again to Delhi.
('92', 417, 10, 19, 687302) He wanted to go to Noakhali from Calcutta.
('92', 417, 10, 20, 687345) It was a difficult journey and he was in poor health.
('92', 417, 10, 21, 687399) But one had to do one’s duty and trust in God to make the way smooth.
('92', 417, 10, 22, 687469) It was not that God necessarily and always removed hardships from one’s path, but He always enabled one to bear them.
('92', 417, 11, 23, 687587) He did not want anyone to come to the station.
('92', 417, 11, 24, 687634) India had given him enough affection.
('92', 417, 11, 25, 687672) It needed no further demonstration.
('92', 417, 12, 26, 687708) He was not going to Bengal to pass judgment on anybody.
('92', 417, 12, 27, 687764) He was going there as a servant of the people and he would meet Hindus and Muslims alike.
('92', 417, 12, 28, 687854) Some Muslims looked upon him as an enemy today.
('92', 417, 12, 29, 687902) They had not done so always.
('92', 417, 12, 30, 687931) But he did not mind their anger.
('92', 417, 12, 31, 687964) Were not his own religionists angry with him at times?
('92', 417, 13, 32, 688019) 1 Addressee’s husband
('92', 417, 14, 33, 688041) 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”
('92', 418, 0, 1, 688085) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 419
('92', 418, 1, 2, 688130) From the age of seventeen he had learnt the lesson that all mankind, be they of any nationality, colour or country, were his own kith and kin.
('92', 418, 1, 3, 688273) If they were God’s servants, they had to become servant of all His creation.
('92', 418, 2, 4, 688350) It was in that capacity that he was going to Bengal.
('92', 418, 2, 5, 688403) He would tell them that Hindus and Muslims could never be enemies.
('92', 418, 2, 6, 688470) They were born and brought up in India and they had to live and die in India.
('92', 418, 2, 7, 688548) Change of religion could not alter that fundamental fact.
('92', 418, 2, 8, 688606) If some people liked to believe that change of religion changed one’s nationality also, even then they need not become enemies.
('92', 418, 3, 9, 688734) Suffering of women had always melted his heart.
('92', 418, 3, 10, 688782) He wanted to go to Bengal and wipe their tears and put heart into them if he could.
('92', 418, 3, 11, 688866) In Calcutta he would try to see the Governor and the Prime Minister Mr. Suhrawardy and then proceed to Noakhali.
('92', 418, 4, 12, 688979) He was proceeding under auspices none too happy.
('92', 418, 4, 13, 689028) He referred to the ugly demonstration before the Viceroy’s House on the day before when Jawaharlalji and some of his colleagues in the Interim Government were abused and insulted.
('92', 418, 4, 14, 689208) It was bad.
('92', 418, 4, 15, 689220) Why should such things happen when the two parties, the Muslim League and the Congress, had formed a coalition at the Centre?
('92', 418, 4, 16, 689346) Praise or abuse made no difference to the leaders who wanted to serve them to the best of their ability.
('92', 418, 4, 17, 689451) But the people had to behave.
('92', 418, 4, 18, 689481) Let us all still pray and hope that all the Ministers will be able to work as a team.
('92', 418, 4, 19, 689567) If India can speak with one voice, she will be the greatest country in the world and every true Indian must wish her to attain that status.
('92', 418, 5, 20, 689707) Gandhiji told the audience that about 30 men and women had taken part in the spinning examination held in the afternoon.
('92', 418, 5, 21, 689828) The cotton had been procured.
('92', 418, 5, 22, 689858) God always enabled one to procure the means for a good project.
('92', 418, 5, 23, 689922) He (Gandhiji) himself had joined them in spinning and had spun the slivers prepared by them.
('92', 418, 5, 24, 690015) It was a noble sight.
('92', 418, 5, 25, 690037) They all knew their job and went about it in perfect quiet.
('92', 418, 5, 26, 690097) The music of a well running wheel or wheels was most soothing for the mind and the spirit.
('92', 418, 5, 27, 690188) All those who took part in the spinning were well to do people.
('92', 418, 5, 28, 690252) They did it as a sacrificial act.
('92', 418, 5, 29, 690286) A number of such mandals were being established to popularize the idea of sacrificial spinning.
('92', 418, 5, 30, 690382) The whole conception and the demonstration of it that he saw that day were beautiful.
('92', 418, 6, 31, 690468) Harijan, 10 11 1946; and The Hindustan Times, 28 10 1946

('92', 419, 0, 1, 690580) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 419, 1, 2, 690622) 605. DISCUSSION WITH DIRECTOR OF BRITISH DAILY 1
('92', 419, 2, 3, 690671) NEW DELHI, [Before October 28, 1946] 2
('92', 419, 3, 4, 690710) GANDHIJI: We are today suffering from a double evil— suppression of facts and concoction.
('92', 419, 4, 5, 690800) DIRECTOR: It does not pay to emphasize news about riots.
('92', 419, 4, 6, 690857) My paper does not.
('92', 419, 5, 7, 690876) But Gandhiji told him that he and his paper would be doing a real service to India not by suppressing relevant facts but by presenting them truthfully, without bias or prejudice.
('92', 419, 5, 8, 691055) He said : Truth never damages a cause that is just.
('92', 419, 6, 9, 691107) Replying to another question as to when the present trouble would end, Gandhiji remarked that it was bound to go, though he did not see any signs of abatement just yet.
('92', 419, 6, 10, 691276) He added : There are interested parties fomenting it.
('92', 419, 6, 11, 691330) Mine may be a voice in the wilderness today, but I maintain that so long as British troops are here, both Hindus and Mussalmans will continue to look up to them for help and the trouble will continue.
('92', 419, 6, 12, 691531) Nothing worse could happen to a people struggling to be free.
('92', 419, 7, 13, 691593) This shocked the British conscience of the friend.
('92', 419, 7, 14, 691644) He asked: “The Britisher
('92', 419, 8, 15, 691669) would like his troops to go out quicker.
('92', 419, 8, 16, 691710) Who obstructs?” Who else but the British themselves, unless you can show that it is physically impossible to effect immediate withdrawal.
('92', 419, 9, 17, 691848) After some parrying the friend admitted that the British commercial and other
('92', 419, 10, 18, 691926) vested interests in India and their henchmen stood in the way of their withdrawal.
('92', 419, 11, 19, 692009) was, however, still doubtful as to the function of British troops in the maintenance of
('92', 419, 12, 20, 692097) law and order.
('92', 419, 12, 21, 692112) “You say there can be no peace while they are here.
('92', 419, 12, 22, 692164) Yet every day there
('92', 419, 13, 23, 692184) is an increasing demand for them for the maintenance of peace.
('92', 419, 13, 24, 692247) The complaint is that
('92', 419, 14, 25, 692269) they are not sufficiently used.”
('92', 419, 15, 26, 692302) G. That is the very reason why they should be withdrawn.
('92', 419, 16, 27, 692359) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “A Friendly Overture”.
('92', 419, 16, 28, 692410) Pyarelal explains that “a Director of an influential British daily paper had come to see Gandhiji at New Delhi and told him that his paper was anxious to do a friendly turn to India”
('92', 419, 17, 29, 692593) 2 Gandhiji left New Delhi for Calcutta on the morning of October 28, 1946.
('92', 420, 0, 1, 692668) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 421
('92', 420, 1, 2, 692713) Their presence, in my opinion, does not act as a preventive measure but becomes punitive.
('92', 420, 1, 3, 692803) Where they are used to maintain law and order, it is after the trouble.
('92', 420, 1, 4, 692875) Future historians will bear this out.
('92', 420, 1, 5, 692913) Order will be restored in East Bengal too.
('92', 420, 1, 6, 692956) But after what slaughter, what suffering?
('92', 420, 1, 7, 692998) No, the British troops are in India not to protect India but to protect British interests which were imposed on India and which are now so well entrenched that even the British Government cannot dislodge them.
('92', 420, 1, 8, 693208) The British did not come here as philanthropists, nor is there any altruism in their continued stay here or the conti nuation of their troops, all that might be claimed to the contrary notwithstanding.
('92', 420, 2, 9, 693410) D : How do you think the succession of war such as we have witnessed of late can be stopped?
('92', 420, 3, 10, 693503) G. I have no doubt that unless big nations shed their desire for exploitation and the spirit of violence of which war is the natural expression and atom bomb the inevitable consequence, there is no hope for peace in the world.
('92', 420, 3, 11, 693730) I tried to speak out during the war and wrote open letters to the British people 1, to Hitler 2 and to the Japanese 3 and was dubbed a fifth columnist for my pains.
('92', 420, 4, 12, 693895) D : But non violence might take a long time to act.
('92', 420, 4, 13, 693947) But for the Second Front there probably would have been no Russia.
('92', 420, 5, 14, 694014) G. All these are arguments dictated by reason.
('92', 420, 5, 15, 694061) It is not permitted me to think in these terms or else I would be denying my faith which today burns brighter than ever in spite of all the bitter experiences that I have had.
('92', 420, 5, 16, 694237) History provides us with a whole series of miracles of masses of people being converted to a particular view in the twinkling of an eye.
('92', 420, 5, 17, 694374) Take the Boer War.
('92', 420, 5, 18, 694393) It has given to the English language the word ‘mafficking’.
('92', 420, 5, 19, 694453) People went mad on the Maffeking Day.
('92', 420, 5, 20, 694491) Yet inside of two years the whole British nation underwent a transformation.
('92', 420, 5, 21, 694568) Henry Campbell Bannerman became the Premier and practically all the gains of war were given up.
('92', 420, 5, 22, 694664) The recent labour victory at the polls was another instance in point.
('92', 420, 5, 23, 694734) To me it is a sufficient miracle that in spite of his oratory and brilliance, Churchill should cease to be the idol of the British people who till yesterday
('92', 420, 6, 24, 694891) 1Vide “To Every Briton”
('92', 420, 7, 25, 694915) 2Vide “Letter to Adolf Hitler”, 24 12 1940
('92', 420, 8, 26, 694958) 3Vide “To Every Japanese”
('92', 421, 0, 1, 694984) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 421, 1, 2, 695026) hung on his lips and listened to him in awe.
('92', 421, 1, 3, 695071) All these instances are enough to sustain the faith of a believer like me that when all other powers are gone, one will remain, call it God, Nature or whatever you like.
('92', 421, 2, 4, 695241) His own faith in the triumph of non violence he likened to that of the witnesses in the Second Coming of Christ.
('92', 421, 2, 5, 695354) It was to take place within the lifetime of the witnesses though it has taken two thousand years and yet remains a distant dream.

('92', 426, 12, 25, 702391) A Mysorean draws my attention to .
('92', 426, 13, 26, 702426) I have had the misfortune to advise the destruction of stray dogs.
('92', 426, 13, 27, 702493) But that had to be, if men would be so cruel as, out of a false sense of pity, to feed pariah dogs and permit them to become a menace to the neighbouring population.
('92', 426, 13, 28, 702659) But my advice can never include impounding such dogs and torturing them as those mentioned
('92', 426, 14, 29, 702750) 1 The extract from the correspondent’s letter is not reproduced here.

('92', 427, 1, 2, 702862) by my correspondent seem to have been.
('92', 427, 1, 3, 702901) Humanitarian instinct demands destruction of such animals in an instantaneous and painless manner.

('92', 427, 3, 9, 703702) 620. VILLAGE INDUSTRIES 1
('92', 427, 4, 10, 703728) A thoughtful friend, writing of village industries, says : 2
('92', 427, 5, 11, 703789) The children should be paid at the rate of one anna and the adults four annas per day from the day they begin to work.
('92', 427, 5, 12, 703908) As they acquire more skill, the wages of the children should be increased up to five annas and those of the adults up to eight annas per day.
('92', 427, 6, 13, 704050) The manufacture in one village should be confined to one kind of goods only, so that in about two months’ time the workers will acquire skill and avoid making mistakes.
('92', 427, 6, 14, 704219) The manufactured article should be such as can be utilized locally.
('92', 427, 6, 15, 704287) The State should arrange to supply raw material and appoint two or three experts to train workers.
('92', 427, 6, 16, 704386) The State should also undertake to popularize the manufactured goods and arrange for their transport and cheap distribution to the poor consumer.
('92', 427, 7, 17, 704532) This scheme will enable millions to add to their income and make the two ends meet without throwing them on the unemployment dole or loss of self respect.

('92', 428, 4, 30, 707249) The reconstruction of the villages along these lines should begin right now.
('92', 428, 4, 31, 707326) That might necessitate some modifications in the foregoing scheme.

('92', 429, 1, 3, 707598) My second difficulty is that in the scheme under question training and education have been divorced from each other.
('92', 429, 1, 4, 707715) In fact training is a judicious blending of craft, hygiene, education and art.

('92', 433, 5, 20, 716250) By its very nature this state of things cannot last.
('92', 433, 5, 21, 716303) Human nature won’t stand it.
('92', 433, 5, 22, 716332) As Abraham Lincoln said, “You cannot fool all the people for all time.” There seem to be indications that the people are already beginning to sicken of the carnival of blood and bestiality.
('92', 433, 5, 23, 716522) They had been fighting amongst themselves like wild beasts.
('92', 433, 5, 24, 716582) The fighting could do no good to Calcutta, Bengal, India or the world.
('92', 433, 6, 25, 716653) To make peace between quarrelling parties, the speaker said, had been his vocation from his early youth.

('92', 435, 4, 18, 720417) SODEPUR, CALCUTTA, Friday, [November 1, 1946]
('92', 435, 5, 19, 720463) The whole of India, Gandhiji said, was faced with a difficult situation.
('92', 435, 5, 20, 720536) That of Bengal was still more so, he remarked in his after prayer address on Friday last.
('92', 435, 5, 21, 720626) He had been asked as to what their duty was under the circumstances.
('92', 435, 5, 22, 720695) According to the scriptures, that was dharma which was enjoined by the holy books, followed by the sages, interpreted by the learned and which appealed to the heart.
('92', 435, 5, 23, 720861) The first three conditions must be fulfilled before the fourth came into operation.
('92', 435, 5, 24, 720945) Thus one had no right to follow the precepts of an ignorant man or a rascal even though they commended themselves to one.
('92', 435, 5, 25, 721067) Rigorous observance of harmlessness, non enmity and renunciation were the first requisites for a person to entitle him to lay down the law, i.
('92', 435, 5, 26, 721210) e., dharma.
('92', 435, 6, 27, 721222) He had told them what he considered to be his duty.
('92', 435, 6, 28, 721274) But they had to judge for themselves what their duty was.
('92', 435, 6, 29, 721332) He did not ask them to follow him but he pointed out
('92', 435, 7, 30, 721385) to them the way to discover what their duty was in the difficult position they found themselves in.
('92', 435, 7, 31, 721485) The Gita had told them that if they only waited on God, they would know the way.
('92', 435, 7, 32, 721566) Harijan, 17 11 1946
('92', 435, 8, 33, 721586) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”
('92', 436, 0, 1, 721630) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 437
('92', 436, 1, 2, 721675) 633. GREEN CROSS SOCIETY Red Cross Society one is aware of.
('92', 436, 1, 3, 721735) It had at one time only military associations and used to have an imperialist flavour.
('92', 436, 1, 4, 721822) Now it has expanded into civil work and covers every form of first aid work for the relief of suffering humanity.
('92', 436, 1, 5, 721936) Nevertheless its activities are largely confined to cities.
('92', 436, 1, 6, 721996) It has hardly touched Indian life.
('92', 436, 1, 7, 722031) England is a country for lost causes: humanitarian and even strange causes.
('92', 436, 1, 8, 722107) One such is represented by the Green Cross Society for the wild life heritage.
('92', 436, 1, 9, 722186) Mrs. M. H. Morrison is its Hon.
('92', 436, 1, 10, 722218) Secretary (41, Asmuns Place, London, N. W. 11).
('92', 436, 1, 11, 722266) The Society aims at the U. N. O. identifying itself with it.
('92', 436, 1, 12, 722327) The following resolution is to be submitted to the U. N. O. for acceptance :
('92', 436, 2, 13, 722404) (a) That U. N. O. ideals should include immediate effort in each country to delimit the area of any suitable National Park incorporating Nature Reserves for the protection of unique and valuable wild life—flora, fauna, avifauna— with the distinctive terrain upon which these depend.
('92', 436, 3, 14, 722687) (b) And, further, that the world at large should consent to an International Park, or World National Park in South America, Africa or Asia.
('92', 436, 3, 15, 722827) If in Asia then upon, around or within—it is suggested—the immense mountains encircling Tibet, Britain, China, India, Russia and U. S. A. appointing Custodians and acting as Trustees.
('92', 436, 3, 16, 723011) Reasons adduced for inviting the U. N. O. to pass the foregoing resolution are :
('92', 436, 4, 17, 723092) 1. That a stand must now be made against the maddening encroachments of materialism.
('92', 436, 5, 18, 723177) 2. That the idealism and realism of the United Nations Organization should include an urge to all the world and to each nation to protect our heritage of wild life—its beauty, grandeur and interest—wild birds, wild animals, wild flora (flowers, plants, trees) and wild country or landscape; to protect our heritage wherever possible; and with special care within the Nature Reserves of National Parks.
('92', 436, 6, 19, 723579) 3. That the United Nations will jointly set an example to the component nations by claiming its own World Nature Park, or International Park in South America, Africa or Asia.
('92', 436, 6, 20, 723754) If in Asia, then upon, around, or within the immense mountains encircling Tibet.
('92', 436, 6, 21, 723835) In this case Britain, China, India, Russia and U. S. A. might appoint Custodians and act as Trustees to prevent disastrous and disfiguring exploitation.
('92', 437, 0, 1, 723988) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 437, 1, 2, 724030) 4. And, further, that such “Far Horizon’, can give direction and
('92', 437, 2, 3, 724095) cohesion to friends, allies, sympathizers and well wishers gathering in groups
('92', 437, 3, 4, 724174) along the way for the march and drive on toward the distant goal.
('92', 437, 3, 5, 724240) Among the numerous signatories to the resolution are Sir Alfred J. Munnings, President, Royal Academy of Arts, Dame Laura Knight and the world famous George Bernard Shaw.
('92', 437, 3, 6, 724411) Mrs. Morrison would like the signatures of leading Indians and other leaders in Asia and Africa.

('92', 437, 7, 14, 724854) But there was a girl just eighteen years old, whose mind retained such fortitude that, though suffering from a protracted illness, she wrote a fascinating book which has become very famous.
('92', 437, 7, 15, 725044) You can achieve some such thing if you but make up your mind.
('92', 437, 7, 16, 725106) The secret of Ramanama is that one should repeat it mechanically even when one cannot concentrate.

('92', 438, 4, 6, 726013) 635. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('92', 438, 5, 7, 726045) SODEPUR, CALCUTTA, [November 2, 1946]
('92', 438, 6, 8, 726083) Mahatma Gandhi indicated that he was trying to do some work in the metropolis.
('92', 438, 6, 9, 726162) He was not, therefore, leaving for Noakhali .
('92', 438, 6, 10, 726208) Gandhiji added that the arrival of the four members 3 of the Interim Government might help in the peace movement.
('92', 438, 7, 11, 726322) Gandhiji impressed upon the people how the desire of retaliation and the tendency to look to the Viceroy or the Governor, the military and the police for protection were incompatible with independence to which they were all pledged.
('92', 438, 7, 12, 726555) The Viceroy’s powers vested in the Cabinet, the Governor’s in the Bengal Ministers.
('92', 438, 7, 13, 726639) If they wanted lasting peace, it must come from the people’s hearts.
('92', 438, 7, 14, 726708) He had been proclaiming from the housetops that no one could protect them except their own stout hearts.
('92', 438, 7, 15, 726813) No one could ever dishonour the brave.
('92', 438, 7, 16, 726852) Retaliation was a vicious circle.
('92', 438, 7, 17, 726886) If they wanted retaliation they could not have independence.
('92', 438, 7, 18, 726947) He said : Supposing someone kills me, you will gain nothing by killing someone else in retaliation.
('92', 438, 7, 19, 727047) And, if you only think over it, who can kill Gandhi except Gandhi himself?
('92', 438, 7, 20, 727122) No one can destroy the soul.
('92', 438, 7, 21, 727151) So let us dismiss all thought of revenge from our hearts.
('92', 438, 7, 22, 727209) If we see this clearly, we shall have taken a big stride towards independence.
('92', 438, 8, 23, 727288) Harijan, 17 11 1946; and The Sunday Hindustan Standard, 3 11 1946

('92', 439, 13, 23, 728571) The Prime Minister wanted him to pass the Bakr Id in Calcutta.
('92', 439, 13, 24, 728634) His presence in the city might be helpful for peace.
('92', 439, 13, 25, 728687) Gandhiji said that he had come to Bengal to serve the Muslims as well as Hindus and others.
('92', 439, 14, 26, 728779) 1 This is written on the reverse side of letter dated November 2, 1946. 2 Vide the following item and “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 4 11 1946 3 Communal rioting had broken out in Bihar following a hartal on October 25, and Morning News, an organ of the Muslim League, had stated that the number of persons killed was of the order of hundreds of thousands.

('92', 439, 14, 28, 729272) The first paragraph is reproduced from Hindustan Standard.
('92', 440, 0, 1, 729331) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 441
('92', 440, 1, 2, 729376) From his earliest childhood, he had learnt to dislike the wrong, never the wrongdoer.
('92', 440, 1, 3, 729462) Therefore, even if the Muslims had done any wrong, they still remained his friends, but it was his duty to tell them that they had done wrong.
('92', 440, 1, 4, 729605) He had always applied that rule in life with regard to his nearest and dearest.
('92', 440, 1, 5, 729685) He held that to be the test of true friendship.
('92', 440, 1, 6, 729733) He had told them on the previous day that revenge was not the way of peace, it was not humanity.
('92', 440, 1, 7, 729830) The Hindu scriptures taught forgiveness as the highest virtue.
('92', 440, 1, 8, 729893) Forgiveness became a brave man.
('92', 440, 1, 9, 729925) A learned Muslim friend had come to see him on the day before.
('92', 440, 1, 10, 729988) He had told the speaker that the teaching of the Koran was also similar.
('92', 440, 1, 11, 730061) If a man killed one innocent person, he brought upon his head the sin, as it were, of murdering entire humanity.
('92', 440, 1, 12, 730174) Islam never approved of but condemned murder, arson, forcible conversions, abductions and the like.
('92', 440, 2, 13, 730274) If they could be generous enough to forgive a person who gave them a slap, remarked Gandhiji, they could give him one in return.
('92', 440, 2, 14, 730403) He could understand that.
('92', 440, 2, 15, 730429) But if the miscreant ran away and the injured party slapped his relation or co religionist by way of retaliation, it was below human dignity.
('92', 440, 3, 16, 730571) If someone abducted his daughter, the speaker continued, was he to abduct the abductor’s or the abductor’s friend’s daughter?
('92', 440, 3, 17, 730697) He held it to be infamous.
('92', 440, 3, 18, 730724) Muslim friends had condemned such acts in Noakhali.
('92', 440, 3, 19, 730776) But what was he to say of Bihar if what he was told was true?
('92', 440, 3, 20, 730838) He was pained beyond measure to hear of the reported happenings in Bihar.
('92', 440, 3, 21, 730912) He knew the Biharis well.
('92', 440, 3, 22, 730938) The cry of blood for blood was barbarous.
('92', 440, 3, 23, 730980) They could not take revenge in Bihar for the happenings in Noakhali.
('92', 440, 3, 24, 731049) He was told that some Muslims, who were running away from Bihar in panic, were murdered by Bihari Hindus.
('92', 440, 3, 25, 731155) He was shocked to hear it.
('92', 440, 3, 26, 731182) He hoped that the report was not true.
('92', 440, 3, 27, 731221) It was contended that the Mahabharata advocated the way of retaliation.
('92', 440, 3, 28, 731293) He did not agree with that interpretation.
('92', 440, 3, 29, 731336) The lesson of the Mahabharata was that the victory of the sword was no victory.
('92', 440, 3, 30, 731416) That great book taught that the victory of the Pandavas was an empty nothing.
('92', 440, 4, 31, 731494) He told them of the talk he had with Shaheed Saheb, their Prime Minister.
('92', 440, 4, 32, 731568) Years ago he had met him at Faridpur.
('92', 440, 4, 33, 731606) Shaheed Saheb then took pride in calling himself the speaker’s son.
('92', 440, 4, 34, 731674) He knew they had many grievances against their Prime Minister.
('92', 440, 4, 35, 731737) But the latter had given him his assurance that he wanted peace.
('92', 440, 4, 36, 731802) It had grieved him to alienate his Hindu friends.
('92', 440, 4, 37, 731852) He, the speaker, could not disbelieve that assurance till it was found to be untrue.
('92', 440, 4, 38, 731937) He had by giving that assurance put himself to test.
('92', 440, 4, 39, 731990) The golden way was to be friends with the world and to regard the whole human family as members of one family.
('92', 440, 4, 40, 732101) He who distinguished between one’s own family and another’s, miseducated the members of his own and opened the way for discord and irreligion.
('92', 440, 5, 41, 732244) Harijan, 17 11 1946; and Hindustan Standard, 4 11 1946

('92', 444, 1, 2, 737217) 643. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 444, 2, 3, 737249) SODEPUR, CALCUTTA, November 4, 1946 Yesterday, while speaking to you, I referred to the news which had come from Bihar.
('92', 444, 2, 4, 737369) The news moved me deeply, and so I sent the following telegram 2 to Jawaharlalji through the Prime Minister, Shaheed Saheb.
('92', 444, 2, 5, 737493) Panditji has sent the following reply :
('92', 444, 3, 6, 737533) Report in Morning News grossly exaggerated and vague.
('92', 444, 3, 7, 737587) Government here doing its utmost but situation tense and grave in many places.
('92', 444, 3, 8, 737666) Am staying on here with Nishtar.
('92', 444, 3, 9, 737699) Vallabhbhai and Liaquat Ali going on to Delhi.
('92', 444, 3, 10, 737746) It is evident from the reply that although there has been exaggeration in the news, yet things have gone wrong and the condition is serious.
('92', 444, 3, 11, 737887) This is unbearable for me as one who is attached to the province of Bihar and also wants that the infection should not spread to other provinces.
('92', 444, 3, 12, 738033) I have been thinking deeply what my duty should be in this connection.
('92', 444, 3, 13, 738104) The Congress belongs to the people, the Muslim League belongs to our Muslim brothers and sisters.
('92', 444, 3, 14, 738202) If Congressmen fail to protect the Mussalmans where the Congress is in power, then what is the use of a Congress Premier?
('92', 444, 3, 15, 738324) Similarly, if in a League province the League Premier cannot afford protection to the Hindus, then why is the League Premier there at all?
('92', 444, 3, 16, 738463) If either of them have to take the aid of the military in order to protect the Muslim or Hindu minorities in their respective provinces, then it only means that none of them actually exercises any control over the general population when a momentous crisis comes.
('92', 444, 3, 17, 738727) If that is so, it only means that both of us are inviting the British to retain their sovereignty over India.
('92', 444, 3, 18, 738837) This is a matter over which each of them should ponder deeply.
('92', 444, 3, 19, 738900) Let us wait for what Panditji and Nishtar Saheb are able to do in Bihar.
('92', 444, 3, 20, 738973) Let us see whether the Hindus of Bihar shed their madness or not?
('92', 444, 3, 21, 739039) Tomorrow is the day of Bakr Id.
('92', 444, 3, 22, 739071) It is not an occasion when we should quarrel with one another.
('92', 444, 3, 23, 739134) Let us also wait and see what Shaheed Saheb does tomorrow.
('92', 444, 3, 24, 739193) How nice it would be if from tomorrow Hindus and Mussalmans and every other community

('92', 447, 5, 8, 742380) 648. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU November 5, 1946
('92', 447, 6, 9, 742429) JAWAHARLAL, The events in Bihar have distressed me.
('92', 447, 6, 10, 742481) I can clearly see my duty.
('92', 447, 6, 11, 742508) My bonds with Bihar are close.
('92', 447, 6, 12, 742539) I cannot forget it.
('92', 447, 6, 13, 742559) If half of what I hear is true, it means that Bihar has lost all humanity.
('92', 447, 6, 14, 742634) To say that goondas were responsible for whatever happened there would be quite untrue.
('92', 447, 6, 15, 742722) Although I have tried hard to avoid the fast, I shall not be able to do so.
('92', 447, 6, 16, 742798) It is the seventh day today since I gave up milk and cereals.
('92', 447, 6, 17, 742860) The cough and the boils were responsible for it, but also I was tired of the body.
('92', 447, 6, 18, 742943) Then Bihar made matters worse.
('92', 447, 6, 19, 742974) And the cry came from within: ‘Why should you be a witness to this slaughter?
('92', 447, 6, 20, 743052) If your word, which is as clear as daylight, is not heeded, your work is over.
('92', 447, 6, 21, 743131) Why do you not die?
('92', 447, 6, 22, 743151) Such reasoning has forced me to resort to fasting.
('92', 447, 6, 23, 743202) I want to issue a statement that if in Bihar and other provinces slaughter is not stopped, I must end my life by fasting.
('92', 447, 6, 24, 743324) The letter Mohammed Yunus wrote to Shamsuddin 1 is with Sardar Baldev Singh 2. See it.
('92', 447, 6, 25, 743411) Is what it says correct?
('92', 447, 6, 26, 743436) It is our duty to give full report of what happened.
('92', 447, 6, 27, 743489) My low diet will continue.
('92', 447, 6, 28, 743516) There may be delay in under taking the fast.
('92', 447, 6, 29, 743561) In Delhi you had asked me about the fast.
('92', 447, 6, 30, 743603) I had said I had no idea then.
('92', 447, 6, 31, 743634) Now the situation is not the same.
('92', 447, 6, 32, 743669) Still you may say what you want to say.
('92', 447, 6, 33, 743709) If it appeals to me I shall give up the idea of a fast.
('92', 447, 6, 34, 743765) What I hope is that, knowing my nature, you will appreciate my position.
('92', 447, 6, 35, 743838) Whatever the issue, I shall advise that all of you continue to do your work.
('92', 447, 6, 36, 743915) Do not waste time thinking of my

('92', 449, 0, 1, 745423) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 449, 1, 2, 745465) 650. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('92', 449, 2, 3, 745497) SODEPUR, CALCUTTA, November 5, 1946
('92', 449, 3, 4, 745533) The Hindus, said Gandhiji, might say: did not the Muslims start the troubles?
('92', 449, 3, 5, 745611) He wanted them not to succumb to the temptation for retort but to think of their own duty and say firmly that whatever happened they would not fight.
('92', 449, 3, 6, 745761) He wanted to tell them that the Muslims who were with him in the course of the day had assured him that they wanted peace.
('92', 449, 3, 7, 745884) They were all responsible men.
('92', 449, 3, 8, 745915) They said clearly that Pakistan could not be achieved by fighting.
('92', 449, 3, 9, 745982) If they continued quarrelling with each other, independence would vanish into thin air and that would firmly implant the third power in India, be it the British or any other.
('92', 449, 3, 10, 746157) India was a vast country, rich in minerals, metals and spices.
('92', 449, 3, 11, 746220) There was nothing in the world that India did not produce.
('92', 449, 3, 12, 746279) If they kept on quarrelling, any of the big powers of the world would feel tempted to come and save India from Indians and at the same time exploit her rich resources.
('92', 449, 4, 13, 746447) They wanted independence.
('92', 449, 4, 14, 746473) They were ready to sacrifice their all for the Congress, the organization which had done so much for India.
('92', 449, 4, 15, 746581) Were they going to undo all that the Congress had done for more than the last 60 years?
('92', 449, 4, 16, 746669) He had told them they should return blow for blow if they were not brave enough to follow the path of non violence.
('92', 449, 4, 17, 746785) But there was a moral code for the use of violence also.
('92', 449, 4, 18, 746842) Otherwise, the very flames of violence would consume those who lighted them.
('92', 449, 4, 19, 746919) He did not care if they were all destroyed.
('92', 449, 4, 20, 746963) But he could not countenance the destruction of India’s freedom.
('92', 449, 5, 21, 747028) The reports of the happenings in Bihar were awful if true.
('92', 449, 5, 22, 747087) Pandit Jawaharlal had told the guilty parties that the Central Government would never tolerate such barbarism.
('92', 449, 5, 23, 747198) They would even use aerial bombing to put it down.
('92', 449, 5, 24, 747249) But that was the way of the British.
('92', 449, 5, 25, 747286) The Congress was an organization of the people.
('92', 449, 5, 26, 747334) Was the Congress to use the foreign mode of destruction against the people whose representative it was?
('92', 449, 5, 27, 747438) By suppressing the riots with the aid of the military, they would be suppressing India’s freedom.
('92', 449, 5, 28, 747536) And yet what was Panditji to do if the Congress had lost control over the people?
('92', 449, 5, 29, 747618) The better way, of course, was to give up the reins of Government, if the people were not amenable to discipline and reason.
('92', 449, 6, 30, 747743) To retaliate against the relatives or the co religionists of the wrong doer was a cowardly act.
('92', 449, 6, 31, 747839) If they indulged in such acts, they should say good bye to independence.
('92', 449, 6, 32, 747912) Harijan, 17 11 1946
('92', 449, 7, 33, 747932) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”

('92', 450, 1, 2, 748021) 651. TO BIHAR
('92', 450, 2, 3, 748035) SODEPUR, November 6, 1946
('92', 450, 3, 4, 748061) TO BIHAR, Bihar of my dreams seems to have falsified them.
('92', 450, 3, 5, 748120) I am not relying upon reports that might be prejudiced or exaggerated.
('92', 450, 3, 6, 748191) The continued presence of the Central Chief Minister and his colleagues furnishes an eloquent tale of the tragedy of Bihar.
('92', 450, 3, 7, 748315) It is easy enough to retort that things under the Muslim League Government in Bengal were no better, if not worse and that Bihar is merely a result of the latter.
('92', 450, 3, 8, 748478) A bad act of one party is no justification for a similar act by the opposing party, more especially when it is rightly proud of its longest and largest political record.
('92', 450, 3, 9, 748648) I must confess, too, that although I have been in Calcutta for over a week I do not yet know the magnitude of the Bengal tragedy.
('92', 450, 3, 10, 748778) Though Bihar calls me, I must not interrupt my programme for Noakhali.
('92', 450, 3, 11, 748849) And is counter communalism any answer to the communalism of which Congressmen have accused the Muslim League?
('92', 450, 3, 12, 748959) Is it Nationalism to seek barbarously to crush the fourteen per cent of the Muslims in Bihar?
('92', 450, 3, 13, 749053) I do not need to be told that I must not condemn the whole of Bihar for the sake of the sins of a few thousand Biharis.
('92', 450, 3, 14, 749173) Does not Bihar take credit for one Brajkishore Prasad or one Rajendra Prasad?
('92', 450, 3, 15, 749251) I am afraid, if the misconduct in Bihar continues, all the Hindus of India will be condemned by the world.
('92', 450, 3, 16, 749358) That is its way, and it is not a bad way either.
('92', 450, 3, 17, 749407) The misdeeds of Bihari Hindus may justify Qaid e Azam Jinnah’s taunt that the Congress is a Hindu organization in spite of its boast that it has in its ranks a few Sikhs, Muslims, Christians, Parsis and others.
('92', 450, 3, 18, 749618) Bihari Hindus are in honour bound to regard the minority Muslims as their brethren requiring protection, equal with the vast majority of Hindus.
('92', 450, 3, 19, 749763) Let not Bihar, which has done so much to raise the prestige of the Congress, be the first to dig its grave.
('92', 450, 3, 20, 749871) I am in no way ashamed of my ahimsa.
('92', 450, 3, 21, 749908) I have come to Bengal to see how far in the nick of time my ahimsa is able to express itself in me.
('92', 450, 3, 22, 750008) But I do not want in this letter to talk of ahimsa to you.
('92', 450, 3, 23, 750067) I do want, however, to tell you that what you are reported to have done will never count as an act of bravery.
('92', 450, 3, 24, 750178) For thousands to do to death a few hundreds is no bravery.
('92', 450, 3, 25, 750237) It is worse than cowardice.
('92', 450, 3, 26, 750265) It is unworthy of
('92', 451, 0, 1, 750283) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 451, 1, 2, 750325) nationalism, of any religion.
('92', 451, 1, 3, 750355) If you had given a blow against a blow, no one would have dared to point a finger against you.
('92', 451, 1, 4, 750450) What you have done is to degrade yourselves and drag down India.
('92', 451, 1, 5, 750515) You should say to Pandit Jawaharlalji, Nishtar Saheb and Dr. Rajendra Prasad to take away their military and themselves and attend to the affairs of India.
('92', 451, 1, 6, 750671) This they can only do if you repent of your inhumanity and assure them that Muslims are as much your care as your own brothers and sisters.
('92', 451, 1, 7, 750811) You should not rest till every Muslim refugee has come back to his home which you should undertake to rebuild and ask your Ministers to help you to do so.
('92', 451, 1, 8, 750966) You do not know what critics have said to me about your Ministers.
('92', 451, 1, 9, 751033) I regard myself as a part of you.
('92', 451, 1, 10, 751067) Your affection has compelled that loyalty in me.
('92', 451, 1, 11, 751116) And since I claim to have better appreciation than you seem to have shown of what Bihari Hindus should do, I cannot rest till I have done some measure of penance.
('92', 451, 1, 12, 751279) Predominantly for reasons of health, I had put myself on the lowest diet possible soon after my reaching Calcutta.
('92', 451, 1, 13, 751394) That diet now continues as a penance after the knowledge of the Bihar tragedy.
('92', 451, 1, 14, 751473) The low diet will become a fast unto death, if the erring Biharis have not turned over a new leaf.
('92', 451, 1, 15, 751572) There is no danger of Bihar mistaking my act for anything other than pure penance as a matter of sacred duty.
('92', 451, 1, 16, 751682) No friend should run to me for assistance or to show sympathy.
('92', 451, 1, 17, 751745) I am surrounded by loving friends.
('92', 451, 1, 18, 751780) It would be wholly wrong and irrelevant for any other person to copy me.
('92', 451, 1, 19, 751853) No sympathetic fast or semi fast is called for.
('92', 451, 1, 20, 751901) Such action can only do harm.
('92', 451, 1, 21, 751931) What my penance should do is to quicken the conscience of those who know me and believe in my bona fides.
('92', 451, 1, 22, 752037) Let no one be anxious for me, I am like all of us in God’s keeping.
('92', 451, 1, 23, 752105) Nothing will happen to me so long as He wants service through the present tabernacle.
('92', 451, 2, 24, 752191) Your servant, M. K. GANDHI Harijan, 10 11 1946

('92', 452, 6, 9, 752621) 653. INTERVIEW TO UNITED PRESS OF INDIA
('92', 452, 7, 10, 752661) SODEPUR, November 6, 1946
('92', 452, 8, 11, 752687) Gandhiji was asked whether he thought that after the withdrawal of the British troops from this country, the present disturbances would immediately stop and how he thought that the minority communities would be safeguarded from a fear of the majority communities in the different parts of the country.
('92', 452, 8, 12, 752989) Replying Mahatma Gandhi observed : The disturbances will not stop immediately, but they must stop much quicker when the British troops are withdrawn.
('92', 452, 8, 13, 753139) Today we have to witness the degrading spectacle of wanting the help of the British troops.
('92', 452, 8, 14, 753231) When they are withdrawn, people will neces sarily learn the art of self defence with counter violence or, better still, with non violence.
('92', 452, 8, 15, 753370) The minorities will undoubtedly keep the British troops if they can unless they learn to be brave and trust the majority.
('92', 452, 8, 16, 753492) Again, when the British troops are gone, the majority will know how to behave towards the minority.
('92', 452, 8, 17, 753592) Today, even the best behaviour of the majority does not receive its full value
('92', 452, 9, 18, 753671) 1 Congress member of the Bengal Legislative Assembly 2 Sarat Chandra Bose 3 Gandhiji had met them on November 5 at the residence of H. S. Suhrawardy about forming a Central Peace Committee; vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 5 11 1946
('92', 453, 0, 1, 753904) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 453, 1, 2, 753946) whilst the temptation of relying on British troops exists.
('92', 453, 1, 3, 754005) By British troops, I do not mean merely White soldiers, but all who have been trained by British officers and have been trained to be loyal to the British in India and have often enough been used against the people to crush their freedom.
('92', 453, 1, 4, 754244) In any event people will have first to learn to do without the protection of the military or the police during communal troubles.
('92', 453, 1, 5, 754374) The function of the police is to protect the citizens against thieves and robbers, of the military generally to defend the country against the foreign aggressor where the people have not learnt the matchless bravery of non violence.
('92', 453, 2, 6, 754607) When Gandhiji’s attention was drawn to the fact that in Calcutta and other places, people could move about quite safely even in the riot affected areas if they were dressed in European fashion as the miscreants took them to be Christians, he said : It is impossible for any self respecting man to appreciate the advice that he must look like a Christian in order to avoid murder.
('92', 453, 2, 7, 754987) The suggested change would cast a reflection on the Hindu as well as the Muslim.
('92', 453, 2, 8, 755068) In order to live at peace with one another, we have to imbibe the virtue of toleration of the manners, customs and dresses of the different communities living in India.
('92', 453, 2, 9, 755237) The Hindu, 11 11 1946

('92', 454, 1, 2, 755596) 655. SPEECH AT KUSHTIA November 6, 1946
('92', 454, 2, 3, 755636) Addressing the waiting crowd Gandhiji said that his object in going to Noakhali was not to take sides and promote mutual quarrelling.
('92', 454, 2, 4, 755770) He had toured all over Bengal including East Bengal with the late Ali Brothers.
('92', 454, 2, 5, 755850) Those were the days when they had Hindu Muslim unity.
('92', 454, 2, 6, 755904) Large numbers of Muslims joined the Congress.
('92', 454, 2, 7, 755950) The Congress then belonged to all.
('92', 454, 2, 8, 755985) But today he was not going to East Bengal as a Congressman.
('92', 454, 2, 9, 756045) He was going there as a servant of God.
('92', 454, 2, 10, 756085) If he could wipe away the tears of outraged women, he would be more than satisfied.
('92', 454, 3, 11, 756169) Shaheed Saheb wanted to accompany him on the East Bengal tour but he was held up in Calcutta.
('92', 454, 3, 12, 756263) He had sent Shamsuddin Saheb (the Labour Minister) instead.
('92', 454, 3, 13, 756323) Shamsuddin Saheb had not come to spy upon him but to ensure Government help wherever it was required.
('92', 454, 3, 14, 756425) He was hopeful that the tour would have good effect and the Hindu Muslim unity of the Khilafat movement would come back.
('92', 454, 3, 15, 756546) In the Khilafat days, no one talked of dividing India.
('92', 454, 3, 16, 756601) Now they did so.
('92', 454, 3, 17, 756618) But partitioning, even if it was desirable, could not be achieved through violence.
('92', 454, 3, 18, 756702) Even if it could be achieved, it could not be retained except by the goodwill of the people concerned.
('92', 454, 3, 19, 756805) The Bengal Ministers had assured him yesterday that the Muslims did not believe in Pakistan through force.
('92', 454, 4, 20, 756912) Continuing, Gandhiji said that perhaps his place now was in Bihar.
('92', 454, 4, 21, 756979) He had served Bihar much more and he had much greater influence on the people there than in Bengal.
('92', 454, 4, 22, 757079) For the time being, instead of proceeding to Bihar, he was satisfied by addressing an open letter 1 to the Biharis which they would all see and all that he had to say to the audience was that they could not live in India as enemies.
('92', 454, 4, 23, 757312) They had to be friends and brothers.
('92', 454, 4, 24, 757349) All that had happened in Bengal and was happening in Bihar was most unbecoming.
('92', 454, 4, 25, 757429) They were being disgraced before the whole world.
('92', 454, 4, 26, 757479) He had to go to Noakhali and would stay on till Hindus and Muslims again lived as blood brothers.

('92', 455, 7, 19, 759777) 657. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF AMERICA 2
('92', 455, 8, 20, 759825) November 6, 1946
('92', 455, 9, 21, 759842) CORRESPONDENT: In view of recent Indian history—1942 unrest, I. N. A. movement and unrest, R. I. N. mutiny, Calcutta Bombay disturbances, movements in Indian States such as Kashmir and recent communal riots—can it be said that your creed of non violence has failed, in so far as non violence has not taken roots in Indian life?
('92', 455, 10, 22, 760170) GANDHIJI: This is a dangerous generalization.
('92', 455, 10, 23, 760216) All you mention
('92', 455, 11, 24, 760232) 1 What follows is reproduced from The Hindu.
('92', 455, 11, 25, 760277) 2 The interview appeared under the title “A Challenge to Faith” by Pyarelal.
('92', 455, 11, 26, 760354) According to The Bombay Chronicle, 8 11 1946, the interview took place on board the steamboat Kiwi during Gandhiji’s journey to Chandpur.
('92', 456, 0, 1, 760492) VOL.92 : 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOVEMBER, 1946 457
('92', 456, 1, 2, 760537) can certainly be called himsa but that can never mean that the creed of non violence has failed.
('92', 456, 1, 3, 760634) At best it may be said that I have not yet found the technique required for the conversion of the mass mind.
('92', 456, 1, 4, 760743) But I claim that the millions of the 700,000 villages of India have not participated in the violence alluded to by you.
('92', 456, 1, 5, 760863) Whether non violence has taken roots in Indian life is still an open question which can only be answered after my death.
('92', 456, 2, 6, 760984) What should one do in his day to day life—that is, what is the minimum programme—so that one can acquire non violence of the brave?
('92', 456, 2, 7, 761116) The minimum that is required of a person wishing to cultivate the ahimsa of the brave is first to clear his thought of cowardice and in the light of the clearance regulate his conduct in every activity, great or small.
('92', 456, 2, 8, 761335) Thus the votary must refuse to be cowed down by his superior, without being angry.
('92', 456, 2, 9, 761418) He must, however, be ready to sacrifice his post, however remunerative it may be.
('92', 456, 2, 10, 761500) Whilst sacrificing his all, if the votary has no sense of irritation against his employer he has ahimsa of the brave in him.
('92', 456, 2, 11, 761625) Assume that a fellow passenger threatens my son with assault and I reason with the would be assailant who then turns upon me.
('92', 456, 2, 12, 761751) If then I take his blow with grace and dignity, without harbouring any ill will against him, I exhibit the ahimsa of the brave.
('92', 456, 2, 13, 761879) Such instances are of everyday occurrence and can be easily multiplied.
('92', 456, 2, 14, 761951) If I succeed in curbing my temper every time and though able to give blow for blow I refrain, I shall develop the ahimsa of the brave which will never fail me and which will compel recognition from the most confirmed adversaries.
('92', 456, 2, 15, 762181) Harijan, 17 11 1946

('92', 458, 3, 4, 763594) October 6, l946
('92', 458, 4, 5, 763610) I have consulted some of my colleagues about the matter discussed by us yesterday and over the possibility of a rapprochement between the Muslim League and the Congress.
('92', 458, 4, 6, 763780) We are all agreed that nothing could be happier and better for the country than that these two organizations should meet again as before as friends having no mental reservations and bent on resolving all their differences by mutual consultation and never desiring or allowing the intervention of the British Government through the Viceroy or others or of any other foreign power.
('92', 458, 4, 7, 764160) We would, therefore, welcome the decision of the League to join the Interim Government for it to work as a united team on behalf of India as a whole.
('92', 458, 5, 8, 764310) The points put forward by you in our conversation yesterday were :
('92', 458, 6, 9, 764377) 1. the formula suggested to you by Gandhiji,
('92', 458, 7, 10, 764422) 2. the League not being responsible for the members at present representing the
('92', 458, 8, 11, 764502) Scheduled Castes and the minorities,
('92', 458, 9, 12, 764539) 3. what should be done in case any vacancy should arise among the members
('92', 458, 10, 13, 764613) representing the minorities other than the Scheduled Castes
('92', 458, 11, 14, 764673) 4. the procedure tobe adopted over what may be called major communal issues, and
('92', 458, 12, 15, 764754) 5. alternating Vice Presidentship
('92', 458, 13, 16, 764788) Regardng No.
('92', 458, 13, 17, 764801) 1, we feel that the formula is not happily worded.
('92', 458, 13, 18, 764852) We do not question the purpose underlying it.
('92', 458, 13, 19, 764898) We are willing as a result of the elections, to accept the Muslim League as the authoritative representative organization of an overwhelming majority of the Muslims of India and that as such and in accordance with democratic principles they have today the unquestionable right to represent the Muslims of India, provided that for indentical reasons the League recognises the Congress as the authoritative organization representing all non Muslims and such Muslims as have thrown in their lot with the Congress.
('92', 458, 13, 20, 765409) The Congress cannot agree to any restriction or limitations to be put upon it in choosing such representatives as they think proper from amongst the members of the Congress.
('92', 458, 13, 21, 765583) We would suggest, therefore, that no formula is necessary and each organization may stand on its merits.
('92', 458, 14, 22, 765688) Regarding No.
('92', 458, 14, 23, 765702) 2, I am to say that the question of the League being responsible does not arise and, as you do not raise any objections to the present constitution of

('92', 459, 9, 21, 767591) LORD WAVELL’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW
('92', 459, 10, 22, 767623) WITH GANDHIJI AND NEHRU 1
('92', 459, 11, 23, 767649) August 27, 1946
('92', 459, 12, 24, 767665) I said that I had asked them to come and see me because I had returned from Calcutta.
('92', 459, 12, 25, 767751) I gave a description of what I had seen in Calcutta; and said that the only way to avoid similar trouble all over India on an even larger scale was by some lessening of communal tension and settlement between Hindu and Muslim.
('92', 459, 12, 26, 767978) I stressed the importance of coalition Governments, both in Bengal and at the Centre.
('92', 459, 13, 27, 768064) 1. I said that while I recognized the difficulty in reopening negotiations with the Muslim League, I felt sure that the country expected it as a result of what had happened in Calcutta.
('92', 459, 13, 28, 768250) The crux of the whole matter lay in the doubt about the
('92', 459, 14, 29, 768306) 1Vide”Letter to Lord Wavell”, 28 8 1946
('92', 460, 0, 1, 768346) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOEMBER, 1946 461
('92', 460, 1, 2, 768389) Congress interpretation of the Grouping in the Constituent Assembly.
('92', 460, 1, 3, 768458) I said that I thought I had been quite clear in my mind that Congress had now agreed to abide by the Statement of May the 16th, and to me this had meant the acceptance of the Grouping arrangements.
('92', 460, 1, 4, 768656) When I made my broadcast a few nights ago, the draft of which I had shown to Nehru, I had been quite convinced that this was the intention and that it was on this understanding that I had said what I did in my broadcast.
('92', 460, 1, 5, 768877) I said that I thought the only chance of a peaceful transfer of power in India was if the Congress made a categorical statement that they would accept the position that the provinces must remain in their sections, as intended by the Mission, until after the first elections under the new Constitution.
('92', 460, 1, 6, 769179) I said that I could not undertake the responsibility of calling together the Constituent Assembly until this point was settled.
('92', 460, 1, 7, 769307) I handed to Gandhi and Nehru the draft of a statement which I asked them to make, as follows :
('92', 460, 2, 8, 769402) 2. “The Congress are prepared in the interests of communal harmony to accept the intention of the Statement of May 16th that provinces cannot exercise any option affecting their membership of the Section or of the Groups if formed until the decision contemplated in paragraph 19(viii) of the Statement of the 16th May is taken by the new Legislature after the new constitutional arrangements have come into operation and the first general elections have been held.”
('92', 460, 3, 9, 769868) 3. Gandhi began by saying that he thought it was a matter for the Interim Government.
('92', 460, 3, 10, 769954) I said that it was a matter for Congress who had challenged the interpretation of the Mission.
('92', 460, 3, 11, 770049) He then went off into long legalistic arguments about the interpretation of the Mission’s statement.
('92', 460, 3, 12, 770150) I said that I was a plain man and not a lawyer, and that I knew perfectly well what the Mission meant, and that the compulsory Grouping was the whole crux of the Plan.
('92', 460, 4, 13, 770318) 4. The argument went on for some time, and we did not make much progress.
('92', 460, 4, 14, 770392) Nehru at one time got very heated and said that this was simple “bullying” by the Muslim League.
('92', 460, 4, 15, 770489) Gandhi said that if a blood bath was necessary, it would come about in spite of non violence.
('92', 460, 4, 16, 770583) I said that I was very shocked to hear such words from him.
('92', 460, 4, 17, 770643) In the end they took away the formula, but I do not think there is much hope of their accepting it.
('92', 460, 5, 18, 770743) 5. The interview lasted about forty minutes.

('92', 461, 1, 2, 770930) APPENDIX III LETTER FROM SUDHIR GHOSH TO GANDHIJI 1
('92', 461, 2, 3, 770982) LONDON,
('92', 461, 3, 4, 770990) September 7, 1946
('92', 461, 4, 5, 771008) DEAR BAPUJI,
('92', 461, 5, 6, 771021) I got your message of the 28th August.
('92', 461, 5, 7, 771060) 2 and I cabled an answer back.
('92', 461, 5, 8, 771091) I went and saw Pethick Lawrence as soon as I got the cable.
('92', 461, 5, 9, 771151) 3 I guessed that you had sent it after your meeting with the Viceroy the previous evening.
('92', 461, 5, 10, 771242) I therefore knew what it meant and I had no difficulty in interpreting it to Pethick Lawrence.
('92', 461, 6, 11, 771337) I had a long discussion with him but he was rather sticky.
('92', 461, 6, 12, 771396) He took the line that Congress people were trying to have it both ways; on the one hand they want to get hold of as much power as possible and want the British and their Viceroy to have as little to do with India’s affairs as possible and on the other hand they want British to step in and take a retrograde step, viz., to exercise their extraordinary authority in provincial matters and to suppress a constitutionally elected ministry in Bengal.
('92', 461, 6, 13, 771843) He expanded himself on the subject.
('92', 461, 6, 14, 771879) I explained to him that there was no desire on the part of Congress to take any retrograde step; all that we were worried about was that we could not afford to have a repetition of the Bengal tragedy.
('92', 461, 6, 15, 772080) If Mr. Suhrawardy feels that injustice has been done to the Muslim League and he must seek redress by breaking the law of the land he is entitled to do so, and in that case he should go out of the Government, break the law and face the consequences.
('92', 461, 6, 16, 772330) But if he chooses to be the keeper of the law and the breaker of the law at the same time, the situation becomes intolerable.
('92', 461, 6, 17, 772456) Pethick Lawrence pointed out that he had no evidence that Mr. Suhrawardy was implicated in the crime of breaking the peace in Bengal.
('92', 461, 6, 18, 772590) I told him that I could not produce legal proof but there was enough circumstantial evidence of his guilt and in any case even if he was not implicated in the crime of breaking the peace, it was obvious to the whole world that he had fallen down on the job of maintaining order in the province which is the primary duty of a Government, and it resulted in gruesome tragedy, such as we have never before witnessed in the history of our country; this was sufficient justification for the dismissal of the Ministry in Bengal.
('92', 461, 6, 19, 773113) Nobody in the Congress would like to take such a step, but how are they to deal with the numerous big problems that await their attention if they are not in a position to keep the country as a whole in order?
('92', 461, 6, 20, 773322) Pethick Lawrence explained that he did not believe that that was the way to keep the country in
('92', 461, 7, 21, 773418) 1Vide footnote 3, “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 28 8 1946 2 Omissions as in the source 3 ibid
('92', 462, 0, 1, 773507) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOEMBER, 1946 463
('92', 462, 1, 2, 773550) In his view the root of the trouble was the dissatisfaction in the Muslim mind and the only way to remedy it is for the Congress, who are now in a powerful position, to make some further concession which would induce Mr. Jinnah to come into the Government and thus there would be no further trouble from the Muslims.
('92', 462, 1, 3, 773867) The concession which he thinks would satisfy Mr. Jinnah is that Congress should allow the provinces to go into their respective sections, according to the British plan, when the Constituent Assembly meets, and that they should make an announcement to that effect right now.
('92', 462, 1, 4, 774141) He suggested that I should make a suggestion to Mr. Gandhi and persuade him to see the reasonableness of it.
('92', 462, 1, 5, 774250) I had to be rather harsh to him and to tell him that I myself did not see the reasonableness of such a suggestion and therefore I was unable to say anything to Mr. Gandhi about it and in my view such a policy of appeasement would only make things worse.
('92', 462, 1, 6, 774504) He was rather upset about it.
('92', 462, 1, 7, 774534) Thus I have made myself somewhat unpopular.
('92', 462, 2, 8, 774578) But Attlee showed a great deal more understanding.
('92', 462, 2, 9, 774629) I went to him two days after I saw Pethick Lawrence.
('92', 462, 2, 10, 774682) I showed him the cable and explained to him what it meant.
('92', 462, 2, 11, 774741) I also showed him the cuttings of the Statesman editorial comments on the Calcutta tragedy.
('92', 462, 2, 12, 774833) He did not try to be diplomatic.
('92', 462, 2, 13, 774866) He plainly said that if in Gandhi’s judgment the situation is such that the Viceroy needs the assistance of a mind abler than his own and if Gandhi thinks that, otherwise, a repetition of the Calcutta tragedy is not only possible or probable but certain, then that is a matter which must be taken seriously.
('92', 462, 2, 14, 775174) He explained that he was naturally anxious to leave these things to the Secretary of State but he was going to call the Secretary of State and have a talk with him about all this.
('92', 462, 2, 15, 775354) He told me that your letter to the Viceroy on this subject had been cabled to the British Government and he showed me the copy he had got.
('92', 462, 2, 16, 775493) He said that all these things would be discussed at the next meeting of the Cabinet and he added that I might go and see him again on Wednesday the 4th.
('92', 462, 2, 17, 775646) I therefore went to see him again on Wednesday.
('92', 462, 2, 18, 775694) He said he was happy to hear from the Secretary of State that although the week end was difficult time at Delhi, things had improved since the Congress leaders actually took office on Monday, the 2nd September and that there is really no need to worry about the progress of things at Delhi.
('92', 462, 2, 19, 775985) He then talked at some length about the Viceroy and your message.
('92', 462, 2, 20, 776051) He admitted that there was a good case for a new Viceroy but there was no sense in making a change unless he was in a position to find someone who was obviously better than the present occupant of the post.
('92', 462, 2, 21, 776258) And it is not easy to find a man from this country who is very much better.
('92', 462, 2, 22, 776334) Then he went on to remark (he was thinking aloud) that the kind of assistance which Gandhi thinks the Viceroy needs should now be provided by Nehru—who has a very able mind and legal mind.
('92', 462, 2, 23, 776523) (Here he joked about legal minds and remarked that although he himself was a barrister he had left the profession early enough!) I said that the Prime Minister had hit the nail on the head; if he would now
('92', 463, 0, 1, 776729) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 463, 1, 2, 776771) give instructions to the Viceroy that henceforward the Viceroy, in the exercise of his extraordinary authority, must always be guided by the advice given him by his Prime Minister Pandit Nehru, then the whole problem would be solved.
('92', 463, 1, 3, 777005) The Prime Minister would not commit himself but he said he very much hoped things would work out that way.
('92', 463, 2, 4, 777112) Cripps is returning to London tomorrow.
('92', 463, 2, 5, 777152) But I hear he is not very well in spite of his stay in Switzerland.
('92', 463, 2, 6, 777220) He therefore will not be able to do much to help us.
('92', 463, 2, 7, 777273) I have kept him fully informed about developments in India but he really has no very great influence with the British Cabinet.
('92', 463, 2, 8, 777400) He is a good man but he is not what they call a good “party man” like Pethick Lawrence is.
('92', 463, 2, 9, 777491) Cripps’s influence therefore is much less than that of Pethick Lawrence.
('92', 463, 2, 10, 777564) Attlee, on the whole, is very sensible about India.
('92', 463, 2, 11, 777616) I am told that he is very different from what he used to be during the Round Table Conference days.
('92', 463, 2, 12, 777716) My impression is that he is keen to get on with Congress.

('92', 463, 5, 15, 777850) APPENDIX IV
('92', 463, 6, 16, 777862) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE’S RESOLUTION ON KASHMIR 1
('92', 463, 7, 17, 777915) September 25, 1946
('92', 463, 8, 18, 777934) Recent events in Kashmir have been repeatedly considered by the Working Committee and the Committee have been greatly affected by them.
('92', 463, 8, 19, 778070) They refrained, however, from expressing any opinion as they hoped that the situation could be handled satisfactorily by friendly mediation.
('92', 463, 8, 20, 778211) Their approaches, however, to the State authorities had an unfriendly response, and the situation has progressively deteriorated, involving repression of, and suffering for, the people.
('92', 463, 9, 21, 778397) Recently, the popular leader of the people and the President of the Kashmir National Conference, Sheikh Abdullah, was sentenced to three years’ imprisonment.
('92', 463, 9, 22, 778555) This has added to the gravity of the situation and distressed and angered large numbers of people within and outside the State.
('92', 463, 10, 23, 778683) When Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru went to Kashmir and was arrested there, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, the then President of the Congress, asked him to come back in order to continue the valuable work he was doing for the Congress in connection with the negotiations with the Cabinet Mission.
('92', 463, 11, 24, 778967) Maulana Azad had assured him then, with the consent of the Working
('92', 463, 12, 25, 779034) 1Vide “Draft Resolution for the Working Committee”, 25 9 1946
('92', 464, 0, 1, 779096) VOL.92: 9 AUGUST, 1946 6 NOEMBER, 1946 465
('92', 464, 1, 2, 779139) Committee, that the Congress would make his cause in Kashmir their own.
('92', 464, 1, 3, 779211) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru willingly returned, though not without misgivings.
('92', 464, 1, 4, 779286) The Working Committee regret to find that his misgivings were justified.
('92', 464, 2, 5, 779359) From all accounts received by the Committee, repression of an open as well as a subtle type is continuing, and the people connected with the Kashmir [National] Conference are being harassed in many ways.
('92', 464, 3, 6, 779563) It is reported that while elections have been announced for the State Assembly, large numbers of names are being struck off the electoral rolls, and many prospective candidates for the election have been disqualified.
('92', 464, 3, 7, 779781) No attempt is being made to liberalize the Constitution and to make it more democratic and responsible.
('92', 464, 4, 8, 779885) In view of these reports, the Working Committee feel it necessary to send a deputation, consisting of persons of unquestioned ability and impartiality, to inquire into the reports of repression and suppression of civil liberties.
('92', 464, 4, 9, 780115) The Committee, therefore, earnestly recommend to Kashmir State that they should invite such a deputation.
('92', 464, 5, 10, 780221) Recent events in Kashmir have a large significance affecting the rulers and peoples of all the States in India and Committee trust that the States will welcome the step that they are taking in regard to Kashmir.
('92', 464, 6, 11, 780433) While noting with deep regret the sentence passed on Sheikh Abdullah, the Committee would consider his incarceration as a worthy sacrifice if it results in the achievement of the freedom for which he was labouring.
('92', 464, 6, 12, 780648) The Committee express their sympathy for all those who have suffered or are suffering for the cause of freedom in Kashmir.
('92', 464, 7, 13, 780771) Sardar Patel’s Correspondence, 1945 50, Vol. I, pp.
('92', 464, 8, 14, 780823) APPENDIX V
('92', 464, 9, 15, 780834) LORD WAVELL’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW WITH GANDHIJI 1
('92', 464, 10, 16, 780882) September 26, 1946
('92', 464, 11, 17, 780901) I had also an hour with Mr. Gandhi.
('92', 464, 11, 18, 780937) He told me that there was no fixed date for his departure, and obviously means to stay as long as the negotiations last.
('92', 464, 12, 19, 781058) I outlined to him the result of my discussion with Jinnah and used the same general line of argument as with Nehru.
('92', 464, 12, 20, 781174) He listened patiently and then said that he had no doubt of the honesty of British intentions, that he entirely agreed that the Muslim League must come in, but that the Nationalist Muslim was a difficult issue.
('92', 464, 12, 21, 781385) As usual, he then began splitting hairs, saying that if it was merely a Congress
('92', 464, 13, 22, 781466) 1Vide “Discussion with Lord Wavell”, 26 9 1946 Lord Wavell also transmitted the text of the note to the Secretary of State the same day.
('92', 465, 0, 1, 781603) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('92', 465, 1, 2, 781645) “right”, they could make concessions on it, but that if it was a “duty”, it was a different matter.
('92', 465, 1, 3, 781745) He said that the proper way of settling the matter would be by a meeting between Jinnah and Nehru.
('92', 465, 2, 4, 781844) Gandhi then really disclosed his hand, by saying that he wished to know what we should do if the worst happened and the Muslim League did not come in.
('92', 465, 2, 5, 781995) His own view was that in that event it would be of no use for the Constituent Assembly to meet, and it would be quite honourable for the British Government to say that their scheme could not be enforced, and that the solution of a Constituent Assembly in which the Muslim League was not represented would not be maintained by British arms.
('92', 465, 3, 6, 782335) I then said to him that that was a possible line of argument, but supposing the worst did happen, which I refused to admit and was not going to allow, what was his solution : “Where did he go from there?”
('92', 465, 4, 7, 782540) He than said that though the Constituent Assembly should be dropped, the Interim Government should go on, the vacant Muslim seats being filled by other prominent Muslims.
('92', 465, 4, 8, 782711) This of course has been Gandhi’s objective and the objective of the majority of the Congress, I think, from the first : i.
('92', 465, 4, 9, 782834) e., to establish themselves at the Centre and to suppress, cajole, or buy over the Muslims, and then impose a Constitution at their leisure.
('92', 465, 5, 10, 782975) I said quite firmly that I was not prepared to accept his solution; I was not going to allow the present negotiations to fail, but that if they did His Majesty’s Government would have to reconsider the whole position.
('92', 465, 6, 11, 783193) He concluded by saying that he hoped I would do something to prevent Kashmir from becoming a major issue.
('92', 465, 6, 12, 783299) W(AVELL)
